column2: Irving Maidman, realty investor and developer of West Side properties, has bought two large parcels adjacent to his holdings on West 42d and 44th Streets.

An offering to the public of $20,000,000 of 5 per cent external loan bonds due 1978 of Milan, Italy, is being made today by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and associates. The bonds are priced at 98 to yield 5.63 per cent to maturity.
FREEPORT, L.I., July 10-- El Diablo, an 18-foot Glastron runabout from Texas, was a shark that chased--and caught --minnows today in the fifth annual Around Long Island Marathon.
The Treasury's gold stock declined by $50,000,000 last Friday. A purchase by France was probably responsible in whole of part.
The leader of Jehovah's Witnesses announced yesterday the translation of the sect's Bible into six modern languages and the publication of 980,000 copies.
MIAMI, July 10--A former President of Venezuela, Marcos Perez Jimenez, will remain in jail here under custody of the United States Government un-...
ST. LOUIS, July 10 (UPI)-- Gov. John M. Dalton and other state officials were named defendants today in a suit to force reapportionment of the Missouri House of Representatives.
Eleven hundred truck drivers and yard workers struck 80 building supply companies here yesterday, halting deliveries to construction jobs in the metropolitan area.

Another attack on imports of cotton products, now totaling a billion square yards yearly, was issued yesterday by The Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York in its annual review, entitled "Ten Years of Cotton Textiles."
MADRID, July 10--The Spanish regime disclosed today that many workers in Asturias and in the Basque provinces abstained from voting in the nationwide election for shop stewards last month.
DUBLIN, July 10--Ireland is a poor country getting richer, a land of famous sons slowly finding its place in the Western world.

CHICAGO, July 10--Two Roman Catholic lay leaders declared today that Catholic priests and nuns had "every right" to participate in the antidiscrimination march planned by Negro leaders for Aug. 28 in Washington.

The State Commission on Human Rights ruled yesterday that a Syracuse landlord who had rejected a Negro applicant was guilty of discrimination even though he had already accepted another Negro family as tenants.

Automatic Radio Manufacturing Company, Inc., of Boston, a maker of car radios and other auto accessories, has filed a $15,000,000 antitrust suit against the Ford Motor Company, it was disclosed yesterday. The suit, filed in the Federal District Court of Massachusetts, seeks injunctive relief and treble damages.
DENVER, July 10--Jackie Robinson, the former Brooklyn baseball star, was cited by the United Church of Christ today for "serene courage in the face of racial discrimination."

The Tri-Continental Corporation, the nation's largest diversified closed-end investment company, reported yesterday in its quarterly financial statement that asset value a share increased by 10 per cent in the six months to June 30 and by 30 per cent in the year.

The Metropolitan Opera will lead from strength and present its strongest casts during its two-week contribution to the New York World's Fair next spring. This fact became evident when details of the 16 post-season, non-subscription performances to be offered April 27 to May 10 were announced yesterday.
The nation's expenditures for medical research have paid off in dollars as well as in lievs saved and the relief of suffering, the National Health Education Committee said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris were still out of the line-up tonight, but the New York Yankees still had their redoubtable Whitey Ford. The ace lefthander bulled his way to his 14th victory as the Bombers downed the Los Angeles Angels, 3 to 2, in 10 innings. The triumph was Ford's 10th in a row.

NEW DELHI, July 11 A United States Ambassador in India can choose one of two styles: He can try to present through his own actions and words an image of the United States, or he can be a professional diplomat, concentrating on his relationships with officials and politicians and remaining invisible to the public.
WASHINGTON, July 11 Spain has privately sounded out Washington about increasing her shipping to Cuba.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The chairman of a House Public Works subcommittee ruled out today any action this year on legislation to pay New York for its toll roads that are now a part of the Federal interstate system.
NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., July 11 Of all the barges that ply the Ohio River, the Point Counterpoint is the most unusual.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 11 Nadine Netter, an 18-year-old Welleslay sophomore from Scarsdale, N.Y., and Elaine Scarpone of New York today reached the final round of the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship. They will play at 1 o'clock tomorrow for the title at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 11 The Negro labor movement in Westchester made demands for reform in construction-hiring practices tonight, and in effect threatened violence if rebuffed.

Seven persons were arrested at the construction site of a Lower East Side housing project yesterday as demonstrators pressed their campaign for more jobs for Negroes and Puerto Ricans in building trades.
Record second-quarter sales and earnings of the General Electric Company lifted halfyear results well over the level in the six months of last year, Ralph J. Cordiner, chairman, reported yesterday.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 11 The New York Jets took the field for the first time today at their training camp and Coach Weeb Ewbank began at the beginning. He taught the team how to form a huddle.
ATHENS, July 11 The Greek Ministry of Justice announced today the release of 17 prisoners, 14 of whom took part in the postwar Communist uprising. Three were Nazi collaborators.

LONDON, July 11 The possibility of a nuclear test-ban treaty will be doomed if the Russians insist on an EastWest nonaggression pact as a condition for agreeing to halt tests, reliable sources said tonight.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 11 The Zionist Organization of America met in Israel today for the first time.

The newest entry on the list of organized debutante parties in this area is one that has been designed for parents who want neither the tremendous expense of the private party nor the tremendous numbers of some of the mass debuts.
Cotton futures were $1 a bale up to 40 cents down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
DENVER, July 11 A cutoff of funds next July 1 to segregated churches and institutions was voted early today by the United Church of Christ.
Dr. Ralph B. Flanders, retired associate professor of history at New York University, died Tuesday in Chattanooga. He was 60 years old and lived in Chattanooga.
BUENOS AIRES, July 11 (AP) Torn and seared by explosions and fire an Argentine river boat loaded with passengers sank today in the River Plate estuary.
Gerardo A. (Jerry) Re; his son, Gerard F., and three co-defendants were convicted of conspiracy in a multimillion-dollar stock fraud in United States District Court yesterday.

FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla., July 11 (AP) A rocket head fired from a jet fighter on a ground-strafing exercise ripped into a protective bunker with at least 16 persons inside today, killing two and injuring 14.
An agreement providing for the acquisition of the American Agricultural Chemical Company by the Continental Oil Company was signed by both companies yesterday.
The Publishers Association of New York City asked yesterday for a change in the state unemployment insurance law that would bar strikers from benefits.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Five surplus Air Force planes will be burned up deliberately next September in an experiment to see how the lives of passengers could be saved in air crashes.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 Dr. Herbert T. Kalmus, the scientist who invented Technicolor, died today of a heart attack at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 81 years old.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 11 (AP) Less than halfway through its first season, the Guthrie Repertory Theater is more than two-thirds of the way to a financial break-even point.
LONDON, July 11 Demonstrators against the Greek royal family's visit to London fought with the police tonight for the second time in three days. Seventy-five of them were arrested.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 David E. Snodgrass, outspoken dean of the Hastings College of Law in this city, died in Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday after open-heart surgery. He was 68 years old.

LYTHAM SAINT ANNE'S, England, July 11--Phil Rodgers, a former marine from La Jolla, Calif., sank a 15-foot downhill putt on the 18th hole for a birdie 3 today and took a stroke lead halfway through the British Open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The Communications Satellite Corporation took the first steps today toward seeking the development of a "multiple access system" for communication satellites. This would permit countries to receive and send messages simultaneoutly.
Urban freeways, financed solely by special motorists' taxes, are the mainstay of metropolitan development and will continue to be, the Automobile Manufacturers Association said yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 11 (AP) The seas oft Newport haven't been rough enough for the experimental hydrofoil ship Denison.
Stockholders of the Bank of New York approved yesterday a stock split and dividend that will increase the bank's capitalization and raise the dividend to shareholders by 3 per cent a year.
TOKYO, July 11 (AP) Communist China acknowledged today that it would be a long time probably 10 to 20 years before it achieved industrialization and had a modern army.

THE team-of-four contest for a trophy memorial izing the late Morton Rubinow has now been in progress since last November and still is not settled; there will be a two-way or three-way tie and by the time a playoff can be concluded the contest may be a year or more old.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (AP) Milwaukee cut down St. Louis and a former teammate, Lew Burdette, 5 3, in the second game of a double-header tonight after the Cardinals scored five times in the seventh inning to win the opener, 6 3.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 Elmer Rice's play "The Adding Machine" will be converted into film in the New York style.
ALBANY, July 11 Governor Rockefeller announced today that $25,200,000 in additional savings would be achieved this year.
CHICAGO, July 11 (UPI) Most grain futures had moderate-to-sharp losses today on the Board of Trade.
The Port of New York Authority moved a step further yesterday in its $95,000,000 redevelopment program for the Brooklyn waterfront.
WESTON, Vt., July 11--Like the phoenix, which rises out of its own ashes, the Weston Playhouse opened last night on the site of its destruction by a flash fire exactly one year ago.
Chrysler got a chill yesterday afternoon and the stock market shivered.
WASHINGTON July 11 Operation Second Chance, a pioneer project designed to train rural youths for nonfarm jobs, was begun today by North Carolina.
WASHINGTON, July 11 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that he foresaw a "leveling off" of defense spending but he would not, in response to questions, indicate when.

CHICAGO, July 11--Demonstrators from the Woodlawn area, including a dozen Roman Catholic priests and five seminarians, picketed City Hall today. They staged two brief sitins, one outside the Mayor's office.
PARIS, July 11 A toplevel economic policy meeting of the Atlantic nations failed today to produce any new remedies for the chronic deficit in the United States balance of payments.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP)--Administration leaders are expressing concern over the attitude taken by some Congress members toward a proposal to make the food stamp plan permanent.
PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP) Despite some zany running that resulted in four men, getting tagged out on the basepaths, the San Francisco Giants defeated the Philadelphia Phils, 4 3, tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 11 "Be careful 'about swappin' bugs with the Russians."
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 11 Ambassador Frederick E. Nolting Jr. Returned today after an absence of seven weeks and said that South Vietnam was on its way to victory over the Communist guerrillas.
ST. LOUIS, July 11 The Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen lifted its 87-year-old ban on nonwhite membership today.

Rapid progress in the medical sciences and unprecedented growth of the population have created a dual dilemma in American medicine. The population increase means that more physicians are required, which, in turn, means an increase in needed medical schools. But the vast expansion in the field of the medical sciences has made training for a career in medicine so arduous as to discourage qualified young men and women from entering the profession.
Business picked up on most European stock markets yesterday, but activity in London remained at a low level.
The Gulf American Land Corporation disclosed yesterday in statements filed with the American Stock Exchange that it had paid $6,167,322 for a 46 per cent interest in Fenestra, Inc.
Cardinal Spellman denounced discrimination against Negroes yesterday as "an outrage which Americans cannot tolerate." He spoke before an audience of 500, most of whom were Negroes.
The William A. Shea Stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, will not be ready for use until the end of this year, city aides admitted yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11--Controversy continues to swirl over plans of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company to build a 325,000-kilowatt nuclear power unit at Bodega Bay, on the Pacific 50 miles north of this city.

A headwaiter said to treat unemployment insurance personnel with a hauteur usually reserved for busboys and tourists was arrested yesterday and charged with bilking the state of $4,000 in false unemployment claims.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 11 A formal request was made today for "urgent" meetings of the Security Council to consider the problems of racism in South Africa and colonialism in Portugal's African territories.
QUITO, Ecuador, July 11 The army ousted Ecuador's hard-drinking President Carlos Julio Arosemena Monray today and sent him into exile.
WASHINGTON, July 11 Department-store sales in the week ended July 6 were 9 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year.
NOROTON, Conn., July 11 Mrs. Allegra Knapp Mertz, representing the American Yacht Club at Rye, N.Y., today captured the women's Long Island Sound sailing championship for the fifth time.
ROME, July 11 The Chamber of Deputies voted its confidence in Giovanni Leone and his government late this evening by 255 to 225, with 119 abstentions and 31 members absent.

WASHINGTON, July 11 A new controversy was reported today in the already controversial TFX airplane contract award. According to the transcript of today's hearing before the Senate Permanent Investigating Subcommittee, the new dispute involves the Air Force and the two winning defense contractors on the question whether there should be one or two assembly lines.

DURHAM, N.C., July 11 (UPI) Federal Judge Edwin M. Stanley today ordered the Durham school board to give Negro elementary and junior high students "the absolute right to attend the school of their choice."
GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 11 In an effort to eliminate racial imbalance in schools, cities and suburbs were urged here today to set up educational centers.

SOME years ago, when Panayotis Pipinelis was serving the Greek Government as an envoy, he arrived late at a reception. He was so late that it was only when the host was escorting guests to the door that the host saw him.

Makers of air conditioners thrive on hot weather, which is just what they had in June. The heat wave, which spread over the eastern United States probably will increase sales for the industry to 375,000 units for the year 25,000 more units than the 350,000 expected, according to industry observers. In 1962, the industry sold 308,000 units.
LONDON, July 11 A highranking Soviet intelligence official has defected to the West, authoritative sources said tonight.
Sugar and cocoa declined yesterday in a mixed and quiet day on New York commodity markets.
DAVID LOWRY, a lanky, carrot-topped teen-ager, is an inveterate partygoer. During the school year, he averages three birthday parties a week. He is usually the principal attraction.

LONDON, July 11 (Reuters) The House of Commons gave an unopposed second reading, agreement in principle, tonight to a bill paving the way for the dissolution of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland. The date set for dissolution was Dec. 31.

Eighteen months ago, McCall's Magazine astonished Madison Avenue by announcing that it would henceforth charge the same rate $38,800 for both four-color and black-andwhite advertising pages. The action was a sharp departure...
Paperboard production in the country totaled 263,443 tons in the week ended July 6, the National Paperboard Association reported.

LOLIONDO, Tanganyika. June 24 After a day of rehabilitation of gear and morale, somewhat battered by a trip to this corner of Africa, our safari was ready to make one more move. Scouting parties had found concentrations of game about 30 miles west of this little village.

The Atlantic Refining Company is experimenting with a new kind of outdoor advertising sign that looks somewhat like a giant photo transparency. The poster utilizes full-color "see-through art lithographed on durable translucent film. Richard Bor

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 11 Ed Johnston, a Baltimore attorney who left Blackstone on the shelf for a few days, and Scott Schwarz, a Villanova senior on vacation from his books, today toured the West course of the Winged Foot Golf Club as if they'd studied it all their lives.

SUFFIELD, Conn., July 11 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Haynes Miller of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Connell Miller, to Pirie MacDonald Tuchings. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Tuchings of New York.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 11 Amin el-Hafez, who was promoted yesterday to the rank of major general and appointed Chief of Staff and acting Minister of Defense in addition to his posts as Minister of the Interior, Deputy Premier and Military Governor, seems to be emerging as Syria's new strong man.

They hovered expectantly over the news tickers in banks and investment houses as the hour approached 4 P.M. yesterday, only to be disappointed. The big news of the day in the financial community here and abroad was that the Federal Reserve discount rate was unchanged. It remained at 3 per cent, as it has since Aug. 12, 1960.

Jacob L. Holtzmann, a longtime civic leader and member of the state Board of Regents from 1949 to 1958, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived at 671 East 17th Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, July 11 The House Foreign Affairs Committee cut $430,000,000 today from President Kennedy's $4,500,000,000 foreign aid authorization request.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 11 (AP) Helmore Farm's Best Course won the Monmouth Park feature today by a nose over Hillcrest Farm's Power to Strike.
Like most other examples of American mass-entertainment art forms, the Mets create a prolonged illusion of suspense while proceeding to a thoroughly predictable, almost ritualistic, conclusion.
ALTHOUGH everyone knows that American women are marrying carlier, Saks-34th has discovered that they are also going to the altar later and oftener.
The Internal Revenue Service has proposed regulations that would make it more difficult for the small business to gain access to the capital markets.

A lawyer representing Anne M. Kelly, deputy commissioner of the city's Department of Commerce, yesterday denounced as illegal the action of Commissioner J. Edward Conway of the State Commission for Civil Rights in publicly recommending that she be disciplined for bias.
LOUIS MARDER, patient editor of The Shakespeare Newsletter, Kent, Ohio, has done a brave deed. He has answered 17 leading questions put to him by a Baconian.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 94.5 Wednesday, from 94.3 Tuesday.
Quo Vadis Restaurant, 26 East 63d Street, TE 8-0590, In the most essential things cuisine and service the Qua Vadis is one of the city's best restaurants.

The five-story office building at 1 South Street, northeast corner of Whitehall Street, has been purchased by a group of European investors headed by Donald P. Kurtis of Abbott Adams, Inc., brokers. The property was sold by Ernest Brown, in whose family it had been held for 43 years. The building, which contains 22,500 square feet space, will be remodeled at a cost of $225,000. The improvements will include central air-conditioning and automatic elevators.
The Government securities market waited quietly in vain, yesterday for a possible move by the Federal Reserve on the discount rate.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 Miguel Najdorf of Argentina retained the lead today after tabulation of completed games in five rounds of the Piatigorsky Cup 8-man, round-robin chess tournament. Paul Keres of the Soviet Union and Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia were tied for second place one-half point behind Majdorf.
A 32-year-old insurance broker, Sandy Farber, will bring "The Student Gypsy or The Prince of Liederkranz" to Broadway in the fall.

WHAT the nut is to the squirrel, the recipe is to the home cook something to be gathered and tucked away for future use. And nothing inspires a woman's recipe gathering instincts like the sight of an unfamiliar ingredient.

The stalemate in contract talks with the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company was the main item discussed yesterday at the beginning of a two-day meeting of the general executive board of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.
The multibillion-dollar pension funds of the state and city became more deeply involved in the civil rights controversy yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 11 A House Armed Services subcommittee today completed five weeks of testimony on the nation's civil defense program. A basic decision on whether to recommend continuation of the program was put off until tomorrow.

SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., July 11 The click-click-click of the wheel of fortune, which for years has been one of the most lucrative sounds at fund-raising carnivals in New York State, will be muted this year.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it has developed a computer system capable of fully automatic type composition. The computer in one hour can produce enough perforated tape to set as many as 12,000 11-pica lines of 8-point type, hyphenated and justified, the company says.
BRUSSELS, July 11 The European Common Market's Council of Ministers agreed today to hold discussions with Britain every three months on European political, and economic matters.

By a closely split decision the Court of Appeals, highest in New York State, has banned Henry Miller's "The Tropic of Cancer" from sale in New York State. Judge John F. Scileppi, in writing the majority opinion, found the book to be "dirt for dirt's sake."

A sense of this country's history coursed through Secretary of State Rusk's testimony on civil rights before the Senate Commerce Committee. There were echoes of Lincoln's remarks on equality and the rights of free men in Mr. Rusk's statement reminding us that the Declaration of Independence did not say "All men except those who are not white" are created equal.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon appealed to Congress today to approve increases in the financial resources of two international lending institutions of which the United States is a member.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Truck and rail loadings in the week ended July 6 were ahead of the volumes in the corresponding week last year. However, mainly because of the Independence Day holiday, the loadings were below the preceding week's level.
Met Stadium Opening Put Off to '64

THERE is a special sort of magic that clings to some of the most familiar stories in history. They are so inher ently dramatic, romantic, pitiful or tragic that professional storytellers never tire of repeating them, each according to his own taste and the fashions of his time, And every few years a new generation of readers or

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Republican Congressional leaders said today that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower had denied with some heat a report that he opposed either Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona or Governor Rockefeller of New York as the 1964 Presidential nominee.
Jean Handzlik, a contralto who sang in opera and in Broadway musicals, died Tuesday in St. Barnabas's Hospital the Bronx. She was 41 years old.
All he wanted was some pictures, plain portraits of deserving Democrats and it was all for the aid of the party.
THE summer loan exhibition of paintings from private collections, which opens today at the Metropolitan Museum, is a particularly fine one.

PHOENIX, Ariz, July 11 The Attorney General of this state expects to rule shortly that Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, may legally run for both the Presidency and his Senate seat in 1964.
A credit pinch among major New York City banks eased in the week ended Wednesday.

THE difficulty of handicapping pleasure boats for races was demonstrated again Wednesday in the fifth annual Around Long Island Marathon. Instead of finishing reasonably well-bunched, as the handicappers had intended, the boats came home over a four-hour span.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Newly independent governments which are members of the United Nations got sound advice at Geneva from Adlai E. Stevenson yesterday. Speaking to the Economic and Social Council of the U.N., he warned these governments that their "acts of impatience" toward the South African Republic and Portugal would undermine the U.N. if they were imposed in the form of policy decisions.

WESTBURY, L.I, July 11 When Jamin of France won the International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway in 1959, his owner celebrated with a champagne party. Today, the prospects of an equally liquid if not so exotic party were being considered at the Westbury track: Martini II of France is scheduled to arrive tomorrow.
Corporation Counsel Leo A. Larkin and the district attorneys of the five counties of New York are pressing a charge of ogscenity against "Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure."
Safety rubber surfaces were added this week under slides, see-saws and jungle gyms at two more city playgrounds.

BIRDIE Tebbets was talking about Early Wynn during the conversational batting practice at the All-Star Game in Cleve land. Birdie is the manager of the Indians and this includes the noblest Indian of all, the 43-year-old Wynn, A victim of the most tantalizing series of frustrations, Wynn had been balked for the sixth time a couple of days earlier in his effort to gain the 300th victory of his major league career.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 11 (AP) A Federal District judge ruled today that Oklahoma City schools had not truly integrated. He ordered complete integration of both pupils and teachers starting in September.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 11 The Rev. Dr. Willard P. Soper, minister emeritus of the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church of Pelham Manor, N.Y., died here today at his home, Todd Drive. He was 80 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP)--The American Newspaper Guild approved unanimously today a report calling on governmental authorities to "recognize their constitutional responsibility to give news reporters full access to sources of information and individuals involved in inter-group controversy, integration demonstrations and similar events."

The Radio Corporation of America had the highest sales and earnings in its history for the second quarter and first six months of this year, according to the semiannual report released for publication today.

BONN, July 11--Testimony in a Karlsruhe courtroom this week has tarnished the vaunted reputation of the West German espionage apparatus. The service, the Federal Intelligence Ageney, is headed by its founder, Reinhard Gehlen, a former Wehrmacht general.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 Dr. Maxwell Rafferty, California's Superintendent of Public Instruction, considers the episode of "The Dictionary of American Slang" a closed book.

Robert A. Becker, Inc., a pharmaceutical advertising agency, has leased most of a floor in the new Burroughs Building at 805 Third Avenue, at 39th Street, from Fisher Brothers, the builders and owners. The lease involves 14,000 square feet and is double that now occupied by the lessee at 630 Third Avenue. It was negotiated by David Kaufman of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agents for the building.

MOSCOW, July 11 Soviet and Chinese Communist delegates are finding it so difficult to repair their ideological differences that they are looking for a face-saving way to end their conference, it was reported today.

ROME, July 11 Pope Paul VI received U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, in a private audience today and discussed with him the possibility that Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty might leave the United States Legation in Budapest and come to Rome.

Lewisohn Stadium paid tribute last night to Vienna, but it was no ordinary tribute. For the soloist was Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, and the conductor was Willi Boskovsky, making their debuts in this summer series.

DANVILLE, Va., July 11 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. came today to this Virginia textile and tobacco center, where stringent laws and tough police have slowed a six-weekold Negro civil rights drive. He said mass demonstrations would resume at once.
MADISON, N.J., July 11 Wesley Ellis of Mountain Ridge took a one-stroke lead after the first round of the 42d annual New Jersey open golf championship today.
A DESIGN revolution that may affect the interiors of American homes is under way in Ireland.
WASHINGTON, July 11 The Public Health Service, faced with a serious outbreak of intestinal illness in the Northeast, warned today against buying and using cracked and unclean eggs.
MOSCOW, July 11 (Reuters) An American moviewriter, Abby Mann, drew applause today from Soviet moviemakers when he backed the artist's right to criticize any "official point of view."

With considerable fanfare the Kennedy Administration has announced two new measures advertised as curbing Cuba's ability to engage in subversive activities. But on examination they are mostly bark and little bite.
WASHINGTON, July 11 The New York Congressional delegation launched an offensive on two fronts today to fight the problem of airport noise.
WASHINGTON, July 11--Negro leaders of a scheduled civil rights march in Washington on Aug. 28 conferred with police officials today on plans for the mass appeal to "the conscience of America."

1. That the unions in the building and construction trades give full and complete information to the New York City Department of Labor concerning their apprenticeship training programs, including qualification requirements, number of applicants to be accepted, etc.
RYE, N.Y., July 11 Fiftyone, young women will make their formal bows to society at the 25th Westchester Cotillion at the Shenorock Shore Club here on Sept. 6.

Thygold of the Milange Farm won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The event was at 1 1/8 miles on the turf, and was named the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce Handicap. It attracted half a dozen contestants.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Friday, July 12 At least five white persons, including two National Guardsmen and a 12-year-old boy, were wounded last night as racial violence flared anew here. Roving bands of gunmen defied all efforts to restore order.

WASHINGTON, July 11 A two-step procedure emerged today as the recommendation that President Kennedy is likely to make to Congress for disposing of the issues in the railroad work rules dispute. The procedure would provide for mediation first and arbitration if mediation failed.
TEL AVIV, July 11 The Israeli trans-Atlantic liner Shalom, which was dedicated in a French shipyard today, is the center of a violent controversy over dietary regulations.
The New York foreign exchange market passed another expectant day yesterday, waiting to see what if anything would happen to the discount rate. Operators continued to be restrained.
Mayor Wagner's "action panel" on job equality offered a program yesterday to open membership in construction trade unions to qualified Negroes and Puerto Ricans.
The favored J.S. Dale won the featured $3,400 Queens Village Pace and $4.10 for $2. J.S. Dale triumphed over Earl L. Lusty by three-quarters of a length in 2:02 3/5. Gar Hanover was third.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 11 Iraq complained to the Security Council today that the Soviet Union was inciting Kurdish rebels.

A week after the start of the Soviet-Chinese ideological talks in Moscow it is clear that relations between both countries and both Communist parties are worse than ever. During the week both sides have traded charges in public, each accusing the other of trying to poison the atmosphere. The most spectacular move was the public demonstration in Peking to honor the five Chinese expelled from Moscow.
BALTIMORE, July 11 Gov. J. Millard Tawes was urged today to call a special session of the Legislature to broaden the scope of the state equal accommodations law.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The Western Union Telegraph Company was authorized today to increase domestic telegraph rates immediately. The increase will provide what the company has contended is an urgently needed $16,500,000 a year in additional income.
Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., submitted 1,402 acceptances yesterday of its plan to pay unsecured creditors under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act.

TRENTON, July 11 Gov. Richard J. Hughes took issue with Governor Rockefeller of New York today on the question of injecting the civil rights issue at the Governors Conference, which will convene July 20 in Miami.
The Seafarers International Union called yesterday for the equivalent of impeachment proceedings in the "house of labor" against Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union.
Further evidence of the political power struggle in Harlem was made public yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 (UPI) The 72-foot ketch Ticonderoga, in a see-saw battle with the 72-foot yawl Audacious, today swept into the lead of the trans-Pacific yacht race just beyond the halfway point to Honolulu.
Lumber production in the country totaled 146,777,000 board feet in the week ended July 6, according to reports received from regional lumber associations.

The 73-foot yawl Bolero, the fleet's scratch boat, was reported yesterday to be in the lead, approximately 1,300 miles from Plymouth, England, in the 12th day of the 2,864-mile trans-Atlantic race from Newport, R.I.

WASHINGTON, July 11 A delegation from Salisbury, Md., told the Senate Commerce Committee today how their town had striven to become "an island of hope and an example" to other communities beset by racial problems.
SEABROOK, N.J., July 11 A pretty 3-year-old girl trotted confidently behind about 30 older youngsters today as the bell rang at a small one-room school set in a pine-encircled clearing near here.

PARIS, July 11 A Parisian first-night audience was taken by surprise tonight when Allan Kaprow's company presented an authentic "Happening" as the final United States contribution to the 10th season of the Theater of the Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 11 A delegation from Salisbury, Md., told the Senate Commerce Committee today how their town had striven to become "an island of hope and an example" to other communities beset by racial problems.

PARIS, July 11 A Parisian first-night audience was taken by surprise tonight when Allan Kaprow's company presented an authentic "Happening" as the final United States contribution to the 10th season of the Theater of the Nations.
MUNSTERLAGER, Germany, July 11 Defense officials said today that West German industry would be given the goahead for a multimillion-dollar tank construction program "within the next few days."
The Columbia Broadcasting System will televise a special show each year for five years from the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

An East-West nuclear test-ban treaty cannot be achieved, according to sources in London, if the Russians insist on linking it with an East-West nonaggression pact. The United States and British delegates at the test-ban talks, scheduled to open in Moscow on Monday, are understood to have no authority to negotiate on anything except the test ban. NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 12--A German shepherd dog put on probation three years ago after attacking a woman here is in trouble again.

MADISON, N.J., July 12-- Wesley Ellis Jr. of Mountain Ridge shot a four-under-par 69 in the second round of the 42d annual New Jersey open golf championship today, giving him a seven-stroke lead at 137.
After a day of talks with city officials, a contractor agreed yesterday not to resume construction next week on the $29,000,000 Harlem Hospital Annex.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 --Gambling is illegal in California but for three months, without interference from police, a gambling operation has been drawing lines of patrons, six nights a week, since April 10, into a former bocce-ball court in North Beach.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 12--The South African security police arrested Walter Sisulu late last night. He is the secretary general of the banned African National Congress who disappeared about six weeks ago.
The Paris Bourse celebrated Bastille Day a little early yesterday with a lively rally. Most French shares registered substantial gains.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., attributed the low level of film rentals and the poor results of several new motion-picture releases for a loss the company registered in the 12-week period and 40 weeks ended June 6, according to the report released today.
Cocoa prices showed new strength but sugar futures continued to decline yesterday in moderately active trading. Other New York markets were quiet.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) July 12--Former Premier David Ben-Gurion has threatened to revive the Lavon affair, which rocked the country almost three years ago. The controversy split Israel's dominant political party, broke up the Government and tarnished Mr. Ben-Gurion's reputation.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- The Administration won a major victory for its civil defense program today. It set the stage for a new drive to provide atomic shelter protection for millions of Americans.
TOKYO, July 12--The Japanese police are investigating a case in which a Tokyo trading company allegedly shipped cinder instead of transistor radios to a New York concern.

MILWAUKEE, July 12 (AP) --Harry Johnston Grant, who built the Mihwaukee Journal into an outstanding newspaper and later turned its ownership over to the company's employes, died tonight at his apartment. He was 81 years old.

Two Negro students who have been named recipients of four-year National MedicalSloan Foundation Scholarships will be the first members of their race to attend the medical schools of Duke University in Durham, N.C., and Emory University in Atlanta.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 12 --A plan of the Famous Artists Schools, Inc., to construct a building on a 20-acre tract in a residential zone has erupted in controversy here.
Officials of the Security National Bank of Long Island and the Grace National Bank, New York City, have discussed a possible merger, usually well-informed industry sources reported yesterday.
Directors of Nedick's Stores, Inc., have voted to increase the company's quarterly dividend to 7 cents a common share from 5 cents in the previous quarter.
NEWARK, July 12--Anthony (Tony Pro) Provenzano was sentenced today to seven years in prison and fined $10,000 on a charge of extorting 8,600 from a trucking company.

PARIS, July 12--Premier Khrushchev was represented today as believing that, with goodwill on both sides, the foundations, for a treaty banning nuclear tests could be laid at the Moscow talks opening Monday.

BOSTON, July 12 (UPI)-- The New York Central Railroad was ordered yesterday to pay John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company the full $1,865,066 debt and interest it owes jointly with the bankrupt New Haven Railroad.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 12 --When Mrs, Gloria Hays Richardson went to a White House gathering of the heads of women's organizations this week, she did something unusual, First, she kept an urgent appointment at the Department of Justice.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 12 (UPI)--Steve Opperman of South San Francisco and 18year-old Bobby Lunn, also from San Francisco, slugged their way into the final of the 1963 national public links golf tournament today.
The belief is widespread that folk singers are an untidy lot about such musical matters as vocal pitch and intonation or keeping their instruments in tune.

TRENTON, July 12--Robert C. Weaver said today that racial bias in housing was restricting the nation's economic growth, undermining its integrity and contributing to other forms of racial discrimination.
The American Society of Travel Agents, Inc., yesterday filed a complaint with the Civil Aeronautics Board seeking a complete overhaul of the minimum fare structure of transAtlantic airlines.
GARDEN CITY, L.I, July 12--A reception and art exhibition here tonight at Adelphi College's new library started the Long Island Festival, a summer program of cultural events.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12--Intent on expanding her growing tourist traffic, Yugoslavia has contracted with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) for a loan of $35,000,000 for the extension of her national road network.

No book appearing this year is likely to have a more impressive title page than "Etruscan Culture, Land and People." It says the book was "written with the collaboration of King Gustaf Adolf of Sweden." Nine other authors, members of the Swedish Institute in Rome, are listed.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- The Govermnent is asking most of the nation's union locals to report on their racial composition.
Danny Kaye arrived at Idlewild Airport from Moscow last night with some thoughtful observations about his first trip there.

PEKING, Saturday, July 13 --Communist China declared today "with a heavy heart" that the current Soviet-Chinese ideological talks in Moscow had turned out badly. It warned that "the present situation is very serious."

LENOX, Mass., July 12-- The first two weekends at Tanglewood this summer are forming a festival within a festival, specifically, a Mozart festival. And tonight Erich Leinsdorf began the second of the Mozart weekends with an exquisite concert.
NEW DELHI, July 12--A Western plan for the air defense of India against a possible Chinese Communist air attack has received the tacit approval of the Government of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

The Sunbeam Corporation is expanding its foreign activities through the acquisition of a 51per cent interest in Rowenta Metallwarenfabrik, G.m.b.H., Offenbach-Main, a German manufacturer of electrical home and commercial appliances.

ATHENS, July 21--Queen Frederika complained on her return to Greece today that the newspapers had given more attention to the antics of 500 London demonstrators than to the welcome of the 100,000 "happy people" who greeted her and King Paul during their state visit to Britain.
BUENOS AIRES, July 12--A big increase in meat exports and a successful vaccination campaign for cattle have become bright spots in the outlook for the Argentine economy.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 12-- California legislators have left Sacramento for the weekend and associates of Gov. Edmund G. Brown are pondering the results of the special session's first week.
The man-in-space program is in the throes of a management crisis that is deeply worrying a growing number of highly placed officials.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 12 (AP)--Chuck McKinley, the newly-crowned Wimbledon champion from San Antonio, Tex., advanced to the semifinals of the Baastad tennis tournament today with a 6-3, 4-6, 6-3, 10-8, victory over Jovergen Ulrich of Denmark.

WASHINGTON; July 12--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, whose multi-billion budget request is being pruned by Congress, defended today a $131,000 award to a journalism school to study dissemination of space science news.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP)--Doubles by Roy Sievers, Don Demeter and Clay Dalrymple drove in all the runs tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated San Francisco, 7--5, despite three Giant home runs.
MECHANICSBURG, Pa., July 12--The aluminum products industry has a tremendous future before it.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Senator Barry Goldwater was given another push along the road to the Republican Presidential nomination today.
TORRANCE, Calif., July 12-- Intergrationsists scored a longsought triumph tonight when a Negro buyer purchased a home in a suburban housing tract.
Latin, sometimes called a dead language, has died again. A Seattle radio station, after briefly broadcasting a weekly half hour in classical Latin, has had to revert to all-English programing.
The brewing industry continues to be fiercely competitive although enjoying an upward trend in sales.
In almost soldierly array, 2,251 Jehovah's Witnesses were baptized by total immersion yesterday at Orchard Beach in the Bronx. The precise and decorous baptism took one minute less than an hour.
Chateaugay of the Darby Dan Farm, the colt that won the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes, will oppose 10 rivals in the Dwyer Handicap at Aqueduct today.

CAMBRIDGE,. Md., July 12--Gov. J. Millard Tawes sent 425 rifle-carrying National Guard troops into this racially explosive Eastern Shore town today. He acted after six whites had been hit by gunfire during wild violence last night.
LONDON, Saturday, July, 13 --The senior Soviet intelligence officer who defected to the West was named today as Anatoly Dolnytsin, a middle-aged career official.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Soule Apsey of New York, formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margery Stabler Apsey, to David Rawlins Moulton. He is the son of John R. Moulton of Charles Town, W. Va., and Mrs. A. Charles Morse of Winnetka, Ill.
LAST week a player in a New York club game bid a grand slam at Spades, holding A-K-Q-x-x as his trump suit and knowing that his partner had at least three or four spades in support.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 2--A recent visitor asked President Chiang Kai-shek if he stood by his prediction that the Nationalist Government would return to the Chinese mainland in 1963.

LONDON, July 12 (AP)-- Bud Edelen of Sioux Falls, S.D., was pushed to a United States record in the six-mile run tonight in the British Amateur Athletic Association track and field championships. Dave Weill of Stanford won the discuss throw and Japanese athletes took two field events.

LYTHAM SAINT ANNE'S, England, July 12--Phil Rodgers of La Jolla, Calif., today tied the left-handed Bob Charles of New Zealand at 277 in the final round of the British Open golf championship after Jack Nicklaus of Columbus, Ohio, had ruined his chances by taking bogey 5's on the last two holes.

The bond market took heart yesterday because the Federal Reserve Bank of New York chose not to raise its lending rate to member banks the day before and staged a modest rally.
NEW ORLEANS, July 12-- Three Negro girls had to be escorted by Federal marshals when they started the first grade in a New Orleans public school three years ago this coming November.
PARIS, July 12 (Reuters)-- France announced today a move that will help ease the United States deficit in international payments.

The Newport-Jamestown ferry, one of the last of the dozens of such carriers that once plied the waters of southern New England, is still moving vehicles and passengers across lower Narragansett Bay after nearly 300 years of continuous operation. KANSAS CITY, July 14-- Swinging back into high gear today, the New York Yankees resumed their pleasant task of putting pressure on the rest of the American League by taking two games from the Kansas City Athletics.

MOSCOW, July 14--United States and British representatives to the three-power talks on a treaty to ban nuclear testing arrived here today amid rising hopes that they would be able to reach a limited agreement with the Soviet Union.
The state commission that has been investigating the New York liquor law called upon the state's police chiefs and sheriffs for assistance yesterday.
Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes has submitted a $100,000,000 plan to Mayor Wagner to nearly triple the capacity of the Long Island Expressway.
Scientists of eight nations will discuss the nature, causes and consequences of birth defects here today through Friday at the Second International Conference on Congenital Malformations.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP)--The league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers extended their winning string to seven games with a rain-shortened 3----2 victory today over the Philadelphia Phillies.

Joseph McD. Mitchell, the Newburgh, N.Y., city manager who recently resigned to become a representative of the John Birch Society, criticized President Kennedy and the current racial integration campaign yesterday.
Dr. Francis J. Ryan, chairman of the department of zoology at Columbia University, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home at 80 La Salle Street. He was 47 years old.
Leaders of the two major parties called yesterday for the creation of special commissions to investigate financial problems of the city and state--in each case under the other party's administration.
LONDON, July 14--One has the impression that either an open season has been declared on spies or that practitioners of this sordid trade have suddenly lost their expertise.

Russell Janney, theatrical producer and author of "The Miracle of the Bells," a best-selling novel of 1946, was found dead yesterday in his apartment at 320 East 70th Street. He was 79 years old. The police said he had died of natural causes.

John Huston will direct the filming of Rudyard Kipling's short story "The Man Who Would Be King" as part of a three-picture agreement with Seven Arts Productions. Mr. Huston, who has been planning...
Jose Greco and his Spanish Ballet appeared at Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday night, but they did little to dispel the chilly dampness of the vast amphitheater.
The president of the Lutheran Church in America called yesterday on the 3,200,000 members of the church to help end racial discrimination.

QUITO, Equador, July 14-- tends that Ecuadoran politics are so involved in compromise and complication that none of the parties was capable of putting through the national reforms that all ostensibly supported.

Though some professors contend that ours is a "salesman's society," many salesmen apparently disagree. Convinced that "selling has become a dirty word," they've' banded together to finance an advertising campaign in college newspapers to present the salesman's side of the case.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 2--A recent survey by a Taipei English-language newspaper showed that a shoeshine boy in this provisional capital of the Republic of China can earn more than a minor Government official.
WASHINGTON, July 14 --Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that a compulsory solution to the railroad work-rules dispute would threaten the institution of collective bargaining.

LONDON, July 14--Prices moved narrowly and irregularly on the London stock market last week and turnover was small. Oil issues attracted some sup port, with interest in them still stimulated by the British Petroleum-Shell bid for Burmah. By contrast, real estate issues eased.

Leading Soviet and Chinese Communist party leaders held a series of secret meetings in the last three years, but they failed to end the Moscow-Peking ideological rift. This was disclosed in the latest Soviet statement on the dispute.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 (UPI)--Chet Nichols, with the help of Dick Radatz, pitched Boston to a 5-0 victory over Los Angeles today after the Angels had outlasted the Red Sox, 10-8, in the first game of a doubleheader.
Herman Appley, Inc., a real estate company with headquarters in Brooklyn, has contracted to buy the six-story elevator apartment building at 85 Van Reypen Street in Jersey City.
The executive committee of the New York City Interfaith Committee of Religious Leaders will go to Washington on July 31 to urge passage of President Kennedy's civil rights legislation.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Kennedy Administration will ask the Governors of all the states neat week to support actively the President's tax program in the interest (of economic development.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 14 --Boutique clothes and ac cessories were shown today at the opening of the Italian fashion week at Pitti Palace. If Italian designers are right, either it is going to be a mild winter or everyone will need a vacation in the sun. There was not a thick ski sweater...
Su Mac Lad--with $25,000 more tucked under his harness --will spend the next few days on a farm, as befits a member of the landed gentry.
New York's newest motion picture theater, the 34th Street East near Second Avenue, opens tonight with the premiere of the British drama, "This Sporting Life."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15 The Security Council will meet Monday to take up a charge by 32 African states that "a state of war" exists in some Portuguese territories.

CALL it coincidence but the compleat moviegoer is suddenly being exposed to Bohemia with a vengeance. Last week a sincere if terribly obvious collection of art, beatniks and harried romance was part of a locally made, fine photographic tour pertinently labeled "Greenwich Village Story."

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 The State Supreme Court reversed today the contempt of court convictions of two Philadelphia Bulletin executives. They had refused to answer questions and produce documents requested by a grand jury investigating City Hall.

Rapid changes in this country's stockpile programs are having an unsettling effect on international metal markets. Among the metals affected in varying degrees are tin, aluminum, copper, lead and zinc.
BUFFALO, July 15 (UPI) The president of the 20,000member Switchmen's Union of North America said today his organization's greatest problems came from outside interference.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 15 This was a day of sailor's delight clear skies and fair breezes for those who manned 341 boats today for Larchmont Race Week.

POINT PLEASANT, W. Va., July 15 The barge of the American Wind Symphony Orchestra was docked, the gangplank was down, the musicians were seated, the sun dappled the Ohio River, the flags snapped in the breeze and conductor Robert Boudreau came to the microphone.
LONDON, July 15 Dr. Giuseppe Martelli, a 39-year-old Italian physicist, was found not guilty today of having spied in Britain for the Soviet Union.

LONDON, July 15 The British Government, worried about the emigration of scientists to the United States and elsewhere, announced today plans to make the scientific environment more attractive in the hope of keeping more scientists here.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) A Republican Senator said today he had asked President Kennedy in effect to cancel a four-year-old arrangement with Canada that has involved more than $600,000,000 in defense orders from Canadian plants.
State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Sarafite ruled yesterday that New York residents who traveled abroad had the right to ship home the legal quantity of duty-free liquors.

Allegheny Airlines said yesterday it was prepared to take over all routes of Northeast Airlines north of Washington if Northeast does not solve its financial difficulties. Northeast faces possible loss of its planes in about 60 days if it fails to meet creditors' demands.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) A Democratic Representative from South Carolina urged Congress today to halt what he called "abusive editorializing over the air waves."
WASHINGTON, July 15-- Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama attacked the Kennedy Administration today for permitting Air Force personnel to participate in racial demonstrations.

The annual luncheon for the benefit of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 16. It will mark the public opening of the association's annual finance campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 15 The House subcommittee on Indian Affairs tried to find out today how much the Federal Government owes the Seneca Indians for the damage the Kinzua Dam will do to their reservation in western New York.
LONDON, July 15 A 25minute ovation greeted the Bolshoi Ballet's production of "Romeo and Juliet" at Covent Garden tonight.

JERSEY CITY, July 15 Ernest Miller, a 50-year-old gasoline station owner, fired a few shots in the air last week to scare off some teen-age thugs who were threatening him. He was arrested and charged with carrying a concealed weapon and firing it within the city limits.
The Federal Government made its long-promised decision yesterday, appointing American Export Lines as its general agent to operate the nuclear ship Savannah.

BRUSSELS, July 15 Inflation is the biggest threat to sustained economic growth in Europe, but a major pitfall in the United States is the danger of deflation, one of Europe's foremost economists said today.
Senator Barry Goldwater said yesterday that Republicans should go after "every available vote" in the 1964 Presidential election. He disclaimed making any sectional or racial appeal.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 15 The United Nations said today that the Congo's economy was "on its way to recovery." But it warned that further progress would require drastic fiscal and economic reforms.
WASHINGTON, July 15 The longtime dream of harnessing the tides surging into Passamaquoddy Bay came alive again today.

It should come as no surprise that homegrown neo-Nazis were among the hoodlums who fomented trouble at the Bronx hamburger restaurant that is being picketed to call attention to its employment practices. These armed white savages from the so-called National Renaissance party naturally gravitated to a place where their philosophy of racial and religious hatred could be fanned into street fighting.
Myron G. Lehman, a retired Buffalo engineer and businessman, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 75 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15-- The National Science Foundation has granted the University of California $1,100,000 to build a marine laboratory at a site in northern California that has provoked controversy.
Cocoa, cottonseed-oil and sugar futures declined in active trading yesterday, while most other New York staples rose in slow dealings.

HEAT, humidity and dust are the natural enemies of the objets d'art collector. Rising temperatures speed tarnishing of silver; humidity, or the lack of it, causes warping or splitting of wood or ivory, and soot can permanently damage fabric fragments.
The New York Mets, as amazing in victory as in defeat, ended their losing streak at 15 games last night at the Polo Grounds, then slid back to the land of lost causes.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Secretary of the Navy Fred Korth and Senators investigating his role in the TFX military plane contract award were reported to have clashed heatedly today at a closed hearing.

WASHINGTON, July 15 President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanganyika arrived today for a two-day official visit and pointed to the Declaration of Independence as a beacon in the worldwide struggle against racism.

NEW YORK reputedly has a larger Puerto Rican population than San Juan, and the wonder is that there are so few well-known Puerto Rican restaurants in the city. There is one restaurant, however, that enjoys widespread fame, the El Radiante at 640 Prospect Avenue (near Kelly Street) in the Bronx.

THERE was a time when the summer was a dead season for bridge clubs, but today the attendance is about as great in summer as in winter. No one is quite sure whether this should be credited to air-conditioning or the statistical increase in the number of bridge players.

WASHINGTON, July 15-- Governor Rockefeller's hardhitting attack on the "radical right" was seen here today as giving voice to the rising concern of the liberal and internationalist wing of the Republican party.
MIAMI BEACH, July 15 Creation of an "American Joint Council on Maritime Problems" was called for today by Louis Waldman, counsel of the International Longshoremen's Association.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 15 (AP) Members of the Electrical Workers Union went on strike against the General Electric Company facilities here today because of what the union said was a breakdown in negotiations for a local supplement to the national contract with the company.
Mrs. Sally Ames Langmuir's Bolero continued yesterday to be the apparent leader of the 14-yacht fleet in the trans-Atlantic race from Newport, R.I., to Plymouth, England, which started June 30.
Steel production bounced back last week after an unusually severe drop in the Fourth of July week. The increase in output followed six weekly declines.
International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday the highest earnings for any quarter or half-year period in its history for the three and six months ended June 30.
WASHINGTON, July 15 New efforts by the Kennedy Administration to persuade United States allies to impose a trade and travel ban on Cuba are meeting with only partial success.
WASHINGTON, July 15 Discounts on newly offered Treasury bills continued to rise this week and reached their highest level in more than three years.
MOSCOW, July 15 Talks between Soviet and Chinese Communists on Marxist ideology were resumed today in spite of the vehement attack on the Chinese position published by Pravda yesterday.
Westinghouse Electric Corporation named yesterday a new president to succeed Mark W. Cresap Jr., who resigned for reasons of health.
"The Robert Goulet Show," a special hour-long musical variety television program, will be taped in September for the 1963-64 season by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Carol Lawrence will co-star.
LOLIONDO, Tanganyika, June 26 For a hunting safari, a day starts before dawn. It begins with the African worker assigned to take care of a hunter bringing a hot pot of tea to the hunter's tent.

Wall Street brokers were mulling over a new pattern in the stock market yesterday the "Blue Monday" pattern. For the 13th consecutive Monday, stock prices, as measured by the Dow-Jones industrial index, sagged. The New York Times combined average of 50 stocks has declined every Monday since June 10.

Birmingham, Ala., which had tentatively agreed to the presentation of an integrated vari ety show before a nonsegregated audience in its City Auditorium Aug. 5, has informed the show's sponsors that the auditorium will not be available on that date.
WASHINGTON, July 15 Robert I. Biren, a senior official of the Agency for International Development, died on Saturday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 51 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15 The Secretary General, U Thant, has received the Soviet Union's suggestion that during United Nations observance of the International Cooperation Year, chiefs of state should lead their delegations to the 20th General Assembly session.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 15 Deputy Prime Minister Abdul Razak of Malaya said today there was still time before the formation of the Federation of Malayasia on Aug. 31 to determine whether the people of Sarawak and North Borneo was to be part of the new federation.
HAVANA, July 15 (UPI) One of the 59 United States students touring Cuba drowned yesterday in a motel swimming pool.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 15 Following on the bare heels of the sunny boutique collections shown yesterday, the fall Italian couture showings today indicate that colors will blaze on city streets as well as at winter resorts.
CHICAGO, July 15 (UPI) Soybean contract prices plunged sharply, most wheat contracts showed strong gains, while corn and oats futures fell today on the Board of Trade.
The Buildings Department began a block-by-block inspection yesterday for housing violations in three "critical" sections.

Mrs. Clemencia Hand Kessler, a scholar in the field of medieval illuminated manuscripts, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 55. She had been hospitalized since last December for a brain tumor.

FORT AMADOR, C.Z., July 15 Subversive actions that threaten the solidarity of the Western Hemisphere and methods of combating them were outlined today for more than 80 delegates attending the fourth Conference of the American Armies.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 15 Buddhist leaders announced today a renewal of their religious struggle against the Government. Their supreme priest in Saigon said the Buddhists' belief in President Ngo Dinh Diem had been "somewhat reduced."

CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., July 15-- Gordon Linderman of Milwaukee gained the jump on six rival skippers today as an unusual four-day regatta to uncover talent for Olympic 5.5-Meter Class racing started on Long Island Sound.

LIBERTY, N.Y. MANY of the doctors and lawyers of tomorrow are following a time-honored tradition by earning their college tuition at Catskill mountain resort hotels as the busboys and bellhops of today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 The Treasury announced today that it was "giving consideration" to the idea of selling oneyear Treasury bills every month, instead of quarterly, as at present.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 15 The New York Giants opened their training camp today on a note of strong optimism Al Sherman, normally a most cautious coach, conceded that he had a lot of good football players on hand.
WASHINGTON, July 15 Senators on an Appropriations subcommittee considering the record budget of the National Science Foundation were critical today of its policies on aid to universities.

Trading on the London stock market opened the week yesterday with what, after the last few weeks, looked almost like a spurt.

CREAMRIDGE, N.J., July 15-- Thirty high school and junior high school science teachers, some from Alaska, California and Florida, deserted their classrooms and laboratories at Columbia University today to study the flora, fauna, marine life and fossils of central New Jersey.

TWENTIETH-CENTURY American painting and sculpture is rewardingly surveyed in an exhibition, "26 American Artists From the Collections of the Whitney Museum and Its Friends," opening at the museum today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 15 Fifty high school students marched from Bayville to the railroad station here today, a distance of about five miles, to enlist support for a school budget that has been defeated twice and comes up for a third vote on July 23.

THE Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of New York University's downtown campus became an opera house for an hour or two last night not a very well-equipped one, but sufficient to the purpose. The purpose was the first performances of two short American operas, Michael Miller's "A Sunny Morning" and Thomas Wagner's "The Crocodile."
MOSCOW, July 15 Premier Khrushchev opened the threepower talks today on a treaty to forbid nuclear testing, Restrained hope about the prospect for agreement persisted after the initial session.

The six-story garage building on plot 125 by 102 feet at 422 West 15th Street has been sold by 422 West 15th Street, Inc., Holmes Rieke, president. It was bought by Leon Benau and William B. Rosenzweig, the operators of the garage, who will continue in business there. The sale was arranged by Rudolph J. Ribarich of Charles G. Keller Co., broker. The terms were cash over a purchase money mortgage of $400,000.

DETROIT, July 15 (AP) The General Motors Corporation, the American Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation reported today that their 1963 model car production has exceeded 1962 figures, with several weeks left for the present model run.
MADRID, July 15 The Spanish regime told the national assembly today it would seek to remain in power after Generalissimo Francisco Franco ceased to be the head of state.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 Pal Benko, who was last in a chess tournament here, knocked Miguel Najdorf out of first place last night in the seventh round of the eight-man Piatigorsky Cup round-robin competition here.
Washington is the locale of Garson Kanin's new play, "The Chosen Few," which David Susskind wants to produce with Mr. Kanin directing. No contracts have been signed.

Manuel Ycaza, a jockey who loves baseball (he's a Yankee fan), batted 1,000 yesterday at Aqueduct. The popular Panamanian won with the only two mounts he had, one of whom, the Nanuet Farms' Miss Twist, scored a victory in the featured Astoria Stakes.
An assault charge brought against a newspaper photographer by Gareth Martinis was dismissed in Bronx Criminal Court yesterday because Mr. Mr. Martinis failed to appear to press the charge.
The Rockefeller Brothers Fund gave $7,449,181 for local, national and worldwide philanthropies last year.
MASSENA, N.Y., July 15 Governor Rockefeller defended his programs to finance capital construction today in the face of new Democratic attacks accusing him of "back-door financing."
Prices of Treasury bills and long-term bonds rose yesterday in light to moderate trading. Prime corporate issues dropped in late dealings and municipals were steady.
NEW ORLEANS, July 15 (AP) A Mississippi voter registrar, accused of trying to flunk Negro applicants for registration, was convicted of civil contempt of Federal Court today.

National Cleaning Contractors, Inc., which is one of the largest building maintenance concerns in the world, has leased the entire second floor containing 15,000 square feet of space in the building at 60 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of 27th Street. National already occupied the first floor and basement with 15,000 and now has 40,000 square feet for executive offices.

The Johnson Johnson Company has decided to switch agency assignments for several of its major products. The decision will affect four advertising agencies.
BONN, July 15 West Germany has signed an agreement giving responsibility to the United States Air Force for training West German pilots to fly the supersonic F-104G Starfighter.

The solar eclipse on Saturday may generate interest in solar astronomy among hitherto uninterested observers. Norton will publish on Aug. 27. "The Sun and the Amateur Astronomer" by W.M. Baxter, which could help make a hobby of this study.
DUBLIN, July 15-- The cornerstone of Dublin's long-awaited new Abbey Theater will be laid by President Eamon de Valera of Ireland within two months.

Governor Rockefeller in his weekend statement denouncing the "radical right lunatic fringe" wrote a 1964 Republican platform for his party and offered it some guidance on policy that could be read as advising against making Barry Goldwater the man for President.
WASHINGTON, July 15 Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, Norway's Ambassador to the United States from 1942 to 1958, died today in Doctors Hospital. He was 75 years old.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 15 The people of Benin and Delta Provinces in Nigeria's Western Region have voted overwhelmingly to form a new region.
Seventy-five Harlem parents and children peacefully picketed the Board of Education for 90 minutes yesterday afternoon, demanding an end to racial imbalances in the city's schools.
Stock prices showed another Monday decline yesterday. They opened slightly below Friday's closing levels and drifted down steadily in light trading throughout the day.
Eleven Manhattan executives were on the first commuter run from Port Washington, L.I., aboard the hydrofoil craft Albatross yesterday.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 15 Mr. and Mrs. Wellington Vandeveer have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Hanford Vandeveer, to Michael Richard Scott. He is the son of Mrs. Adams Batcheller of Far Hills, and the late Michael Simon Scott of London.

LONDON, July 15 John Strachey, a prominent member of the Labor party and a symbol of British austerity after World War II, died of a heart attack today in King Edward VII Hospital for Officers. He was 61 years old.
FARMVILLE, Va., July 15 (AP)-- Volunteers planning a remedial education and recreation program for Negro children of Prince Edward County, Va., began registering youngsters for classes today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 A National Labor Relations Board trial examiner found today that a New York union had engaged in unfair labor practices to try to force the assignment of certain work to its members.

The indicated second-quarter net income of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., increased over that of a year ago with sales the highest for any guarter in its history. WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) The Tariff Commission ruled today that the United States steel industry was not being injured by the pricing policies of French producers of hot-rolled carbon steel wire rod.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) President Kennedy's special railroad fact-finding board today set Thursday for completing a report on the work-rules dispute.
KANSAS CITY, July 15-- Whitey Ford didn't score his 15th victory today, but that was only a minor burn suffered by the Yankees on this sweltering afternoon before a crowd of 16,363.
Corporations and banks report they are about two-thirds finished with their laborious task of collecting tax-account numbers from shareholders and depositors.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 15 (UPI) A Government communique said today that Clement Barbot, a rebel terrorist, and his brother, Harry, were killed yesterday in a clash with militiamen three miles north of Port-au-Prince.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 15 Ocean-going commercial traffic through the Panama Canal in the last 12 months failed to set a record for the first time in 11 years.

A rooftop tank holding 10,000 gallons of water on an office building in Greenwich Village collapsed at about 2:45 P.M. yesterday, but no one was injured.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 15 "Australia, tired of having the farm bloc pull the wool over her eyes, now has her sight set on becoming a major factor in the fishing industry," one of that country's fisheries executives said here recently.
Despite improving business conditions, the United States still needs tax reductions to stimulate demand and reduce unemployment, according to 400 leading college economists.
A new type of chromosomal difference between men and women was discussed at length here yesterday during an international conference on birth defects.

JACKSON, Miss., July 15 District Attorney William Waller moved in State Circuit Court here Monday to obtain an order to send Byron de La Beckwith to the State Mental Hospital at Whitfield for psychiatric observation.

THE Sonny Liston-Floyd Patterson fight for the heavyweight championship of the world is sneaking up on us with to tal unobtrusiveness, so quietly and sedately that you can almost hear a pug drop. This type of promotion would have appalled Jack Kearns, a master of the art of ballyhoo and the last of the big-time spenders.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell argued yesterday that he was immune from arrest under the Constitutional privilege protecting members of Congress from arrest during sessions of Congress, as well as "in going to and returning from the same."
The Jewel Tea Company, Inc., is planning to expand to the West Coast. The food chain said yesterday it proposed to acquire Food Giant Markets, Inc., in a transaction involving about $75,000,000.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 15 Governor Tawes said tonight that the National Guard would have to stay indefinitely in Cambridge, where troops were recalled a week ago.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved, today a proposal to prohibit any United States military aid to African countries beyond their "reasonable" requirements for internal security.
HOLLYWOOD, July 15-- More than 200,000 square feet of a small mountain at Universal Studio will be leveled to make way for the eventual construction of eight large sound stages.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 15 Maj. Gen. Henry Clay Hodges Jr., the oldest living graduate of the United States Military Academy, died today. He was 103 years old and lived at 65 Prospect Street.

CHICAGO, July 15 The integration of public libraries has progressed faster than desegregation of other public facilities in the South and usually without much trouble a report to the annual conference of the public Library Association said today.
Forty-two persons, including 14 Negro clergymen, were arrested yesterday in a civil rights demonstration at the construction site of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.

NEW HAVEN, July 15 Herman H. Chapman, an authority on forest management and a member of the Yale University faculty for 37 years, died on Saturday at his home here. He was 88 years old.
