The statement by Senator Dodd of Connecticut that Ghana is probably "the first Soviet satellite in Africa" is almost as harmful to the position of the United States in Africa as it is unjust to Ghana. The irresponsibility of the statement is obvious from the fact that even Senator Dodd only claims to have talked to one man, who is a respected Ghanaian opposition leader in exile, Dr. Kofi Busia.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 15 What might have been a major racial disorder was averted here tonight five minutes before the deadline of an ultimatum set by Negro leaders.

OTTAWA, July 15 A high court judge who investigated labor warfare in Great Lakes shipping urged Canada today to put the maritime unions and the operation of tugs, dredges, barges and ferries under temporary Government trusteeship.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 15 The superintendent of schools of Atlanta told civic leaders today there were three essentials to the peaceful integration of schools. They are a responsible press, the presence of a large group of citizens willing to take a stand and a church with a willingness to speak out openly and vigorously on the moral issues involved, Dr. John Letson said.
WASHINGTON, July 16-- The Organization of American States appealed to Haiti today to observe "the principle of respect for human rights."

THERE are few food assemblages in the city as capa ble of stimulating appetite and imagination as the acres of delicacies in Macy's fine foods department. A starting point for a gastronomic tour may be the extensive spice shelves, with vanilla sugar and vanilla beans for desserts, file powder for gumbos, and crushed juniper berries for sauerkraut.
WASHINGTON, July 16-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy won easily over a group of liberals in the House today in his bid to expand coverage of the Sedition Act.
In an obvious attempt to strengthen the international standing of the dollar the Federal Reserve Board has approved an increase in the discount rate from its present 3 per cent to 3 per cent.
Klausner Associates, realty Investors, have bought the 13story and penthouse apartment building, at 1049 Park Avenue, between 86th and 87th Streets.
NOWATA, Okla., July 16 (AP)--"There are times when I want to feel bitter, but when I reflect I am not."

PARIS, July 16--A French union leader accused aviation authorities today of bringing in United States Air Force personnel to take the place of French workers at Orly Airport, where strikes are threatening to tie up air traffic this week.
WASHINGTON, July 16--A group of labor-management experts agreed today that collective bargaining was doing much better than the public seemed to believe.

Spot prices of the British pound and the Canadian dollar both eased yesterday following the announcement of an increase in the Federal Reserve Bank discount rate and the rise in the maximum interest rates allowed to member banks on time deposits.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 16-- Many Ecuadorans are beginning to hope that a period of rule by the new military junta may have one important effect on political life here--that is, freeing it from the influence of its two rival caudillos.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 16--President Juan Bosch has, repressed for the time being what was building up to a serious attempt to unseat his four-and-a-halfmonth-old Government by a sector of the military, according to reliable sources.
WASHINGTON, July 16-- The Federal Housing Administration financed the sale of fewer new houses in the first six months of this year than it did during the like period of 1962.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 16--The Larchmont Yacht Club's distinguished old Race Week ran into a wall of calm today as it almost always does at some time or other during its eight-day span.
THE Automobile Competition Committee of the United States, generally referred to by the racing fraternity as Accus, is a busy and powerful organization.

WASHINGTON, July 16-- Commissioner of Education Francis Keppel renewed his plea today for Federal aid-to-education legislation that has all but been lost in the running Congressional debate over civil rights.
WASHINGTON, JULY 16 (AP)--The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission asked Congress today to avoid legislation dealing with radio and television editorials.
RIVER FOREST, Ill., July 17 (AP)--Chuck McKinley, Dennis Ralston and Arthur Ashe today advanced to the third round of the national clay court tennis tournament.
MOSCOW, July 16--A recess in the talks between Soviet and Chinese Communists was apparently called today, but Soviet sources said another meeting was scheduled for tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)--Tributes were heaped on Representative Carl Vinson today to honor him for having, served in the House of Representatives longer than any other man in history.

IN the first act of Norman Norell's long-awaited fall and winter collection presented yesterday (with a preview on Monday evening for friends, store presidents and those fashion editors who were not already covering the European showings), one spectator was bombarded insistently by memories of the Duchess of Windsor. The Duchess as she was in her heyday, that is, before her fashion philosophy took its present, girlish turn.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission cited six brokerdealer stock firms in the New York area today for allegedly participating in a fraudulent scheme to promote Diversified Funding, Inc.

Surrogate S. Samuel di Falco yesterday set Aug. 1 for a hearing without a jury on the authenticity of a will attributed to John Shubert, of the extensive Shubert theatrical interests, who died last November at the age of 53.
Few 2-year-olds in recent seasons have won the fancy of racing fans as has Raise a Native, who is the favorite to add the Great American Stakes to his list of accomplishments today at Aqueduct.
Carroll Rosenbloom, the millionaire sportsman who owns the Baltimore Colts, was absolved yesterday of all charges that he had bet on National Football League games eight to 10 years ago.
Stock prices inched down yesterday after moving in a narrow range during a day of dull and quiet trading.
BONN, July 16--Minister of Agriculture Werner Schwarz said today that West Germany accepted in principle a French compromise proposal to settle the Common Market's grainprice crisis.
WASHINGTON, July 16-- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara issued orders tonight curtailing the participation of military personnel in racial demonstrations.

MALVERNE, L.I., July 16 --The Malverne Board of Education tonight asked Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, to reconsider an order that would require the board to change its enrollment procedures to eliminate racial imbalance.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16--The youthful South African singer Miriam Makeba appeared before the Committee on Apartheid today and described racial troubles in her homeland as a "nightmare."
Cotton futures declined 25 to 60 cents a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
The nation's racial situation will be explored in a series of five telecasts on the American Broadcasting Company network.
Confidence that coming major tariff negotiations would bring a strong revival of liberaltrade sentiment was voiced yesterday by a spokesman for the International Chamber of Commerce.
Manhattan College will put into use in September the first critical, or "hot," nuclear reactor in New York City, Brother Gregory, president of the college, announced yesterday.

Treasury bills, the most liquid security available to investors, now yield more than common stocks, among the riskiest of investments.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16--Pakistan has obtained a $5,000,000 credit from the International Development Association (I.D.A.), for a $10,000,000 flood-control project in her eastern province during the next three years.
MIAMI BEACH, July 16--In a move that took delegates by surprise, the International Longshoremen's Association today set tomorrow as the time for the election of national officers.
CHICAGO, July 16--Momo Salvatore Giancana, the reputed leader of Chicago's underworld, won a dispute today with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which has been keeping him under surveillance.

The 5,955 paying customers at the Polo Grounds yesterday and the 10,000 Midget Mets who were guests of the management came upon a truth that has been overlooked lately. The Mets do not make all the bad plays in the National League.

CHICAGO, July 16 (UPI)-- Wheat futures ended broadly mixed while most other grains were steady to higher in uneven trading today on the Board of Trade.

NOTHING is too good for Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival parishioners in Central Park. The two Irish wolfhounds in the Forest of Arden conjured up in the Delacorte Theater are so well bred that they get a program listing. And so does the goat, which comes from no careless backyard but from the Central Park Zoo.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 16 --Here in Nevada's largest city a heavyweight championship fight is scheduled to begin next Monday at 7:30 P.M., Pacific daylight time, and the party of the first part in the dispute is confident he will have completed his day's work before sunset. On Monday, sunset will be at 7:54.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 16--The determined bid of the Minnesota Twins to elbow their way into the American League pennant race struck a snag tonight.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Ford Motor Credit Company announced yesterday that they had increased interest rates on short and long-term maturities of commercial paper issued and sold directly to investors.

The second major housing project of three planned for the City Hall area is ready for construction. All are adjuncts to the developing Manhattan Civic Center.
HONOLULU, July 16 (UPI) --The parade across the finish line at Diamond Head started today for the 32 boats in the 1963 trans-Pacific yacht race.

WASHINGTON, July 16-- The chief executives of the principal railroads said today that legislation by Congress was the only way to head off a nationwide railroad strike.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 16-- Julia Slator, a maiden 4-yearold pacing mare, won the ninth race at a return of $80.70 and topped off the largest twindouble payoff in New York State tonight at Roosevelt Raceway--$23,563.90. Six fans in the crowd of 25,582 held winning tickets.
WASHINGTON, July 16--Executive agencies of the Government have no objection if a Senate committee investigates possible antitrust law violations by some American drug companies in Latin America.

The head of the city's construction unions retreated yesterday from the strong stand he took last week against a plan for providing more openings for Negro and Puerto Rican apprentices in the building trades.
MADRID, July 21--Talks on renewal of United States rights to military basis in Spain are entering a decisive stage this week, informed sources here say.

Two major United States shipping associations have asked the Kennedy Administration to protect American shipping against what they call a new threat posed by the Agriculture Department in the transport of American farm products overseas.
The Lutheran Church in America made public a study report yesterday questioning the reasoning of the Supreme Court in its rulings against Bible reading and prayer in the public schools.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP)-- The grain market experienced some brief periods of firmness last week, but the trend remained downward and rather broad losses were shown for the second successive week on the Board of Trade.

The Japan Fund, Inc., announced over the weekend that the United States Treasury Department would recommend that it be exempt from certain provisions of proposed interest equalization tax legislation.
LEVITTOWN, Pa., July 21-- Two Pennsylvania and New Jersey Congressmen are joining in a drive to obtain Federal legislation authorizing a nearby bistate bridge agency to go into port development.
DALLAS, July 21--Jack Nicklaus, a young man who has achieved more in 13 months than most golfers do in a lifetime, captured the Professional Golfers Association's 45th annual championship today.
ACCORDING to a United States Department of Agriculture economist, the Quartermaster Corps will purchase about 1,750,000 pounds of freeze-dry foods this year for use by the Armed Forces.
QUAN LONG, Vietnam, July 21--South Vietnamese Government forces inflicted heavy casualties on a strong Communist unit in a fierce battle in the northern section of the Mekong Delta yesterday.

ELLINGTON, Conn., July 21 --Mr. and Mrs. Calmun Myerowitz have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Molly Louise Myerowitz, to Joel N. Levine. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Bertram A. Levine of White Plains.

MILWAUKEE, July 21 (UPI) --The Milwaukee Braves blasted eight Los Angeles pitchers for 26 hits today and won a double-header from the Dodgers, 7--2 and 13--7. The double loss trimmed the Dodger National League lead to six games.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 21 --Tomorrow will be a more critical day than most for this deeply troubled city that Gov. J. Millard Tawes has called one "of almost hourly crises."
Combine elements of industry, banks, insurance and investment companies and hospitals and research institutions.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 21-- A listing of great dates in Nevada history includes these items: 1864--Nevada became the 36th state; 1931, the Legislature passed a six-week divorce law and made gambling legal; 1953, the first atomic cannon shell was fired in the Nevada desert.

NEW ORLEANS, July 21 (UPI)--A Roman Catholic priest swimming without a life jacket towed a teen-age girl to safety through seven miles of choppy Lake Pontchartrain last night. He then obtained help for three other persons put into the water with him when their 18foot outboard motor boat was swamped.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21-- A 23-year-old former Cornell varsity oarsman, Don Spero of New York, and the St. Catharines Rowing Club of Ontario, Canada, won individual and team honors today in the 89th regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen on the Schuylkill River.
Paul O'Dwyer, regular Democratic designee for councilmanat-large in Manhattan, declared himself opposed yesterday to any use of the Condon-Wadlin Act against a possible teacher strike this fall.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 21-- Charles (Sonny) Liston, the holder of the world's most valuable individual sports distinction--the heavyweight boxing championship--will risk his status tomorrow night against Floyd Patterson. They will meet in a contest that hardly anyone expects to go the scheduled distance of 15 rounds in Las Vegas Convention Center.
LONDON, July 21--A little more than five months after his election as the Labor party's leader, Harold Wilson remains one of Britain's most controversial political figures.
MADRID, July 21--The Spanish couture is be-- ing discovered and the click of the castanets means more than music to many a buyer"s ear.

Although day-to-day changes were mixed, the trend of cotton futures prices last week was lower. At the close of trading on Friday, prices of active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 85 cents to $2.55 a bale from the close of a week earlier.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21-- Seven more persons were executed in Damascus today on charges of participating in last Thursday's attempted coup, bringing the total executed so far to 27.

BRUSSELS, July 21--The dollar-defense innovations announced in Washington last week very likely will solve old problems for the United States, but very likely, too, these measures will create some severe new problems for Europe.
Political leaders are wondering whether the upsurge of racial demonstrations will show any effect in voting patterns when Negroes face whites as candidates.
BOSTON, July 21--Houlder Hudgins, an educator and businessman, died here yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- The United States agreed today to ease prospective barriers on the flow of new capital into Canada by modifying its proposed tax on the purchases of foreign securities by United States citizens.
CHICAGO, July 21 (UPI)-- Bob Tillman's 10th-inning home run off Hoyt Wilhelm and scoreless relief pitching by Dick Radatz today carried the Boston Red Sox to a 3-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

Second-quarter earnings of the American Can Company were slightly above those a year ago despite a drop in sales. Results for the half-year declined, according to the report of William C. Stolk, chairman, and Roy J. Sund, president, released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 21-- The nine-month-old District of Columbia National Bank, which is avowedly "color-blind," is off to a fast start.

Herman D. Hillman, director of the New York regional office of the Federal Public Housing Administration, said yesterday that the demand for low-rent public housing in the Northeast had increased considerably in the fiscal year that ended June 30.

The African-Asian bloc appears to have dropped for the moment its insistent demands for the expulsion of South Africa and Portugal from the United Nations. Such demands have been part of its campaign to compel South Africa to abandon its racial apartheid policy and force Portugal to grant immediate independence to its African "provinces."
Exceptional activity on the docks in the last half of 1962 was blamed for a slight increase in the 1962 accident rate for longshoremen in the Port of New York.
ELMSFORD, N.Y., July 21-- Don Allen of Rochester regained the New York State golf championship today when he defeated Richard Rooney of Hamilton, 7 and 6, in the 36hole final.

The first public test of strength on the proposal to create a four-and-a-half-mile oceanfront park at Breezy Point in Queens comes today at a public hearing before the City Planning Commission at City Hall.
WASHINGTON, July 21--The leader of the Negro desegregation movement in Cambridge, Md., said tonight that President Kennedy might have to make a personal appearance there to avert "a civil war."

MOSCOW, July 21--Valery Brumel of the Soviet Union leaped 7 feet 5 inches today for a world record in the high jump, but United States trackmen managed to gain a 119114 victory in the two-day meet between the two countries.
PARIS, July 21--"I've changed my mind. I now think something ought to be done."

A look at the investment strategy of mutual-fund managers is in order, since total assets of the industry grew by about 12 per cent in the first half of this year, despite a decline of nearly 30 per cent in sales of fund shares and an increase of more than 20 per cent in share redemptions.
President Julius Nyerere of the newly independent republic of Tanganyika expressed confidence yesterday that the United States would resolve its racial problems "peacefully and quickly."
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)--Lieut, Gen. John P. Daley, commander of the Army's Combat Developments Command at Fort Belvoir, Va., died today of heart attack in Albany, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

MOSCOW, July 21 (AP)-- The United States track coaches today sharply criticized the conduct and attitude of some members of the American women's squad. The coaches said the girls' actions may have affected the performances of the male stars in the meet with the Soviet Union.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 21--Opposition forces are reported to be putting up strong resistance to Haitian Government forces in the mountains above Port-auPrince.

CHICAGO, July 21 (UPI)-- The Wimbledon champion, Chuck McKinley, successfully defended his national clay court men's singles title today. He defeated the second-seeded Dennis Ralston, 6--2, 6--2, 6--4.

The Rockefeller Foundation appropriated $30,047,036 last year for study and research, it was announced yesterday. This brought to $763,000,000 the amount the foundation had appropriated in its 50 years of existence.

MIAMI BEACH, July 21--The nation's Governors were deeply divided over civil rights today as they prepared for the opening of their annual conference tomorrow. formal debate on the issue, or perhaps a bitter floor fight, seemed certain.
WASHINGTON, July 21-- The Department of Labor reported today that the number of years the average man will work has, for the first time, declined.
LONDON, July 21--Four years after it opened within the jagged walls of a blitzed warehouse on the bank of the Thames, the Mermaid Theater has arrived.
The first American performance of Benjamin Britten's "War Requiem" at Tanglewood's Berkshire Music Festival in Lenox, Mass., will be taped for a two-hour telecast in New York, Washington and Boston.
The cigarette industry's decision to impose certain voluntary restrictions on its advertising apparently has encouraged producers of "smoking deterrents" to step up their promotional efforts.
MOSCOW, July 21--Delegates to the three-power talks on a nuclear test ban treaty were reported today to be seeking a compromise formula for an East-West nonaggression agreement.
The promise of something new and a great view, too, have induced the committeewomen of the Travelers Aid Society to travel.
Sumner A. (Huey) Long was losing his sea legs by twisting at an early-morning party on the Isle of Wight yesterday when the word came:
LENOX, Mass., July 21-- Tanglewood had two intruders this afternoon. One was a chill rain that raised havoc with the weekend plans of many concertgoers; the other was Joseph Haydn.

A civil rights demonstration in Brooklyn yesterday drew thousands of churchgoers, many of them shouting a promise to demonstrate this morning at the construction site of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 20 --A few days ago a group of Negroes from North Birmingham went to City Hall, took the elevator to the third floor and entered the Council chamber where Mayor Albert Boutwell and the new City Council were in session.
LONDON, July 21 (AP)-- A farmer who faces eviction because he insists on keeping pigs drove a tractor to Buckingham Palace today to protest to the Queen.
Agnes DeMille, celebrating her 20th year since creating the revolutionary dances for "Oklahoma!," will begin rehearsals next Wednesday on her 17th musical.
MOSCOW, July 21--Leaders of the Soviet and Chinese Communist parties confirmed today that their representatives had failed to resolve their chief ideological differences.

Critics of President Kennedy's "interest-equalization tax" find it curious that before a bill to implement the tax on purchases of new foreign securities has even been written, two tax forms have already been introduced.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 21--Frank Rice and Jane Converse each won two championships today at the Hollows School of Equitation horse show.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- President Kennedy has alerted the Democratic leadership in the Senate to prepare for swift ratification of a limited nuclear test ban treaty. The President acted in the expectation that the agreement would be initialed in Moscow this week.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 21 (AP)--Sweden made a clean sweep in the Davis Cup European Zone semi-finals today with two victories over South Africa in the last day's singles matches. The Swedes won the zone semi-finals, 5--0.
REDLANDS, Calif., July 21 --Mrs. Grace Mullen, a whitehaired, patrician widow of 87, can make her wheel chair seem like a throne.
LOS ANGELES, July 21--A proposal to outfit a jet aircraft as a year-round astronomical laboratory will probably be made soon by one of the chief organizers of the International Quiet Sun Year.
Dr. Richard Derby, prominent Long Island surgeon, and sonin-law of President Theodore Roosevelt, died yesterday in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 82 years old.
Although much can still happen, the signs now point to a strike by New York City teachers when the new school term opens Sept. 9.

YONKERS, July 21--Oscar Moore, a 25-year-old office worker, won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's 15kilometer senior championship run for the second consecutive year today while pacing the Pioneer Club to a repeat team title victory.

Martini II's failure in the fifth annual International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway Saturday night--he was beaten a half-length by Su Mac Lad-- provided an exciting finish to an otherwise commonplace contest. It also started a concerted effort to bring about a change in the distance of next Saturday night's Challenge Cup race, the sequel to the International.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 21-- After a long period at subzero temperatures, relations between the United States and the Communist Government of Bulgaria appear to be reaching a milder stage.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 21 --The hot ticket, to use one of Broadway's respectful phrases, is one that permits you to see "The Three Sisters" at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- The Securities and Exchange Commission hopes and expects to be able to follow a policy of "cooperative regulation" as it moves to put into effect a vast array of new controls over the securities markets.
HONG KONG, July 21--Communist China welcomed its delegates home last night from the deadlocked ideological talks with the Soviet Union.

Ujpest of Hungary suffered its second upset loss in five days yesterday when the Hungarians bowed to Halsingborgs of Sweden, 5-1, in one of the second-section games in the International Soccer League at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

The proposed tax on American purchases of foreign securities is the one big surprise in the Administration's new program to defend the dollar. It also is the one big incalculable element. There is no way of measuring its precise effect, either psychologically or financially, on the balance of payments.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., July 21--Dick Petty of Randleman, N.C., led all the way in a 1963 Plymouth today and won a 100-mile Grand National stock car race on the 2.85-mile Bridgehampton course.

PHILADELPIA, July 21-- The games the Mets lose twoby-two they pay for inning-byinning. Against the Philadelphia Phillies today, payment began early. It lasted 4 hours 54 minutes and resulted in 8-0 and 7-2 defeats in a rain-spattered double-header at Connie Mack Stadium.
LONDON, July 21--The Festival Ballet gave the London premiere this week of its new full-length ballet, "Peer Gynt."
WASHINGTON, July 21-- President Kennedy returned earlier than scheduled tonight from a weekend on Cape Cod. A heavy day's work awaits him tomorrow on major domestic and foreign developments.
LONDON, July 21--The Beefeaters who guard the Tower of London assumed a more modern stance today: they set aside their elaborate costumes and halberds and picketed the tower.

Jack Brause, realty investor, has contracted to buy the 22story commercial building at 141 West 36th Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, in the heart of the sportswear and knit wear area. The plot is 60 by 100 feet. Leading blouse, knitwear and sportswear concerns occupy about 90 per cent of the 138,000 square feet in the building. L.V. Hoffman Co. were the brokers in the sale.
ROME, July 21--Pope Paul VI, alluding to Moscow negotiations for a ban on nuclear testing, said today that he saw "greater hope" on the world horizon.
ST. LOUIS, July 21 (AP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Houston Colt 45s, 9--4, today as Bob Gibson gained his 10th victory in his last 12 decisions.

DETROIT, July 21--A new contract that places 6,000 Great Lakes seamen under the pension and welfare program now in effect for deep-sea members of the Seafarers International Union, has been announced by the union.

A folk-music variety show called "Hootenanny '63" was presented Saturday night at the Forest Hills Music Festival in Queens. An audience of 7,000 braved the threatening weather at the open-air concert.

JOE LOUIS, the former heavyweight champion, was a man of excitement in the ring but not outside. In the center of the arena he was in spectacular charge of his own affairs, but in the world beyond the ropes he was the pawn of assorted sharpshooters, who reduced him to debt and the ultimate degradation of wrestling

All accounts from Moscow agree that a nuclear test ban agreement is ready for initialing. This is cause for rejoicing, even though it is prudent to remember the hurdles that will have to be surmounted before a hard and fast treaty is signed and delivered to a grateful world.

NOT long ago I revisited the campus of a small and distinguished New England college. LONDON, July 21--The investment temperature is much cooler here following President Kennedy's tax proposals to curb the outflow of American capital.
Like sparrows before a hawk clam diggers in Jamaica Bay fled the marshes and the mudflats yesterday as Inspector Herbert J. Edelman struck again.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 (UPI) --Bill Virdon singled off Jack Warner's glove in the 14th inning and scored Donn Clendenon as the Pittsburgh Pirates posted a 6-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs in the second game of a double-header today. The Cubs won the first game, 5-1.
LOS ANGELES, July 20--An elaborate system of computers may open new vistas of knowledge in man's fight against blood disorders and heart disease.

LITTLE ROCK, July 18-- With all the heat gen erated by racial demonstrations and President Kennedy's proposed civil rights legislation, the talk of Little Rock once again is dominated by questions of integration.

HONORARY members in bridge are commonplace, but yesterday players in the Brooklyn Championships tournament paid Mrs. Barbara Rappaport what may be an unprecedented honor. They elected her an honorary champion in the men's pairs.
A key official of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference charged here yesterday that there was a lack of responsible Negro leadership in the North.
Irving Berlin celebrated his 75th birthday in May, and it was commemorated Saturday night at Lewisohn Stadium by a concert of his music.

CLEVELAND, July 22 Joseph K. Gannett, an engineer who led in the development of windowless factories in which atmospheric and other conditions were controlled, died yesterday at his home in suburban Pepper Pike. He was 77 years old.
The Government securities market inched up yesterday in quiet trading. Prime corporate issues were also up and mu nicipals were steady in slow sessions.
MIAMI BEACH, July 22 The Governors Conference stopped a Republican drive for a showdown on civil rights today by abolishing its resolutions committee.
"They'll always give us opportunities to act like animals,' said a Negro lawyer on a civil rights picket line yesterday "That's what the PattersonListon fight means to me."

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 22 (AP) Barclay Stable's Why Lie, given a well-judged ride by Larry Gilligan, rallied from just off the early pace to win today's feature at Monmouth Park. The race, at a mile and a sixteenth, was for 4-years-olds and upward in the allowance division.
Joshua Logan has agreed to direct Alexander H. Cohen's musical production of "Baker Street," in which Sherlock Holmes is the main character. Contracts are expected to be signed soon.
LONDON, July 22 For nearly four hours today, Christine Keeler stood on the witness stand in No. 1 courtroom of the Old Bailey Courthouse and told of her life with Dr. Stephen Ward.
Three American Jewish organizations denounced the Soviet Union yesterday for "shocking distortions" about the extent of anti-Semitism in the United States.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 22 A plan to end racial imbalance at the Lincoln School in Englewood will be presented to the State Commissioner of Education on or before Aug.1 and placed in effect at the opening of the fall school term.

NEW DELHI, July 22 The Government announced tonight its agreement to a Western plan for joint training exercises for Indian Air Force personnel in the use of complex radar and ground equipment for flying supersonic fighter planes.
A second band of citizens, the Greenwich Village Committee, has been formed to try to keep the contents of the Cooper Union Museum from being moved.
LONDON, July 22 Harold Wilson told the House of Commons today that a Labor Government would repeal the 1957 Rent Act, which provided that housing be freed progressively from rent controls.
Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., in the three-month and six-month periods ended June 30.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 22 Prime Minister Eric Williams put before the Premiers of Jamaica, British Guiana and Barbados today a plea for an association of West Indian territories.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 A Negro appointee to a municipal judgeship took under advisement today a demand that he resign from the board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

The American container ship San Juan and the Norwegian tanker Honnor were moving toward New York yesterday. The two vessels crashed Sunday shortly after noon at a point about 225 miles east of Cape Henry, Va.

The New York State Savings Association announced a few days ago that June deposits had been the highest ever for that month, some $12,000,000 above the same period in 1962. It is good to read impressive statistics the same paper noted that there now are 1,500,000 motel rooms as against 600,000 in 1952, if you want another but something should be said about the people who brought in all that money.
The machinery George Meany and the A.F.L.C.I.O. are setting up to fight racial discrimination is new evidence of the desire of organized labor's top leadership to stamp out Jim Crow practices.
WESTSURY, L.I., July 22 There were no horns blaring for Sonny Liston tonight.

ROME, July 22 Valerio Cardinal Valeri, prefect or head of the Vatican's Congregation of the Religious, died here today. He was 79 years old.

There has been a growing emphasis on new products at many consumer goods companies. When sales of established brands start to fade, these companies simply put the brand into limbo and start a new item.

Drawing on a rich background of his experience in unsuccessful candidacies, as well as memories of how his elder brother as Mayor solved big city problems, Paul O'Dwyer has offered to the public his views on the threatened teacher strike here. Mr. O'Dwyer is the regular Democratic candidate for councilman at large in Manhattan.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 22 A strong rally in the final quarter gave Josedale Senor Hal handled by Joe McDonald, a three-quarter-length victory over favored J.S. Dale in the Rockville Centre Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
CHICAGO, July 22 Integration pickets clashed with the police today at the Board of Education Building. They also held a one-hour demonstration at the City Hall offices of Mayor Richard J. Daley.
The demonstration at the site of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn yesterday was directed by a committee of Negro clergymen with militarylike discipline.

PARIS, July 22 The French Government would expect to be consulted by its allies on application of any nuclear test ban treaty if the United States and Britain conclude one with the Soviet Union, informed source said today.

Petrocarb, Inc., engineers of fuel injection systems, have leased more than 10,000 square feet of space in the new 29-story office building at 250 Broadway facing City Hall Park. The lease was negotiated by John Lewis of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agents for the building, which is owned by Sam Minskoff Sons. The space will be occupied ...

A committee of leading foreign securities dealers here drafted counterproposals yesterday to President Kennedy's plans to tax American purchases of foreign stocks and bonds. The proposals will be presented to the Treasury on Thursday.

"Night Line," an early-morning television program afford ing viewers a chance to talk by telephone with personalities in show business and other fields, will make its debut Sept. 17 over station WABC-TV (Channel 7).

MOSCOW, July 22 "Soccer is the favorite sport in the schools in the Soviet Union," said Gavriel Korobkov, coach of the Soviet National track team. "Gymnastics come next. Perhaps track comes third, perhaps not.

President Sukarno of Indonesia has suddenly raised quibbling new objections to the proposed Malaysian state. He alleges violation of an agreement with Indonesia and the Philippines that Malaysia would not be formed until the U.N.'s Secretary General had ascertained the will of the peoples involved.
WASHINGTON, July 22 President Kennedy asked Congress today to head off a national railroad strike by referring the rail work-rules dispute to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

E.J. Korvette, Inc., a discount department store chain, has obtained a loan of $24,000,000 from the Prudential Insurance Company of America. With the $9,000,000 it obtained by selling Alexander's Department Store stock back to that company recently, it now has in excess of $31,000,000 to finance its current expansion program.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The official diplomatic talk here is about a test-ban treaty and other possible deals with Moscow, but there is also increasing speculation that something much more profound may be happening in the world.

PARIS, July 22 The search for a formula for cutting exceptionally high tariffs in world trade was resumed today in Geneva. There were no immediate results, nor even a strong prospect that a formula might be found this week.
Railroad workers here expressed disappointment and disapproval yesterday of President Kennedy's proposals to solve the railroad work-rules dispute.
