Six Brooklyn men, including four brothers, were indicted yesterday on charges of assaulting a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent outside a Roman Catholic church during a requiem mass for the father of a gangland figure.
BOSTON, July 22 (AP) Hughes Tool Company acquired today 80 per cent control of the financially faltering Northeast Airlines.
PATERSON, N.J., July 22 A prisoner in the Passaic County Jail gained his freedom yesterday by impersonating an inmate who was scheduled to be released.
CAIRO, July 22 President Gamal Abdel Nasser renounced tonight an agreement to unite Egypt, Syria and Iraq. He said the rejection would stand as long as the Baath party regime held power in Syria.

Second-quarter earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation more than doubled those of the preceding three months and the second quarter last year when production fell sharply following the early steel-labor settlement.
WASHINGTON, July 22 The nation's total output of goods and services rose by nearly $8,000,000,000 in the second quarter of this year.
A power failure caused by two fires in electric lines and cables last night darkened homes and apartments in the North Central Bronx, affecting nearly 10,000 people.
Cocoa and sugar futures declined yesterday in moderately active trading. Other New York commodities were mixed and dull.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 22 Floyd Patterson set an en durance record for his series with Sonny Liston tonight.
Brooklyn bankers and public officials hailed yesterday the emergence of the Negro as a factor in the white business community.
In an atmosphere similar to that of a dentist's waiting room, Wall Street awaits the third and final segment of the Securities and Exchange Commission's staff study on the stock market.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 22 In the charged atmosphere of racial bitterness that divides this community, one of the most delicate positions is held by Brig. Gen. George Morris Gelston.
The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter rose 18 per cent over those in the first quarter and 12 percent over the same three months last year.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) Cockpit voice recorders will be required in all jet-powered airliners under a regulation to be proposed by the Federal Aviation Agency next month. The hope is that they will help solve "unsolvable" air crashes.
MADRID, July 22 At least 4,500 coal miners were reported on strike today in Asturias in the north of Spain, some in their pits.
WASHINGTON, July 22 The Navy announced today that it had placed in orbit a satellite that, for the first time, uses only the forces of nature to keep one face always pointed at the earth.
LAS VEGAS, July 22 (AP) Former heavyweight champion Joe Louis said that he believed Floyd Patterson would retire.
Bob Ussery, who earned $7,280 for a two-minute ride on Cyrano last Saturday in the Brooklyn Handicap, was back at Aqueduct yesterday busily picking up smaller change.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 Adlai E. Stevenson exchanged views and sometimes caustic comment today with a group of uninvited visitors to the headquarters of the United States delegation.
BONN, July 22 John BoydCarpenter, chief secretary to the British treasury, arrived here tonight to press the West German Government for speedy purchases of arms and other equipment in Britain.
CHICAGO, July 22 (UPI) Prices of most grain contracts fell today on the Board of Trade. Most July contracts went off the board at noon in the minus column.

A first mortgage loan of $4,000,000 has been obtained by the Second 79th Street Company on the 18-story building containing 211 apartments at 239 East 79th Street. The loan is for 10 years at 5 per cent and was made by a savings bank through the SonnenblickGoldman Company, mortgage ...
WASHINGTON, July 22 President Kennedy is considering plans to send a major Senatorial delegation to Moscow to join W. Averell Harriman at the conclusion of negotiations for a test ban treaty.

Although the stock market apparently is absorbing the impact of the discount rate rise, the foreign securities tax proposal and the critical report by the Securities and Exchange Commission, there is a good indicator to watch. Sometimes it indicates the weather ahead.
WASHINGTON, July 22 The Urban Renewal Administration today granted New York City $400,000 more to complete planning under its community renewal program.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 22 One of Connecticut's least known nature centers will observe its 50th anniversary Aug. 3.
LONDON, July 22 A small art gallery in Bloomsbury will put the pencil and chalk sketches by Dr. Stephen Ward, a major figure in the Profumo scandal, on display tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 A three-way tie for first place among Paul Keres of the Soviet Union, Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland and the world champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, developed after last night's session of the doubleround-robin Piatigorsky Cup chess tournament.

It was Blue Monday once again in the stock market yesterday as prices fell in relatively slow trading. As measured by The New York Times 50-stock average, it was the seventh consecutive Monday on which the market took a loss. It was also the ninth straight trading session marked by falling prices.

MOSCOW, July 22 The delegates of the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain reported tonight that they had made "further progress" in drafting a treaty that would outlaw nuclear testing in the atmosphere, in outer space and under water.
The theme song of the integration movement, "We Shall Overcome," has had its own history of integration, passing from Negro singers to white and back again to Negro.

A proposed "area concept" in trans-Atlantic air operations, under which the two major American carriers would divide the European cities they could serve, was assailed yesterday by a Pan American World Airways executive as "utterly immoral and unjust."

After a one-week respite steel production resumed its downward course last week tumbling to the lowest point since early February. Despite the sharp decline, output exceeded the figure for the corresponding week last year by a wide margin.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 22 The long-delayed construction of a Suffolk County health building at Farmingville and of a county general office building at Hauppauge was approved here today by the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors.
Taking candy from babies is tough, dangerous work compared with the New York Yankees' business of taking ball games from second-division visitors to Yankee Stadium.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 22 Reports reaching here from neighboring Haiti indicate that a group of Haitian exiles have made a successful landing at Arcahaie, a small coastal town 20 miles north of Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Senator Kenneth B. Keating offered an amendment today to broaden the basis of the Administration's proposed ban on discrimination in public facilities.

CHICAGO, July 22 Federal Judge Richard B. Austin today fined Marlin W. Johnson, agent in charge of the Chicago office of the Federal Bureau of Investigations, $500 for contempt of court in refusing to answer questions about F.B.I. surveillance of Sam (Moe) Giancana, Chicago's No.1 gangster.
The Canadian dollar made a strong comeback in trading on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, R.I., July 22 Governors of the states of the Union are back in the Presidential sweepstakes after an interim in which experience in international affairs determined the choices of the national conventions of the opposition party.
The Austrian Government will make a donation to the new Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts: It will be a set of crystal chandeliers.
WASHINGTON, July 22 For the third week in a row, yields on newly-issued Treasury bills moved up to their highest point in more than three years.
The Chain Belt Company of Chicago announced yesterday plans to purchase Hanna Engineering Works, Inc., a privately owned company.

Just before the referee finished his count over Floyd Patterson last night on the 18-by20-foot screen at Loew's State, a man leaped up from an aisle seat near the back of the theater, bolted for the door and said:
A man plunged 1,000 feet to his death from the Empire State Building yesterday after kicking free of a guard who tried to stop him.

Richard M. Flynn charged yesterday that Representative Charles A. Buckley, the Bronx Democratic leader, and Carmine G. De Sapio were engaged in a conspiracy to block democratization of the Democratic party in the city.

The United States Maritime Administration entered a ship auction in Philadelphia yesterday and for $7,560,000 acquired full title to a $14,100,000 tanker in which it had invested $11,945,282.11 last March.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 22 Three million bushels of surplus American gains, primarily wheat, have been used to pay for an 823-mile extension of the underwater communication cable on the Atlantic Missile Range.
SEATTLE, July 22 (AP) Senator Warren G. Magnuson was hospitalized here today for extensive laboratory tests after running a high fever for three days.
REPORTS from an inveterate reader of books about the out-of-doors: A form of literature that used to idealize nature is becoming a branch of natural philosophy.
George Whitney, former head of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., and an international known banker for more than 40 years, died yesterday morning in Doctors Hospital. He was 77 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Hope that Ellis Island may be preserved for some kind of public use has been virtually abandoned by Congress.

THE final event of the Brooklyn Championships Bridge tournament, played over the weekend, was won by the team of Murray Schnee, Kalman Apfel, Michael Becker and Steven Becker, the last two being sons of B. Jay Becker, the bridge expert and writer.

FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., July 22 Arthur P. Davis's Patricia, a 40-foot sloop of the Rhodes-27 Class sailing out of the Beach Point Y.C., won the Commodore John B. Shethar Bowl today with a first-place finish on corrected time in the 81-mile overnight race that opened the 32d annual American Yacht Club Cruise.

NOT every store executive and Seventh Avenue manu facturer has gone to Europe to attend the European show ings. Some find it more profitable to look at what the couturiers have to offer in relative detachment from this side of the Atlantic.

Net sales of shares of the United Funds group of four mutual funds declined by nearly one half, from $82,710,200 in the first half of last year to $41,658,200 in the first half of this year, it was revealed in the group's semiannual report.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 22 A movie was made of the Sonny Liston vs. Floyd Patterson proceedings in the Las Vegas Convention Center tonight. It will be a short-short. Perhaps the title should be "Demolition at Sunset."
More than 2,000 picketsmost of them foes of the Breezy Point park proposal demonstrated outside City Hall yesterday as their leaders argued the merits of the plan before the City Planning Commission.

MAHWAH, N.J. July 22 The Board of Education tonight rescinded a decision it made last Monday to continue the reading of the Bible and the recitation of the Lord's Prayer in schools here despite the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court.
NEW ORLEANS, July 22 (UPI) Birmingham, Ala., faced today orders to desegregate its schools in September. But Jackson, Miss., apparently will not have to follow suit.
Demonstrators, of course, have the right to call attention to the obviously discriminatory apprenticeship and job requirements of certain unions, such as those in the building trades in New York.

DETROIT, July 22 (AP) The United States auto industry is expected to set a record this week when it turns out the 7,130,001th car of the 1963 model run. That car will break the production mark set in the 1955 model year.

MOSCOW, July 22 (AP) The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia said today that a former employe of the topsecret United States National Security Agency had defected to the Soviet Union and requested political asylum.
DAMASCUS, Syria July 22 The Syrian Army was reported today to have spread a dragnet throughout the country for those believed responsible for last Thursday's unsuccessful coup.
The Ultronic Systems Corporation announced yesterday that it has received permission, from the New York Stock Exchange to attach its new stock ticker display system, Lectrascan, to ticker ...

Burt Lancaster will play a leading role in "The Train," a film that will be directed in France by Arthur Penn. The drama, dealing with the Nazi theft of Parisian art works in 1944, will be produced for United Artists by Jules Bricken who also wrote the screenplay.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 22 -A new season got under way here today for the New York Giants, the champions of the National Football League's Eastern Conference, as the seasoned players, for the first time, joined the rookies and several old hands who had started workouts a week ago.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, July 22 The Government's Rice Marketing Board building and adjoining Wharf were dynamited today. The Russian freighter Michurinsk is tied up at the wharf with a cargo of 3,000 tons, including foodstuffs.

WASHINGTON, July 22 A man stung a wasp today. In fact he stung 30 of them. His name is Dr. John Pisano. It's not that he's unfriendly to wasps. He and two co-workers at the National Heart Institute, ...
LAS VEGAS, Nev., ,July 22 (AP) "I have no immediate plans, but I will not retire. I hope to fight my way back into the picture and a third fight with Liston."
Visitors at the World's Fair next year will have the chance to swing around and over the entertainment area on a 4,000foot-long monorail system.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) President Kennedy named Eugene P. Foley today to head the Small Business Administration. Mr. Foley succeeds John E. Horne, whom Mr. Kennedy nominated today as a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Dr. Joseph E. Smadel, a physician who helped to identify and cure a number of virus diseases, died yesterday at the University of Maryrland Hospital. He was 57 years old.
This nation stands on the brink of a nationwide rail strike that would, in very short order, create widespread economic chaos and distress.

AUTOMATION is a spirit, a point of view, as well as a matter of machined contraption. Any writing rich in dogged banalities and haggard cliches is a tribute (of sorts) to the automated spirit, the standardized point of view.

The "intrusion" of the Federal courts into areas of law once considered to be in the exclusive jurisdiction of state tribunals will be closely examined at a seminar of appellate court judges now in progress at the New York University Law Center.

LOLIONDO, Tanganyika, June 30 The appalling suddenness with which a serious situation can arise when dealing with one of Africa's most dangerous species, the buffalo, must be experienced to be believed.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 22 (UPI)?Federal Judge Frank Gray denied today a motion to clear James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, of jury-tampering charges.
LONDON, July 22 Frank Dobson, the sculptor, died today in the Princess Beatrice Hospital here. He was 74 years old.
A Washington, D.C., couple pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to an indictment charging them with being spies for the Soviet Union.
The eighth annual Shaker Museum Festival will be held on the grounds of the museum in Old Chatham, Columbia County, N.Y., on Aug. 3 and 4.
LONDON, July 22 Maya Plisetskaya, the Bolshoi ballerina, knew tonight for probably the first time what it was like to have a London audience in the palm of her hand.

IT is half-past summer, and still not fall. Summer wardrobes are looking tired, but it is still too hot to think about as large investment like a coat or a suit that will languish in a closet waiting for cool weather.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 The Bank of America pioneered today a new field for major commercial banks.
LONDON, July 22 British Honduras will attain internal self-government next January 1, the Colonial Office announced today.
The united Federation of Teachers recommended yesterday that white and Negro schools be "paired" to achieve better racial balances among pupils.
PARIS, July 22 The conservative house of Jacques Heim caused an uproar during the opening day of the Paris collections.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 Liberia warned the Security Council today not to wait for "an explosion" in Portugal's African colonies before acting to enforce United Nations resolutions.
The President's civil rights program is a definite advance but does not go far enough, in the opinion of five national Negro leaders.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 22 Charles (Sonny) Liston blasted Floyd Patterson into a knockout defeat in 2 minutes 10 seconds of fighting tonight. Liston, the holder of the heavyweight championship of the world, floored the challenger three times in the first round of the scheduled 15-round fight.
Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Capelin of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Lee Capelin, to David Paul Helpern.
United States concessions to Canada on the proposed new tax on purchases of securities from foreigners by American citizens gave a big lift to Canadian stock markets yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, July 22 A $150,000,000 urban renewal program in the downtown core of this city got under way today with the demolition of the old Ferris Avenue school to provide space for a publicly financed apartment house.
WASHINGTON, July 22 The Justice Department today kept a delegation of negotiators from Cambridge, Md., in an eight-hour bargaining session that ended at midnight and will resume at 11 A.M. tomorrow.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 22 Rocky Marciano and Joe Louis were among the former heavyweight champions at ringside tonight when Sonny Liston met Floyd Patterson for the title both had held with distinction.
BUDAPEST, July 21 Many Hungarians are certain today that the Soviet Union will soon announce the withdrawal of its troops from Hungary.
A proposal that has attracted little attention in President Kennedy's proposed "interest-equalization tax" could wipe out the market for the most popular foreign bond
AS engaging a set of summertime visitors as you could wish for came to Delacorte Theater in Central Park last night to present the second event of the 1963 Rebekah Harkness Foundation Dance Festival.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 22 The Wimbledon champions, Chuck McKinley of St. Louis and Margaret Smith of Australia, headed the list of 112 men and women who began play today in the 64th Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club.
THE Alaska king crab is the stuff of which nightmares are made. This giant of the deep may measure up to six feet between its vicious claws.
It looks as if Jimmy Piersall will have to shop around for another job in baseball. The New York Mets announced yesterday that the National League club would ask waivers on Piersall today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 President Kennedy's proposal to send the railroad labor dispute to the Interstate Commerce Commission evoked an immediate controversy in Congress today as to whether the plan would constitute compulsory arbitration.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Members of the Federal Reserve Board are deeply divided over the board's move last week to increase interest rates.

After losing $5,324,000 in the first quarter this year, United Air Lines, Inc. turned in the highest quarterly income for any quarter in its history during the three months ended June 30, W.A. Patterson, president, reported yesterday.

A committee of dissident stockholders, including a former president of Ohrbach's, Inc., plans to attempt to oust management of United Artists Theatre Circuit, Inc., a chain of almost 300 motion picture theaters in 10 states.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 23 A tiny Buddhist nun, the mother of one of her country's most distinguished scientists, said quietly but firmly today that she planned to burn herself to death.

It was French Opera Night at Lewisohn Stadium last night, but it might just as well have been called "An Evening with Arlene Saunders." The young American soprano, making her stadium debut, held the audience in the palm of her hand.

One of the chief, financially interested opponents of the proposed Breezy Point Park raised an interesting point at the nine-hour hearing before the City Planning Commission. Martin Seligson, president of the Atlantic Improvement ...
WITH a sympathetic ear for the "help us furnish attrac tively on a budget" pleas of customers, both Abraham Straus and Gimbels opened their fall model rooms today.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 23--Roosevelt Raceway has revised the line-ups for both divisions of Saturday night's Challenge Cup Trot. The most important change was the promotion of Duke Rodney from the $15,000 second section to the $25,000 top tier.
HARRISON, N.J., Wednesday, July 24 A high-speed Hudson Tubes train collided with a Pennsylvania Railroad diesel locomotive just before 1 A.M. today about a mile east of here.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the first half of this year a consolidated net income of $180,032,000, or $1.73 a share. This represents an increase of 19.3 per cent over the net earnings of $150,968,000, or $1.45 a share, in the first six months of 1962.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 23 (Reuters) Switzerland announced today the arrest of two Swiss citizens alleged to have illegally supplied Israeli intelligence with information about a Zurich company that has been linked with jet-engine projects in the United Arab Republic.
CHICAGO, July 23 (UPI) Though wheat futures declined, soybeans led an upward trend today on the Board of Trade.

MIAMI BEACH, July 23 Democrats at the Governors Conference regained the initiative on civil rights today and disposed of the issue by instructing a committee to give it the highest priority in the coming year.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) July 23 Two Israeli Air Force jets clashed this morning with two MIG-17's of the United Arab Republic Air Force along the Negev Desert frontier with Egypt.
The new Museum of Early American Folk Arts will benefit from the fourth annual Forecast of Fashion Dinner Dance, to be held in the Trianon Ballroom of the New York Hilton on Oct. 3.
WASHINGTON, July 23 President Kennedy asked Congress today to abolish the quota system of immigration within five years.
BONN, July 23 The Federal High Court disclosed today that three West Germans who spied for the Soviet Union betrayed "at least" 95 agents of the West German Federal Intelligence Agency.

The American Tobacco Company increased second-quarter sales and earnings from those of a year ago. But half-year results were slightly down, reflecting the loss of a shipping day in the first quarter from the 1962 period.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The Administration opened a concerted drive today to head off opposition in the Senate to a treaty for a partial nuclear test ban. The Administration believes the treaty can herald a new era of world peace.
"Open End," which openly and noisily ended on Channel 5 last spring, will return to New York television as a weekly fixture on Channel 11 in October.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) The space agency changed today the flight plan for its Syncom II communication satellite to advance the first message relay tests four to six days.
FORT DIX, N.J., July 23 Enlisted men staring down at their mess trays today saw strange, round, experimental objects called plates.
Mayor Wagner was advised yesterday that "too many cooks spoil the broth" as pressure mounted for him to define the duties of his two deputy mayors in the interest of orderly government.

WHITE PLAINS, July 23 Bus schedules for transporting 65,000 commuters a day between Westchester County and New York City in the event of a national rail strike next week were drafted today by a Westchester transit coordinating committee.
NOROTON, Conn., July 23 "There are certain people you want very much to beat."
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)--Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago asked Congress today to authorize Federal purchase of the financially troubled Chicago Skyway and conversion of it to a freeway.
DAMASCUS, Syria, July 23 The Syrian Government announced today that it still sought unity with Iraq although President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic had denounced the plan.
SANDBANK, Scotland, July 22 In a week of racing on the Clyde, the new 12-meter Sovereign has shown that she is a good boat. However, she has had teething trouble.

THE coordinator of a committee of 75 Negro minis ters that is directing the demonstration at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn is a 29-year-old Baptist minister who feels he is racing to head off an "unquenchable conflagration."
LONDON, July 23--A key witness for the prosecution in the trial of Dr. Stephen Ward retracted today most of the damaging evidence she had given against him.
New York City borrowed $103,000,000 yesterday for various municipal purposes and projects on bonds due from 1964-83.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23 The Soviet Union denounced Portugal and her "Western accomplices" today and demanded that the Security Council impose a world wide economic and political boycott on Portugal.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI)--House members voted themselves today additional appointments to the Military, Naval and Air academies.
The Customs Agency Service of the Treasury Department has been reorganized to strengthen its effectiveness as the enforcement and investigatory branch of the Customs Bureau.

Construction loans amounting to $10,650,000 on a proposed 20-story office building in Philadelphia will be provided by a group of New York, Boston and Philadelphia banks. The Equitable Life Assurance Society agreed in March to supply the permanent financing for the project, which will be known as 4 Penn Center Plaza.
PARIS, July 23 A more cooperative French attitude toward the United States and France's other allies was predicted tonight in the wake of an important meeting of President de Gaulle and his Cabinet.

MOSCOW, July 23 The delegates of the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain were reported to have discussed today the arrangements under which negotiations might take place for an East-West nonaggression agreement.

In his testimony yesterday on the Administrations bill to refer the railway featherbedding controversy to the Interstate Commerce Commission, Secretary of Labor Wirtz said the White House definitely expects the I.C.C. to order modernized work rules into effect within 120 days

PARIS, Wednesday, July 24--The French Government announced its intention yesterday to raise wages by 10 per cent in public services and nationalized industries. Anti-Government agitation has increased in recent weeks during nationwide strikes in those areas.

PAGE, Ariz., July 23 On the semiarid wasteland behind Glen Canyon Dam, workmen are building a marina. The spiderlike steel contraption will have 20 boat berths with provisions to add 50 more, a fueling dock, public restrooms, a store, sanitary disposal facilities, houseboats for employes and perhaps a lunchroom.
Even before the Sino-Soviet ideological meeting had reached its predestined failure, both sides had taken off the gloves and were slugging it out.
WASHINGTON, July 23 The nation's railroads were under intense Congressional pressure today to postpone once more a showdown in the battle over rail work rules.
CAIRO, July 23 The United Arab Republic paraded two new rockets today and announced that it had developed "the first Arab submarine, which will be tested at sea within 15 days." One
The United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation held its once-postponed annual meeting yesterday at its Brooklyn factory, and it may have been the hottest place in town.
MOSCOW, July 23--Is the Soviet Union planning to deemphasize sports? Has it at least been forced to cut back on its sport budget?
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 23--A sentimental tribute was voiced here today to the original Provincetown Playhouse, where the dramas of Eugene O'Neill received their first recognition.
STRATFORD, Conn., July 23 Connecticut courts were advised today by the state's Supreme Court of Errors to allow "wide discretion" to local zoning authorities.
Merck Co., Inc., achieved the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or half year in its history in the three and six months ended June 30, John T. Connor, president, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 President Kennedy's proposed liberalization of the immigration laws would remove the last vestiges of the racial restrictions that have been applied since 1882 to the influx of potential United States citizens.
NASHVILLE, July 23 (AP ) An aide to Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy testified today that he had had access to grand jury testimony in the James R. Hoffa jury-tampering case.

The modifications that the Administration has been making in its hasty and ill-advised proposal to tax American purchases of foreign securities will lessen much of the plan's potential effect on the balance of payments. They also expose the weakness in the international monetary network that has been built up over the past decade.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the city would proceed at once with plans for a new East River subway tunnel.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Senate investigators made public today testimony that a public relations firm had helped to set up a committee of Portuguese-Americans, paid its chairman $400 a week and used it to lobby for Portuguese colonial interests.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 23 In the horse rooms of this gambling metropolis wagers are accepted on anything. Ac cording to a whisper that was heard above the whir of the roulette wheels at one casino, a high-roller from Hollywood got down the most macabre bet of all before the so-called heavyweight championship bout last night between Sonny Liston and Floyd Patterson.
WASHINGTON, July 21--The space agency announced today that Dr. George E. Mueller would succeed D. Brainerd Holmes as chief of the United States programs to put men on the moon before 1970.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 23 Charles (Sonny) Liston, the president of Intercontinental Promotions, Inc., a Pennsylvania corporation, presided at a press conference today.

Share asset value of the Broad Street Investing Corporation, diversified mutual fund in the Broad Street group, was reported at $14.09 on June 30, representing a gain of 9.4 per cent in six months and 26.4 per cent in a year.
Robert Moses, president of the New York World's Fair, gave renewed assurances yesterday that the fair would open on time April 22, 1964. He also attacked critics who, he said, "foul the city's nest."
INDIANAPOLIS cars and drivers will be back at Trenton Sunday to carry on with their 150-mile national championship race. The race was rained out last Sunday.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 Chuck McKinley, the Wimbledon and national clay court champion, began his quest for the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today and proceeded to lose a set in his first match. He finally won, 6 2, 4 6, 6 4.

The Clark Equipment Company is planning to acquire the assets of the Tyler Refrigeration Corporation in exchange for Clark stock. The transaction, which would involve about $10,000,000, is subject to the approval of Clark directors and Tyler shareholders.
MILWAUKEE, July 23 Richard S. Davis, who started out as a concert singer but became a reporter instead, died today in a hospital at Sturgeon Bay, Wis. He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee made a 50 per cent slash in a key Latin-American aid program today, then severely restricted loans by the Agency for International Development.
Another bank entered the new field of equipment leasing yesterday.
THE American Bridge Teachers' Association will hold its annual convention at Los Angeles tomorrow and Friday, preceding the national tournament that begins at Los Angeles Saturday.
Construction work is expected to be resumed next week on a new tunnel for the IND Sixth Avenue line at 13th Street and the Avenue of the Americas.
LISBON, July 23 The Portuguese Foreign Ministry disclosed today that talks were held last week with a nationalist leader from Portuguese Guinea.
TOKYO, July 23 (AP)--A tanker that is designed to sail the seas with 31 crewmen, half the normal complement, was launched today.
"Should I hold or sell?" . Holders of railroad issues have been bombardnng rail analysts at their brokerage firms with that question for days.
A member of the Board of Education proposed yesterday that after the World's Fair was over, its site and facilities be used for a "comprehensive educational campus" by the city school system.
CALDWELL, N.J., July 23 The first of three verticalrising planes being built under a joint Air Force-Army-Navy program was unveiled here today.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 23 President Juan Bosch charged last night that the Trujillo family was trying to recover expropriated properties here in collusion with Panamanian and American investment companies.

LOLIONDO, Tanganyika, July 1 By any measure ment the African buffalo has the qualities that any top game animal should have. He is extremely tough, intelligent and not at all loath to give a hunter a fight to the finish.
RUWANDIZ, Northern Iraq, July 18(AP) Kurdish rebels and Iraqi Government troops are engaged in one of the biggest battles of their 22-monthold war.

LONDON, July 23 Christian A. Herter told British officials today that he was encouraged by his latest round of talks with the six Common Market countries on next year's trade and tariff negotiations the socalled Kennedy round.

WASHINGTON, July 23 Recent concessions by the Government of South Vietnam to Buddhist opponents have raised cautious hope here that the 10week-old religious dispute in that country may be headed toward a settlement.

The Eaton Manufacturing Company announced yesterday it was offering publicly $25,000,000 of 4 3/8 per cent, 25-year debentures through an investment banking group headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., at 99 5/8 and accrued interest, to yield 4.40 per cent.
The container ship San Juan, her bow smashed in a crash with the Norwegian tanker Honnor last Sunday east of Cape Henry, Va., is due to dock at Port Elizabeth, N.J., this morning.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Dr. W.C. Hueper of the National Cancer Institute told Senators today that the publiC was frequently unaware of the "biological dynamite" in commonly used pesticides.
LONDON, July 23 Prime Minister Macmillan lent a measure of substance today to widespread reports here that an East-West summit meeting was in view.
The Canadian dollar fell and rebounded yesterday on the New York foreign exchange market.
With five games remaining in the second section of play in the International Soccer League, three contests have a direct bearing on the outcome of the race. One of the key
CHARLESTON, S.C., July 23 (AP) Sixty-two downtown Charleston merchants agreed today to integrate their stores. But the move failed to placate leaders of protest demonstrations.
Prices slumped again on the Tokyo Stock Exchange yesterday, ending the market's brief rally.
The Public Service Commission was told yesterday that an engineering survey had recommended that Nassau County take over private water-supply companies.

Seaboard World Airlines, the nation's only all-cargo transAtlantic air carrier, has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to adopt a "horizons-unlimited" approach in its forthcoming investigation into United Statesflag services to Europe.

CINCINNATI, July 23 Roman Catholic schools here are facing a financial crisis that may lead to the abandonment of their first four grades, according to Bishop Paul F. Leibold, chairman of the Archdiocesan School Board.

Laurance S. Rockefeller, chairman of the State Council of Parks, came out yesterday in support of a Breezy Point park in the Rockaways. But he suggested that the project should exclude acreage on which apartment construction was under way.

DETROIT, July 22 (AP)--Norm Cash whacked a game-winning grand-slam homer in the opener and Al Kaline drove in three runs on three singles in the second game as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Chicago White Sox tonight, 5--1 and 6--4.
The city school system will set up two "tension control" teams this fall to help smooth the way for expanded integration efforts.

LOS ANGELES, July 23 The world champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland were tied for first place in the double-round-robin Piatigorsky Cup chess tournament after the completion of the twelfth round here last night.

The Karamu Opera Players of Cleveland, who gave a Haydn opera in Central Park last week, presented one by Handel there last night. It was a semi-staged version of "Julius Caesar" with two-piano accompaniment.
For three years now the Chase Manhattan Bank has been assuring the public, "You have a friend at the Chase Manhattan."

NEWARK, July 23 (AP) The receiver for Office Buildings of America, Inc., has agreed in Federal bankruptcy court to cancel leases on six properties in this state and divide this month's rents among the syndicated owners.

PARIS, July 23 On the secday of the Paris collec tions the air calmed. Despite Jacques Heim's dramatic departure yesterday from the current hem length and the long-standing ban on the early publication of photographs, skirts stayed short, as everyone expected, and photographs were forbidden until the official release date of Aug. 26.

Consolidaed Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday declines in net income and gains in operating revenues, and sales of gas, electricity and steam for the half and the 12 months ended June 30.
New York's 122 construction unions voted unanimously yesterday to set up a committee to pass on the qualifications of Negroes desiring to be apprentices or journeymen.
Leaders of seven predominantly Negro civil rights organizations held another joint conference here yesterday and agreed on plans for a mass march on Washington beginning at noon on Aug. 28.
Sugar and cocoa led most commodities in an advance yesterday.
A flood of funds washed over the money market here yesterday and eroded yields on Treasury bills. Government bonds were mixed; corporates strong, and municipals active and firm.
GLASSBORO, N.J., July 23 Moving time will begin Aug. 1 for 120 families in this small South Jersey industrial town.
WASHINGTON, July 23 A brief but sharp flurry of partisan sniping enlivened the hearings of the Senate Commerce Committee today on President Kennedy's civil rights program.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 Willie Mays was too much for the Mets' pitchers tonight as he cracked two home runs. But even before he clubbed his first of the evening, the Giants were well on their way to a 9-1 victory that lengthened three of the Mets' losing streaks.

President Francois Duvalier lives dangerously. He is always in trouble. There are guerrillas in the hills above Port-au-Prince now and talk of a landing on the coast. Yet he hangs on, and it would be rash to predict his overthrow. He gives the appearance of being indestructible.

The stock market made a brave effort yesterday to halt a decline that had persisted for nine straight trading sessions, but to no avail. After early gains on increased volume on the New York Stock Exchange, prices sagged as demand dried up, and the end result was the tenth consecutive day's loss.
WASHINGTON, July 23 The explosive civil rights struggle in Cambridge, Md., was tentatively settled here today after 72 hours of intensive Federal intervention.
WASHINGTON, July 23 The Kennedy Administration has decided that the Government must become much more deeply involved in protecting workers from the impact of technological change.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 23 Two of the Government's most prominent supporters confirmed today reports that the Nigerian Government planned to press for special powers of preventive detention.

CHICAGO, July 23 The Rev. Arthur M. Brazier, organizer of the Coordinating Council of Community Organizations, threatened today "a massive wave of sit-ins, picketing and selective buying campaigns" if integration demands are not met.
The international jury is still out on President Kennedy's plan to tax United States investment in foreign securities.
TO enter Service Delicacies, 1032 Lexington Avenue (between 73d and 74th Streets) is to enter a land of milk and honey and of all the fresh frozen, cooked and canned products made therefrom.

James C. Hagerty, head of news operations for the American Broadcasting Company, has been elected vice president in charge of corporate relations for American BroadcastingParamount Theaters, Inc., the network's parent company.

BONN, July 23 Bonn is as happy as any other government with the thought that current Moscow negotiations may reduce the chances of war. West Germany knows intellectually and also feels in its bones that it would be obliterated in another conflict no matter how it came out.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The Canadian Government has agreed to take whatever steps are necessary to help the United States stop the excessive flow of American dollars to Canada, treasury officials disclosed today.
Paul R. Screvane, President of the City Council, made two new proposals yesterday in his campaign to put the lending power of the city and state behind the fight against racial discrimination.

EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 23 After the critical dust settles and only forlorn flats and backdrops remain, scenery from Broadway's unwanted shows is shipped here, providing the Children's Summer Stock Theater with enough trappings to produce several pint-size musicals.
The McCrory Corporation, owner of 98 per cent of the common stock of the Lerner Stores Corporation, will sell its shares to the Glen Alden Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

What price bad publicity? Around Wall Street, brokers and their customers have been wondering how prices of seats on the New York Stock Exchange would react to sharp criticism last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission. One answer came yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 Senator Clifford P. Case has asked the Coast Guard to see if it can prevent littering and pollution in the waters along the New Jersey beaches.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Senate investigators disclosed today that Navy Secretary Fred Korth's personal log showed about 16 contacts with General Dynamics Corporation officials during the competition last year for the TFX fighter plane contract.

Stan Williams and John Blanchard, two spectacular flops of the first half of the season for the New York Yankees, took charge at the Stadium last night as the champions pushed their league lead to a new high for the season nine games.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The Securities and Exchange Commission endorsed and adopted as its own today the vast majority of the recommendations made last week by its Special Study Group for Reorganizing Securities Markets.
The Stratford (Ont.) Shakespeare Festival will present two productions next year during London's observance of the 400th anniversary of the dramatist's birth.
SAIGON Vietnam, July 23 Armed United States helicopters inflicted heavy casualties on a Communist guerrilla unit after it attacked two companies of South Vietnamese rangers north of Saigon yesterday.

OCALA, Fla., July 23 Picketing of restaurants and lunch counters was resumed here today in a protest against segregation in these establishments. The picketing was conducted by the Youth Council of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
"It's like anything else," a bettor was saying at Aqueduct yesterday. "Too much of one thing is bad. And I think 112 days of continuous racing at one track is too much. We need a change of scenery."
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 The Reading Railroad reported today a deficit of $1,153,917 for the second quarter, putting the carrier in the red for $2,922,477 for the first six months of this year.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 23 Plans for express bus services to carry an additional 40,000 Nassau County commuters in the event of a national railroad strike that would affect Long Island Rail Road were announced today by the Franchised Bus Service Council of Nassau.
WASHINGTON, July 23--The United States has apparently persuaded the Soviet Union to agree to a treaty for a partial ban on nuclear tests without making it conditional on other East-West agreements.
Mass civil rights demonstrations led to the arrest of 116 persons yesterday in Brooklyn and 27 in Jamaica, Queens, in continuing efforts to block construction work.
MOSCOW, July 23 (AP) Leaders of Soviet bloc countries arrived by train and plane today for economic strategy talks which will open tomorrow under the direction of Premier Khrushchev.
PORTSMOUTH, England, July 23 (UPI) Two yachts finished a trans-Atlantic race less than a minute apart today after 3,000 miles of sailing.
Newly released Government statistics on the economy were generally interpreted yesterday as indicating the business advance is continuing, but at an uninspired pace.

PARIS, July 24--Labor unions here pressed their campaign against President de Gaulle today, capitalizing on resentment in Parliament over the Government's refusal to compromise on controversial legislation.
CHICAGO, July 24--The Palmer House is alive today with the sound of music, a welter of cacophony set up by 400 exhibitors at the annual show of the National Association of Music Merchants.

JUST a five-minute ferryboat ride from the Scottish mainland is the Isle of Skye famous for the clans Macleod and Macdonald and for a little terrier that bears the name of the 48-mile long strip of land. The Skye is one of the oldest of the terrier breeds. Although most...
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Administration is agreeable to broadening the constitutional base for its proposed ban on discrimination in public accommodations, high officials said today.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Railroad officials will decide tomorrow whether to agree to urgent Congressional requests to delay for 30 days action that would touch off a national railroad strike.
Fifty-five persons were arrested yesterday in continuing mass civil-rights demonstrations in Brooklyn and Staten Island, and five Manhattan demonstrators received stiff workhouse sentences.

The Ford Motor Company achieved record earnings and sales in the second quarter of this year. The country's second biggest auto producer had earnings of $155,900,000, equal to $1.41 a share. That was 11 per cent above the $140,600,000 or $1.28 a share earned in the second quarter of 1962.
BERLIN, July 24--I went into Communist East Berlin tonight to see without Communist police and Communist guides what life is like behind the Iron Curtain.
The Japanese Finance Ministry's proposals of Tuesday to support stock market activities produced an energetic rally on the Tokyo Stock Exchange yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 24-- The House Rules Committee reversed itself today and cleared for floor action the long-delayed plan for payment of the remaining $73,000,000 in Philippine war damage claims.
The New York State driver's license of Gareth Martinis was revoked yesterday.

THE search for the right hairdresser is like shopping for clothes. One woman's delight may be another's downfall. But in New York, where beauty salons abound, there should be, in theory at least, a stylist to satisfy every feminine whim.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) --Don Drysdale scored his fourth victory of the month tonight, as the Los Angeles Dodgers increased their National League lead to a seven games by defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5--1. Drysdale yielded five hits.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 24-- City officials and leading businessmen showed their strength today in a determined behindthe-scenes campaign to block a segregationist effort to upset this city's fragile racial truce.

LYON, France, July 24 (AP) --Gen. Joseph Vuillemin, formet chief of staff of the French Air Force and the first man to fly a plane across the Sahara, died yesterday at Desgenettes Military Hospital. He was 80 years old.

The Inland Steel Company, major Chicago-area steel producer, reported yesterday second-quarter earnings 66 per cent above those for last year and the second best in the company's history. Ingot production set records for the quarter and the six months.

The Jaclyn Stable's 3-year-old Ahoy scored the eighth victory of his career in the $22,700 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday afternoon.
State Supreme Court Justice Charles Marks ruled yesterday that "Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure," known for 200 years as "Fanny Hill," was obscene.
PARIS, July 24--The collar is on the rise, and tailoring stays soft. This is the message of the Paris collections now in their third day.
Ginn Co., Boson, and Random House., Inc., announced yesterday het purchase by Ginn of the Blaisdell Publishing Company, a division of Random House.
Washington's Commission of Fine Arts, 53-year-old guardian of the capital's traditional classic image and bastion against the inroads of change, has fallen to the New Frontier.
LONDON, July 24--The Government is preparing to sponsor short television propaganda films against smoking.
WASHINGTON, July 24-- The Air Force confirmed today that special quarters at Otis Air Force Base had been refurbished for a possible emergency delivery of Mrs. John F. Kennedy's third child.
WHEN both players queen pawns one after the other, the game remains complex, unpredictable and dangerous for both sides. Such doublequeening games are rarely seen in grand master tournaments.
WASHINGTON, July 24-- President Kennedy told 100 teen-age "Senators" of Boys Nation today that they had shown "more initiative in some ways than the Governors Conference down in Miami."
General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday new second-quarter and firsthalf highs in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales and net income.

JAMESTOWN, R.I., July 24 --Samuel G. Barton's Westray, a Concordia yawl from the host club, won on corrected time today in Division I of the 32d American Yacht Club cruise. Pursuit, Richard Sheehan's Ohlson-36 sloop of the Larchmont. Yacht Club triumphed in Division II.
Charles G. Mortimer, chairman of the General Foods Corporation, called yesterday for a prompt tax cut for persons and corporations to amount to $10,000,000,000.

Generalissimo Franco is one of the hardest, shrewdest bargainers in the international field. He is apparently ready to do some hard bargaining for a renewal of the United States air and naval bases in Spain. The 10-year treaty with Spain expires this year.
OYSTER BAY, L. I. July 24 --The town board of Oyster Bay authorized spending $2,436,000 today for a 46-acre park in Syosset.

HARRISON, N.J., July 24-- Five investigations were begun today into the crash of a fourcar Hudson Tube train and a Pennsylvania Railroad diesel switching engine early this morning. Two persons were killed and 28 were injured.
Civic and business groups trying to block a 67-acre addition to Flushing Meadow Park, the site of the 1964 World's Fair, will ask the Board of Estimate today to decide when a park is not a park.
John A. Byrnes, a former chief justice of the New York City Court, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 446 East 20th Street.

Dinamo of Yugoslavia, set up a decisive meeting Sunday with Gornik of Poland for the Section 2 title in the International Soccer League tournament when it beat Ujpest of Hungary, 2--0, last night in the feature match of a doubleheader at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

Two maritime unions accused each other of unfair labor practice yesterday as an arbitrator began closed hearings under the internal disputes, machinery of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24--As delegates drifted from the Security Council chamber today, Dr. Alberto Franco Nogueira, Portugal's Foreign Minister, joined an African diplomat.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 45 cents a bale down yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The search for excellence in staffing city government can never stop for long in New York. Mayor Wagner has been rather fortunate during his long term in keeping his official family together, but now he is losing a key man through Presidential appointment of Charles H. Tenney to the Federal bench. Mr. Tenney, an able official, has been City Administrator and since the Charter revision a Deputy Mayor.
HOLLYWOOD, July 24--Nuclear war is the subject of an antiwar movie to be started late in September or early October.

LONDON, July 24--The Government rejected today the Cunard Steamship Company's latest proposal to help pay for a replacement for the aging Queen Mary.

WASHINGTON, July 24-- This capital has been surprised and somewhat puzzled by the silence of the skeptics as the Administration moves toward a treaty with the Russians to prohibit nuclear tests above ground and under water.

The chairman of the Board of Higher Education asked the city yesterday to approve in principle the establishment of a new community college in Manhattan.
NOROTON, Conn., July 24-- Beth McAleer, a Mamaroneck High School senior representing the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club, today captured the Long Island Sound girls' sailing championship.
BOSTON, July 24 (UPI)-- The Kansas City, Athletics swept a double-header tonight from the Boston Red Sox, 5--2, and 7--6, and tumbled Boston from second to fifth place in the American League.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 24-- An 11-week struggle over religion has produced no solutions and no new hope for South Vietnam. If it has produced anything, it is a new force in Vietnamese politics, a determined Buddhist movement headed by young, militant, highly political leaders.
Like the Mets, Governor Rockefeller hasn't been winning many games lately. But he had a victory of sorts at the Miami Beach meeting of the Governors Conference.

A political feud that began six years ago in Albania ended here yesterday in a firehouse when a man cornered his adversary under a fire truck and killed him with a gunshot. A woman passerby was shot in the leg.

XENIA, Ohio, July 24 (AP) --An all-white jury convicted today 17 white college students of trespassing charges filed after a sit-in at a barber shop in Yellow Springs. One Negro defendant was acquitted.
WASHINGTON, July 24-- The United States has delivered a stern diplomatic protest to Ceylon on that country's plans to drive out United States and British oil companies.

Selected American shares, a mutual fund in Chicago, reported in its six-month statement that asset value a share on June 30 was $9.68, compared with $8.97 last Dec. 31. The figure was $7.75 on June 30, 1962, after last May's stock market's collapse.
The Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York will hold its annual dinner dance at the Plaza on Nov. 1.

A film in which President Kennedy and Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy discuss Gov. George C. Wallace in connection with the desegregation of the University of Alabama is being planned for televising.

Whenever the president of a certain major out-of-town company arrives at a New York City airport (about once a week), he is met by two uninvited officials of an advertising agency.
HAVANA, July 24--The Cuban Government expropriated today the United States Embassy building and grounds.
The General Dynamics Corporation realized a 44 per cent increase in second-quarter earnings and a 14 per cent gain in its half-year profit over the corresponding periods last year.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Senate voted today to bar the construction of embassy chancelleries, or offices, in any residential area of the District of Columbia.

Although many skittish investors are holding back from stock market purchases, several companies have become intermittent buyers of their own shares. One result of... these purchases, called "buyin," is a prop under stock prices.
PARIS, July 24--The French Government will reject tomorrow a United States-supported study of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's strategic requirements and resources.
Action by New York City this fall to prohibit by law the use of a nuclear reactor to manufacture electricity here was indicated yesterday.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 713,000 barrels in he week ended last Friday, it was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 191,468,000 barrels, compared with 192,181,000 a week earlier and 184,031,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 24--A Washington citizens committee proposed today that the nation's biggest visitor and student center be built here. It immediately received the Administration's backing.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 24-- Because promazine, a tranquilizing drug which is not a stimulant, was found in a urine sample of Juno, a pacing mare that won last Thursday night's ninth race at Roosevelt Raceway, Del Insko, the trainer and driver of that 7-year-old bay, at the time, tonight was suspended, pending further investigation.
MOSCOW, July 24--The delegates of the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain agreed tonight on a formula for overcoming the final obstacle to a treaty for a partial nuclear test ban.

WASHINGTON, July 24--Some key members of the Senate appeared persuaded today that a partial ban on nuclear testing, far from hurting United States security, would mean a large stride toward a safer and more peaceful world.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 24 --A 27-year-old medical student, married and the father of a son, was found shot dead in his auto on the Merritt Parkway here at 2 A.M. today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24--Portugal challenged her African accusers today to visit her "overseas territories" in Africa and see for themselves the reforms she has put into effect since 1961.

CHATTANOOGA, July 24 (AP)--A Tennessee Valley Authority spokesman disclosed today the receipt of six identical bids on a $2,290,000 contract for power cable to interchange electricity between T.V.A. and a private utility group.
TEL AVIV, July 24--An Israeli justice who compared the Talmudic definition of a Jew to Nazi racist laws has expressed regret that his remarks were construed as critical of the Jewish religion.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 24 --Col. William M. Colvin, U.S. A., retired, died today in Greenwich Hospital after a heart attack. He was 88 years old and lived on Field Point Drive.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 24-- The Mets have blown many games in the late innings, the ninth in particular, but still the players never get used to seeing a good chance of winning go down the drain.

MOSCOW, July 24 (AP)-- Aleksandr Mikhailovitch Gerasimov, Stalin's favorite artist and former president of the Soviet Academy of Arts, died yesterday at the age of 82, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, reported today.
William L. Stewart Jr., chairman of Union Oil Company of California, said yesterday that Daniel K. Ludwig had purchased 1,340,517 shares of Union Oil stock from the Phillips Petroleum Company.

The new management of the Arden Farms Company won yesterday a proxy fight started by J. Frank Holt, the former president, who had sought to return to power.

Msgr. Martin A. Scanlan, pastor since 1935 of St. John's Roman Catholic Church in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, died Monday night at its rectory, 3021 Kingsbridge Avenue. He was 83 years old.
"I Picked a Daisy," the Richard Rodgers-Alan Jay Lerner musical that was recently withdrawn, may turn up early next year as the collaboration of Burton Lane (score) and Mr. Lerner (book and lyrics).

The movement of general cargoes through the Port of New York last year registered, a 15-year high, S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the Port of New York Authority reported yesterday.

HELSINKI, July 24 (UPI)-- United States marksmen and women dominated the individual and the team events, as the 22d world archery championships opened today.
Potato and sugar futures fell yesterday in a dull and directionless day on the New York commodity markets.
LOLIONDO, Tanganyika, July 2--Leopard hunt ing is like making an appointment with one's dentist--a difficult time can be expected.

THERE were two stories last night at Philhar monic Hall. The musical one concerned the first concert of the Midsummer Music Festival, in which Paul Callaway led the Cantata Singers in Mozart's "La Clemenza di Tito." Five more equally interesting events will follow within the next two weeks.

OTTAWA, July 24--A new policy aimed at reducing Canada's wheat surplus was announced today by Mitchell Sharp, Minister of Trade and Commerce. Canada may give about $40,000,000 worth of wheat and flour annually in the next few years to underdeveloped countries, he told the House of Commons.

Five years ago a Senator named Kennedy wrote a pamphlet the theme of which was summed up in its title, "A Nation of Immigrants."

MIDDLETOWN, R.L., July 24-- The Governors at their Miami Beach conference may have returned to their posts better equipped to administer on an interstate pattern the problems common to them all. This was the original design of these conclaves.
Sociologists and other experts may understand the ills of America, but America has difficulty understanding the experts.

Two court-appointed trustees reported to Judge Thomas F. Croake in United States District Court yesterday that they needed more than the month given them to provide a reorganization plan for the shipping interests of Manuel E. Kulukundis.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 24 (UPI)--A federal judge refused today to dismiss juryfixing charges against James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters: The defense had charged the indictment was vague.

NEWARK, July 24--Construction unions in Essex County agreed today to "accept for employment" qualified apprentices and journeymen regardless of race.

Dr. Philip Cohen, attending pediatrician at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital and professor of clinical pediatrics at the New York Medical College, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old. His home was at 1056 Fifth Avenue and his office at 1175 Park Avenue.
Short-term Treasury issues declined and long-term bonds rose yesterday as the Government securities market waited for word about the August refinancing.
WASHINGTON, July 24--A new experimental program to upgrade the people as well as the buildings in urban renewal areas was begun today with a $442,611 Federal grant to New York City.
CHICAGO, July 24 (UPI)-- Soybeans advanced, most wheat futures took a sharp loss and other grains ended steady to up today on the Board of Trade.

Cus D'Amato, Floyd Patterson's adviser, charged last night that Patterson was fouled by Sonny Liston during the heavyweight championship bout Monday night.

Reminder to the forgetful and the crafty: bank accounts and other monies in financial institutions that have been idle for 10 years will be turned over to New York State if they are unclaimed by Oct. 31.

WASHINGTON, July 24-- Secretary of the Navy Fred Korth offered yesterday to resign if it could be found that he had acted improperly in the controversial award of the TFX airplane contract, potentially worth $6,500,000,000.

IN this age of specialization, it is no great problem to find building and repair experts --an electrician to install a panel of ceiling lights, a carpenter to build a storage unit, a plumber to put in a new sink or a locksmith to burglar-proof a door.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 24 (AP)--Steve Brooks and Joe Notter, two jockeys; Preston M. Burch, a trainer, and four horses--including Native Dancer--have been elected to the Hall of Fame in the national museum of racing at Saratoga Springs.
The stock market broke out of a 10-day slump and made a modest advance yesterday. Trading activity, however, was the slowest since Jan. 2.

CINCINNATI, July 24 (UPI) --The Southern Railway asked the Federal Court here yesterday to set aside an Interstate Commerce Commission order raising multiple-car rates on grain shipments into Southeastern states.

THE most effective foreign policy tends to lie, on the side of the nation that has --and is prepared to use--the most powerful armaments.

TENAFLY, N.J., July 24-- Wes Ellis began his quest for a third straight New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association championship today with a 34, 33--67 that gave him a onestroke lead in the first round.

John Blanchard continued his demolition of the Los Angeles Angels yesterday. He blasted another three-run homer and batted in four runs in the course of an 8--4 victory for the New York Yankees before a crowd of 14,465 at Yankee Stadium.
Negro leaders yesterday began distributing a manual of instructions to the thousands of churches, unions and social agencies planning to take part in the Aug. 28 march in Washington.

GUATEMALA, July 24--Col. Enrique Peralta Azurdia, Guatemala's chief of state, announced today that diplomatic relations with Britain had been broken because Britain decided to give neighboring British Honduras limited autonomy.

The directors of the Motor Wheel Corporation yesterday raised the quarterly dividend 5 cents with the declaration of 15 cents a share on the common stock.

WASHINGTON, July 24-- The Treasury announced today that it was refinancing $6,600,000,000 of maturing debt in a manner specifically designed to bolster the Government's intensified efforts to reduce the balance-of-payments deficit.

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes listed below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of companies whose shares are listed on that exchange.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)--United Air Lines ex pressed alarm today at the safety threat of "cramming more and more seats into aircraft."

TENAFLY, N.J., July 25-- Wes Ellis of Mountain Ridge fought off a strong challenge today to retain his lead in the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship at the Knickerbocker Country Club.

CONCORD, N.H., July 25-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Andrew McC. Heath of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Kate Heath, to Edward L. Reboul. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J.B. Reboul of St. James. L.I.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25-- Willie Mays contributed the biggest share of trouble today as the New York Mets once more gained the record book in the column of negative statistics. It was Mays's three-run homer in the fifth that assured the San Francisco Giants an 8-6 victory and handed Casey Stengel's forces their 19th straight road defeat.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., July 25 (UPI)--Five Negroes were arrested in the nation's oldest city yesterday after a noisy, six-hour Negro demonstration that the sheriff described as being near a riot.

Ken McBride, a prime candidate for Frank Lary's vacated role as the American League's chief Yankee-stopper, brought a six-game winning streak to an end yesterday by pitching the Los Angeles Angels to a 5-0 victory at Yankee Stadium.

Second-quarter sales of the Kennecott Copper Corporation increased from the level of a year ago, but earnings were down lower. The half-year profits and sales were sharply reduced from those of last year, according to the report of the large copper producer.

Klausner Associates, realty investors, have bought the 15story and penthouse apartment building at 124 West 79th Street, adjacent to Mount Neboh Synagogue. The property, with a plot 102 by 106 feet, was sold by Miriam R. Schlechter.
Superintendent of Schools Calvin E. Gross proposed, yesterday that teachers sign a two-year contract guaranteeing salary increases on July 1, 1964.

HONG KONG, July 23--The continuing deterioration of relations between Peking and Moscow may be undermining the unity of the Communist bloc, but it is strengthening the unity of the Chinese leadership, Western analysts here believe.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- The agreement announced today to outlaw nuclear tests is the first advance since World War II along the tortuous path toward disarmament.

Despite strenuous opposition from Queens residents, the Board of Estimate paved the way yesterday for the Consolidated Edison Company to build a conventional plant in Long Island City for the manufacture of electricity.

The Government bond market greeted the terms of the Treasury's $6,642,000,000 mid-August refinancing with a broad advance yesterday. Activity centered on the "rights" issues to the new 3 per cent, 15-month notes.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 25--Tect, Inc., of Northvale, a maker of detergents and solvents, and three of its officers pleaded not guilty today to charges of violating the state law banning the importation and transportation of strike-breakers.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today the Justice Department had no evidence that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other leaders of the civil rights movement were "Communists or Communist-controlled."
LONDON, July 25--The House of Commons acclaimed Prime Minister Macmillan tonight when he announced the success of the negotiations in Moscow for a treaty limiting tests of nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, July 25--In a radio and television address tomorrow night President Kennedy will caution the nation against expecting too much to result from the initialing of a treaty for a limited nuclear test ban.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25-- In 90-degree heat, Margaret Smith put on a display of overpowering tennis that has hardly been equaled by any other woman on the Merion Cricket Club turf and defeated Judy Alvarez of Tampa, Fla., today, 6--1, 6--0.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday first-half operating revenues of $60,078,503 compared with $56,495,834 a year earlier. Net income rose to $7,446,685, equal to $1.38 a share, from $6,376,736, or $1.17 a share, in the comparable 1962 half.

LOS ANGELES, July 25-- Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland and the world champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, retained the lead in the 8-man, double-round-robin Piatigorsky Cup, chess tournament after the semi-final round here last night at the Ambassador Hotel.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 25--A survey to determine the feasibility of lighting a public golf course at Salisbury Park in East Meadow for playing at night was authorized today by County Exectitive Eugene H. Nickerson.
PAINTERS are at work in the Carnegie house that Hattie built. When they are finished sometime in August, 42 East 49th Street will be launched in a new fashion direction.

John Houseman will resign as television producer of "The Great Adventure" because of differences of opinion with the Columbia Broadcasting System about the kind of shows to be done.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 25 (UPI)--Defiant Buddhist monks barricaded themselves in their main pagoda here today to gird for battle in their dispute with the South Vietnam Government over religious discrimination.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 25--Five persons were killed and 51 wounded during a mutiny today at La Planta jail here.
Hope continues to grow in the minds of consumers. They have pushed up installment debt past the $50,000,000,000 level, and the Chase Manhattan Bank can find no signs of slackening.

BRUSSELS, July 25--The chances or reaching a quick peace next week in the United States-European chicken war have suffered a severe setback.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 24--The South African Commissioner of Police, Lieut, Gen. J.M. Keevy, has ordered "a thorough examination" into last year's figures of Africans convicted under influx-control and pass regulations.
ROCHESTER, July 25--Dr. Charles O. Warren, research associate in physiology at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry, died Tuesday after a long illness. His age was 58.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 25--Maj. Gen. Edward Allen Noyes, former chief surgeon of the Army in Europe, died here today at Brooke General Hospital in Fort Sam Houston. He was 71 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Democratic leaders set out today to muster a near-unanimous Senate vote for the treaty providing for a limited ban on nuclear tests.
Representatives of about 150 New York City organizations met yesterday afternoon to commence mobilization of their members for the projected Aug. 28 civil rights march on Washington.
WASHINGTON, July 25--Intercity truck loadings for the week ended July 20 was 3.1 per cent ahead of the volume in the corresponding week in 1962.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 25 (AP)--"One-sided, defamatory" coverage of James R. Hoffa by Nashville's two daily newspapers makes it imposssible for him to get a fair trial here, his lawyers charged today.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday second-quarter earnings substantially higher than a year ago, although the gain was not so dramatic as that shown by other producers. For the first six months, earnings were less than last year.
WASHINGTON, July 25,-- George Meany, president of the A.F.I-C.I.O., tolg Congress today that the unions needed the backing of Federal power to eradicate racial discrimination within their ranks.

Fourteen pickets who chained themselves together at the wrists mere arrested yesterday in demonstrations at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn to obtain more jobs in the construction industry for Negroes and Puerto Ricans.
A policeman was arrested at 1 A.M. yesterday as a member of a gang that planned to murder "informers," Acting District Attorney Alfred J. Scotti announced.
MOSCOW, July 25--The United States, the Soviet Union and Britain concluded today a treaty to prohibit nuclear testing in the atmosphere, in space and under water.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP)-- The year's second best putting round on the pro circuit gave Fred Hawkins a fast start in the $50,000 Western open today when he shot an opening-round, four-under-par score of 67.
One of the largest terminal operators on Staten Island reported yesterday that ship arrivals and tonnage loadings in the first six months of this year were up 50 per cent from last
The stock market closed in retreat yesterday, ending a short-lived recovery that had interrupted its 10-day slide Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, July 25--Legislation expanding the Government's authority to regulate the securities industry has been tentatively scheduled for Senate consideration next week. The bill is expected to pass, without difficulty and possibly without even the formality of a roll-call vote.
The Board of Higher Education appointed Dr. Albert H. Bowker of Stanford University as chancellor of the City University yesterday. He will take office Oct. 1.
UPTON, L.I., July 25--The Brookhaven National Laboratory reported today that fallout contamination on Long Island had risen to a record.
BETHESDA, Md., July 25 (AP)--Omar B Ketchum, executive director of the Veterans of Foreign Wars' foreign office, died in a hospital here today after an extended illness. He was 65 years old.

MADISON, Wis., July 25 (UPI)--A newspaper publisher challenged today an Attorney General's ruling that a person is violating Wisconsin's lobbying laws by writing to his legislator without sending copies of his letter to all other legislators.

Surveys by the State Department of Health and independent sanitary engineering companies have shown that the waters off the Rockaways, Coney Island and the eastern Staten Island beaches are suitable for bathing, a departmental hearing was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- The Senate space committee tentatively voted today to knock out the controversial space electronics center that would be established in the Boston area by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The 6-to-5 vote crossed party lines.
The case of Gareth Martinis, the judge's son who was involved in a fatal Bronx collision May 19, became a political issue for both major parties in that borough yesterday.
A newly wed dentist who assertedly posed as a police surgeon on an emergency call was charged yesterday with causing an auto accident in which two patrolmen were seriously hurt.

LOLIONDO, Tanganyika, July 3--Bagging a trophy size leopard in the last five minutes of hunting time left on a safari is probably the best way to finish a month of hunting and filming game in the African bush.

If it can be arranged, Del Insko and Beverly Carter, the harness racing driver and his groom who were suspended Wednesday night pending the completion of a drugging investigation, will be given lie-detector tests today.
The New York Times Company had an indicated net income in the second, quarter of 1963 of $2,050,000, compared with $1,064,000 in the same 1962 period.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 25-- Governor Rockefeller takes his political hopes for 1964 into the redwoods of Bohemian Grove this weekend for exposure to about 2,000 members of the California Establishment.

THE annual European championship tournament has been under way since last Friday at Baden Baden, the Black Forest resort in West Germany. The tournament will continue through Aug. 2.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Members of President Kennedy's Council of Economic Advisers told Congress today that the business outlook past the end of this year was "uncertain."

Kelly Nason, Inc., advertising agency, has leased a floor in the 18-story, office building being erected at 300 East 42d Street by the Fred F. French Investing Company. Joel Jacobson and Peter Speier of Julien J. Studley,...

LOS ANGELES, July 25-- "The Prisoner of Zenda," Anthony Hope's novel which first appeared in 1894, is getting a royal transformation that will make previous stage and movie versions of the mythical land of Ruritania seem unimaginative.
LONDON, July 25--Dr. Stephen Ward took the witness stand in the Old Bailey today for the first time and conceded that he was "a thoroughly immoral man."
The Board of Estimate approved in principle yesterday the establishment of a new community college in Manhattan. The action had been requested by the Board of Higher Education.
Most major European stock exchanges moved forward briskly yesterday, but the Tokyo stock market went into another tailspin.

LEEDS, England, July 25 (Reuters)--Garfield Sobers (102 runs) and Rohan Kanhai (92) of the West Indies returned to their best form against England today as the fourth test cricket match began at Headingley.
