Achievement of an agreement to ban nuclear tests in the atmosphere, in space, and under water may allay one widespread fear of the Atomic Age, the fear of fallout.
WASHINGTON, July 25--Secretary of the Air Force Eugene M. Zuckert disavowed today any "personal, political or other extraneous considerations" in his role in the TFX airplane contract.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- The Kennedy Administration is pleased, hopeful and dispassionate about the limited testban agreement initialed today.

BOSTON, July 25--Louis Fabian Bachrach, second in the three generations of Bachrach portrait photographers, died yesterday at the New England Baptist Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in West Newton, Mass.

Peter Luger's Restaurant, 178 Broadway, Brooklyn, EV 7-7400. This Brooklyn landmark is one of the best steak houses in New York and vicinity. The restaurant is a friendly, sometimes noisy, place, as unprerentious...
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk is seriously considering the extradition of Marcos Perez Jimenez, former dictator of Venezuela.
The Council of the Humanities of Princeton University, using a $335,000 grant from the Ford Foundation, is surveying American scholarship of the last three decades in 13 fields of study.
VIENNA, July 25--Although the United States has Cut Austria off from the barter-purchase of American surplus grain, the Austrian Government uas denied all responsibility for the grain diversion.
Alexander's Department Stores, operator of six stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, announced plans yesterday to build its first Manhattan outlet.

ANDOVER, Mass., July 25-- Robert M. Kimball, secretary of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and treasurer of Phillips Academy here, was found dead last night at his home. The police said he committed suicide with a 22-caliber rifle.
PARIS, July 25--The major non-Communist nations pledged here today to increase their aid further to the underdeveloped world.
Mickey Mantle will remain out of the Yankee line-up for an indefinite period because of a loose cartilage in his left knee.
SPEAKING of Shakespeare, as we were on July 12, Ivor Brown has dust written an illuminating book that turns the scholarly myth into common sense.
LISBON, July 25--The Portuguese Government announced today the nomination of a Negro as secretary general of the terrorist-ridden province of Portuguese Guinea.

A communique issued by the Cuban Ministry of Information on behalf of President Batista on July 26, 1953, read: "Today a new crazy attempt against the armed forces and public order was made in Santiago de Cuba by elements in accord with former President Prio and his followers." The incident was mentioned on front...
Policing a nuclear test ban in the atmosphere, under water and in space is an exceedingly complicated business. The difficulty has probably been greatly underestimated by the public.

PARIS, July 25--France is prepared to agree to a compromise plan for establishing an inquiry into the North Atlantic alliance's strategy and resources, informed sources reported tonight. However, President de Gaulle's Government would insist on two conditions, one of which might stall the inquiry at the starting line.
"My Friend Musa and Other stories," by Edwin Samuel, will be published by AbelardSchuman on Sept. 16. This is a collection of 17 humorous tales about people living in the Middle East--Jews Arabs,...

ALBANY, July 25--Governor Rockefeller announced today the appointment of George W. Herz to fill a vacancy on the Supreme Court in Queens. The vacancy has existed since the resignation last Dec. 31 of Justice John F. Scileppi to become a member of the State Court of Appeals.

Barter, the earliest and most basic way of doing business, seems to be making a modest comeback on Madison Avenue. A growing number of companies and agencies seem to be acquiring advertising space and time--not by direct payment but through complex trades.
Louis J. Galen, a West Coast savings and loan executive, said yesterday that savings associations in the Los Angeles area probably would trim dividend rates by the end of the year.
OCALA, Fla., July 25--Not since the sales tax was imposed by the Florida Legislature in 1948 has anything shaken Ocala as much as the Negro demonstrations against segregation here.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 25 --Albert Hosmer Bowker, who has been appointed chancellos of the City University of New York, has a dry sense of humor, touched with cynicism, which follows him around as much as his reputation for executive ability.
An alert bank teller, a bank guard and a policeman foiled an attempt by a former convict yesterday to cash stolen travelers checks in a midtown bank.

OVIEDO, Spain, July 25-- Roman Catholic prelates told Asturian workers at a rally in Oviedo today that the church was supporting labor. A number of this northern region's striking coal miners were in the audience.
Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that it was "realistically not possible" to meet Negro demands to put large numbers of Negroes on skilled construction jobs here "overnight."
The United States has had both successes and failures in its efforts since World War II to resolve disputed issues with the Soviet Union through treaties or other agreements.
Education planning experts warned the Board of Regents yesterday that the state's colleges and universities might face a shortage of 130,000 to 180,000 places for students within six years.
CHICAGO, July 25--biracial committee including two Federal judges, has been quietly created here.

The Chrysler Corporation reported yesterday sharp increases in earnings and sales for the second quarter and first half of this year. This reflected the auto industry's near-record year in both production and retail sales.
Although Phase One of the acoustical correction of Philharmonic Hall has not been fully evaluated after three days of rehearsals and a public performance, the results so far have proved encouraging.

The most important business before the City Council, for the promotion of the general welfare, is the resolution presented by four members to create a commission for thorough review and reform of the city's tax structure. The need for such study was recognized in mid-May, during the battle over the Mayor's new taxes.

The railroads' agreement to delay the application of modernized work rules for a month spares the country the rigors of a serious strike. It also gives Congress adequate time to consider the deficiencies of the special law President Kennedy has proposed for resolving the long controversy over eliminating unneeded rail jobs.

MALCOLM Frager, the pianist who won the 1959 Leventritt competition and who returned recently from a successful tour of the Soviet Union, created quite a sensation at Lewisohn Stadiuan last night with his playing of the Prokofieff Piano Concerto No. 2, in G minor.

ASHLAND, Ore., July 25-- The longest season of the oldest Shakespearean theater group now operating in North America opened here in the foothills of the Siskiyous last night with "The Merry Wives of Windsor."
BUENOS AIRES, July 18-- The United States wants to end its aid program in Argentina in the next few years, according to official sources here.

Earl D. Johnson, who resigned without explanation last month as vice chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation, was elected yesterday as executive vice president of Delta Air Lines, a prosperous carrier based in Atlanta.

PARIS, July 25--About 10,000 workers massed at the Place de la Republic late today in a last-ditch show of union solidarity against President de Gaulle's labor policy. But the Government overrode opposition to push its controversial strike bill through the National Assembly on its final reading.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 94.2 Wednesday, from 94.0 Tuesday.

The Union Pacific Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to dismiss, as against the public interest, the bid of the Chicago North Western Railway to acquire control of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.

WASHINGTON, July 25--The desire to limit membership in the "club" of nuclear powers propelled both the Soviet Union and the United States as well as Britain toward agreement on a nuclear test ban treaty.
New York was both the beneficiary and the victim yesterday of what meteorologists call "the greenhouse effect," as the temperature went to 91 degrees.

History was made yesterday in Moscow when the United States, Britain and Soviet Russia initialed a treaty banning nuclear weapons tests in the atmosphere, under water and in space. It is still a limited treaty, made possible by the effectiveness of national detection systems, and leaves underground tests untouched.
IN the middle of the hottest day of the year the air-con ditioner begins behaving peculiarly. Finally, it wheezes out a last feeble breath of cool air, shudders, and dies.
The Aetna Life Insurance Company reported yesterday that it had paid $10,000 to the widow of a Miami man who was shot to death on July 11 while applying for a policy.

Orders for machine tools, the machinery used to make production equipment, fell sharply in June from the level in May, according to an analysis of figures reported yesterday in Washington by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

MOSCOW, July 25--Six letters scrawled at the bottom of a typewritten page sealed today one of the most important East-West agreements since World War II. They contained the promise of the world's three most powerful governments to refrain from further contaminating the air and the ocean with nuclear explosions.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- The Joint Chiefs of Staff are expected to endorse the treaty for a partial nuclear test ban initialed in Moscow today.

NEWARK, July 25--A split in the ranks of civil rights groups in Newark was indicated today as pickets appeared in front of City Hall for a twohour demonstration against racial discrimination on construction projects.

CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI)-- Holly Stover, former president of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad and executive assistant to the president of the Burlington Route, died in St. Luke's Presbyterian Hospital here Tuesday. He was 80 years old.
A 21-year-old night club singer who has appeared on Broadway only once will play Fanny Brice in "Funny Girl," the new musical planned for this season.

THE writing of topical fiction about contemporary history is one of the most difficult subdivisions of the art of fiction. The writer must be half reporter and half novelist, and the reporting and the fiction rarely fuse into a unified whole.

WARSAW, July 25--The Polish Communist Government ordered today that strict measures be used to stimulate lagging labor productivity and end inefficient use of manpower by the nation's factories.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 25-- Miss Lucy Bloomingdale Cullman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar M. Cullmay of New York and Stamford, was married this evening in the home here of her parents to Frederick Michael Danziger. The bridegroom is a...

ONE hundred and ten years ago, an American-Indian chef took umbrage because his french-fried potatoes were pronounced soggy. Taking a razor blade, he furiously slashed some potatoes into paper-thin slices and fried them in deep fat until they were light and crisp.

NEW DELHI, July 25--A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that "openly announced collaboration" between Communist China and Pakistan, coupled with reports of a massive Chinese military build-up along the northern border, were "causing concern" to the Indian Government.

STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 25 (UPI)--The United States won two more gold medals and the basketball team scored two victories today in the second day of the 12th Stoke Mandeville Paraplegic Games.

WASHINGTON, July, 25-- The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to ban further economic and military aid to Indonesia unless the President made a public finding that it was vital to United States security interests.

The Seafarers International Union of Canada has asked the Canadian Department of Justice to investigate the conduct of the recent inquiry into the union's long battle with the Canadian Labor Congress.
CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI)-- Soybean futures registered sharp gains today, wheat was mixed and most grains slipped on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- The nation's railroads postponed today until Aug. 29 work rules changes that would set off a national railroad strike.
The proposal for a $150,000,000 Manhattan civic center occupying about 60 acres north of City Hall was unanimously approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday.

CHINCOTEAGUE, Va., July 25--For two days each year this fishermen's village is congested by 20,000 visitors. What brings the throng here are the Chincoteague ponies.
PUBLIC hearings will be held today and Monday on Long Island to consider proposed boating legislation for 1964 in general and one "hot potato" in particular.
LOS ANGELES, July 25-- The Los Angeles Dodgers lost their Tax Series today with Los Angeles County.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- The United States is resisting Indian efforts to modify a recent agreement between the two countries to set up a Voice of America transmitter in Calcutta.
Cocoa futures rose, potatoes declined and sugar prices were irregular in active trading yesterday. Other New York markets were mixed and quiet.
WARSAW, July 25 (AP)-- The United States and Poland open a two-day track and field meet tomorrow in the ultramodern, 100,000-seat. Tenth Anniversary Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- Postmaster General J. Edward Day has submitted his resignation and it has been accepted by President Kennedy.
The treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union to outlaw nuclear tests in the atmosphere, in space and underwater may influence materially the balance of nuclear power.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the first half of this year had a record consolidated net income of $513,000,000, M.J. Rathbone, chairman reported yesterday.

CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, N.B., July 25 (AP)--The late President Franklin D. Roosevelt's 34-room summer home, given to the United States and Canada as a shrine, is closed to tourists this summer--and it may take Congress to open it.
BONN, July 25--The Bonn Government saluted the nuclear test ban treaty tonight as "a partial success" that led to hope for progress toward general disarmament.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 25--Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman warned Cambodia today either to choose peace or a "policy of confrontation."
NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 25 (AP)--City Manager Joseph McC. Mitchell, whose resignation is effective Sept. 9, said today he had turned down a post with the John Birch Society.

MANILA, July 25--Vice President Emmanuel Pelaez said today he was definitely "severing all ties" with the administration of President Diosdado Macapagal.
PARIS, July 25--President Kennedy today expressed the hope that President de Gaulle would adhere to the nuclear test ban treaty initialed in MOSCOW.
Immediate action was blocked last night on a proposal to designate 67 acres, in the Willets Point-Corona area of Queens as an addition to Flushing Meadow Park, site of the 1964 World's Fair.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Sales by department stores in the week ended July 20 were 5 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year.
Del Insko was cleared of responsibility in a horse-drugging episode and his indefinite suspension was lifted with the help of a lie-detector test yesterday.

TENAFLY, N.J. July 26-- Wes Ellis, the Mountain Ridge pro, won the 37th New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association championship for a record third straight time today with a record 72-hole total of 272 at the Knickerbocker Country Club.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 26-- South Vietnamese forces have withdrawn from a highly publicized and supposedly permanent base in the heart of Zone D, a long-time holding of Communist guerrillas. Americans protested the pull-out.
BALBOA, C.Z., July 26-- Prices charged by the Panama Canal for tug hire, line handling, harbor pilotage, cargo shifting, repairing vessels and other services have risen or will go up shortly.
TRENTON, July 26--The alignment of the new Interstate Freeway 287 through Morristown was approved by the Federal Bureau of Public Roads today, ending, a long controversy.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 26-- To Gene Fullmer, former world middleweight champion, West Jordan, Utah, U.S.A.:

NEWPORT, R.I., July 26-- The annual racing cruise of the New York Yacht Club that will begin tomorrow will be different from any other that the country's most distinguished yacht club has ever held. It will include powerboat competition on a predicted-log basis for the first time.
A near-capacity audience turned out for the second program in the Midsummer Music Festival at Philharmonic Hall last night devoted to "The Concerto Grosso."
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 25--With the great day barely five weeks off, Kuala Lumpur is preparing for Aug. 31.

Second-quarter net earnings of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company showed a substantial increase in results over the corresponding period last year. Half-year--profits, however, dropped slightly on increased sales, the company disclosed yesterday.

The Yiddish theater, impervious to insinuations about imminent rigor mortis, will put four productions before the Lower East Side footlights this season, more than any other foreign-language group can offer in multilingual New York.

There was some uncertainty as to who was in charge of the American container ship San Juan at the time she collided with the Norwegian tanker Honnor last Sunday, the San Juan's master told the Coast Guard yesterday.

BLOOMFIELD, Conn., July 26 (AP)--A helicopter undergoing tests crashed in a Bloomfield street today, killing both occupants and a man getting out of his car. The craft came down on Newberry Road, only a stone's throw from the Kaman Aircraft Corporation property, from where it had taken off.
The Federal Reserve Board approved yesterday by a 4-to-1 vote the proposed acquisition of the First National Bank of Farmingdale, L.I., by the Bankers Trust Company.
Massachusetts Investors Trust reported increases yesterday in net asset value a share and in total assets in its second-quarter report.
WASHINGTON, July 26--Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz plunged into a new effort tonight to mediate a settlement in the bitter and tangled railroad work-rules dispute.

Zora Folley and Ernie Terrell, two heavyweigght contenders who want to fight Sonny Liston (according to their managers, anyway), will meet tonight in a nationally televised 10-round bout at Madison Square Garden. The fight is regarded as a toss-up.

The Dell Publishing Company's purchase on Thursday of a 60 per cent share in The Dial Press, Inc., will put capital acquired in mass magazines and paperback books into the competition of the hard-cover book trade.

WARSAW, July 26--John Pennel of Miami bettered his world pole-vault record by a microscopic dimension tonight as the touring United States men's track team swept to a 68-36 lead over Poland in the first day of a two-day dual meet. The Polish women's squad led by only 27--23.

WASHINGTON, July 26-- The Pentagon authorized military commanders today to designate as off limits to servicemen any areas in the vicinity of military bases that practice "relentless discrimination" against Negroes.
Texaco, Inc., reported yesterday for the first half of 1963 a net income of $247,952,000. This is a new high for any first-half period and it is equal to $1.95 a share on the outstanding stock.
LOS ANGELES, July 26, --The national tourna ment of the American Contract Bridge League is officially under way at the Biltmore Hotel here.

Two Teamster Union welfare funds in New Jersey and their possible connection with two overseas research foundations are being investigated by a Federal grand jury, it was disclosed yesterday in Federal Court, Manhattan.

Directors of the Collins Aikman Corporation approved a two-for-one split yesterday of the common stock. One additional share of authorized but unissued common stock will be distributed on Aug. 30, to holders of record Aug. 16.

ALEXANDRIA, United Arab Republic, July 26--President Gamal Abdel Nasser charged in a speech tonight that the Baath party leaders of Syria and Iraq sought unity with Egypt last spring "only to gain time."
LOS ANGELES, July 26 (AP) --Tony Taylor drove in five runs with three singles tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated Los Angeles, 6-5, and cut the Dodgers' National League lead to five games.
ONLY mad dogs and summer people go out in the noon day sun here and the latter stroll languidly along Main Street wearing shorts, duck hats and sunburned noses.
BOSTON, July 26 (UPI)--A mighty homer by Dick Stuart and clutch hits by Ed Bressoud and Bob Tillman tonight enabled the Boston Red Sox to defeat the Los Angeles Angels, 5--4.
A Presbyterian minister suggested this week that the Roman Catholic Church, by virtue of the success to date of the Second Vatican Ecumenical Council, had "stolen our Protestant thunder."

UNITED NATIONS, July 26 --The United States, Britain and France told the Security Council today that they would not vote for an African-Asian resolution that would order all members of the United Nations to apply a partial embargo against arms shipments to Portugal.
Major European stock markets reacted with seeming indifference yesterday to the nuclear test ban accord reached in Moscow Thursday.
NORWALK, Conn., July 26-- Two hundred and seventy workers at the Hat Corporation of America were notified today of an indefinite layoff by W.P. Morin, vice president in charge of labor relations.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26-- Governor Rockefeller said here today he had been invited to attend a briefing on the full meaning of the test ban agreement between the Soviet Union, Britain and the United States.
CHICAGO, July 26 (UPI)-- Wheat futures edged upward while other grains dropped sharply today on the Board of Trade.
It was a dull day in the stock market yesterday, compounded of hot weather, vacations, economic doubts and a feeling that perhaps money might be just as well off in the bank.

Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Russian poet who has impressed the Western world as the prime example of a new creativity in the Soviet Union, has written the text for "Moscow," an illustrated portrait of the city. This book of pictures by William Klein will be published by Crown in October.

A program of 8-mm. films will be shown Monday evening at 7:30, 9:15 and 11 o'clock by the Film-Makers Showcase, a nonprofit distribution center for independent movies, at the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street.

Erie J. Treulich, majority leader of the City Council, announced at City Hall yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination in September for Supreme Court Justice from the Eleventh Judicial District in Queens.
Stock prices of many real-estate companies are in a private market slump.
There will be no free evening chamber music concerts in Washington Square Park this summer because of insufficient funds. The opening concert had been planned for Aug. 4.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, July 27 (AP)--South Korea's ruling Junta announced today that it would hold national elections this fall and return the country to civilian rule in December.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP)-- Bob Gibson pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 4-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

WASHINGTON, July 26-- The Federal Communications Commission released a letter today sharply critizing the Government-chartered Communications Satellite Corporation.

BONN, July 26--It is rare for those who attain power to shed that habit easily and Konrad Adenauer is no exception to this rule. And it is unlikely that the effective and far younger men now taking over in Bonn would actually have managed to edge the 87-year-old Chancellor toward retirement had not time conspired with them.
A hogfish and some other interesting specimens acquired by the New York Aquarium at Coney Island yesterday are in for a new experience.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- The index of wholesale primary market prices was unchanged at 100.5 per cent of its 1957-59 base during the week ended July 23, the Bureau of Labors Statistics reported today.
BALTIMORE, July 26 (AP) --Milt Pappas stopped the Chicago White Sox, 6--0, on three hits tonight as the Baltimore Orioles moved into second place in the American League.
Next week's calendar of new fixed-interest debt offerings is expected to perk up the usually slow summer market for new issues.

FRESH beets are arriving in city markets from the farms of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New York. The beets offer two vegetables for the price of one because the green-leafed tops, which are rich in vitamins A and C, can also be used. They make an excellent addition to the salad bowl, and they can be cooked and served much like spinach.

The Hamburg South American Line is about to build the first new large West German passenger liner since before World War II and will enter her in the highly competitive North Atlantic passenger field.

LENOX, Mass., July 26--It was hot tonight, and 6,779 persons sweltered while listening to the Boston Symphony under Erich Leinsdorf. The temperature must have been around 90, and even the piece of moon hanging in the sky seemed ready to drop from sullen heat prostration.

It is completely understandable that the African states are exercising great pressure to achieve independence for the Portuguese colonies. But the risks of instant independence for countries not yet ready for it are again being brought home to the world by the continuing troubles in one of Africa's richest and sickest states--the Congo.
SEOUL, Korea, July 26--South Korea will quietly observe tomorrow the tenth anniversery of the armistice in the war that began with Communist North Korea's attack June 25, 1950.

The case of the missing bonsai, which had baffled the police for nearly a year, was apparently cleared up yesterday. The solution came with the arrest of two men as they were taking a second specimen of the artifically dwarfed Japanese tree from the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
An effort to end tuition charges at the community colleges of the City University will be made by the Board of Higher Education.

Skoplje, which was devastated by an earthquake yesterday, has been a focus of power in the Balkans since the ancient times. Under President Tito it has been a center from which Yugoslav power has radiated throughout Macedonia.
The Board of Education is preparing special materials for city teachers on the contributions Negroes have made to society.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 26 --Jack Dohoney of the Rockville Links and Gene Francis of Wheatley Hills supplied the fireworks today as match play started in the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Garden City Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 26-- Secretary of the Air Force Eugene M. Zuckert said today that the General Dynamcis proposal for a new type of airplane had been consistently rated higher than the proposal by the Boeing Company.
What might be the greatest array of baseball talent ever assembled on one field will gather today at Yankee Stadium when the New York Yankees stage their 17th annual Old-Timers' Day.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 26-- In the $50,000 International Trot last Saturday at Roosevelt Raceway, Su Mac Lad of the United States was 9 to 20 and Martini II of France was 10 to 1.
PAGE, Ariz., July 23--Upstream from the controversial Glen Canyon Dam on the Colorado River, near the confluence of the Colorado and Green, lies Canyonlands.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- The new test ban treaty still looked good to the Administration today, and so did its chances in the Senate, but officials quickly found that it posed many problems.
A one-hour program on the nuclear test ban agreement will be televised tomorrow by the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, July 26--A huge jump in sugar prices and the first general price rise for cigarettes in more than five years helped push the consumer price index to a record level in June.
Two Chinese refugees from Cuba facing deportation to Jamaica were taken off a vessel 45 minutes before she was to sail yesterday after some fast work by a Federal judge and a relief agency.

CHICAGO, July 26--The Christian Century, a liberal nondenominational Protestant weekly that has often spoken out strongly for civil rights, attacked today "bigots" and "extremists" in the "racial revolution."
Five major aluminum producers agreed yesterday to grant extended vacations each year to one-fifth of their nearly 30,000 workers.
PARIS, July 26--Pierre Cardin's collection, dashing and youthful, was a joy to see after a hectic week of Paris showings.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- The Sperry Gyroscope Company says its new fuel control, which was patented this week, brings the gas turbine a step closer to the family car.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., July 26--Four Negro juveniles are in the county jail here today awaiting transfer to Florida schools for delinquents as a result of participation in demonstrations against segregation.
MOSCOW, July 26--Premier Khrushchev declared today that the conclusion of a treaty for a partial nuclear test ban had created favorable opportunities for a further advance toward ending the cold war.

A 43-year-old manager of a Brooklyn garage was released in $10,000 bail yesterday by Judge Benjamin Schor in Criminal Court in Brooklyn when he was arraigned on a charge of conspiring to obtain weapons to be used in gangland slayings.
HOUSTON, July 26--The New York Mets did it again tonight. They established a major league record that no other team wants.

JAMESTOWN, R.I., July 26 --The 32d annual American Yacht Club cruise, a six-day sail that began off Rye, N.Y., with an overnight race Sunday, ended today with a 13.1-mile race, under excellent sailing conditions, from Bristol Harbor to Conanicut Yacht Club off here.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- The Civil Aeronautics Board stripped Northeast Airlines of the valued New York-Florida route today. The vote was 3 to 2.
HAYTI, Mo., July 24--Travelers passing through southeast Missouri are surprised to find themselves halting their cars for school buses on blistering days like today.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- The Mayor of Atlanta appealed to Congress today to pass legislation to eliminate segregation, which he called "slavery's stepchild."

The directors of Hydrometals, Inc., and the Miller Manufacturing Co. of Detroit have agreed in principle on a merger, according to an announcement made here yesterday. The agreement is subject to ratification by the shareholders of both companies.
Sugar and cocoa futures plummeted yesterday in moderately active trading.
PATERSON, N.J., July 26 --Unions in the building and construction trades here voted unanimously today to open their journeyman and apprentice programs to all qualified applicants.
HAVANA, July 26 (AP)-- Premier Fidel Castro called today for Cuban-style revolutions in Latin America.
The rest of the American League must be discouraged at the way the New York Yankees keep rolling on.

LONDON, July 26--History repeated itself for the Bolshoi Ballet at Covent Garden tonight. Last fall at the Met the smash hit of the Bolshoi season was the premiere of "Ballet School."
LEE, Mass., July 26--If the Western Theater Ballet of England is typical of its place of origin, the city of Bristol, which is in the west of England, must be lively, friendly and frank.
PARIS, July 26--Japan was invited today to become a member of the 20-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, heretofore an all-Atlantic group.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 26 --Finalists at Forest Hills a year ago, Margaret Smith of Australia and Darlene Hard of Los Angeles will play for the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship tomorrow at 1 o'clock at the Merion Cricket Club.
The decision on Italian participation in the New York World's Fair of 1964-65 is up to a committee in Rome, Edward Corsi said yesterday.

MONTREAL, July 26--Christian unity, though not yet near, is inevitable if the world continues on is present path, according to delegates to the fourth World Conference on Faith and Order of the World Council of Churches. The meeting closed today. Parley Asks Fight on Bias
CHICAGO, July 26--The Journal of the American Medical Association urged today that physicians become more knowledgeable about prescription drugs.

Jockeys go on losing streaks, and when they do their followers are quite likely to discover a short cut to the poorhouse. So it was with relief that Bob Ussery guided the Bright Elm Stable's Keep Cool into the winner's circle yesterday after the fourth race at Aqueduct.

ATLANTA, July 26 (UPI)-- Dr. Martin Luther King, the integration leader, said yester day a 39-year-old Negro linked by Congressional committees to the Communist movement had worked twice for his Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., has decided not to repurchase about 43 per cent of its stock that is owned by E.J. Korvette, Inc., for $9,834,436 plus interest.
NEW DELHI, July 26--India warmly welcomed today the agreement for a limited nuclear test ban initialed yesterday in Moscow.

Prices of Government bonds rose yesterday, as they have all week. It was a fairly active session for a summer Friday, dealers said. The high-grade corporate and municipal markets were steady in quiet trading.

Prices of Government bonds rose yesterday, as they have all week. It was a fairly active session for a summer Friday, dealers said. The high-grade corporate and municipal markets were steady in quiet trading.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 26--Syncom II, a new breed of space communications station, rocketed into orbit today. It cleared two big hurdles toward its goal as the world's first synchronous satellite--one that hangs over one area of the globe.
LONDON, July 26--The Cunard Steamship Company will build a liner to replace the aging Queen Mary if the interest rate on a regular Government loan is not too high.

A 59-ton earth-moving machine to be used in the construction of the Mont Cenis Dam in the French Alps was loaded yesterday aboard the vessel Egda here for shipment via the port of Antwerp, Belgium.
Ceremonies starting an extended weekend graduation program got under way yesterday at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The Federal Communications Commission told American broadcasters today to give Negro leaders and spokesmen for all "responsible" groups fair air time on programs dealing with racial segregation.
In the slowest trading since last Oct. 12, stock prices showed practically no change yesterday until the final half hour of the afternoon when they inched upward slightly.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 23 --Wool industry authorities here are taking a sober view of the high prices which marked the end of the 1962-63 wool auction year.
LONDON, July 26--Dr. Stephen Ward ended three hours of cross-examination today asserting that he was the victim of perjured witnesses and a police conspiracy.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (UPI)--Chuck Hiller, who had been benched for weak hitting, smashed a two-run homer in the ninth inning tonight to give the San Francisco Giants a 6-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., acknowledged yesterday that the 1,000,000-kilowatt steam generating plant it planned to build in Long Island City was an alternate to the one originally slated for the lower East Side.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- Strict new regulations were issued today to prevent racial discrimination in union-management apprenticeship programs sponsored by the Government.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- President Kennedy, speaking to the nation tonight in a "spirit of hope," described the treaty for a limited nuclear test ban as a "victory for mankind" in its pursuit of peace.
FOR the shopper who has reached the "If I don't sit down, I'll scream" stage, it is a comfort to know that most New York department stores have eating places within.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 26--A three-day festival of folk music conceived and run by seven musicians opened here tonight.

PARIS, July 26--Former Premier Rene Pleven warned President de Gaulle today against defying public opinion by ignoring the United StatesSoviet-British nuclear test ban treaty and continuing French tests.

The decision of the Civil Aeronautics Board to oust Northeast Airlines from the New York-Florida market, while a shattering blow for Northeast, was regarded by much of the industry yesterday as a constructive move reducing heavy competition.
As usual, there are a couple of $100,000-plus weekend races for thoroughbreds today. Not as usual, both are distaff races.
BONN, July 26--West Germany raised a warning voice today against the political consequences in Europe that could flow from the new Soviet-Western nuclear test treaty.
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 26-- Hundreds of Negroes and whites marched two and one-half miles in 100-degreee heat today to protest economic discrimination against minorities.

WARSAW, July 26--Polish health authorities widened today their vaccination campaign as an outbreak of smallpox in the southwestern city of Wroclaw threatened to spread to other areas. There were fears that the disease might also spread to Warsaw.
The executive director of the Protestant Council of New York joined civil rights demonstrators in Brooklyn yesterday and promised that more white Protestant ministers would take part next week.
New Yorkers took to the shady side of the street yesterday as the temperature soared into the 90's for the third straight day.
SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Saturday, July 27--A massive earthquake devastated the city of Skoplje at dawn yesterday while most citizens slept, leaving more than 500 dead and 3,000 injured.
HONG KONG, July 26--A Chinese Communist official expressed confidence today that China would have nuclear weapons "in the not too distant future."
The desert in bloom--until now a phenomenon of occasional springtime rains in the Middle East--is coming closer to lasting reality in Israel.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 26 --This Colonial town, which was settled in 1639 and named in 1845, recalled a bit of its heritage today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26-- Twelve investor-owned Western public utilities will announce tomorrow that they will share the cost of a survey to determine how a nuclear power plant would fit into their systems.
Roy F. Atwood, a 66-yearold stockbroker, was found dead yesterday in his 15th-floor penthouse apartment at 164 East 72d Street.

The management of the United Service Organizations in the United States on a national level has been terminated and transferred to local boards of directors with the responsibility for local financing.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- Switzerland has informed Cuban authorities that she will not abandon the United States Embassy in Havana unless physically forced by Cuba to do so.
MADISON TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 26 (AP)--A volunteer fireman was charged today with the murder of a 4-year-old boy who died in a fire the man allegedly had set.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) President Kennedy voiced to President Tito and the Yugoslav people today America's sorrow over the Skoplje earthquake disaster. He offered whatever United States help was possible.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., July 27 (Canadian Press) The Detroit Boat Club's senior eight today finished a length ahead of St. Catharines in the final championship event of the fourday Royal Canadian Henley Regatta.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Not even Sonny Liston exhibited quicker footwork and more fighting blood last week than Governor Rockefeller, the new Miami Mauler. But unlike Liston, who already owned the title and was confronted by no more than a glass jaw, Governor Rockefeller still is a mere challenger in what is plainly going to be a Pier Six brawl.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 The Philadelphia Phillies, beating Johnny Podres on his home field for the first time in six years, defeated Los Angeles, 4-1, tonight and trimmed the Dodgers' league lead to four games.

LIMA, July 27 Presidentelect Fernando Belaunde Terry's plans for Alliance for Progress aid to Peru range from one of the world's most ambitious highway projects to the forming of equipment pools for Indian communities in the Andes.

HUNTER, N. Y. The temperature in the Catskills may be in the' 70's these days, and a breeze through the nearby notch may come as a welcome relief, but here at Hunter Mountain, home of a major wintertime ski area, enthusiasts have been skiing down a small strip of man-made carpet as though it were February.
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 27 Among the 30 commercial galleries that line the narrow cluttered streets of this Cape Cod town, the Provincetown Art Association stands venerable and distinctive.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 26 It was last Thursday before a contact scrimmage when Al Sherman, coach of the New York Giants, accosted Hugh McElhenny, his new 34-yearold running back, and said, "Mac, we're going to hit this morning. How do you feel about it? Do you want to hit or don't you? You don't have to. I know what you can do."
LEEDS, England, July 27 (Reuters) The West Indies sent England sliding toward defeat today before a crowd of more than 30,000 in the fourth test cricket match at Headingley.

MOSCOW. THE young Soviet artists and intellectuals who are struggling for greater freedom of expression have reason to be gratified by what happened here during Moscow's third International Film Festival, which ended Sunday.

NUTLEY, N.J., July 27 The marriage of Miss Linda Rose Silvestri, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip James Silvestri, to George Sykes Jr. took place this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sykes of Darien, Conn.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. July 27 In offices a few steps from the United Nations a small group of men and women prepare to celebrate the 40th anniversary of service to an ideal.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 27 Two hundred African students who are employed in the metropolitan area while on vacation from colleges over the United States entertained their summer hosts at a lawn party this afternoon.

THE day When a national television network edi torially endorses one Presidential candidate and opposes another, which could add a fillip to campaign festivities, does not appear to he one of the imminent occurrences of the 1960's.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, July 27 When British Guiana's Parliament convenes Tuesday, Premier Cheddi B. Jagan and three other Assemblymen of his party, who were suspended in the last session, will be present.

RICHMOND, Va., July 27 State Republican party leaders began preparing this week for November elections throughout the state. They are entering their largest number of candidates since Reconstruction days.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., duly 27 The General Assembly's Special Committee on Colonialism ended a five-month series of sessions this week by approving a resolution designed to promote the independence of three African enclaves.

ST LOUIS A spectacular face-lifting is taking place on St. Louis's grimy riverfront. Two stubby legs of a giant arch that soon will soar above the city are beginping to grow. The gleaming stainless steel arch will rise 630 feet to become the country's tallest National Monument, surpassing the 555-foot Washington Monument in the capital.
BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP) Dave Nicholson made five hits and drove in five runs tonight as the Chicago White Sox swept a double-header from the Baltimore Orioles, 5 3 and 10 1.
MOSCOW, Sunday, July 28 Government leaders of the Soviet Union and seven other Communist countries proposed today the "convocation of a United Nations world conference on trade and development."
GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 27 Atomic irradiation may put pasteurized food alongside pasteurized milk in the family refrigerator.
PORT ARTHUR, Ont., July 27 A massive assault seems to be vanquishing the sea lamprey, vampire of the oceans, whose invasion of the Great Lakes has threatened to destroy the fishing industry there.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 27 The defeat of a proposed preventive detention act here this week would appear to confirm Nigeria as one of Africa's democratic countries.
WASHINGTON, July 27 Efforts to mediate the railroad work-rules dispute continued today under intensified pressure from Congress for a negotiated settlement.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 27 Darlene Hard of Los Angeles scored one of the great victories of her career today.

DARIEN, Conn., July 27 Miss Katrina Victoria OhlssonBogert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Ohlsson-Bogert of Rowayton, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Brandon Hart. He is the son of Mr, and Mrs. Harry Carlton Hart of Princeton, N.J.
Department store, sales rose five per cent in the week ended July 20 from the level of the corresponding week last year.
CHICAGO, July 27 A grant of $68,300 received recently from the National Science Foundation will enable the University of Chicago to enlarge its study of the stock market.
TRENTON, July 27 Three private utility concerns are seeking permission to draw water from the Delaware River to operate three new generating plants.
BRUSSELS, July 27 The condition of the coal industry in the European Economic Community, as elsewhere in the free world, can be summed up in three words: sick, sick, sick.
The Rockefeller Institute, the University of Pennsylvania and New York University announced yesterday the establishment of a fellowship program for creative writing in science.

The junior high school, prodigy of American education progress of the 1920's, has become the problem child of the 1960's. Lingering dissatisfactions were first given a voice by Dr. James B. Conant in his 1960 report on "Education in the Junior High School Years." He said that the emphasis on marching bands, varsity athletics and the worst aspects of high school life had shocked him.

There came a brief note the other day from the Sudan, where for a month a team of scientists had been living deep in the Red Sea in watertight villages containing such home comforts as air-conditioning and television. The wife of Jacques-Yves Cousteau, French explorer, diver and head of the group, would go below and would tidy up the place a little.

The passing years may have wrought some vast changes in baseball. But so far as an imposing array of old timers, who attended the festivities at the Stadium yesterday, could see, they're still the same old Yankees.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 25 More water for industrial and household use is one of this state's major problems. The solution most frequently advocated here is the Central Arizona Project.

CONTROVERSIES affecting every branch of the hobby are expected to animate the American I Numismatic Association conven tion in Denver from next Saturday through Aug. 11. The official agenda runs from Aug. 5 through the 7th.

The installation of highvoltage feeder cables to interconnect three Consolidated Edison substations in mid-Manhattan will begin tomorrow.
LUNENBURG, N.S., July 27 (Canadian Press) A new version of the famed Nova Scotia schooner Bluenose was launched here this week.

THE furor about the twist has died down and ex hausted oldsters have come to realize that it was never right for them, but the twist itself is very much alive and filling a useful and necessary function in our culture.
LOS ANGELES, July. 27 California is taking physicians out of the pharmacy business.

"Slice-of-life" commercials are much in vogue on Madison Avenue these days. The trend has reached such proportions, in fact, that some advertising men have begun to wonder, as one agency man puts it, "just how many slices the American public will take."

One more scene in the 4-yearold drama over railroad work rules unfolded last week when the carriers agreed to postpone putting changes into effect until Aug. 29, That put off once more the denouement of this cliffhanger.
SCRANTON, Pa., July 27 Mrs. Clare C. Hodge's whippet, Ch. Selbrook Highlight, won the best in show award today at the Lackawanna Kennel Club show.

A school for "build-it-yourselfers" has been started by a home builder at Shirley, L. I.

Rudolf Friml returned yesterday from a European concert tour sponsored by the State Department with only one small worry. He couldn't help wondering how his delicate waltz "Jacqueline" sounded at the hands of the Marine Corps Band.
WASHINGTON, July 27 The time and the climate may be congenial again, but the road to real respite still runs through Germany.
More than 300 persons attended the first Black Muslim rally in Brooklyn yesterday and heard a leader in the movement preach unity among Negro civil rights groups.

CHICAGO, July 27 A resolution calling for all Roman Catholics to support, as a moral imperative, the President's civil rights program received preliminary approval today at an emergency meeting of the National Catholic Conference for Racial Justice.
WASHINGTON, July 27 An investigation into the volume, scope, cost and conduct of the research programs operated by the Government or with its funds is being projected in the House of Representatives.

DUSSELDORF. THERE is something saddening about listening to some of Dmitri Shostakovich's early works, not because they are bad but because they are so good. BONN, July 27 The aura of new beginnings in international relations emanating from Moscow is evoking in West Germany a re-examination of a national problem so long unsolved that many Germans have ceased to think about it.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 27 Officials of two Methodist congregations, separated for 99 years, have completed negotiations for a merger of the First Methodist and St. Paul's churches in Peekskill this fall.

Ernie Terrell, a 6-foot-7-inch heavyweight with visions of Sonny Liston dancing in his head, neatly supplemented his dreams with a relentless left hand last night as he jabbed his way to a unanimous 10round decision over Zora Folley at Madison Square Garden.

DARIEN, Conn., July 27 Miss Joan Ellen Caspersen of Larchmont, N.Y., and Robert Donald Stillman of New York plan to be married Sept. 21 at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

A PETITE and puckish Englishwoman, Pamela Hans ford Johnson, like her husband C. P. Snow, has earned a considerable writer's reputation on both sides of the Atlantic. CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) Two major Midwest pharmaceutical concerns, Abbott Laboratories and G.D. Searle Co., plan to merge, their executive officers said today.

Mere graduation from high school is no longer the "Open, Sesame!" to State U., one time haven for every student who could fill out an application. HOLLYWOOD ON the basis of a few meetings and press con ferences, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has achieved its first objectives in trying to end discrimination against Negroes in movies and television. It has made Hollywood realise it is serious in its fight and that it is prepared to exert enormous economic power to win equal rights for Negroes. It has also obtained some tactical concessions.

Black and white is strong fashion. This year, its effect is doubled by the way it is used boldly in half-and-half contrast or brashly in giant plaids. Tailoring is also important. The shirt is precise and military; the jacket emerges with shirtlike cut. Coats do the unusual: A back-fastened one looks like a dress; and a blanket coat closes with frogs.

HARTFORD, July 27 Marian Anderson, Joseph Vernen Reed, executive producer of the American Shakespeare Festival Theater, and Mrs. Mary Hunter Wolf, former associate producer of the Theater Guild, are among those who have been appointed to a 15-member commission that will make a comprehensive survey of arts facilities in Connecticut.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 27 The First Presbyterian Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Margaret Russell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Macdonough Russell Jr. of North Branford, formerly of Middletown, to the Rev. Dr. George Stuart Heyer Jr. He is the son of Mrs. Greer Marechal of Houston, and the late Mr. Heyer.

The bituminous coal industry appears to be well into the competitive fight with other fuels. Although badly battered, and with several markets definitely lost, the soft coal industry continues to hold a prominent position in the nation's energy picture, but only through its meeting of great challenges.

WHEN a camera club sets out to document the community in which its members live, work and play, the least one should expect of the results is a reasonably conscientious effort to interpret, as well as to describe.
Victims of accidents and sudden illnesses at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair will be treated in a hospital designed to be erected in a few days for catastrophes and to reduce costs to patients.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 27 Bergen County is moving on two fronts to improve its county ana municipal parks, Freeholder Alfred S. Walden, chairman of the beard's Parks Committee, Said today.

RESPECT for the musical genius of Joseph Haydn grows stronger with every new work that ap pears on records. The evidence is rapidly mounting that, rather than the paler Mozart he was once supposed to be, Haydn was an original and daring dramatic musician, whose music commands a niche among the supreme creators in the art.

In Moscow last week East and West reached agreement on a treaty providing for a limited ban on nuclear testing. It was the first treaty to emerge from 18 years of negotiation on the arms race, the first East-West treaty involving any major cold war issue since Austrian sovereignty was restored eight years ago.

WASHINGTON,July 27 (AP) Born in controversy and reared amid sensation, the House Commitee on Un-American Activities may be due for a respite from the storms that have marked much of its 25year history.

IN the ideological dispute raging between Communist China and the Soviet Union, one of Peking's com plaints has been that the Russians are getting too "bourgeois"; that they are now more interested in their own affluence than in supporting revolutionary struggles. Moscow hotly denies this, but there is no doubt that the Russian people relish the improvement in living standards and the increase in consumer goods that has occurred, and are eager for more.

Western analysts trying to probe the factors behind Premier Khrushchev's "peace offensive" toward the West in recent weeks are paying increasing attention to the economic pressures upon the Soviet leader. Two leaders in the space industry have opened a determined campaign to end what they call "verbal hide-and-seek." Their objective in addition to ending "gobbledegook," is the more serious effort to cut costs.

JAMES KENNAWAY, the knowing author of "Tunes of Glory" and other novels, turns to the subject of brainwashing in THE MIND BENDERS (Atheneum, $3.50), a subtly modulated laboratory nightmare that builds to an eerie crescendo of terror. The book's springboard is the suicide of an Oxford physiologist who hops out of a speeding train after having been given a suitcase full of five-pound notes by agents of a Foreign Power.

A PUNDIT once said, "A Green Thumb is noth ing but a Dirty Thumb," which could be the slogan for all gardeners. REGARDLESS of its shortcomings as a novel-its predictable plot, its tendency to pontificate-Earl Conrad's "The Premier" is monumentally timely. For it is the story of a Negro nationalist whose dream is a "Central Plains Republic," a black state carved out of the American West. One of his maps shows it covering Wyoming and portions of seven other states. Its shape is that of the continent of Africa.
GRASSE, France, July 27 (AP) John Neville Judkyn, 50 years old, of New York, was killed in an automobile accident near Grasse today.

ROQUEBRUNE, France, July 27 (Reuters) The Duke of Leeds died yesterday in this town on the Riviera at the age of 62. He had lived here and in the Channel Islands.

DAMASCUS, Syria, July 27 (AP) Maj. Gen. Amin elHafez emerged today as the undisputed strong man of Syria. He was named army Commander in Chief and chairman of the ruling Revolutionary Council.

TO call this just another book on the South Seas would probably be unfair and is certainly inaccurate, for it is almost as much about the author as about the places he visited. Deliberately it begins on the personal note of emotional dislocations making a Wonderjahr seem indicated, and continues as a rueful struggle between the copy-seeking professional writer and his wariness of South Seas stencils. Alternately he shies from and embraces them.

NEW YORK moviegoers who have never had their fill of Charlie Chaplin now have some thing very special to look forward to. The great comic artist, who normally allows revivals of his celebrated films only at rare intervals, has given favorable attention to a plan of Ilya Lopert to re-release no fewer than seven of the master's works.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 27 Su Mac Lad, regarded by many as the world's greatest trotter, was beaten in the Challenge Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) Curt Simmons and two relief hurlers checked the Chicago Cubs on three hits today in pitching the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-2 victory.

THE Santa Barbara Kennel Club will stage today the nation's largest one-day outdoor show on the spacious grounds of the Santa Barbara Polo Club, a few miles south of the California city on the Pacific. A new location has been chosen for this 35th anniversary show.

A PERMANENTLY installed lawn sprinkling System, connected by underground piping to the household water supply (or to a separate well) will enable any homeowner to irrigate his lawn by simply turning a valve. Such a system will not only eliminate the need for dragging wet garden hoses around when the lawn needs watering, it will also assure the homeowner of more uniform coverage with a minimum of waste.
CHICAGO, July 27 Sam Snead and Arnold Palmer passed the slumping Fred Hawkins today and tied for first place in the $50,000 Western open golf tournament.

LOS ANGELES The Summer National Tournament of the American Contract Bridge League is now un der way at the Biltmore Hotel here and will continue through Aug. 6. However, one of the two principal events of the 11 days of play is weakened by the absence of the team that has been seeded first or second for the last 14 years.

MADRID. THE Roman empire has consummated its fall here, and Samuel Bronston seems confident that his star will continue to rise. Associates of the American producer, whose multimillion-dollar blow-up of 15 pages in Gibbon has just been completed, laughs off any suggestion that he might have overextended his film-financing deals.

GREAT BRITAIN, for many years operator of postal systems in the Trucial States and other states of the Arabian Peninsula, such as Qatar on the Persian Gulf, has given up direction of several services and added one.

ATLANTA, July 27 Economic self-interest frequently leads to racial change in situations where other factors seemingly have little influence. This has been underscored again by events in Cambridge, Md.
Mink-trimmed otter and cashmere coats are a current highvolume item, resident buying offices here report. Some buying action on fall items has begun.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 27 (Reuters) President Sukarno will go to Manila Monday for talks with Malaya and the Philippines, he said here tonight, but he will continue to oppose the Federation of Malaysia.

KAMPALA, Uganda, July 4 There is every evidence that the low cost, allinclusive hunting and photographic safari that originated in Uganda a year ago is a working success. Repeat bookings are pouring in. Tanganyika is in the process of setting up its own version of the bargain bush trip.

THERE'S a writer who at the end of the month will find himself published three ways, by three different publishers, in six days. The name is Leslie Waller. Anchor book of the three is a long novel called "The Banker" about one which Doubleday will offer Aug. 2. This is a book club selection and has been sold to the movies. Two days before

BOSTON, July 27 (UPI) Jim Piersall celebrated his return to the American League today by helping the Los Angeles Angels top the Boston Red Sox, 5 2. Piersall, given his release by the New York Mets, had signed an Angel contract after waivers placed on the outfielder had expired. He hit two singles and made two fine plays in center field.
VANDALIA. Ohio, July 27 (AP) The 64th Grand American Trapshoot is scheduled here Aug. 16 to 24.

ABOARD THE YACHT EN RAPPORT, COWES, England, July 26 A small boat crossing the North Atlantic should expect the unexpected; that much is axiomatic. When neither boat nor crew is fully prepared, even for the unexpected, the consequences can range from terrifying to ludicrous.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The economic philosophy of the Kennedy Administration is, and always has been, a practical one. This Administration has never shown any dedication to a particular set of beliefs. The objective of its economic strategy is to solve problems.

The downtown store is again coming to the forefront in the retail world. This was evident in the recent announcements of plans for new stores in New York, which indicated that retail operators are not deserting the heart of the city in favor of suburban locations.

A 162-year-old holding that covers a large part of 10 blocks east of Greenwich Village has been almost completely revamped in the last 15 years with residential, commercial and institutional facilities.
A small Greek town, settled and abandoned in the classical period by refugees from Tiryns, may have played a part in the Peloponnesian War.

CLEVELAND, July 27 (AP) Tito Francona's one-out double to right center in the ninth inning today gave the Cleveland Indians a 3-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics. Al Luplow had opened the inning with a double.

JOHN FOWLES is a very brave man. He has written a novel which depends for its effect on total acceptance by the reader. There is no room in it for the least hesitation, the smallest false note, for not only is it written in the firstperson singular, but its protagonist is a very special case indeed.
LYNBROOK, L.I. July 27 A village trustee charged today that members of the Congress of Racial Equality who marched in front of a White Castle hamburger stand here were paid demonstrators.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 27 Estimates that enrollment in Florida's tax-supported universities will more than double by 1970 have prompted the state to step up its program of expansion in education.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The Administration has approved changes in the Alliance for Progress that would increase Latin America's participation and responsibility in guiding the 10-year program of social and economic growth.

WASHINGTON, July 27 An upturn in the national economy, which began in early spring, has taken some of the urgency out of the drive for tax reduction. Prospects of favorable Congressional action this session nevertheless are still good.

ANGOLA, La., July 27 The hours pass slowly for the 20 men in Louisiana's "Death Row," a group of small individual cells in a dreary gray stone building near the entrance gate to Louisiana's sprawling prison farm here.
WHITE PLAINS, July 27 The state government's efforts at economy have left Westchester County officials baffled and worried about the fate of a number of projects in the county.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 26 Trinidad has drawn up a five-year development plan based on a frank appeal for outside assistance.

TOKYO, July 27 (AP) Japan's three big Mitsubishi companies decided today to merge into a giant industrial combine. They said the step is necessary to meet what they called growing international competition.

EDGEWATER, N. J. July 27 Caribbean House, a fiveand a half story Y-shaped building fronting on the Hudson River, is designed for boat owners who want luxury apartment dwelling with the added convenience of having their boats at the door.

CHILMARK, Mass., July 27 Mr. and Mrs. Allan Darrow of Woodstock, Vt., and Chilmark, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Patricia Darrow, to Lieut. (jg.) Harry Clark Royal 3d, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Royal of Hingham, Mass., formerly of Cleveland.

PHILADELPHIA The business of selling summer sunshine, relaxation, fun and souvenirs is booming at a record pace in the seashore and mountain resort areas of Pennsylvania, southern New Jersey and Delaware, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reports.

"Where else can you get ice in the summertime?"' Dennis Parish, 16 years old, of River Edge, N.J., asked the question as he mopped his brow and then wiped his skates. He is one of 60 youngsters, ranging in age from 10 to 18, attending the fifth annual hockey clinic conducted by the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League at Iceland, atop Madison Square Garden.

ZERO MOSTEL, the star of "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," hopes that funny things will happen when he begins working on a television series planned for release in the fall of 1964. A.J. Russell, TV writer, has completed the initial half-hour script and the pilot film is expected to be made this year by Screen Gems, Inc.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (UPI) The San Francisco Giants capitalized on three errors in the eighth inning today and beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3 1, for their sixth straight victory.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 27 South Vietnam's grinding war against the Communist guerrillas still presents a mixed and somewhat cloudy picture a picture often obscured by 11 weeks of bitter internal strife over religion and politics.

I always suspect a director who says he can afford to be away from the office only for a week at a time. This generally means either that he is a frightened man, for one reason or another, or else he is thoroughly inefficient and incapable of delegation. BRITAIN'S SIR RICHARD POWELL, director-general, Institute of Directors.
HUDSON HOPE, B.C. Here, in this lonely Peace River Settlement 750 miles north of the United States border, they have a new theme song.

The New York Yankees, unaccustomed as they are to public displays of ineffectiveness, devoted 17 innings to humility and one to violence yesterday and barely avoided the ignominy of losing a double-header to the Minnestota Twins at Yankee Stadium.
SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, July 28 (AP)--A Belgian and his wife, dug from the ruins of the Macedonia Hotel, said today that they had nearly abandoned hope and had been ready to commit suicide.

The foreign policy of Pakistan has undergone a distinct change recently as a result of closer United States relations with India and, in particular, American (and Commonwealth) military aid to India. Pakistan has chosen to believe she is now menaced more gravely than ever by India, has shown increasing resentment toward the United States and has moved to develop friendlier relations with India's--and the United States'--chief enemy, Communist China.

WASHINGTON, July 28--It is not necessary to be a Washington "insider" to know all about the men, in every major Government department, who hold the jobs of Assistant to the Secretary for Congressional Relations. They are almost always former members of Congress, defeated-in their-bids for re-election, who didn't want to return to their home districts.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP) --The Philadelphia Phillies took command on Clay Dalrymple's three-run homer in the sixth inning today and handed the first-place Los Angeles Dodgers their fourth straight loss, 7--4.

A group of Americans will leave for the Soviet Union this week to collect information about a major industry behind the Iron Curtain. What's more, the Russians, fully aware of their mission, give every indication of welcoming the visitors with open arms.

LOS ANGELES, July 28-- Paul Keres and Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union ended up in a tie for first place today in the Piatigorsky Cup chess tournament here. Keres pulled up into the tie by defeating Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia in the 14th and final round.
The Treasury Department seems to have lost its resourceful and imaginative touch in dealing with the money markets.

WASHINGTON, July 28-- Every time they try to make things more modern around here it just increases the confusion. Take the Post Office's zip numbers, for example. The zip numbers were issued recently to take the place of the old zone numbers.
A 17-acre wilderness tract in the Riverdale section of the Bronx is daily unfolding its abundant secrets to a dozen neighborhood children engaged in a special summer science project.
"Our world piteously cries aloud for the fruits of Christian faith," the Rev. Cecil Rhodes said in a guest sermon here yesterday.
The Committee to Save the Cooper Union Museum has warned that it will start legal action to save the museum from dissolution.

LAKE GROVE, L. I., July 28 --Cynthia McClintock's Renita, a bay mare, gained the junior hunter championship of the Fox Hill Stables' horse show today, with blues in two events and three second-place ribbons.

WASHINGTON, July 28-- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 26-- The White House and the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare are involved in a serious disagreement over the location of a proposed $33,000,000 Government health center.

HOLLYWOOD, July 28-- Surrounded by a pile of scripts and a clutter of set designs, Dick Berg, television, writerproducer, is testing a formula for creating oases in video's wasteland.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 28--The Government deferred today a decision on Israel's adherence to the treaty for a partial nuclear test ban. Leaders of the signatory nations have expressed the hope that other nations would endorse the treaty.
PITTSBURGH, July 28-Steel officials reported the first signs of a firmness in the market last week.

A "mitzvah corps" of nine Jewish high school students arrived at Idlewild Airport yesterday after a month-long working visit to Puerto Rico. In Hebrew, mitzvah means a commandment to do a good deed helpful to mankind.
Employing its speed and hustle to great advantage, Gornik of Poland won the Section 2 title in the International Soccer League yesterday by beating Dinamo of Yugoslavia, 4-0, at Downing Stadium.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. July 28--The Security Council will resume its debate tomorrow on the complaint of the 32nation African bloc against Portugal's continued rule in Angola, Mozambique and Portuguese Guinea.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 28-- On almost every level, the three-day Newport Folk Festival of 1963, which closed tonight with more than 13,000 listeners filling Freebody Park, was an enormous success.

SAIGON, Vietnam, July 28-- About 7,000 Buddhists crowded into Saigon's main pagoda today to hear Buddhist leaders pledge to continue their protest movement against the Government of President Ngo Dinh Diem.

DETROIT, July 28 (AP)--Al Kaline cracked a game-winning homer in the opener and started the victory ideally with a single in the second game today as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Washington Senators, 3--2 and 7--4.
The Eastman Kodak Company achieved the highest second-quarter sales and earnings in its history in the three months ended June 16, according to the results announced for publication today.
A 14-story middle-income cooperative for 108 families is planned on the site of an abandoned public school in Yorkville.

THAT was quite a party the Yankees tossed Saturday night at Toots Shor's as a windup to their annual Old-Timers' Day festivities. The pity is that the 40,040 fans who turned out for the afternoon show at the Yankee Stadium could not also have sat in on this one. It would have been something to see their old-time favorites let their hair down; that is, those who still have any left to let down.
BOSTON, July 28 (AP)--Don Lee and Paul Foytack turned in fine pitching performances Sunday as the Los Angeles Angels swept a double-header from Boston, 5--0 and 5--4.
Second-hand ship sales, which had been stimulated during the year's second quarter by a rise in dry cargo freight rates, have subsided again.

TORONTO, July 28 (AP)-- Dr. Walter A. Riddell, a Canadian diplomat who tried unsuccessfully to get the League of Nations to apply sanctions against Italy for its invasion of Ethiopia, died yesterday at his summer cottage in Algonquin Park. He was 81 years old.

Pier hirings in the Port of New York during the first six months of this year were about 24,500 fewer than those reported during the same period of 1962, the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor reported yesterday.

Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc., has purchased half sponsorship of an hour-long children's-program series on the National Broadcasting Company television network. The program is "Exploring," which returns for its second season Saturday, Oct. 12, at 1 P.M.
BALTIMORE, July 28 (AP) --Backed by a 10-hit attack, including the 2,500th career hit of Nellie Fox, Gary Peters pitched the Chicago White Sox to a 4-1 victory today over the Baltimore Orioles.

HOUSTON, July 28--The Mets made some changes today, but not in their ways as they lost their 11th-game in a row and extended their record losing streak on the road to 22 straight tonight. They dropped an 8--2 decision to the Colts.

The National Retail Merchants Association has begun its annual campaign to persuade soft goods manufacturers from giving Christmas gifts to retail store buyers. First begun in 1961, the campaign has made "an impression," said William Burston, secretary of the association's vendor relations committee in an interview. "How much, nobody really knows."

"Alexander's to Open First Store in Manhattan, on East 59th St." "J. W. Mays Company Planning to Open First Manhattan Store." "Macy's New York Plans Another Unit for Queens." These were headlines in the past week that told of New York City's vitality and growth, contradicting the prophets of doom.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 -- The president of the National Urban League warned today that violence would continue in the United States until Negroes achieved their goals.

A youth skirted a roadblock in a stolen car near Idlewild Airport early yesterday and eluded the police in a 100-milean-hour shooting chase. Three hours later, the police said, he was captured in Brooklyn while trying to repair two bullet holes in the car's trunk.

SANDS POINT, L.I., July 28 --Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. McLaughlin Jr. of Harbor Acres have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynne McLaughlin, to John J. Moughty Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moughty of Old Greenwich, Conn.

While the uncertainty over President Kennedy's plan to tax American purchases of foreign securities continues, dollar-financed factory-leasing plans promise to become popular in international circles.
NEWTON, N.J., July 28 -- Adeline H. Isakson's Old English sheepdog, Ch. Tara-Wood's Blue Baron today won the bestin-show award at the Newton Kennel Club dog show.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway had a net income of $29,079,397, or $1.07 a common share, from gross revenues of $304,252,203 in the first half of this year, Ernest S. Marsh, president, reported over the weekend.

Five annual awards were announced last night by the American Shakespeare Festival and Academy in Stratford, Conn. The recipients were Helen Hayes, Oliver Rea, M. J. Rathbone, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and Dr. George F. Reynolds.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 29--Two United States soldiers were killed today in an ambush by Communist North Koreans south of the demilitarized area, the United Nations Command reported.

About 110 Britons were stranded at Idlewild Airport yesterday. A chartered flight on which they had expected to return to Manchester, England, was not scheduled to leave until tonight--24 hours after the take-off time they had been given.

PARIS, July 28--Richard M. Nixon predicted today that Republicans and Democrats in the Senate would vote overwhelmingly to ratify the treaty for a partial nuclear test ban initiated in Moscow last week.
COEUR D'ALENE, Idaho, July 28 (AP)-- Bill Muncey calmly drove the Miss Thriftway to her third straight Diamond Cup triumph today in a race delayed by the destruction of Miss Exide.

The Grand Union Company has leased 20,000 square feet in they Greeley Arcade Building at 132 West 31st Street for executive and buying offices for the Grand-Way discount stores. Trading in the Canadian dollar dominated the foreign exchange market during the past week. Traders attributed the recovery of the dollar to United States concessions to Canada on the proposed new tax. The dollar closed 77/16 cents discount, up 29/64 of a cent over the previous Week.

BRUSSELS, July 28--Among Western political advantages is one which, although infrequently exploited, can at times be significant. This is the human talent available in the form of big men from small countries.

WASHINGTON, July 28-- The Kennedy Administration was expected to have some good news for a debt-conscious Congress this week: postponement for a few months of a request to raise the ceiling on the national debt.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP)-- Speculators pushed both sides of the grain market last week but mostly on the selling side and prices were driven generally off on the Board of Trade.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 28--President Kennedy and most of the members of his numerous family celebrated Mrs. Kennedy's 34th birthday today with cruising, swimming and a day in the sun.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation in the first half of this year had consolidated net earnings of $31,868,964, Edward L. Steiniger, president and chief executive officer, reported over the weekend. SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 (AP)--Willie Mays blasted a two-run homer today that sparked the San Francisco Giants to a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. The triumph was the Giants' seventh straight and Jack Sanford's first since June 18.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 28--George F. Kennan left Yugoslavia today after serving two years as United States Ambassador. One of his last acts was to lead a group of 40 embassy employes in donating blood for the victims of the Skoplje earthquake.

WASHINGTON, July 29-- Yields on newly issued Treasury bills rose to a recent record for the fourth consecutive week. The Treasury announced that the average discount on its new 91-day bills was 3.263 per cent, compared with 3.206 per cent last week. This was the highest rate since May, 1960.

RABAT, Morocco, July 29-- The Moroccan Government has annexed most of the Spanish enclave of Ifni, on the northwest African coast, the semi-official Moroccan news agency reported today.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 29 --The Board of Education decided tonight to establish a citywide integrated sixth-grade school and to permit pupils in the first through fifth grades at Lincoln School to transfer to three predominantly white schools. The plan will go into effect in September.

Steel production continued its decline last week. In the week ended Saturday, the country's mills turned out 1,856,000 tons, down 4.3 per cent from the 1,939,000 tons poured the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The figure was the lowest since the week ended Dec. 29.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 29 --In an effort to reduce, Suffolk's mounting highway fatalities, County Executive H. Lee Dennison has proposed formation of a corps of residents who will pledge themselves to report traffic violators to the police.
