LEEDS, England, July 29 (Reuters)--The touring West Indies cricket team, paced by the fine all-round effort of Gary Sobers, posted a 221-run victory over England today.

The Government bond market backed away yesterday in listless trading. High-grade corporates were a touch easier and municipals dull in quiet sessions.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) --Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said today that compulsory arbitration in the maritime industry "might produce worse effects than the ills sought to be cured."
LONDON. UNITED STATES visitors to the British Isles wanting to sample the angling will find things far more crowded than at home.

LOS ANGELES, July 30-- The national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League continued here today with a semifinal round of the masters' pair contest this afternoon and the final round of the mixed-team contest tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30--The Security Council broke off its debate on the Portuguese territories in Africa today after the United States rejected suggested amendments to an AfricanAsian resolution.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., July 30-- State Senator Fred B. Rooney, a Democrat, was elected today to the United States House of Representatives from Pennsylvania's 15th District. He defeated Robert G. Bartlett, Republican, a personnel official at the Bethlehem Steel Company, in a special election.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- Representative Emanuel Celler, manager of the Administration's civil rights bill in the House, agreed today to incorporate a Fair Employment Practices Commission provision in the omnibus measure.
Stock prices climbed sharply yesterday, with strength show ing up in the speculative as well as the investment issues. Volume moved up along with the rise in prices.
COATS have long been the stepchildren of maternity clothes. Expectant mothers could select a wardrobe from bathing suits to ball gowns, but coats were not included in the maternity shop collections.
The eighth inning at Yankee Stadium last night began with the score 2--2. The inning, and the game, ended with the score New York Yankees 6, Kansas City Athletics 2.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 30-- The way the odds-on favorites have been breaking stride in races at Roosevelt Raceway recently, it was a pleasure for most of the 27,610 fans at the track tonight to see Ricci Reenie stay on stride and win the featured pace at odds of 7 to 20.
PARIS, July 30--Le Corbusier, an architect with less honor here in his adopted land than abroad, has been commismissioned to build a national museum of modern art in Paris.
IBADAN, Nigeria, July 30-- Gene Fullmer was nearly mobbed today by thousands of cheering Nigerians as he drove in an open car through this city of more than a million.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)--The minimum wage for 24,000,000 persons in the United States will be stepped up 10 cents to $1.25 an hour Sept. 3.

SCOTT HARVEY and Warren Tiahrt of Detroit won the Singing Sands national rally run over the weekend from a Gary, Ind., headquarters. Dennis and Sally Koelmel of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., were second and Suzanne Hundertmark and Robert...

PHILADELPHIA July 30 (AP)--Stockholder Lewis D. Gilbert of New York, a onetime Army corporal, questioned General of the Army Douglas MacArthur today before some 1,000 other stockholders and guests at the annual meeting of the Sperry Rand Corporation.
Despite "glaring contradictions" in testimony at the trial of Gareth Martinis last July 1, his acquittal was consistent with the evidence, a Bronx bar association declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30-- Dr. Harry Shay, director of the Fels Research Institute and Clinical Professor of Medicine at Temple University School of Medicine, died today. He was 65 years old and lived at Park Towne Place here.
MOSCOW, July 30--The Soviet Union has granted political asylum to H.A.R. Philby, the "third man" in the BurgessMaclean spy case.
Thirty dancers of the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow will give four performances in Madison Square Garden on Oct. 10, 11 and 12 during a 10-week tour of the United States and Canada.
A syndicate of more than 460 municipal bond houses successfully negotiated the purchase and resale of $197,000,000 of bonds issued by the Public Utility District No. 2 of Grant County, Wash.

WOOD SHOLE, Mass., July 30--High winds and heavy rain belted the New York Yacht Club cruise contestants today on the squadron run from Edgartown. A number of contestants decided that racing should be fun and not an ordeal, and the number of starters dropped to 56.
LONDON, July 30--Sir Archie Marshall, the judge in the trial of Dr. Stephen Ward, said today that the defendant had been "abandoned" by prominent friends who might have come forward as witnesses.

Fundamental research in animal pathology having real as well as potential application to the pathology of man is acquiring impressive dimensions in the research laboratories of American colleges of veterinary medicine.

Jacob Baal-Teshuva, Israeli author, is preparing a book: "Professor Toynbee, the Jewish People and Israel." Thoms Yoseloff will publish it in January. The book will deal with the writings of the British historian, Arnold J. Toynbee, a critic of...
SANTA FE, N.M., July 30 (AP)--Maj.Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, former Ambassador to China, died here tonight. He was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- The Justice Department indicated today that it might attempt court action to block the proposed merger of the CrockerAnglo National Bank of San Francisco and the Citizens National Bank of Los Angeles.
A special television program, "The Press and the Race Issue," will be presented on Aug. 21 from 7:30 to 8:30 P.M. on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 (AP)--The United States Court of Appeals ruled today, in effect, that the proposed merger plans of the FMC Corporation and the American Viscose Corporation may proceed.

DANVILLE, Va., July 30 (AP)--A Negro civil rights leader said today "unless the white power structure of Virginia and Danville begins to respond with justice to the fair demands made by its citizens, there will be blood flowing in the streets."
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has set a record in first-half earnings and sales. Second-quarter results were well ahead of last year.
NEW HAVEN, July 30--Ordinances adopted by New Haven and Hamden to compel the New Haven Water Company to fluoridate the public water supply were ruled invalid today in Superior Court here.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- The International Monetary Fund announced today a renewal of the standby arrangement with Britain. It permits drawings up to $1,000,000,000 over the next 12 months in currencies held by the fund.
WASHINGTON, July 30--A bill to permit private ownership of fissionable material, including uranium and plutonium, was endorsed today by the Atomic Energy Commission.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a complaint in Federal Court yesterday charging officers and directors of Continental Growth Fund, Inc., an investment company, with "gross misconduct" and "gross abuse of trust."

THE gentleman's tailor has long had a devoted female following. Symbols of the sacrosanct in masculine attire, such as Brooks Brothers, J. Press, Inc., or Chipp, Inc., have been slipping their feminine fashions in on the side for many years.
Air traffic around New York City is "bumper to bumper," Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, reported yesterday.
The following listing includes events that have been selected by New York Times critics. For children of all ages unless otherwise noted.

Politics swings like a pendulum in any country with a two-party system. What is so fascinating--and bewildering--about British politics to an American is how quickly the pendulum swings and in what a short arc.

WASHINGTON, July 30--The United States is nearly ready to initiate retaliatory action against the European Economic Community for the tariff increases that have blocked almost all exports of American poultry to West Germany.

ALBANY, July 30--Lack of a clear definition of Federal and state authority in enforcing radiation safety could be detrimental to atomic industrial development in New York State, a committee of the State Bar Association said today:

DEARBORN, Mich., July 30 --Michigan dignitaries and more than 1,000 ordinary citizens gathered between a modern highway interchange and a broad bean field today to dedicate a historical marker on the site where Henry Ford was born 100 years ago.

The United States Steel Corporation disclosed yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter were nearly double the net income for the like 1962 period. Earnings for the June quarter rose to $73,214,182, or $1.23 a share, against $40,181,081, or 63 cents a share in last year's period.
SHRUB OAK, N.Y., July 30 --Today was a lucky one for some of Westchester's stately old shade trees in the path of highway construction.
BONN, July 30--West Germany has received assurances from its allies that East Germany will be excluded from the treaty to outlaw most nuclear tests.
Second-quarter profits of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company rose 18.5 per cent over the same period last year, the company reported yesterday. Sales in the same period rose by 34 per cent.

CHICAGO, July 30--A two-hour recital of integration problems in the Chicago school system was presented to School Superintendent Benjamin C. Willis and four members of the city Board of Education today by representatives of the Congress of Racial Equality and other civil rights groups.
The city's streak of six straight 90-degree days was broken yesterday, giving New Yorkers an idea of how the Mets feel when they win one.
A Federal grand jury indicted the newly elected international organizer of the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday on charges of embezzling $2,125 from his home local.
SOMERS POINT, N.J., July 30--The American Civil Liberties Union is considering testing the constitutionality of a local law curbing teen-agers in rock 'n' roll taverns.
The continuing debate over the purposes of advertising had another contributor yesterday-- the General Motors Corporation's director of advertising and market research.
STRATFORD, Ont., July 30 --The play's the thing and the acid test for a moderndress production of Shakespeare is how it serves the play.

LONDON, July 30--Delegates from more than 50 coffee exporting and consuming countries are meeting here to establish machinery for stabilizing coffee prices under an international agreement negotiated last year.

GENEVA, July 30--The United States pledged in the 17nation disarmament conference today to "carry forward" the momentum given East-West negotiations by last week's agreement on a partial nuclear test ban.

Last week, William Zeckendorf, chairman of Webb Knapp, Inc., gave a talk at the Overseas Press Club. In the course of his remarks, he offered his company's property on Broadway between Cedar and Cortlandt Streets in downtown Manhattan to the New York Stock Exchange for a new home.
LONDON, July 30--The British Government announced today that it would build a 50,000-ton aircraft carrier.

Four films, two of them prize winners, by the French directors Robert Bresson, Jacques Demy, Georges Franju and Jean-Pierre Melville have been acquired for American release by a new distribution company.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, July 31--Communist China proposed today a conference of the heads of government of all countries "to discuss the ques tion of complete prohibition and thorough destruction of nuclear weapons."
Cocoa and domestic sugar futures showed moderate, losses here yesterday and world sugar prices were irregular in active trading.

BRAUNSCHWEIG, Germany July 30 (AP)--Jutta Heine, a sprint star who impressed United States indoor track fans last winter, led the West German women's track and field team in a 71-45 victory over the United States today.
The French sauces and other delicacies were simmering as usual at Le Cafe Chambord at La Cote Basque last night, and then the gas went out.

The 12-story and penthouse apartment building at 12 East 88th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, has been purchased by David W. Frankel, realty investor. The building contains 68 apartments and occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet. It was sold by the Carleton Company, which erected it in 1932.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People threatened yesterday to call a boycott of the city's schools unless the Board of Education offered by Sept. 1 a plan and a timetable for integration that satisfies the association.

LOS ANGELES, July 30-- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, said tonight that the country faced new violence if President Kennedy's civil rights program was not passed by Congress.

The combination of perfect weather and Beethoven last night brought Lewisohn Stadium its third largest crowd of the season. An audience of approximately 10,000 was further rewarded by some excellent performances.

BRUSSELS, July 30--The Common Market Council of Ministers tried for four hours today to reach an agreement on tariff reductions for United States poultry but all attempts to find a compromise formula failed.
LONDON, July 30--The Kennedy Administration's retreat on some of its foreign tax proposals has made a generally unfavorable impression on the London financial fraternity.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) --A House Public Works subcommittee approved today a bill that would permit construction of a new mint at Philadelphia to meet a growing demand for coins.

For a luncheon honoring his retirement as supervisor of the Transit Authority's lost property department, Daniel J. Duffy turned up yesterday with a large Boy Scout flag that somebody had left behind on a subway train.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 30--The women's finalist at Wimbledon and the men's runner-up at Merion were beaten in the second round of the Eastern grass-court championships today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

A Texas insurance man's lifelong ambition to join the Broadway managerial ranks will finally be realized when Langston Hughes's "Tambourines to Glory" opens Oct. 15 in the Little Theater at 240 West 44th Street.
The first two Negroes to become Democratic party district leaders in the Bronx will take office tomorrow, a spokesman for the Bronx County Democratic Committee said yesterday.
HANDSOME and quietspoken, Harold Adrian Russell Philby looks every bit the suave undercover agent of Britain's popular spy thrillers.
WASHINGTON, July 30--The House Ways and Means Committee meets tomorrow to start what is described as the "final round" of voting on President Kennedy's tax program.
The Tokyo stock market rallied strongly yesterday and recovered most of Monday's heavy losses.

The Pacific Power and Light Company raised $40,000,000 yesterday in the competitive sales of bonds and preferred stock. The market gave the bonds a fair reception and the preferred stock a good reception.

The President's proposal for a special tax on American purchases of foreign securities is proof, if proof is needed, of his determination to defend the dollar. But it is not his determination that has been called into question. It is his approach to the specific problem of curbing the outflow of long-term capital.
Two nuclear physicists--one an American and the other a Russian--will share the sixth Atoms for Peace Award, it was announced, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 30-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk will fly to Moscow this weekend to sign the test ban treaty and hold further talks with the foreign ministers of the Soviet Union and Britain.

BABYLON, L.I., July 30--If the first two days of racing can be taken as a criterion, there will be some strong competition for honors in the various classes being sailed in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Cruise Week championships.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- United States and British officials suggested today that the regime of Premier Cheddi B. Jagan in British Guiana lacked authority to carry out its announced plan to grant landing rights to Cuban aircraft.

Elfrieda Bos Mestechkin, violinist and teacher, died on Monday in the home of her daughter, Mrs. Eugenia M. Conticchio, 160 Claremont Avenue. She was 75 year old and lived at 76 East 53d Street, Brooklyn.
LOS ANGELES, July 30--It was a wonderful birthday celebration for Casey Stengel tonight. The Mets won.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30--David K., a 2-to-1 shot, of the Harbor View Farm displayed excellent grass-running ability today in winning the Schenectady Handicap, the $10,000 purse that featured the racing program.
It has been 50 years since the first children were invited to have garden plots at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, pull weeds and not seedlings, and learn which insects were good and which were bad.
A thorough restudy of the design and construction of the Navy's nuclear submarines has started as a result of the loss of the Thresher and a number of pipe failures in other submarines.

BUENOS AIRES, July, 30-- About 150 political and labor union prisoners have been released by the Government since the national election July 7. In addition, President Jose Maria Guido has assured leaders of the General Labor Confederation that 50 labor prisoners will be released soon.
The projected British-French supersonic airliner, the Concorde, has made a second inroad into the United States market.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he favored abolishing entirely the literacy test for voters, but he urged that so long as such tests were required, Spanish-speaking citizens be permitted to take them in Spanish.
WASHINGTON, July 30--The Senate refused today to trim a "pork barrel" bill after a debate that had political overtones.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) --Paul Haney, 35 year old, public information official for the space agency, has been named to succeed Lieut. Col. John A. Powers as spokesman for the nation's astronauts, it was learned today.
PARIS, July, 30--The French Government is pressing for a more positive reaction from both West and East to President de Gaulle's call for a conference of nuclear powers on measures for disarmament.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)--Doing an apparent figure-eight celestial square-dance overhead, the new communications satellite Syncom II continued to drift westward over Africa today with all systems reported to be still working extremely well.

LONDON, July 30--Europeans, who do not bother to shift their forks from left hand to right after cutting food want to know why Americans do so. They say that they have found the habit inefficient. They have suggested various origins for it in letters to the editor, many of them tongue in cheek, appearing in The Times of London.
MOSCOW, July 30--Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman gave Premier Khrushchev an Indian peace pipe today, and the Soviet leader accepted it as a symbol.

HERE's a chance for some bright young man with a flair for mathematics to win immortality of a sort in the strange world of baseball. All he has to do is devise a formula that will provide an accurate statistical gauge of a ballplayer's skills.
The New York Young Republicans Club voted last night against endorsing Richard S. Aldrich, a cousin of Governor Rockefeller, for the Republican nomination for Councilman at large in Manhattan.
MADRID, July 30--Spain and Morocco were reliably understood today to have agreed to refrain from controversy over the enclave of Ifni.
Gustav Mahler's Tenth Symphony, which was left unfinished at his death in 1911 and which has been the center of controversy ever since, is complete and ready for public performance.
WASHINGTON, July 30--The Soviet Union has been considering the idea of providing India with surface-to-air missiles for protection against air attack, informed sources said today.
The city and state were urged yesterday to commit their pension funds to a $2,000,000,000 "crash mortgage-lending program" for housing rehabilitation in Harlem and other areas of the city.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Wednesday, July 31--Charles Haag, who reportedly left New York Friday with a jeweler who was carrying $156,000 in jewels and who was later found slain, returned here voluntarily late last night from Tuscon, Arizona.

WHATEVER, the weather, foods flavored with ginger are always acceptable, as is evidenced by the widespread use of the spice in the tropics and in the hearty Christmas fare of northern climes. Gingered dishes run the gamut from shrimp appetizers through desserts and candies.
WASHINGTON, July 30-- The Senate, without even the formality of a roll call vote, passed legislation today that would greatly enlarge the powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 30 --The Lutheran World Federation, which represents nearly 52,000,000 of the world's 72,000,000 Lutherans, began its fourth assembly here tonight.

A three-year contract offer by Todd Shipyards, Inc., calling for a 28-cents-an-hour package pay increase and fringe benefits has been accepted by the general executive board of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.

An alcoholic is a sick person--a compulsive drinker whose illness erodes his personality and his bodily or mental health. Contrary to the old myth about "Bowery bums," the average alcoholic is between 35 and 55 years old, employed and has a home. And although his illness is reflected in abnormal behavior, it is a treatable illness.
NEW ORLEANS, July 30 (AP)--Bitter infighting in the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit over desegregation cases flared into the open today.

Any Americans interested in the most inclusive survey to date of the graphic arts in this country may see it this fall by traveling to Moscow, to Yerevan in Armenia or to Alma-Ata in Soviet Central Asia.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- Anita L. Ehrman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Ehrman of Armonk, N.Y., and a former reporter for The Washington Post and Times-Herald and the Hearst Headline Service, was found dead in her apartment yesterday. She was 28 years old.

Any Americans interested in the most inclusive survey to date of the graphic arts in this country may see it this fall by traveling to Moscow, to Yerevan in Armenia or to Alma-Ata in Soviet Central Asia.

BONN, July 30--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara is expected to conclude a re search agreement here this week for the joint development of a tank to be used by the United States and West German armies in the ninetenseventies.
CHICAGO, July 30 (UPI)-- Soybean and corn futures declined while most grains traded within narrow ranges today on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, July 30-- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged Congress tonight to order both sides in the railroad work rules dispute back into bargaining under the eye of Congress.

It was inevitable that the success in reaching a limited nuclear test ban accord should have brought up the possibility of a summit meeting. Viscount Hailsham, the British negotiator, said on his return to London that Premier Khrushchev would welcome a heads-of-government meeting in the autumn.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 30 (AP)--A small private plane and a twin-engine Army aircraft collided high in the air today and both plunged into a cornfield. Three persons were killed.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 30--Mike Chiapetta and Jerry Boucher Jr. of Wee Burn Country Club, Darien, Conn., combined their cards for a gross best-ball score of 33, 34 --67, four under par, at Ardsley...

MANILA, July 30--The Southeast Asian conference on Malaysia was formally opened today by President Diosdado Macapagal of the Philippines with an appeal for unity on common problems. Mr. Macapagal said the four-day meeting was a "historic occasion" for Southeast Asia.

PARIS, July 30--The most hopeful interpretation that can be read into the newly developing relationship between the United States and Russia is that Khrushchev, who had already adopted peaceful coexistence as a tactic, now embraces it as political strategy. This is a subject Secretary Rusk will clearly wish to test when he flies to Moscow.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30-- There is a deep dissatisfaction among Republican officeholders in the West about the possibility that either Governor Rockfeller of New York or Senator Barry Goldwater will be the party's next Presidential nominee.

SAIGON, July 30--Tens of thousands of Buddhists staged protests today in Saigon and four other main cities as South Vietnam's religious crisis ended its 12th week. But the Government made no effort to suppress the demonstrations, and there were apparently no major incidents. About 60,000 demonstrators took part.
HONOLULU, July 31 (UPI) -Gen. Emmett (Rosie) O'Donnell, who led the first B-29 bomber raids on Japan, retired from the Air Force today on completion of 35 years of service.
LONDON, July 31 Children in British television commercials must refrain from setting bad examples for child viewers, the ruling body for commercial television said today.
KUMANOVO, Yugoslavia, July 31 (AP) Here in a lush green valley 20 miles northeast of quake-ravaged Skoplje, American soldiers in combat dress go about a mission of mercy.
TWO eminent historians shared the spotlight in a "dialogue" on the Columbia Broadcasting System last night.

The decision to incorporate proposals for a Federal Fair Employment Practices Commission in the Administration's omnibus civil rights bill is sound for reasons other than parliamentary tactics. As President Kennedy made plain when he sent his own message to Congress in June, the eradication of job bias is an essential element in making equality real for the Negro.
WASHINGTON, July 31 The State Department has rejected a Republican suggestion that the United States withdraw diplomatic recognition from the Republic of Yemen.
Stock prices marched up the hill yesterday morning and tumbled down in the afternoon.

HANOVER, Germany, July 31 The touring United States men's track team gained a comfortable lead over West Germany tonight after the first day of the two-day meet.
ORANGE, N.J., July 31 The Board of Education today rejected a proposal by State Education Commissioner Frederick M. Raubinger for desegregation of the Oakwood Avenue School.

CHICAGO, July 31--In the Green Bay Packer--College All-Star game here on Friday night, the responsibility for covering Ron Kramer, the Packers' tight end, will fall in part upon Glynn Griffing, the rookie safety man from Mississippi, who belongs to the New York Giants.

BENJAMIN BRITTEN, very much in the news because of the American premiere of his "War Requiem" at the Berkshire Festival Saturday night, was the focus of attention last night at the Midsummer Musical Festival in Philharmonic Hall, where Thomas Dunn led a concert version of "The Rape of Lucretia."

Before any action is taken on an East-West summit meeting to seek further agreements on armament controls or political compacts, another summit meeting would seem to be far more timely and urgent a meeting of the Western heads of government, in particular one between Presidents Kennedy and de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, July 31 The House Banking and Currency Committee sent to the floor today a modified bill to strengthen the depressed areas redevelopment program for combating unemployment. The House rejected the legislation, 209 to 204, on June 12.
The president of the Board of Education declared last that it would not divert funds from "urgent educational needs" to provide a salary increase for teachers this year.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said yesterday that civil rights demonstrations by Negroes emphasized "the rightful discontent of a minority."

DALLAS, July 31 Efforts to place the Negroes' role in American history in proper perspective are beginning to bear fruit, according to Negro leaders attending the 60th annual convention of the American Teachers Association here.
BUENOS AIRES, July 31 Dr. Arturo Illia, candidate of the moderate and democratic Popular Radical party, was formally elected President of Argentina by a handsome margin late today.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 31 It was a bright day for the third race of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's cruise week series. The skies were clear and the wind was sufficient. It was especially bright for five skippers who maintained perfect records.

Saw the Ambassador from Ceylon; announced Secretary of State Rusk will head an 11-member U.S. delegation going to MOSCOW Friday for signing of limited nuclear test ban treaty; met with National Security Council; accepted resignation of Anthony B. Akers as U.S. Ambassador to New Zealand.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 1,917,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, it was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 189,551,000 barrels, against 191,468,000 a week earlier and 183,537,000 a year ago.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 Two Soviet Lutheran churches were admitted today to membership in the Lutheran World Federation.

QUICK, now, is the tape measure swifter than the eye? Which is higher, 16 feet 8 inches or 16 feet 8 inches? And what ever happened to the two-thousandths of a meter that disappeared in the London fog? Those who relish pure mathematics and stratospheric fiber-glass pole. vaulting will be delighted to know that these baffling mysteries have been solved. And it took no Einstein to uncover the answers.
World sugar and cottonseed oil futures led most New York commodities in a broad decline yesterday. Only cotton, domestic sugar and cocoa prices advanced.
The Amerace Corporation has expanded into the industrial chemical business through the $5,000,000 acquisition of the Penetone Company of Tenafly, N. J.

WASHINGTON, July 31 The Government expects Communist China to refrain from major aggression in Asia despite Peking's ideological dispute with the Soviet Union and despite the leading powers' agreement to a limited ban on nuclear tests.

WASHINGTON, July 31 Rear Adm. Paulus P. Powell, U.S.N., retired, a White House naval aide under two Presidents and a former president of Town Hall in New York, died of cancer this morning at the Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 70 years old.

MARION, Mass., July 31 If yacht Facing were horse racing this would have been a great day for the form players. The odds-on choices on the New York Yacht Club's cruise came through in the four divisions during a sparkling day on Buzzards Bay.

The latest reports on the state of the economy present a mixed picture. Manufacturers' new orders declined in June, but their sales rose in the month. Inventories also rose, while the backlog of unfilled orders fell.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 Things returned to normal tonight. The Dodgers, who are expected to beat the Mets every time they face each other, did so by a 5-3 score. And the Mets, who usually make it close, did so.
WASHINGTON, July 31 The military situation in Korea was authoritatively described today as "no worse and no better" than it has been in the 10 years since the Korean war ended.
Tom Tresh's ninth-inning home run, with two out, nobody on and the count two strikes, gave the New York Yankees a 3-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics at the Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 31 The House of Representatives approved today the compromise plan for payment of $73,000,000 for Philippines war damage claims and sent the long-contested program to the White House.
Mrs. Robert B. Magnus is serving as chairman of the luncheon and bridge party that that will benefit Colony House, a settlement house at 297 Dean Street in Brooklyn.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 31 African countries launched a concerted attack in the Security Council today on South Africa's racial policies.

RYE, N.Y., July 31 The eighth annual benefit luncheonfashion show, sponsored by the Ladies Auxiliary of St. Vincent's Hospital, Westchester, will again be held at the Apawamis Country Club here on Thursday, Oct. 17.

A "chicken war" threatens to poison relations between the United States and the member states of the European Common Market. Tempers are running high in Washington because increased Common Market tariffs on frozen poultry have sharply cut American exports to West Germany, the chief market. Strong pressure on the White House to retaliate by raising United States

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 A proposal for a trade mission to Hong Kong for a meeting with Communist Chinese officials was discussed here today before the World Trade Association of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., July 31 Democratic leaders hailed today the party's victory yesterday in the special election here for a seat in Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 31 A flood of emotional messages to the White House from all over the country has followed the initialing of the treaty for a partial nuclear test ban and President Kennedy's Friday broadcast discussing the United States-British-Soviet agreement.
New York ocean freight forwarders have asked a Federal court to declare unlawful regulations over their business that were proposed in May by the Federal Maritime Commission.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 31 A new concept in zoning that would give homeowners in a subdivision a communal pant or recreation area is being considered by the Planning and Zoning Commission here.
It wasn't the heat, the Weather Bureau reported yesterday. It was just us, the people.
The greatest, prettiest, most colorful fighter in the world, Cassius Clay, who cut his eye teeth not so long ago, will cut his first long-playing record next week for Columbia Records.
PARIS, July 31 Hubert de Givenchy's collection this morning may change the current fashion direction away from loose fitting clothes back to fitted ones.
CHICAGO, July 31 Crowds of whites and Negroes demonstrated separately tonight on the third straight night of racial disorders. A white man was beaten after a crowd of Negroes had stopped his car.
A Federal civil rights committee said in a report yesterday that Negroes were denied employment in most of the building trades here.
WASHINGTON, July 3l The Justice Department filed in Birmingham, Ala., today the largest voting discrimination suit since passage of the 1957 Civil Rights Act.

WASHINGTON, July 31 W. Averell Harriman said today that the Soviet Union would probably insist on an East-West nonaggression agreement before negotiating seriously on other issues. He added that he was unable to determine in Moscow last week what the Russians hoped to achieve through such an agreement.

Spanish probably is the "second language of New York City," as Mayor Wagner says it is. The great immigration from Puerto Rico in the last few years has made it so. The fact remains that English, or the New York City approximation, still is the "first language." We believe it should remain so.

About 300 persons who live in ar Brooklyn area on the Belt Parkway of Coney Island went to City Hall yesterday to demonstrate full or qualified opposition to an urban renewal plan for their part of the borough.

The Standard Oil Company of California in the first half of this year had a net income of $160,308,000, or $2.24 a share, from sales and other operating revenues of $1,285,404,000, R.G. Follis, chairman, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 31 The Senate Interior Committee unanimously approved today a bill to create Canyonlands National Park in Utah.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 31 Shaw at a Shakespeare Festival? The idea would not have turned a hair in the Shavian beard. Shaw predicted, with tongue hardly in cheek, that he would be bracketed with Shakespeare.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 31 The Security Council voted 8 to 0 today to ask all nations to impose an embargo on arms shipments to Portugal for use in maintaining her rule over her African territories. The United States, Britain and France abstained.

ALBANY, July 31 The State Commissioner of Education has agreed to reopen a hearing on de facto segregation in Malverae public schools to hear asserted new evidence and arguments on his right to decide the matter.

Let all lovers of beauty give three cheers, and one cheer more, for Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Martens of Shrub Oak, N.Y. Thanks to their determination, two sugar maples and two Norway spruces with an aggregate age of between 600 and 800 years have been spared the modern highwayman's axe to Live, we hope, for 800 years more.
WASHINGTON, July 31 The House Foreign Affairs Committee rejected today a ban on any foreign aid project involving more than $100,000,000 except with approval of Congress. The vote was 17 to 15.
BONN, July 31 West Germany is not yet ready to accede to the three-power treaty for a limited ban on nuclear testing, a Government spokesman said today.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 31 This quiet suburban village of 7,000 residents is echoing happily to the cacophony of bulldozers and cement mixers on a $14,700,000 state highway job.

Herman Bobbins, chairman of the board of the National Screen Service Corporation, died last night at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 4 Sutton Place.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) Prices that farmers received for crops and livestock rose 1 2/3 per cent during the month ended July 15, from the the level in the preceding month, the Agriculture Department reported today.
The price of gold has been creeping up in the London bullion market and now stands at the highest level in three months, it was reported yesterday from Britain.

Stock prices declined in July, but closed slightly above the low levels of the month.

LONDON, July 31 Dr. Stephen Ward was found guilty tonight of living off the earnings of prostitution. The verdict, the aftermath of a case that almost toppled the British Government, came with Dr. Ward "grievously ill" in a London hospital, the victim of an overdose of barbiturate drugs. Late tonight the hospital said he was still in a deep coma.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) House investigators concluded today that land-buying for Federal roads in Massachusetts "was honeycombed by gross incompetence and downright collusion and fraud" that cost taxpayers millions of dollars.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 1 (UPI) Jim Ferree shot an eightunder-par 64 today and took a one-stroke lead over Don Fairfield in the first round of the $35,000 St. Paul open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 The Atomic Energy Commission postponed today a peaceful underground nuclear explosion designed to try to transmute uranium into new elements heavier than any yet discovered.
July was a summer festival for New York City department stores as their retail sales rose significantly above the pace for July, 1962.

HANOVER, West Germany, Aug. 1 West Germany is preparing a sharp protest to the International Olympic Committee against East Germany's refusal to accept West Berlin for elimination meets between teams from both parts of the country.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 1 Dr. Arturo Illia of the Popular Radical party received 270 electoral votes in yesterday's lengthy balloting for President. He needed 239 for election.
BONN, Aug. 1 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara spend a day today with West German Army units in the field.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 A dozen Roman Catholic priests and ministers mingled tonight with violent street crowds in a vain effort to quiet racial discord in a South Side neighborhood.

CULRAIN, Scotland. DICK PAUL, the stationmaster of Culrain sees the trains pass to the north and south each day. He knows just when to expect them and he is equally expert at spotting a salmon darting up a dark river.
Henriette (Penny) Montgomery, a curly haired wisp of a girl from Queens College, perched on the edge of a couch in a small apartment on the Lower East Side, chatting with her "clients."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) A Texas Congressman's charge that "we now have discrimination in reverse" brought an order today for a House investigation of Federal hiring and promotion practices.

OTTAWA, Aug. 1 The Canadian Government announced today that it would introduce legislation to put five maritime unions operating on the St. Lawrence Seaway and the Great Lakes under temporary trusteeship.
TRENTON, Aug. 1 All state financial assistance to the Orange school system was ordered withheld today until it complies with an order to end racial imbalance in its Oakwood School.
The National Dairy Products Corporation has continued to set records in sales and earnings.
MARION, Mass., Aug. 1 Walter S. Gubelmann's 71 foot Windigo, a yawl from Oyster Bay, L.I., became the winner today of the Queen's Cup, the most coveted prize of the New York Yacht Club cruise.
IT IS surprising what a sudden difference in opinion a string of victories, defeats, can bring about in the course of a major league pennant race that demands that each club play 162 games.
Union Theological Seminary is looking for ways to aid alumni who "face a crisis in regard to civil rights in their communities or churches."

The First National City Bank received approval yesterday to open a branch in Farmingdale, L.I. Consent to the proposal by the Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon, was conditioned upon acquisition of the First National Bank of Farmingdale by the Bankers Trust Company.
Levitt Sons, Inc., one of the country's largest builders of homes, has bought 145 acres at Hamilton Street and Amwell Road, in Franklin Township, N.J.

An unusually strong demand for Federal funds, and purchases by the Reserve System of Treasury issues out to the 10-year maturity area were the highlights of a rising Government securities market yesterday.
Dividend Shares, Inc., reported yesterday that its net assets were $327,054,913, or $3.41 a share, as of June 30. This compared with $265,197,564, or $2.82 a share, one year earlier.

A television-tape recorder for the home that could be as important to the theatrical arts as the long-playing record has been to music is receiving increasing attention from electronic engineers in Britain, Japan, West Germany and the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) The Senate Agriculture Committee approved today a bill to extend the Mexican farm labor program for one year.
The Board of Education has been accused of racial discrimination against white children in a suit brought by four white parents in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
Queens District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor began an investigation yesterday into the possibility of state or city criminal responsilbility in the leakage of sewage into the Bergen Basin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 President Kennedy said today that the United States and Britain had offered further military cooperation to France. This apparently has been done in an effort to persuade President de Gaulle to sign the nuclear test ban treaty.
LONDON, Aug. 1 British medical researchers believe they have found a means of assessing whether a person is a suitable donor for a kidney transplantation.
The London stock market greeted the new month with mixed movements and reduced volume yesterday.

HAVANA, Aug. 1 There is no serious question by now that Cuba is a Communist country, or a "Socialist country," as Cubans prefer to call it. Yet it is far from being a duplicate of the Soviet Union or Communist China.
ROME, Aug. 1 The Vatican radio went out of its way today to remind all Roman Catholics and all free men that no compromise with or indulgence toward Marxism and Communism was permissible.

Nuclear Testing The President said that the United States and Britain had made some suggestions for nuclear cooperation to France on the basis of the pending test treaty. The President gave no details but they were believed part of an attempt to win French adherence to the treaty scheduled for signing in Moscow Monday. He predicted ratification of the treaty by the Senate. He said the United States planned to continue underground testing.
Most stock prices lost ground yesterday after bouncing in various directions during the session.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1--The House voted more than $5,200,000,000 for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration today. The action cut $472,000,000 from the agency's record budget request.

FOR his historical novel, "Who Was Then the Gentleman?" Mr. Israel, an experienced television writer and spinner of tales ("Rizpah," "The Mark"), could scarcely have chosen a more enticingly dramatic subject: the peasant revolt of 1381 in England led by Wat Tyler against the realm of Richard II. If the book does not fully measure...
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UPI) Old crop contracts of wheat and soybeans ended weak while other grain futures were steady to firm today on the Board of Trade.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 The Green Bay Packers, 48 strong, arrived from Wisconsin today to play the College All-Stars tomorrow night in a nationally televised football game.
Electronic stocks, the high fliers of the late fifties that plunged twice as sharply as the rest of the stock market in the 1962 break, continue to swing more widely in price than most issues.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Aug. 1-- A former state champion, Dr. Erich Marchand of Rochester, movead into first place in the New York State chess championship at Cazenovia College last night. He defeated Dr. Bruno Schmidt in the fifth round of the nine-round Swiss system. Marchand has scored 4 - .

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 1 Liberia's Foreign Minister, J. Rudolph Grimes, told the Security Council today that there was "not much time left to avoid disorder and bloodshed" over South Africa's racial separation policy.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Aug. 2 (UPI) Sporadic firing broke out along the Korean armistice line last night, with reports that United States troops may have killed North Korean infiltrators, the United States Eighth Army reported today.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1 (AP) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today eight executive assignments on the policy-making and administrative levels.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 1 Three Federal judges ordered today the desegregation of all public parks, playgrounds, community centers and cultural facilities in New Orleans.
The first artificial kidney for dogs was demonstrated on a closed-circuit TV to 2,200 veterinarians attending the American Veterinary Medical Association convention at the Americana Hotel here.

ON some of the hottest days in recent weeks, a Brazilian woman ordered a mink coat at Bergdorf Goodman, a Japanese woman stocked up on wool and fur lined gloves at The Tailored Woman and a woman from Richmond, Va., bound for a European vacation, bought sum mer dresses in the Sutton Place department at Bloomingdale's.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 The Air Lines Pilots Association announced today that after almost two and a half years of negotiations it had completed and signed a wage contract covering 3,000 pilots with United Air Lines.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 1 A civil rights leader told a Negro mass meeting tonight that negotiations with a committee of 100 white businessmen to desegregate downtown Savannah had taken a favorable turn and might produce an early agreement.

Free reserves of the commercial-banking system dropped by $53,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to a daily average of $106,000,000; but money market experts said that there was no parallel tightening in the tone of the market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) The Senate Appropria tions Committee cut nearly $35,000,000 today from House approved funds for Federal labor activities. But it added nearly $79,000,000 to health and welfare programs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) The Investment Bankers Association of America announced today that it is strongly opposed to proposed new rules governing the purchase and underwriting of investment securities by national banks.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 The National Urban League ended its 53d annual convention today with an expression of support for legal picketing and sitins by other civil rights organizations.

President Kennedy was asked yesterday to instruct Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz to make an immediate study of the "employment consequences" of a Civil Aeronautics Board decision taking the Miami route from Northeast Airlines.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 1 Margaret Smith of Australia and Maria Bueno of Brazil won the only matches completed today before a violent rainstorm forced cancellation of the rest of the program in the Eastern grass court tennis championships.

IBADAN, Nigeria, Aug. 1 (UPI) Gene Fullmer's leg feels fine, his training facilities are excellent and Nigerians are working up a great deal of enthusiasm for his Aug. 10 middleweight title challenge against their favored son, Dick Tiger.

SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 (Reuters) Rescue workers stood in silent tribute here today as a weeping mother, Mrs. Jean Levy of Paris, laid a bouquet of red roses on earthquake ruins where her two teen-age daughters are feared buried.
WASHINGTON, Aug 1 Employment rose last month by substantially more than the seasonal expectation to reach a record of 70,851,000 jobs, the Labor Department said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP) The way was opened today for a title fight Sept. 30 between Sonny Liston, the heavyweight champion, and Cassius Clay in Philadelphia Stadium. Two promoters and the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission came up with an alternate plan to meet legal objections.

DALLAS, Aug. 1 Negro teachers must become actively involved in the civil rights movement if they wish to remain in touch with their students, a New York University professor told the American Teachers Association here today.

"The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window," written by Lorraine Hansberry, author of the 1959 Critics Circle prize play, "A Raisin in the Sun," is due on Broadway in January or February. The presentation will be made by Harold Prince, Burt D'Lugoff and Robert Nemiroff.
Corporate profits are running well ahead of last year's and total earnings appear headed for a record in 1963.
"Black Like Me," John Howard Griffin's book about his experiences when pretending to be a Negro in the South, will be filmed in a Southern location beginning Aug. 26.
Matthew Bender Co., Inc., New York law book publishers, has become a wholly owned subsidiary of the Times-Mirror Company of Los Angeles, through an exchange of common stock.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1 Bold Consort of the Wheatley Stable and Harbor View Farm's Barbwolf won the divided Test Stakes today. The seven-furlong fixture for 3year-old fillies had the same number of contestants in each division, eight, but there the resemblance ceased.
Nine more nations indicated yesterday that they were prepared to join in the agreement for a partial nuclear test ban negotiated by the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 Secretary of State Dean Rusk will stay in the Soviet Union for three or four days after the signing of the three-power nuclear test ban treaty on Monday, the United States Embassy announced today.
World sugar futures rose, domestic sugar prices were irregular and cocoa declined in active trading here yesterday. Other New York markets were quiet and generally lower.
The unity of the Democratic ticket in Manhattan was threatened yesterday by a dis pure between reformers and regulars over the candidacy of Paul O'Dwyer, their Joint designee for councilman at large.

Good afternoon. The end of this summer of 1963 will be an especially critical time for 400,000 young Americans who, according to experience of earlier years, will not return to school when the summer is ended.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 1 Twenty years after his PT exploit, President Kennedy spoke to new midshipmen tonight of the devotion of men...
LONDON, Aug. 1 Prime Minister Macmillan declined to commit himself tonight when asked in a television interview whether he would lead the Conservative party in the next election.
PARIS, Aug. 1 The French Line announced today that a seamen's strike had forced a 24-hour postponement of the next sailing for New York of the luxury liner France.
The Transcontinent Television Corporation announced yesterday it was selling for $38,500,000 all of its broadcasting properties, except its Cleveland AM and FM radio stations, to three buyers.
A Federal court judge reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Securities and Exchange Commission for appointment of a receiver for the Continental Growth Fund, an investment company.

The vest-pocket-fact book trade is expanding, Ottenheimer Publishers, Inc., its leading member, reports that output in the last 12 months has doubled to 3,000,000 volumes and that sales are at more than $1,000,000.

PEKING, Aug. 2 (Reuters) --The Chinese Communist Government summoned all heads of foreign missions here to the Foreign Ministry today and handed them a proposal for a worldwide conference on disarmament.

Jose Stable, a Cuban now living in New York, seeks his fifth straight victory whey he meets Stanley (Kitten) Hayward of Philadelphia tonight in a 10round fight at Madison Square Garden. The bout will be televised nationally.
MIAMI, Aug. 2 (AP)--A big, growing hurricane, the first of the 1963 season, was found by a Navy reconnaissance plane today churning up wild seas over a 230-mile wide area of the Atlantic.

THE brilliant green of they first apples of the new sea son is a welcome sight to the apple pie devotee. The Starr variety predominates in shipments from New Jersey and upstate apple orchards. These apples are juicy, tart and fast cooking and are excellent for pie and applesauce.
The heroes in the featured wrestling exhibition went down to defeat in Madison Square Garden last night.

James M. Landis, former dean of the Harvard Law School and a high Federal official in the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations, pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to a charge that he had failed to file income-tax returns for five years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2-- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz today rejected an appeal by labor and management in the construction industry to postpone application of strict new standards to eliminate discrimination in apprenticeship programs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2-- Secretary of the Navy Fred Korth filed a statement yesterday with the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee explaining the background of a loan made by the bank of which he formerly was president to The General Dynamics Corporation, winner of the controversial TFX airplane contract.

DALLAS, Aug. 2--Achieving high quality in education is an essential step in achieving equality for all, Francis Keppel, United States Commissioner of Education, told a meeting of the American Teachers Association here today.

WHEN summer turns its heat up full blast, there is almost no avoiding a shiny face. Even the most carefully applied make-up tends to melt after an hour or two. A simple way to avoid this unintentional gleam is to try a make-up that, except for lipstick, is completely in powder form.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 2--Adlai E. Stevenson told the Security Council today that the United States would halt all sales of military equipment to South Africa by Jan. 1 pending an end of its segregation policies, but would oppose active sanctions against that country.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2--More than 60 integration demonstrators were arrested here today after they lay in the mud left by heavy rains at a protested school construction project in a Negro area.
HONOLULU, Aug. 2 (UPI) --Honolulu's two major daily newspapers and negotiators for seven striking unions reached agreement today on settling a 43-day walkout.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 2--C. W. Post College looks much like any small-college campus. It is situated among gently rolling hills. Its lawns are green, its trees have a stately look and ivy covers the old buildings.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2-- Lewis Mathde and Edward O. Taylor of Los Angeles today won the lift masters' pair championship, the highest ranked tournament for which contract bridge pairs compete. They scored 838 match points. Possession of the Von Zedtwitz Gold Cup goes with the victory.
The Dreyfus Fund reported yesterday record net assets of $441,739,944, as of June 30. This compared with $283,933,185 a year ago and $361,265,654 at the end of 1962.
Dreams, doodles, designs and dollars are being mixed to produce exhibits for the New York World's Fair.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 20 --The airplane nearing Esenboga Airport north of Ankara passed over verdant hillsides. On closer inspection, the fields could be seen heavy with grain. The spring rains lasted longer this year, and, accordingly, harvests are full of promise.
Bart Lytton, who believes he has reason to boast, predicted yesterday that consolidation of his two California savings and loan associations would raise their earnings 25 per cent.
PARIS, Aug. 2--The split between the United States and France over nuclear and other questions appeared to official and unofficial commentators today to be as wide as ever.
A familiar and controversial Canadian name appeared on the news wires yesterday. Eric W. Kierans, 49 years old, announced his resignation as president of the Montreal and Canadian Stock Exchanges.
ALBANY, Aug. 2--Governor Rockefeller announced today the interim appointment of William T. Cowin of Brooklyn as justice of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District.

BELLPORT, L,I., Aug, 2--A confusing wind at the start failed to mar the next-to-last day of sailing today in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Cruise Week regatta. The finale of the series taken place tomorrow off Westhampton Beach, with several of the class championships to be decided.
SOFIA, Bulgarian July 21-- "In summer we never talk about the weather like people in other European cities," said the Sofia matron, "because here the weather is always nice."
RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 2-- Lewis Stuyvesant Chanler, former president of the New York agency of the Societe Generale, a French bank, died here today in his home on River Road. He was 72 years old.

PEOPLE who are faced with the delightful prospect of visiting country friends during the remaining summer weekends will find an abundant selection of hostess gifts in city shops. The simple teak bookends at Bonniers seem to be a perennialy welcome gift.
Two Brooklyn churches have resolved a split that has kept them apart for 132 years.

WASHINGTON Aug. 2-- Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon announced today that he planned to wait several weeks before putting into effect any new rules covering investments that national banks may make.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--The United States expressed serious concern to the punted Arab Republic today over a bombing attack two nights ago against the border village of Najran in Saudi Arabia.

BONN, Aug. 2--West Germany is pressing its Western allies to make "binding" declarations that would serve to bar Communist East Germany from enhancing its international status by acceding to the treaty on a partial nuclear test ban.

The Transport Workers Union announced yesterday it had the expelled the president of the nation's largest union of airline stewards and stewardesses on charges of mismanaging his local's finances. The unit was said to be more than $300,000 in debt.
DAKAR, Senegal, Aug, 2-- The first foreign ministers' conference of the new Organization of African Unity opened here today on a businesslike note.
TRENTON, Aug. 2--The chairman of a special legislative investigating committee blamed New York City today for the bulk of New Jersey's narcotics problems.

YONKERS, Aug.2--A month's absence from the races obviously had no ill effect last night on Henry T. Adios, Dr. Nicholas T. Derrico's half-millionaire pacer. Henry T. Adios returned to competition at Yonkers Raceway and paced a mile in 2:01 4/5 as he scored a three-quarter-length victory over Cold Front in the $25,000 free-for-all feature.

Secretary of State Rusk is prepared to tell the Soviet Union that an East-West nonaggression pact would be unfeasible. Mr. Rusk, who left for Moscow last night after conferring with President Kennedy, was nonetheless prepared to listen to the Soviet arguments for it. The President was reported interested in the possibilities of a nonaggression pact, but wary of its effect on NATO relationships. [Page 1, Column 8.]
Most New York commodities advanced yesterday in the quietest dealings in many weeks. Cottonseed oil registered the best gains of the day.

CAMDEN, Me., Aug. 2--Kermit P. Snapp, the aging boy wonder of the New Frontier, paused briefly here the other day on one of his dynamic 24-hour vacations and consented to be interviewed while eating a lobster.

NEWARK, Aug. 2--A list of 42 Negroes interested in becoming apprentices or journeymen in the building trades unions has been submitted by the city administration to the Essex County Building and Construction Trades Council.
Loan and investment powers of national bank branches in foreign countries have been liberalized by the Federal Reserve board under authority granted by Congress last year.

Two teen-agers were stabbed to death last night by another youth whom they had stopped to watch as he jitterbugged alone on a Brooklyn street corner. The stabbing suspect was captured by the police in a subway tunnel minutes later.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 2--Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the crumbling Central African Federation signed today a new trade agreement giving Japan the "most favored nation" treatment.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2--Believe it or not, the Mets have a positive record this season. They have won six of the 10 extra inning games they've played in. Forced into 11 innings, the Mets whipped the Braves, 3--1 in the second game of a twilight-night doubleheader at County Stadium tonight.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 2--The Belgian government agreed tonight to provide technical assistance and investment aid totaling more than $1 billion to the Congo.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2--The College All-Star squad accomplished an upset of tremendous proportions tonight by defeating the Green Bay Packers, champions of the National Football League. The score was 20-17 and the outcome marked the first time in five years the All-Stars had defeated the professionals in this annual event.
The smouldering controversy over tax relief for dividend income has burst into flames again after a report that the House Ways and Means Committee would vote severe limits on the relief.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Senator J.W. Fulbright, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, pictured Senator Barry Goldwater today as a sponsor of an international policy of "co-annihilation."

The Swiss franc climbed sharply on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday and inched toward the upper level of the permissible trading limits adhered to by members of the International Monetary Fund.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., Aug. 2-- St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting this evening for the marriage of Miss Mary Chaplin Brooks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Montgomery Brooks, to Jahleel Dudley Woodbridge. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Eliot Woodbridge of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

President Kennedy is considering the appointment of Richard N. Goodwin, a former White House aide, at his special consultant on the arts. Mr. Goodwin would succeed August Heckscher, a director of the Twentieth Century Fund, who resigned on June 16.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 2-- Some Roman Catholics here are extremely worried over the growing political nature of the Buddhist protest movement. They feel most of the problem is not that the ruling Ngo family is Catholic in a predominantly Buddhist country, but rather the authoritarianism practiced by it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI)--The Federal Agricultural Marketing Service and the New Jersey Agriculture Department decided today to wage a public relations campaign to restore the public's faith in eggs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2-- The House Ways and Means Committee formally adopted today a series of proposals designed to limit tax benefits available to corporation executives through stock options.
Forty-two years after Enrico Caruso's death, his voice rang out in Bryant Park yesterday, temporarily displacing the contemporary sound of transistor rock 'n' roll.

New York's business and industrial leaders are showing a gratifying interest in the plans of the Department of Marine and Aviation for a 40-year North River improvement program, Commissioner Leo Brown said yesterday.
BONN, Aug. 2--West Germany has agreed in principle to place orders for military arms worth "about" $1.3 billion In the United States by the end of 1964, defense sources said here today.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 2 (UPI)-- Jack Rule Jr. of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, a second-year man on the Professional Golfers' Association tour, shot an 11-under-par 61 today and took a four-stroke lead in the second round of the $35,000 St. Paul open. His 36hole total is 128.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2--The richest money-winning horse now campaigning, Bohemia Stable's Kelso, will race tomorrow in the Whitney Stakes. The 6-year-old son of Your Host will be the strong choice against eight rivals in the race of 1 1/8 miles.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 2 (AP)--The fourth assembly of the Lutheran World Federation here will try to "take a step forward to find a new expression of our faith," Bishop Hanns Lilje of Hanover said today.
OTTAWA, Aug. 2--Another agreement to send huge quantities of wheat to Communist China was announced here today by Mitchell Sharp, Minister of Trade and Commerce.

A regime that manifests the desperate xenophobia now being displayed by the Chinese Communist Government cannot but be a constant, unpredictable threat to neighboring territories. Red China now displays an implacable hostility not only to the United States but to Russia and all other countries and peoples that do not accept its grim philosophy of hate and violence. This happens to include most of the world.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 2--Oliver La Farge, eloquent champion of the welfare of the American Indian, died this afternoon in Bataan Memorial Hospital. He was 61 years old.

The United Nations Secretary General can, if he will, cut the Gordian knot into which the project for a new state of Malaysia has become snarled. Indications are that he has decided to do so. The way would be through action, on his own and without waiting for reference to the United Nations General Assembly meeting in September, to determine how the people in the Borneo territories concerned feel about joining Malaysia.
The chairman of Mayor Wagner's committee to ease racial tensions arising from discrimination in construction jobs reported "very good progress" at its first meeting yesterday.
The stock market slid into the doldrums yesterday in a typical midsummer session.
The Ralston Purina Company reported yesterday a drop in earnings for the third fiscal quarter as well as the ninemonth period ended June 30, compared with like figures of 1962.
The London stock market put on a late burst of speed yesterday after dragging its feet for most of the week.

MARION, Mass., Aug. 2-- After six successive days of racing, always in southwest winds, the participants in they New York Yacht Club's cruise paused for breath in this handsome harbor today. The anchorage was colored by the brilliance of International Code flags flapping under gray skies in the traditional display of yachts all dressed up on their day of rest.

Airline issues, fueled by rising profits and favorable action in Washington, gave a note of buoyancy to the stock market this week. Climbing to new 1963 highs on the New York Stock Exchange were American Airlines, National Airlines and Eastern Air Lines.

Plans for the erection of 12 portable classroom units at Public School 61, at Crotona Park East, Charlotte Street and Boston Road, the Bronx; were approved yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The 12 units will cost $219,000.
HOUSTON, Aug. 2 (AP)-- The Houston Colts, operating behind the steady pitching of Dick Farrell, lopped a full game off the Los Angeles Dodgers' National League lead tonight with a 4-1 victory.
Directors of Drewrys, Ltd., U.S.A., Inc., a South Bend, Ind., brewer, cut the quarterly dividend yesterday to 10 cents a common share from the 40 cents paid in earlier quarters.

HONG KONG, Aug. 2--An American who refused repatriation after his release as a prisoner of war in Korea 10 years ago said today he was disillusioned by the "lack of individual freedom" in Communist China.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 --The formidable bulk of Jesse M. Unruh, Democratic Speaker of the Assembly, promises to loom large in the Republican campaign picture in California next year.
HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 2-- Producers have finally conceded that the public is entitled to know the names of performers who act well in small roles.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2--A set of pink and brown racing silks of Sir Winston Churchill was installed in the National Museum of Racing this morning as a sequel to the induction of several racing notables into the sport's Hall of Fame.

ON a small island in a faraway sea they changed the flow of victorious talk from gilded rhetoric to bloody reality. Wait till we really get going, the victory orators had said; the future belongs to democracy and freedom. The orators were dead right. But a lot of men, only moderately benefited by interest-paying war...
Vincent G. Potter, vice president of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Thursday in Union Hospital, the Bronx, after a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP)-- Detroit built a 10-2 lead with three home runs and two big scoring, innings, then held on for a 10--9 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
Scheduled offerings of new fixed-interest capital issues are expected to be relatively small next week, reflecting the usual summer lassitude.

THERE are two factories in the north of England where the whir of motors and gears is never heard. In shed after shed within the ancient red brick walls, the same scene takes place. An experienced craftsman bends over white cloth stretched out on polished sycamore tables about 60 yards long. He positions carefully and then drops on the cloth a heavy wooden block oozing with colored dye. Beside him stands a young apprentice.
Gunmen seized a $23,000 pay roll from the Cunard Steam-Ship Company and $14,000 at a housing construction site at 16th Street and Ninth Avenue yesterday.

It taken Bach to do it. The fifth of the six concerts being presented this summer in the Midsummer Music Festival at Philharmonic Hall last night offered the composer's B minor Mass, and for the first time in the series the auditorium had a capacity audience.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Associate Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the Supreme Court refused today to grant a Justice Department request to block the merger of the FMC Corporation and the American Viscose Corporation.
Government securities prices advanced again yesterday in moderately active trading. Prime corporates and municipals closed the week with a quiet session.

TORONTO, Aug. 2 (Canadian Press)--Jack Staples, president of the Canadian Maritime Union, threatened today to start seaway blockades and boycotts unless the Government made an immediate move to remove Hal C. Banks from the Seafarers' International Union of Canada.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 1-- Finance Minister T.B. Ilangaratne, presenting his first budget to Parliament, proposed today to nationalize Ceylon's insurance companies.

Enough progress was reported at the first meeting of Mayor Wagner's Committee on Equal Job Opportunities to justify a continued search for ways to ease the problems of racial exclusion in skilled jobs in this city.
CALDWELL TOWNSHIP, N.J., Aug. 2--Officials and some residents of this Essex County community are preparing for a battle with the state over 2,500 acres of the Big and Little Piece Meadows.

DENVER. Jean McHarg stands 6 feet 1 inch without her cowboy boots, 6 feet 3 inches in them and admits with a grin that her job is "not a ladylike business." She operates McHarg's Employment Service, Inc., believed to be the only full-time cowboy employment agency in the country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2--Engineers of the Boeing Company have patented a method of suspending an astronaut in his, vehicle by cables, so that he has protection and freedom of movement.

OTTAWA, Aug. 2--The Canadian Government announced today that it would embark on a program to increase the capacity of the St. Lawrence Seaway and to create an all-Canadian waterway between the Great Lakes and the sea.

MANILA, Aug. 2--Indonesia, Malaya and the Philippines remained deadlocked tonight on the Malaysia issue after the heads of three governments had agreed to extend their conference on the problem for an extra day, until Sunday.

ROME, Aug. 2--The participation of an Italian industrial consortium in the New York World's Fair has been assured. This development is a result of a visit here yesterday of a committee of Italian-Americans headed by Edward Corsi.

Strange and unexpected happenings intruded on the natural order of things at Yankee Stadium last night. Bats flew through the air, pitchers fell down, infielders threw wildly and Whitey Ford and the New York Yankees lost to the Baltimore Orioles, 5--3, before a crowd of 27,834.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 2 (UPI)--Assistant Attorney General Ralph Odum, in seeking the dismissal of a suit to force the closing of Florida A M Law School, said today the allNegro school was segregated only because no white students had sought admission.

President Kennedy's allocation of $250,000 to support special efforts to prevent pupils from dropping out of school has led to a flurry of activity at the United States Office of Education as school systems applied for funds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) --The six Senators from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania proposed today a survey for a three-state national parkway from Stroudsburg, Pa., to Kingston, N.Y. It would be similar to the Skyline Drive in Virginia.

Our economy is still not expanding fast enough to provide work for all the people who need it. Employment went up by more than 500,000 last month, bringing the total number of American workers close to the 71-million mark. But, impressive as this figure is, it has brought no appreciable change in the unemployment rate. Joblessness stands at 5.6 per cent-- a level that has been maintained without significant betterment for more than five years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today a request by the San Francisco Mining Exchange that communications between S.E.C. staff members be introduced at a hearing on whether the exchange should be closed.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 2-- Governor Rockefeller told 350 women Republican leaders today that an understanding view should be taken toward the wave of civil rights demonstrations.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The United States was favored today to win nine of 10 events tomorrow in the opening of its track meet with Britain at White City Stadium. Coach Payton Jordan of the United States predicted a world record in the 440-yard relay.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Aug. 2 (UPI)--The Atomic Energy Commission will spend millions of dollars in the next few years to expose 1,000 dogs and 10,000 smaller laboratory animals to radioactive pollution.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2 (AP) --Ruth Jessen, playing on a rain-soaked course, posted a one-over-par 73 today for a two-round total of 141 on the 6,508-yard North Shore Country Club. This enabled her to retain a two-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $12,500 Milwaukee women's open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2-- President Kennedy accepted today the resignation of Joseph S. Farland as Ambassador to Panama, Mr. Farland, ranked by some as one of the most effective envoys in Latin America, apparently had disagreed with some United States foreign aid policies.

Actors Equity Association is trying to keep four British performers from entering this country. They have been signed to appear in "The Rehearsal," the Jean Anouilh play which David Merrick plans to open on Sept. 23 at the Royale Theater. Equity has asked the Immigration Department to deny the actors visas on the ground that they are not essential to the production.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 2-- Leading white businessmen and moderate Negro leaders have established the basis for an agreement that they hope will end interracial strife in Savannah.

Gareth Martinis was indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on five counts of vehicular homicide in the death of five persons in a May 19 auto crash on the Henry Hudson Parkway. He was released in $1,500 bail for trial Sept. 11.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2-- Thousands of fish have been killed this summer in the irrigation drainage network in the Sacramento area, and California fish and game authorities are moving into the courts to try to stop the loss.

Two unions representing 81,000 employes of the General Electric Company asked yesterday for annual wage increases of 3 per cent under a new three-year contract.
CHICAGO, Aug 5 Mrs. Claire Giannini Hoffman, a 58-year-old San Francisco banker, became Sears, Roebuck Co.'S first woman director today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) George Meany announced today a merger agreement by the leaders of two printing trades unions.

ALBANY, Aug. 5 (AP) A Manhattan prosecutor urged Governor Rockefeller today to spare the life of the driver of a get-away car in a holdup who is facing a death sentence, but to let two other criminals die.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) A husband and wife team of lawyers from Los Angeles and a writer for the Communist publication. The Worker refused today to answer questions about alleged trips to Cuba.

President Kennedy's allocation of $250,000 in emergency funds to permit the nation's biggest cities to carry out a campaign against school dropouts this month is microscopic in its direct financial impact. The cities involved will be getting less than $10,000 each, and it is inconceivable that even the most hard-pressed municipality could not have found that much money in its own petty cash reserves.
ALTHOUGH volumes have been written on how to freeze foods, the technique is not difficult if a few simple rules are followed.

On Aug. 5 in Moscow in the Grand Kremlin Palace A. A. Gromyko, Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Mr. Rusk, Secretary of State of the United States of America, and Lord Home, Her Britannic Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, signed a treaty banning nuclear weapon tests in the atmosphere, in outer space and under water.
