Housewives who have been frightened by Rachel Carson are being regarded as a large potential market by certain daisy interests in Kenya.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 5 The Committee to Save Our Neighborhood Schools today attacked the Board of Education's plan to solve racial imbalance in Lincoln School as "extreme and unnecessarily radical" and a "complete capitulation" to Negro leaders and pressure groups.
The Bronx Zoo produced the new, the strange and the exotic yesterday some of it so new the public can't even see it yet.
HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 5 (UPI) Communist China bitterly denounced the United States and the Soviet Union today at an antinuclear weapons conference that was marred by rioting by Japanese students.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 5 Five Nassau County patrolmen were charged here today with stealing between $5,000 and $10,000 worth of merchandise from four appliance stores in the last year for use in their homes.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 5 Delegates to the Lutheran World Federation chided one of their committees today for its failure to sum up briefly their doctrinal discussions of last week.

Laurence Harvey and Elaine Stritch will star in "The Time of the Barracudas," opening around Thanksgiving at the ANTA Theater. Peter Barnes is the author of the mysterycomedy, to be directed by Anthony Page. Both are newcomers to Broadway.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 4 The Christian Crusade, a rightwing organization of some prominence in this part of the country, has fallen on hard times.

PANAMA CITY, Fla., Aug. 5 A Florida prisoner who established a new constitutional principle last winter in the Supreme Court of the United States won his own vindication today in a county court house.

Liberal lay leaders and ecclesiastics of the Roman Catholic Church have begun to focus special attention on ways to perfect--and to extend--a church approved method of birth control in a growing determination to find solutions to the world's population explosion.
IT is a great pleasure to come upon such a rich, blithering bonanza of a novel as "The Banker" in these dog-eat-dog days of a melodramatic summer.
DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 5 The new Organization of African Unity was threatened here today with outright disunity on the issue of regional African groupings.
An apparent snub by the building trades industry here yesterday threatened to increase racial tensions arising from demands for more construction jobs for Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 5 A force of Haitian exiles under Gen. Leon Cantave landed early this morning in the Bay of Libert , in northern Haiti, according to a spokesman for the invaders.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 5 The Government said today that the body of a young priest who burned himself to death yesterday as a religious protest in Phanthiet had been turned over to his family. Buddhist leaders in Phanthiet were not sure where the body was after a day-long protest in that seacoast city today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Cameron of Belvedere, formerly of Darien, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Elliott Cameron of New York, to Kevin Young Gebhard. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward Leonard Gebhard of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. Plans have been made for an autumn wedding.

PARES, Aug. 5 Byron Janis, the American pianist, canceled today his scheduled appearance at Monte Carlo on Saturday because of an injury to his left arm received in a scuffle with French policemen last Wednesday.
PARIS, Aug. 5 (UPI) William Bird, a former correspondent for New York newspapers, died Friday in a hospital at the age of 74. He suffered a stroke three weeks ago.

BROWNSVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 5 (AP) A white civil rights leader was held in jail today as the Congress of Racial Equality charged that he had been "beaten unmercifully" and burned with acid. Local authorities denied the charges.
The nation's steel production continued to slide last week. It fell 4 per cent in the seven days ended last Saturday from the week before. The decline was the ninth in the last 10 weeks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5(AP) The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today a bill calling for raises ranging from $5 to $230 a month for nearly 2,000,000 members of the armed forces, effective Oct. 1.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 5 Delirium of the Greentree Stable had a most enjoyable trip in the $35,400 Sanford Stakes today. He won the 5 furlong burst by a length and a quarter. With Braulio Baeza giving him an impromptu ride, Delirium got off in front at the break and stayed there all the way to score over Reginald N. Webster's Traffic.

LONDON, Aug. 5 John Pennel of Miami set a world polevault record of 16 feet 10 inches today as the United States trackmen wound up their triumphant tour of Europe with a 120-91 victory over the British national team. The crowd of 33,000 was the largest to see an athletic meet at White City Stadium in five years.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Aug. 5 (AP) Craig Breedlove, a 26-year-old, onetime hot rodder from Los Angeles, set a world land speed record of 407.45 miles an hour today in a sleek, jet-powered car.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 A bottoming out of the Argentine recession and the wave of optimism that has prevailed here since the July 7 Presidential election have sent Buenos Aires stock market prices spiralling to sensational gains.
A four-hour meeting on coffeehouses drew an overflow crowd of 350 persons to a Greenwich Village hotel last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 5 A pop singer with less than one year of professional experience has been chosen by the State Department to represent the United States at the third Polish International Song Festival.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Broad dissension is developing within Latin-American Communist movements along the lines of the Soviet-Chinese quarrel, a country-by-country survey dis closed today.

SEWANEE, Tenn., Aug 5 Mrs. Anne Farquhar Ellis, widow of the Rev. Julian Rumsey Ellis of Greenwich, Conn., and daughter of Roger Vereker Farquhar of New York, and the late Mrs. Farquhar, became the bride here today of the Rev. William Augustin Griffin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ezma Griffin of Durham, N.C.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Haiti has requested an emergency session of the Council of the Organization of American States to air new grievances against the Dominican Republic.
BUFFALO, Aug. 5 (AP) Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, who is 64 years old, married Joan Martin, a 23year-old Government worker, in a simple church ceremony today.

THE early bird with his crackof-dawn hunting sounds like a bore. So do people who advise rushing out for clothes that cannot be worn for a month or so. The one time early-birding makes sense is for imported items that are quickly snatched up and then rarely make return appearances in the stores.

DUBLIN, THIS green, rolling island country is blessed with a profusion of beautiful inland game-fish waters. There are the many loughs with their hefty brown trout, and the rivers and streams flow down to the sea. It is up these waters that the salmon and sea-run trout move.
MONTREAL, Aug. 5 The leader of one of Qebec's strongest independence groups entered the 28th day of a bread-andwater fast today. The goal is to raise $100,000 for his cause.

NEVER at a loss for clever names, Philharmonic Hall unwrapped its "August Fanfare" last night. This latest package is a three-week m lange of recitals, chamber concerts, dance programs and chamber jazz everything, in fact, except fanfares. "September Saturnalia," anyone?

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5? An exciting, wide-open Republican National Convention, with no undue influence from far rightists, was predicted today by National Chairman William E. Miller.

The directors of the BristolMyers Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock. They also raised the quarterly dividend on the present shares to 40 cents from 35 cents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Youths 17 to 18 years old who enlist directly in the military reserves will now be obliged to serve six years instead of eight, the Defense Department announced today.

The executive committee of the New York County Democratic organization decided yesterday to continue to support Paul O'Dwyer as the party's candidate for councilman at large in Manhattan. But ill feeling persisted over Mr. O'Dwyer's links with reform elements in the party.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 Mrs. Helen Roebling Tyson, widow of Carroll Sargent Tyson, died Friday at her summer home in Northeast Harbor, Me. She was 78 years old and lived in the Chestnut Hill section here.

Sales of United States savings bonds rose sharply in July, the Treasury reported yesterday, offsetting a setback in sales the month before. June was the only month so far this year which did not show an increase over 1962.

The prize Rembrandt at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer," will be back on exhibition on Thursday after a brief absence, and it will be glowing with a new clarity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Yields on newly issued United States Treasury bills declined slightly this week after five straight weeks of rise.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 5 It is at the start of each week that contemporary music has its chief innings at Tanglewood. Tonight about 500 friends of the Berkshire Music Center heard a rather extreme sampling of the sort of thing that has been going on here since early in July.

If plans of the newly organized BusinessIndustry Political Action Committee are carried through, there will be a new and important spokesman in the political arena. The committee is to be bipartisan. Battle, comes to New York headquarters from Alabama via Washington, D.C.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 5 City school superintendents meeting here were offered support on segregation problems by three Government agencies today. But the support was mostly of the moral and consultative variety.
The Canadian dollar improved in trading on the New York foreign exchange market yesterday in a reversal of Monday's decline.
Phoenix, Ariz., borrowed yesterday $12,000,000 in the bond market on a water works revenue issue due 1969-90.

Since the expedition must have come from somewhere (the Duvalier Government understandably says from the Dominican Republic), it creates an international issue.
The Boston Gas Company has placed two billboard advertisements in downtown Boston that show white and Negro children playing together on a slide.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)--President Kennedy and other national leaders paid final tribute today to Philip L. Graham, publishing executive, About 2,000 persons attended a memorial service in Washington Cathedral.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 6--Rebel forces led by Gen. Leon Cantave have bypassed Cap Haitien, Haiti's second city, and were believed today to be heading southwest toward the west coast.

The Kubota Iron and Machinery Works of Osaka, Japan, has privately placed in the United states market $4,900,000 of 7 per cent 15-year notes with warrants good until Oct. 15, permitting buyers of the debentures to purchase common stock of the company at 5 per cent under the market price.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 6 (UPI) The Connollys won two events tonight and so did Hayes Jones in the August track-and-field games here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6-- Senator Barry Goldwater said today he felt that Governor Rockefeller was using "the old Democratic technique of guilt by association" in attempting to identify him with the "radical right."
Eight persons were accused by Federal authorities yesterday of being part of a ring that smuggled Swiss watch movements into this country at a loss to the Government of $1,000,000 a year in revenue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6-- Haiti accused the Dominican Republic today of helping prepare an invasion force of Haitian exiles that is attempting to overthrow the regime of President Francois Duvalier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6--A special committee of the National Science Board, set up to study Project Mohole at the suggestion of White House officials, has firmly endorsed Brown Root, Inc., of Houston, Tex., to continue as prime contractor of the $68,000,000 effort.

Windsor Creations, Inc., manufacturor and importer of artificial flowers, has leased a floor containing 15,000 square feet at 79 Fifth Avenue, corner of 16th Street, for executive offices and showrooms. William Gottlieb of Mills Co., was the broker. The space is double that formerly occupied by the lessee at 12 West 21st Street.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (UPI)-- Soybean futures dropped sharply in persistent selling today on the Board of Trade. Corn and rye also retreated, and other grains were steady to easy.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6--The Bernard Baruch Handicap, which has become one of this region's more attractive races in its short existence, will be run for the fifth time tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)--Many public schools will continue prayer and Bible reading next fall despite the Supreme Court's ruling that such readings are unconstitutional as part of required classroom exercises.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 6 --Mr. and Mrs. Roger Wolcott Converse of Brookline and Marion have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christina Converse, to Patrick Tracy Jackson Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson of Boothbay Harbor, Me.

YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo, July 31. In the wilderness a few miles east of here a great female grizzly bear is on the prowl, sniffing the air for berries, bison or anything else edible, but with a strange persistence she also smells man.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 6-- The American Can Company introduced the movie break today.

Rene Black, an authority on gastronomy and elegance, and a maitre de bouche often described as "The Master of 40 Sauces," died yesterday of a heart attack at his estate in Pound Ridge, N.Y. He was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6-- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today sharp restrictions on benefits available to high-income taxpayers who borrow money to pay life insurance premiums.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6--The Chicago Real Estate Board attacked today a proposed city open-occupancy ordinance as destructive of personal property rights.

The joint meetings Secretary of Labor Wirtz is holding with railroad labor and management represent a final attempt to infuse some vitality into the moribund structure of collective bargaining in this key industry. Only three weeks are left to avert a crippling strike or the forced enactment of a bad law--a choice the country should not have to make.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)--Railroad and union negotiators resumed face-to-face talks today, and the House Commerce Committee suspended consideration of President Kennedy's, legislation to prevent a rail strike.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 6 (UPI)--Rubin, with H.O. Schemann of Germany at the helm, won a 29-mile handicap race today in the Britannia Challenge Cup, the second of a four-race series for the Admiral's Cup, at the Cowes Regatta.
Some reduction in transAtlantic air fares seems likely at an international airline meeting opening Sept. 9 in Salzburg, Austria, aviation sources said Yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6--The Defense Department plans to launch this fall the first pair of experimental satellites capable of detecting nuclear tests in deep space.

Prices of Treasury securities showed few changes yesterday in dull trading. The municipal bond market perked up as it absorbed a rather long list of moderate-size offerings, and the prime corporates were firm in a slow session.

Once before, in late 1961, the pension funds began curtailing share buying, but the securities were taken by other buyers in the bull market of the period.

New York harbor handled more than a fifth of the oceangoing traffic in and out of the nation's 11 leading ports during the first six months of this this year, the Maritime Association of the Port of New York reported yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 6--The problems of Berlin and Germany returned to the East-West negotiating agenda today, apparently without any change in the position of either side.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6--Public school superintendents meeting here to discuss integration problems took some comfort today in a more lenient stand enunciated by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

What has happened to the traditional summer rally? That has been the lament of stock market followers for many a hot, humid day now. Stocks declined sharply on average in June and July and have staged only a moderate gain so far in August.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 6-- American military sources said tonight that 90 Communist guerrillas were killed last week in the Communist-dominated Camau Peninsula. The Communists fell into a trap baited by a Vietnamese team and the United States Special Forces.

ALBANY, Aug. 8--The attorney for the Malverne L.I. School District argued today that Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education, lacked authority to order a correction of racial imbalance in the school system.

ALBANY, Aug. 6 (UPI)-- Intrastate Western Union telegraph rates will be increased 10 per cent and commercial news service rates will be raised 8 per cent, effective Sunday, the Public Service Commission said today.

ALBANY, Aug. 5--Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino said today he saw no conflict of interest or impropriety in his support of a 1961 banking bill that benefited a bank of which he was a director and another of which he was a stockholder.
The appointment of nine Advanced Science Writing Fellows and one associate fellow for the 1963-64 academic year was announced yesterday by the Graduate School of Journalism of Columbia University.

A reduction in ingot prices and a prolonged strike in British Guiana adversely affected second-quarter and half-year earnings of Aluminium, Ltd., Canada, the leading aluminum producer outside the United States reported yesterday.

BOHEMIA, L.I., Aug. 6--A severely burned man who made a heroic attempt to save himself died early this morning at the side of an Air Force plane that had made an emergency crosscountry trip to carry him to Texas for special treatment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6-- William D. Rogers, a Washington lawyer, was named today as deputy United States coordinator of the Alliance for Progress. His appointment was part of a series of shifts in Latin-American policy-making posts.

Directors of the Brunswick Corporation omitted dividend action on the common stock yesterday because of a sharp drop in earnings. Brunswick's stock fell to a four-year low following the announcement yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 7 (AP)--Federal District Judge Edward A. Conger, an early friend and backer of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who named him to the bench of Manhattan's Southern District, died tonight at the age of 81.

The Waldbaum chain of supermarkets has leased a warehouse to be constructed to its specifications in the Roosevelt Field Industrial Center in Westbury, L.I. The building, which is planned on an 11-acre tract, will contain 225,000 square feet...

High officials of central banks in the United States, Italy Switzerland and West Germany rejected yesterday the idea of a new international money mechanism to prevent crises in currency markets and to assure financing of the growing volume of world trade and investment.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7--There are supermarkets and parking lots where the elegant old hotels used to be, but society has not deserted Saratoga. There probably is more blue blood here this week than at any other resort in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) --Edwin P. Neilan, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, charged today that some politicians were practicing "seduction by subsidy" to woo voters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7-- United States officials are optimistic that a series of punitive tariff increases back and forth across the Atlantic can be averted.

SOUTH HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 7--Violence flared between Negroes and Puerto Ricans here last night. The police said the incidents stemmed from the beating of a Negro by four Puerto Ricans early Sunday.
Fidel Castro's mood of confidence seems to include a feeling of certainty that in conferences with the United States, the Soviet Union will not sell Cuba down the river.

ROME, Aug. 7--The factiontorn Christian Democratic party regained its unity this week when it reached an almost unanimous decision to support a program calling for a new "opening to the left" next November.

Ruth Bradley of 14 Washington Place East, a composer, pianist and teacher, died Friday in San Francisco, while on a trip. Her age was 69. She was the wife of Franklin D. Jones, an author and editor of technical books.

Craig Breedlove, who on Monday set a world land speed record of 407.45 miles an hour in an unusual earth-bound vehicle, was under no illusions yesterday that he had driven anything resembling an automobile.
More persons traveled by air across the North Atlantic and in this country in the first half of the year than in the similar 1962 period.

In an attempt to unify and speed efforts to prevent students from dropping out of high school, the Board of Education yesterday created the position of coordinator of all programs designed to cope with the problem.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7-- Union and management officials from the New York City construction industry denied today that they had discriminated against Negroes in the operation of their apprenticeship programs.

BOSTON, Friday, Aug. 9-- The new baby boy of President and Mrs. Kennedy died early today, the White House announced at 4:26 A.M. The baby, born Wednesday, had been named Patrick Bouvier Kennedy.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 -- California's largest minority group will lay its troubles before a representative of the White House here tomorrow.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 --Stanford University has set out to become the country's Shakespearean capital next summer.

CAMBRIDE, Md., Aug. 8-- Segregationists filed a petition today for a public referendum in this Eastern Shore Maryland community on whether Negroes must be permitted to patronize white lunch counters and retaurants.

The net income of the companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group in the six months to June 30, was 98,700,000, or $276,466,000, the group reported yesterday. This is an increase of 2.4 per cent over the first half of 1962, when net earnings were 96,456,000, or $270,076,000.

GLEN COVE, L.I. Aug. 8-- Premjit Lall, a 22-year-old member of India's Davis Cup squad, upset Bobby Wilson of Britain, the first-seeded player, 6--4, 6--4, today in the third round of the Nassau Bowl grass court tennis tournament.
The election of councilmen at large in November was barred yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson.
BONN, Aug. 8--The United States decision to retaliate against the Common Market's import restrictions for poultry was criticized today as "ill-timed and inept."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--The Securities and Exchange Commission study urged the New York Stock Exchange today to shed its "private-club" concept and extend voting powers to all allied members.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- The Canadian Ambassador was afraid he would "muss it up." The Irish Ambassador complained about the color of the binding--it was red instead of green.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor said yesterday that it was investigating Thomas W. (Teddy) Gleason, president-elect of the International Longshoremen's Association.

Three television stations, responding to a suggestion by Acting City Labor Commissioner James J. McFadden, will present a series of programs to teach reading and writing to New York's 500,000 adult illiterates.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--The House of Representatives approved today an extension until Nov. 30 of the temporary national debt limit of $309,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--The Shipbuilders Council of America today warned against a proposal to change laws restricting domestic shipping trade to vessels built in this country.

The Actors Studio Theater is one of six foreign groups chosen by the Royal Shakespeare Theater to participate in next year's celebration of the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare's birth. Receipt of the invitation was confirmed yesterday by Roger L. Stevens, general administrator of the Studio Theater.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8--Two of baseball's best "plane-catchers," Ralph Terry of the New York Yankees and Don Rudolph of the Washington Senators, engaged in a snappy pitching duel at D.C. Stadium today. It should surprise no one that Terry won, 3--1.

Consolidated net earnings of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation in the first six months this year rose to $23,124,000 from $22,361,000 in the initial half of 1962, according to the semiannual report released today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- Sales by department stores in the week ended Aug. 3 were 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year.

AN ironing table, Elvis Presley records, children's clothes and pattern books headed the shopping lists this week of crew members from the Yugoslavian freighter, Slovenija. The seamen made a shopping tour of Abraham Straus arranged by the Seamen's Center.
BEDFORD, N.Y., Aug. 8-- "You know what would be interesting?" mused Loudie Wainwright. "To know about Willy Loman's parents."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara set up a new system today for estimating the probable profits of companies on defense contracts--and assessing their record of previous performance--before awarding further contracts to them.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8-- The Government started action today toward pollution control of four rivers involving nine states, 87 communities and 72 industries.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 8--A complaint by a group of white parents seeking to block a pupil integration plan in Englewood was dismissed in Superior Court today by Judge Donald G. Collester.

The resumption of international polo in this country between England and the United States literally got off to flying start yesterday. For the first time, an entire English polo team and ponies crossed the Atlantic by air.
LONDON, Aug. 8--"The Ides of March," which opened tonight at the Haymarket Theater, is an adaptation of Thornton Wilder's novel of the same name about the last months in the life of Julius Caesar.

The $24,000,000,000 mutual fund industry has suffered severe growing pains in spiraling to nearly 50 times the size it was in 1940.

Lawrence B. Karter, a realty investor who has been active on the West Side in recent months, has added to his holdings by contracting to buy the two five-story apartment buildings at 505-07 West 52d Street, adjoining the northwest corner of 10th Avenue. DETROIT, Aug. 8--Charles T. Fisher, a founder of the Fisher Body Company, now a division of the General Motors Corporation, died today in Harper Hospital here after a long illness. He was 83 years old.
THE North Jersey Bridge Association today will start a weekend tournament at the Bergen Mall Auditorium.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 8--Darlene Hard of Los Angeles and Billie Jean Moffitt of Long Beach, Calif., were chosen today to bear the main burden of the United States defense of the Wightman Cup here Saturday and Sunday.
World sugar and cocoa futures declined yesterday in active trading, largely as a result of profit taking.
MADRID, Aug. 8--Nearly 7,000 coal miners were reported idle today in the northwestern region of Asturias in the wake of a Government order last night that closed seven pits.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) --Secretary of the Air Force Eugene M. Zuckert says it is too late for competitive flight tests beween rival models of the TFX warplane.

The Martin-Marietta Corporation reported yesterday a sharp drop in sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30. This reflected a decline in defense operations, reduced profit margins in some construction lines and elimination of certain operations.

A new area has been opened in the current investigation of Forest Hills General Hospital for asserted padding of expense claims against Blue Cross. The stock market paid almost no attention yesterday to the third installment of the Securities and Exchange Commission's study of the nation's securities market. The market closed virtually unchanged after a day of modest trading activity.
The London stock market recovered yesterday afternoon from early declines caused by profit taking and the poor performance Wednesday of Wall Street.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Aug. 9--Sam Robbins of the Devon Yacht Club, East Hampton, L. I., took individual honors today in the international invitation Sunfish regatta. Robbins gained first place in the men's division and teamed with Katie Muhfeld for a victory in the mixed doubles. The series started yesterday.
The Josephite Fathers, who have ministered to Negro Roman Catholics of the United States since 1871, will open their first foreign mission in the fall.
ATHENS, Aug. 9--The neighbors of the handsome new Athens Hilton are having some free laughs at the hotel's expense this week.
A Federal Court jury yesterday found a union official guilty of embezzling $16,500 in union welfare funds and of obstructing justice.

The Federal Reserve Board has sharply criticized Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon for his rulings that have permitted national banks to underwrite and purchase certain municipal revenue bond issues.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 9--Competitors in the MG Car Club's 1,000-mile international rally today went through the third day of the event without encountering a single road construction or repair project. This was a welcome change from the experiences of the first two days.
The calendar of new fixedinterest debt issues facing the market next week is expected to continue light, reflecting the usual seasonal lull.
Changes in weekend service on the IRT Broadway-Seventh Avenue subway line resulting from the closing of the 225th Street Bridge for tests were put into effect yesterday by the Transit Authority.

The bill overwhelmingly approved by the House to triple Federal aid to vocational education is an essential foundation rock in a structure of increased job opportunity for youngsters in an automated industrial society. The principal gainers will be Negro and Puerto Rican youths, who have been at a particular disadvantage through racial discrimination and inadequate skills.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 9-- Allen Fox of Los Angeles and Gene Scott of St. James, L. I., today gained the semi-finals of the Nassau Bowl grass court tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club.

GAGRA, U.S.S.R., Aug. 9 (AP)--Premier Khrushchev opened his Black Sea retreat to inspection by American newsmen today. Behind an ugly 10foot-high concrete-block wall, the leader of the Soviet proletariat vacations in sun-drenched luxury that many capitalists would envy.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9--William S. Cox of the Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club, a three-time winner of the title, today led the way through the second qualifying round of the Hipkins Cup regatta for the men's Long Island sailing championship.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 9--The Secretary General, U Thant, has agreed to investigate sentiment in North Borneo and Sarawak on the question of joining the forthcoming Federation of Malaysia, but only if his decision is accepted as final and binding.
If the gushing sale of surfing records continues to engulf the country the ho-daddies and their beach dollies may inherit the earth.

OCEAN BEACH, Fire Island, L. I., Aug. 9--Arthur Silsdorf, the Mayor of this resort community, was arrested here tonight on a charge of assaulting an editor-reporter of The Fire Island News, a weekly newspaper.
The London stock market closed yesterday on a firm note, ending its best week since the Profume affair rocked the Conservative Government.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 9 --Miss Catherine Frum was married this afternoon to Paul Arthur Buttenwieser at the Memorial Church of Harvard.
LONDON, Aug. 9--The loss in Britain's great train robbery rose today to more than $7,000,000, most of it in easily disposable banknotes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8--A line-up of scores of depositors trying to recover their savings, reminiscent of the bank failures of the nineteen-thirties, prompted the state of Illinois today to declared a 30-day moratorium on withdrawal of deposits at the Tinley Park Savings and Loan Association in suburban Tinley Park.

Four years ago the Port of New York Authority began warning the public and the governments of New York and New Jersey that specific planning must start at once for a large new airport to serve the metropolitan area. A 10,000acre site in Morris County was suggested, but such a storm of local protest blew up in New Jersey that it became apparent the airport would have to go elsewhere.

WHEN it is hot outside, and something cool is called for inside, there is nothing like a melon. The same holds true when hunger pangs threaten to undermine a diet. The golden, green and pinkfleshed varieties of this fruit are as miserly with calories as they are generous with juice. Consequently, they are ideal appetite appeasers.
Cocoa and sugar futures fell here yesterday in moderate trading. Trading in other commodities markets was irregular and quiet.

CUTCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 9 --Douglas Moore, the American opera composer and musicologist, will celebrate his 70th birthday tomorrow with his wife, daughter and son-in-law in the house in which he was born.

The music stopped this week at Nick's. After 27 years of making jazz history, the Greenwich Village landmark closed its doors Saturday night. With scarcely any public attention, the final chorus of "Tin Roof Blues" blared out and the neon message, "Sizzling Steaks," went dark.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 9--Charles Haag, 40-year-old broker who has been free in $50,000 bail as a material witness in the murder of a New York jeweler, was held today on a charge of receiving stolen goods.

NORTHEAST HARBOR, Me., Aug. 9--The New York Yacht Club's first competitive visit to Maine in 10 years ended today on the same fog-ridden note with which it had begun. This time the difficulties of fog were compounded by an acute lack of wind and kept all 34 starters from finishing within the time limit--which for the lowest rating yachts was before 6 P.M.
SHERBROOKE, Que., Aug. 9 (AP)--Quebec industry is rapidly acknowledging the need for bilingualism, and a number of companies now offer employes courses in French.
PECOS, Tex., Aug. 9 (UPI)-- The Federal Government filed a $10,500,000 tax lien today against Billie Sol Estes, convicted farm promoter, and his wife Patsy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9-- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to reduce the tax of capital gains from the sale of stocks, real estate or other assets held for more than two years.

PITTSBURGH, Saturday, Aug. 10 (AP)--Roberto Clemente lined a bases-filled single in the 11th inning at 2:30 A.M. today and gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 7-6 victory over the Houston Colts in the second game of a twilight-night double-header.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 9 (Reuters)--Buddhist leaders prohibited today what might have been South Vietnam's third recent public suicide by burning. They said they feared the suicide would touch off a wave of suicides.

IBADAN, Nigeria, Aug. 9-- Special police and Army contingents arrived today to insure maximum security for the world middleweight title fight tomorrow night between Gene Fullmer and Dick Tiger.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--The House Foreign Affairs Commit tee warned India and Pakistan today that United States aid would be drastically curtailed unless more progress was made toward settling the Kashmir dispute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) --The Small Business Administration designated Erie and Niagara Counties, New York, and adjacent localities as disaster areas today as a result of flood damage last Wednesday when 3.88 inches of rain fell in five and a half hours.

TOKYO, Aug. 9 (AP)--Dr. Chi Chao-ting, United Stateseducated economist and deputy chairman of Communist China's Council for the Promotion of International Trade, died in Peking today of a cerebral hemorrhage, the New China News Agency said. He was 60 years old.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 8--The United States is favored to win the Wightman Cup for the third successive year in the international women's tennis matches with Britain starting here tomorrow at the Skating Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) --Expressions of sympathy for all over the world poured into the White House today for President and Mrs. Kennedy on the death of their son, Patrick Bouvier.

At the United Nations, the conclusion of the limited nuclear test treaty has been welcomed, in Secretary General Thant's words, as "a significant breakthrough in the protracted and seemingly frustrating negotiations that have been conducted in the field of disarmament over the years."

Unknown hands in the Soviet Ukraine have preserved the graves of the Baal Shem Tov, 18th-century founder of the great Hasidic religious movement, and of the early progenitors of the Hasidic rabbinical dynasties.

THE American Littoral Society is in the middle of an ambitious fund-raising effort. The society is seeking financial help so that a thorough inventory can be made of the thousands of wrecks in the coastal waters of the United States.
IBADAN, Nigeria, Aug. 10-- Dick Tiger retained his middleweight championship tonight when he pummeled Gene Fullmer into submission in seven rounds.
A sociologist has proposed that all privately owned rental housing in this country be operated as a public utility to prevent its exploitation by profiteering slumlords.

Morris Iushewitz, who as a member of the Board of Education and a labor leader wears two official hats, said that as a board member he favored invoking the Condon-Wadlin Act against any teachers who went on strike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that six of the nation's largest drug companies were conspiring to fix prices on tetracycline, the most widely used antibiotic. Sales of this drug used to combat bacterial infection total $100,000,000 a year.
Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara is expected to give his decision soon on the size of the Navy's aircraft carrier fleet.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 10--Miss Barbara May Ziegler and Keith MacKinlay Gunn were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. S. Franklin Mack performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10-- George Reynolds of Haddonfield, N.J., today gained the fourth round of the Middle States senior grass court tennis championship. He defeated Henry Bassford of Staten Island, 11--9, 6--2, at the Germantown Cricket Club.
MUNICH, Germany-- Americans touring by car through Germany and Austria this summer are sure to come home with a new family joke. They will have heard the directional advice, "Gerade aus zum Bahnhof"

THIRTY years ago many readers were--and perhaps many still are--enchanted by Henri Alain-Fournier's "Le Grand Meaulnes" (available in the United States as "The Wanderer"), the narration by one boy of the mysterious adventure of another boy whose poetic and unconventional qualities gave him the strange name which was the title of this novel.
HAVANA, Aug. 10 (AP)-- Prime Minister Fidel Castro said last night he planned to nationalize those large farms in Cuba that "bourgeois" landowners still control. But "there is no hurry," he said.
LONDON, Aug. 10--Detectives investigating Thursday's $7,000,000 mail train robbery got their first solid clues today.

A ranch model with seven rooms has been completed at True Value Homes on Motor Parkway, about a mile east of Route III, in Hauppauge, L.I. It is priced at $19,990 and has two bathrooms, a family den, a basement and an attached garage.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 10--Recovering from the shock of losing the opening match after it had appeared to be won, the United States gained a 2-1 lead over Britain in the first day of the Wightman Cup tennis competition today.

A DOG is said to be man's best friend. The Cornell Veterinary Virus Research Institute is a dog's best friend. As a result of work being done upstate, the sick or injured animal has a much better chance to survive than he did a few years ago.
THIS second volume of Mark De Wolfe Howe's biography of Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes cannot have been an easy book to write.
HELENA, Mont.--An old house that has stood empty for four years is once again a center of activity in Montana's capital city.

SANTA FE, N.M. ONE night, about two weeks ago, at 7 o'clock, the clouds opened and started pouring soup plate raindrops over Santa Fe. This did not look so good for the fate of "Madama Butterfly," scheduled for 8:30 at the Santa Fe Opera, five miles out on Route 64.
PARIS, Aug. 10--In the French Government's view, the nuclear test ban treaty is a first step to virtually nothing.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 8 --Many influential Republicans concede in private that if an election were held now they could not beat President Kennedy. One of them publicly conceded it today.
Buyers are offered a choice of bathroom arrangements in a development of attached homes going up in West Haverstraw, in Rockland County, N.Y.

LONDON--A friend from the United States once complained to me that "all English motorists drive like nervous Americans." His comment was based on a touring holiday around the British Isles, for which he had brought his American car.

TOKYO, Aug. 10--Japanese Government officials are reported to be planning a thorough review of Japan's trading policies with Communist China, under which commerce between the two countries has been rising toward record levels.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP)--The San Francisco Giants downed the Philadelphia Phillies today, 7--6, on a 17-hit attack that included Orlando Cepeda's two-run triple and a pair of singles by Willie Mays that extended Mays's hitting streak to 12 games.
When the Raymond Street Jail in Brooklyn was closed recently, the city's oldest, and probably its most inadequate, correctional facility was eliminated.
Mrs. Claire Giannini Hoffman is one woman who doesn't take a long time to make up her mind.

The Maritime Subsidy Board has bowed out of one area of its authority over subsidized shipping lines. The board, which functions within the Maritime Administration of the Department of Commerce, has rescinded a letter issued over a year ago telling aided lines that they must adhere to steamship conference tariffs.

THE 1963 fair season, which got under way last month with dozens of county exhibitions, has advanced to the state level. From now until Nov. 1-11, when the Arizona State Fair in Phoenix will institute the annual period of winter fun in the Sun Belt, state fairs will be popping up in various places in the United States and Canada.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 10 (AP) --Dick Groat collected four hits and raised his National Leagueleading average to .345 today as the St. Louis Cardinals battled to a 6-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

IN a warehouse down by the North River docks large shipments of imported recordings are being stored that should cause some extra heart flutters among disk collectors. Capitol Records has decided to make available in this country some 800 titles previously released in France, Germany, Italy and England by its overseas affiliates.
ATHENS, Aug. 9--Manolis Glezos, the leading member of the Greek Communist movement, faces a possible treason charge for the second time in his life.
A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner has found that airlines offering reduced-rate air-bus flights have discriminated on a "substantial scale" against passengers seeking ticket refunds.

THE question "What has happened to humor?" used to be good for at least one magazine article every six months or so, but no longer. Humor, for those with a sense of it, comes in novels these days, and in almost every flavor, from hip surrealism to the conventional satiric novel of ideas.

DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 10-- The African foreign ministers recommended today that Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, be the permanent site of the new Organization of African States. The heads of state of the African nations are expected to accept the recommendation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10-- Senator Estes Kefauver, the crusading Tennessee Democrat with the ready handshake and homespun personality, died today at the age of 60.
BONN, Aug. 10--West Germany is the only major power still unable to make up its mind about the Moscow agreement to forego nuclear testing except under ground.

The high cost of experimenting with a new teaching technique has led the Public Schools of Weston, Mass., to develop an equally experimental financing plan. The school system is inviting other communities to join a School Development Cooperative to allow the project to continue and to permit others to benefit from the program.

KINGSTON, Ont.--The sound of the sunset gun at Canada's Old Fort Henry will have a special significance this year. A century and one-half has passed since the first crude fortifications of this citadel were built on the heights overlooking the harbor of Kingston.

A NASSAU COUNTY judge recently charged that suburban teen-agers suffer from a "serious malady--automania." The walls of racial exclusion that have traditionally stood between Negroes and skilled jobs in the building trades are coming down. The changing nature of Wall Street is apparent in the special study of the securities industry finally completed by an independent group of investigators attached to the Securities and Exchange Commission. In contrast to the first official investigation conducted a generation ago, the study found no evidence of widespread fraud. But it offers plentiful proof that protection for the ever-growing number of investors is inadequate in many areas.

THE history of musical style, like that of the other arts, is the tory of gradually evolving tendencies, punctuated here and there by a few violent overturns. One of the latter occurred around 1600, when the group of Florentine dilettantes and students known as the Camerata got together to rescue music from the complexities of Renaissance polyphony and produced the first opera.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 10--There were indications today that renewed violence might have broken out in northeastern Haiti. Witnesses said a military plane carrying at least seven injured men arrived yesterday afternoon from Cap Haitien.

BASED on the 1952 murder of a prominent British family vacationing in France, "The Olive Grove" attempts to explore a similar fictional violence. Its author is a prize-winning Polish novelist (prior to World War II) who now writes in English.

MUSIC in the cornfield last summer made plants grow better for George E. Smith, an agronomist and corn breeder of Bloomington, Ill. He supplied his research plots throughout the season with recorded music and claimed increased yields of 6 to 10.8 per cent.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 10--The First Unitarian Church was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Pamela Keyes Bachrach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Fabian Bachrach Jr. of Newtonville, to John Swink Carlson Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlson of Tulsa, Okla.

THE most perplexing thing about dance in New York this summer is that there is so much of it. Relatively speaking, that is. Last year, only the event-garde Judson Dance Theater had the courage to put on midsummer events (two), and they constituted the only serious dance offerings we had until the Re bekah Harkness Foundation Dance Festival was presented at the Delacorte Theater as a post-Labor Day postscript to the Shakespeare Festival.

At 3:20 p.m. last Thursday, a Senate debate on funds for the space race was interrupted by a call from the back of the chamber: "A message from the President of the United States." The Senate page received a brown paper envelope and took out a 1,500-word message and a facsimile copy of an eight-page document-- four pages in English, four in Russian.

It's harvest time in wide areas of the country and farm equipment makers are already reaping a bumper business. Sales of farm machinery are on the rise for the second year in a row, a welcome development for an industry that has been subject to cyclical ups and downs in recent years.

GETTYSBURG, Pa.--The recent centenary of the Battle of Gettysburg has endowed that historic site with special interest for tourists this summer.

WINNIPEG Man., Aug. 10-- The Canadian Prairies probably will produce the largest wheat crop in their history this year. Grain men with long experience in estimating crops predict that the record 678,000,000-bushel harvest of 1952 will be greatly exceeded. They are forecasting a crop of at least 700,000,000 bushels. Saskatchewan alone may produce 500,000,000 bushels.

BONN, Aug. 10--The United States will reduce its Army garrison in West Berlin by 600 men under a reorganization program to be initiated next month, Army authorities have disclosed.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. Bothersome delays at railroad grade crossings within a few hundred yards of the cataracts, a nuisance long encountered by visitors to Niagara Falls, will end this week, 75 years after relocation of the rail lines was first proposed.

MONTROSE, Ala., Aug. 10-- The marriage of Miss Dorothy Ann Farwell to Meredith William Myers, son of Mrs. Louise Turner Myers and Meredith Charles Myers, both of Mobile, took place here this afternoon.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 10--The marriage of Miss Lisa Jane Vosburgh to Lieut. Stuart Sargisson of the Air Force took place this afternoon in the Bunker Hill Congregational Church. A NOTABLE premiere for the United States Post Office Department will occur on Aug. 30, when the first postal card of its kind ever issued by this country will go on sale. THE nation's railroads are having a generally pros perous summer, judging from observations made on a recent transcontinental trip. Trains were well-filled, some ran at capacity and, at times, space was difficult to obtain.

The world's largest pumped electrical storage installation went into operation last Saturday at Ffestiniog in North Wales. Queen Elizabeth II opened the plant officially for the Central Electricity Generating Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- Members of the Securities and Exchange Commission's special study staff came to one interesting conclusion about last year's big stock maket break that they did not put in their report.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 11--One result of the Moscow test-ban treaty is that our project for a NATO armada of atomic-missile ships has been moved from diplomacy's icebox into diplomacy's deepest freeze. This is not openly acknowledged, yet it is a fact.

SUMMIT, N. J., Aug. 11-- Edward Goodnow Williams of 63 Whittredge Road, retired president of the American Type Founders Company, Inc., in Elizabeth, died yesterday in Jersey City Medical Center after a short illness. He was 70 years old.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 11--One of the great matches in United States women's tennis was played on the hard clay courts of the Skating Club today as the United States Wightman Cup team defeated Britain for the third successive time.

The second floor and part of the third floor in the building at 501 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of 42d Street, has been leased by the Dynamics Corporation of America, producer of specialized aerospace, communications and industrial and consumer products.

A mutual-fund official of the "old school" agreed in an interview over the weekend that contractual plans should be modified, but doubted that outlawing them was "healthy."

A task force of representatives of government, education and philanthropy has been formed to study problems that have hindered the cooperative efforts of universities and the Agency for International Development.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 11-- Company food supplies to 7,000 striking miners and their families at the Catavi Siglo Veinte Mines will be cut off tomorrow, the state-run Bolivian Mining Corporation announced today.

Mayor Wagner faces an extraordinary accumulation of problems as he returns to City Hall after the necessary absence occasioned by his son's illness. The Mayor's annual message to the City Council Aug. 20 could be a vehicle for evaluating the differing degrees of urgency of these problems and establishing some order of priority.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11-- The arrival here of 100,000 to 200,000 persons for a massive civil rights rally on Aug. 28 presents highly unusual problems for the government--national and local.

The names of more than 500 nonwhites who seek construction jobs are being submitted to the building trades unions here in the first massive test of a recent hiring agreement. About 350 of the names have been assembled by the city Department of Labor.
Christian unity will be the object of the Anglican Congress in Toronto this week, the Anglican Archbishop of Dublin said yesterday.
Mrs. Marion Sunshine Siner and Dr. Emanuel Gordon were married at noon yesterday by Rabbi Arthur H. Neulander at the home of the bride in Forest Hills, Queens. The immediate families attended.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP)-- Crop reports became the major influences in the grain market last week and they exerted a bearish pressure in both corn and soybeans, which showed losses for all contracts on the Board of Trade.

COMMACK, L.I., Aug. 11-- Three hundred youngsters here are learning navigation, map reading, water safety, rules of the sea and water survival at first hand under the school district's new summer recreational boating program.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union and one of the strongest foes of the Seafarers International Union, has urged organized Canadian labor "to oppose by all means" the imposition of a Government trusteeship over the Seafarers and four other unions.

Mrs. Corinne Kodziesen Hofheimer, philanthropist and widow of Lester Hofheimer, financier, died at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday after an illness of three months. She was 71 years old and lived at the SherryNetherland. Formerly she had resided at 995 Fifth Avenue.

Ralph Baldwin, who will drive Speedy Scot in Thursday night's $135,127 Yonkers Futurity Trot at Yonkers Raceway, worked the colt four separate miles at the Westchester course yesterday morning, then spruced up, donned big city clothes and rushed to Manhattan for a luncheon at the La Scala Restaurant.
Sugar futures fell sharply yesterday in a reaction to a weak London market, leading most other New York commodity prices in a general decline. Only coffee, copper and cocoa advanced.
British readers regard their newspapers as being a little like their nannies, carrying to them by ... way of letters their small triumphs and their major troubles.

Otto Wahle, a retired accountant and former swimming champion, died Sunday at his home. 70-03 Groton Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 83 years old.
A broad expansion program for the 61-year-old J.C. Penney Company, the nation's second largest merchandising concern, was outlined yesterday by its president, William M. Batten.

DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP)-- Car production dived to an estimated 42,089 last week, as nearly all auto plants ended the 1963 model run, Automotive News reported.

Herman H. Pevler, president of the Wabash Railroad, is expected to be elected today as president of the Norfolk Western Railroad, one of the nation's most prosperous carriers.

Observers around Wall Street are saying that when the executive committee of American Telephone and Telegraph Company meets today, the matter of dividends will be high on the agenda. The question: to raise the rate or not.

The Air Line Pilots Association, the most powerful union in aviation, lost a decision in Federal Court yesterday to an insurgent group of American Airlines pilots.

LONDON, Aug. 12--If either of the world's two reserve currencies comes under pressure, it is likely to be the dollar rather than the pound, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research said today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12--Justice Arthur J. Goldberg of the Supreme Court called on all lawyers and judges tonight to put aside personal views and support the Court's decisions as long as they remain the law.

TORONTO, Tuesday, Aug. 13 --The House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States placed early today the whole weight of its moral authority behind President Kennedy's civil rights program.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)--The New York Herald Tribune is back in good graces at the White House--or at least it is back on some White House desks.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- Four days after the 2.5-million ($7-million) mail-train robbery near Cheddington, the police believe the money may still be within a 30-mile radius of the crime.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk opened today the Administration's campaign for ratification of the treaty to outlaw nuclear tests in the air, in space and under water.

The Board of Education, faced with a backlog of school repairs estimated at $49,500,000, will be unable to make any progress in reducing this load during the present fiscal year because of budget limitations, school officials disclosed yesterday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 13--An 18-year-old Buddhist girl maimed herself last night in protest against her country's religious policies.
Plays by August Strindberg, Henrik Ibsen, Ben Jonson, Sheridan and Shakespeare are among 10 filmed dramas to be televised over Channel 9 during the 1963-64 season.

IN this city, where meat is generally the most favored food, it is something of a surprise to find a sea food store with almost as many comings and goings as Grand Central Terminal. But this was the condition on a recent day at Citarella's, 2135 Broadway (near 75th Street).

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 12-- --The Archbishop of Santiago, when asked about Chile's pressing problems, prefaces his answers by declaring: "I am not a technicain, but I will give you the opinion of a man in the street."
Stock prices rose sharply yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as trading activity quickened to the most active pace in almost two months.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (UPI)-- Stan (The Man) Musial, one of the great hitters of baseball, tonight announced his retirement as a player at the end of the 1963 season.
The London stock market failed to take off on a new rise yesterday despite favorable economic indicators.
The Mark Hellinger Theater is the scene this week of one of show business most lucrative and rapidly growing, enterprises: the industrial show.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Governor Rockefeller has assured key Republicans in Congress that he is prepared to fight for the party's Presidential nomination through at least two major primary contests.
DAKAR, Senegal, Aug. 12-- Africa's "grand march to unity" slowed to a crawl during the conference of foreign ministers that ended here yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 12--The nuclear test ban treaty-has been signed, Parliament is in recess, the Profumo scandal has subsided at least for the moment and the domestic and international crises that remain will just have to wait.

Ground was broken yesterday for a $1,250,000 school building for the Friends Seminary at 16th Street and Rutherford Place, between Second and Third Avenues. The new four-story brick building is designed to harmonize with the present School, which was built in 1860.
Two deputy commissioners of the State Liquor Authority have resigned to return to private law practice.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 --A 15-man crew from Japan bobbed beneath the Golden Gate "Bridge today shooting scenes for "My Enemy, the Sea," a movie based on the remarkable voyage of Kenichi Horie.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 12--The Milford Yacht Club crew, representing the Eastern Connecticut Y.R.A., held a one-point lead in the Area B semi-final series of the North American, Junior sailing championship today after three races in light southerly and easterly breezes on Long Island Sound.

Steel production continued to slacken last week. It fell 1.9 per cent in the seven days ended last Saturday from the level the week before. While this was the tenth drop in the last 11 weeks, there was some comfort in the fact that the dip was somewhat less than the 4 per cent drop a week earlier.

JAMES GALANOS had the last word on fall fashion yesterday. The West Coast designer brought his collection to New York nearly two weeks after most of the Paris couture and a couple of months after most of the Seventh Avenue concerns had their showings.

ATHENS, Aug. 12--An American citizen born in Greece was prevented from leaving Athens today. He sought to defy a new Greek military regulation designed to thwart draft evasion by emigrants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) --Railroad union leaders and carriers' representatives talked long hours today but were unsuccessful in perfecting a formula to break the deadlock in their work-rules dispute.
The Atlantic Refining Company announced yesterday the sale of its producing properties in Eastern Venezuela to three companies. Details of the financing terms were not given.

MANILA, Aug. 2 (AP)--The Philippines formally protested today United States restrictions on the entry of Philippine-made dresses into the United States and asked that the restrictions be removed while the issue is negotiated.

Two newly caught baby white whales, orphaned by whale hunters, joined two somewhat older white whales in their glass-walled outdoor tank and were hand-fed by a skin diver yesterday at the New York Aquarium.

General Alfredo Stroessner began a second six-year term as President of Paraguay yesterday. The Stroessner regime, whatever its guise, has been and will remain an old-fashioned one-man military dictatorship.

IN some of New England's older homes, one can find small camouflaged cubicles built above or below the staircases. Be fore the Civil War these homes were called stations--places where the abolitionists secreted fugitive slaves traveling north to Canada. The operation was known as the Underground Railroad.

BUFFALO, Aug. 16--Following 104 minutes and 57 seconds of frustration in two games, the New York Jets scored the first touchdown in the short history of their newly named franchise tonight. But the Buffalo Bills made two, plus three field goals, to win by 23--8.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 16 Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club won the 38th annual women's New Jersey State match-play golf championship today.

TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 16 J. Clifford MacDonald, former president of the National Association for Retarded Children and owner of the MacDonald Printing Company here, died in Tampa General Hospital today after a stroke. He was 61 years old.
In Dacca, the capital of East Pakistan, less than a third of the 555,000 people are directly served by the public water systems and only about a tenth have sewer connections.

YONKERS, Aug. 16 An aged pacing mare named Juno, driven by a young man named Paul Battis, won the second race at Yonkers Raceway tonight. Most of the 30,050 fans were familiar with the pacer, but quite a few wondered about the driver.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 16 Marcos P rez Jim nez arrived back in his homeland tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 16 Jean Hitchcock, a member of the E junior training staff at the American Yacht Club, Rye, N.Y., captured the Jesse A. B. Smith Trophy today by winning the Long Island Sound Junior Y.R.A. instructors' championship off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Secretary of State Dean Rusk reacted sharply today to an attack on United States policies in Africa by Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar of Portugal.
Cocoa fell and sugar futures were irregular in moderately active trading yesterday. Price movements in most other New York commodities were narrow and trading was quiet.

Joseph M. Levine, a former Magistrate's Court judge and candidate for Controller of New York City, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 220 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Dr. Harold Liverworth, writing in his syndicated column, "Aches and Pains," is exhilarated by the spreading popularity of skydiving. He recommends it to the middle-aged for its excellent stretching action on the spine, but believes that it offers unique therapeutic values for unhappy adolescents.

GENEVA, N.Y., Aug. 16 Mrs. Doris Bell Nestor was married here this noon to Clifford Pace.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 Three home runs in the ninth inning by Tom Tresh, Hector Lopez and Cletis Boyer tonight produced the most shocking instance yet of the recently instituted Yankee policy of lastmoment murder. They produced a 4-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox who fell, stunned, into third place.

LONDON, Aug. 16--Two traveling bags containing 109,000 ($305,200), believed to be more of the haul from the British mail-train robbery, were found today in the Dorking woods, in southern England.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 18--"The standing army everywhere and in all countries," Lenin wrote, "is intended for use not so much against the external as the internal enemy." While Turkey's large standing army has the function of protecting this country against Russia, it also intervenes in politics. The trouble is that sometimes its officers disagree on who the "internal enemy" is.
Leonard Cox, Planning Commissioner for the Virgin Islands and a former New York architect, died in Saint Thomas last Monday. He was 69 years old.

Henry Rothman, a manufacturer of childrens' coats who headed his own concern until his retirement three years ago, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Rothman, who lived at 25 Central Park West, was 80 years old.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 18 --A program designed to increase national exports by stim-- ulating activity at the local business level has been announced by the International Marketing Institute.
LONDON, Aug. 18--A black sports car that may have been bought with money from the Cheddington mail train robbery was found abandoned in a parking lot at London Airport tonight.

AFTER spending the first six weeks of summer in serious research, a charter member of the girl watcher's society declared recently that he could differentiate between a New Yorker and a woman from out of town by subjecting them to a long, critical glance. Hats, hairdos, shoes and a certain il ne sait quoi were the clues that this detective used.

Daniel Nicoll, a newspaperman who began his career at the age of 12 and wound up as associate publisher of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette and a vicepresident of The Toledo Blade and The Toledo Times, died Saturday in French Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 1192 Park Avenue.

WHILE silhouette and hemline changes are gradually evolving in outerwear, the changes in corsetry have been dramatic. Corset manufacturers today refer to their products as fashion accessories, and key them carefully to the shape and colors of outerwear.

Mayor Wagner challenged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to support new measures in the next session of the Legislature to provide jobs for Negroes in the construction industry.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 18--Even the best vineyards do not produce a great vintage every year. On paper, the 1963 Edinburgh Festival, which opened today with Berlioz's "Damnation of Faust," conducted by Georg Solti, looks less good than its two predecessors.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 18-- A French-bred Skye terrier from Oyster Bay, L.I., went best in show today at the first all-breed event held by the Elmira Kennel Club.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (UPI) --A New York widow was reunited here last night with a brother she had not seen for 34 years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18-- The human touch has crept into one Washington lobbyist's reports to the people who sent him here.

THERE is something about a duck that brings a gleam to the average chef's eye. It provides an opportunity to demonstrate culinary ability with some exotic sauce. The mere sight of the succulent bird seems to conjur up visions of oranges or cherries, liqueurs or brandies, with which to crown its natural glory.
ALBANY Aug. 18--Governor Rockefeller, facing a critical period in his political career, told state agencies today to cut their budget requests to "the minimum."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18--"Good evening, ladies and gentlemen of the radio audience and welcome to another network mini-chat, the program that brings America two minutes of elevating thought by the nation's most elevated thinkers. United States shipbuilding prices are on the rise, bucking a worldwide trend in which foreign shipyards are accepting work at starvation prices," according to a study by the Committee of American Steamship Lines.

This country's most exploited workers, its half-million migratory farm laborers, got half a loaf last week when the Senate voted to keep alive the program under which hundreds of thousands of Mexicans have been brought in to harvest United States crops. The Senate authorized a one-year extension, but it softened the hurt its action would inflict on domestic migrants by requiring that they be offered benefits equal to those guaranteed the Mexican laborers.

It is said heaven will protect the working girl. That leaves Congress to protect the small-businessman. And protect him it will, if tax reductions go through as framed last week by the House Ways and Means Committee.
SHREVEPORT, La., Aug. 18 --Miss Helen Leona Lefkowitz, daughter of Rabbi David Lefkowitz Jr. and Mrs. Lefkowitz, was married tonight to Daniel Horowitz in her parents' home.

TRENTON, Aug. 18 (AP)-- Mario (Fats) Caruso of Shrewsbury, Mass., made only one pit stop and then nursed his failing auto across the finish line in winning the 200-mile NASCAR national championship race today at Trenton Speedway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18-- Ren Chalmers, Foreign Minister of Haiti, said today that an armed band of Haitian ex iles staged a second invasion attempt from the Dominican Republic last week, but was repelled by Government forces.
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- Prices dipped slightly last week on the London Stock Exchange, but financial observers said the undertone was firm.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 18-- India's decision, announced yesterday, to send Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's sister, Mrs. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, to the United Nations General Assembly session this year, is seen here as preparation for a possible debate on the Kashmir issue.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 18 (AP)--Ch. Star's Autumn Haze of North'boro, a pug, led a field of 627 today to win the best-inshow award at the 12th Annapolis Kennel Club dog show.
James Farmer, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, said yesterday that the city was "on the threshold" of an agreement to end discrimination in the construction industry.
SIBU, Sarawak, Aug. 18 (Reuters)--A British officer died today of wounds received in a clash with Indonesianbased guerrillas in the southeast Sarawak border area adjoining Indonesian Borneo.

TOKYO, Aug. 18 (AP)--United States swimmers set two more world records and equaled a third today at the sixth United States-Japan swimming and diving meet. The Americans have snapped four records in two days.

John Loeschhorn, a 19-yearold New York University sophomore, and Ron Gustafson a 16year-old Wantagh (L.I.) High School junior, yesterday scored victories in yesterday's Road Runners' Club's 5,000-meter runs in the Bronx.

ROME, Aug. 18--Pope Paul VI appealed to Orthodox churches today to unite with Roman Catholicism under "a common and solid creed." He offered to regraft their "great flowering" onto "the only tree of unity, of Christ."

Joan Baez unwrapped several surprises Saturday night for a capacity audience of 14,700 at the Forest Hills Music Festival at the Tennis Stadium in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18-- A subtle but important difference of opinion divides the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Justice over the extent to which the securities industry should be placed outside the reach of the antitrust laws.

DESPITE two unlucky breaks, grand master Fridrik Olafsson of Iceland scored 7 -6 and tied for third and fourth places with Miguel Najdorf of Argentina in the recent Piatigorsky Cup tournament. Considering the competition at Los Angeles, the achievement was remarkable.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18--Svetozar Gligoric, the Yugoslav grand master, Stayed in front in the United States Open Chess Championship at the Belmont Hotel here last night by defeating Ivan Theodorovich of Toronto in a king's Indian defense in 86 moves.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 18 --Iraqi officials met recently with representatives of the Kurdish insurgent leader, Gen. Mullah Mustafa al-Barzani, in an attempt to end the rebellion in northern Iraq. Private Kurdish sources said the meeting had taken place at the Kurdish village of Raniah.

MRS. VIJAYA LAKSHMI PANDIT, who is returning to diplomacy as the chief of India's delegation to the coming session of the United Nations General Assembly, has served her country both in international affairs and as an aristocratic rebel in the fight for Indian independence.

NORWICH, Vt., Aug. 18-- The marriage of Miss Nancy Ballard, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. William Ballard, to Lester Seigel took place here today. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Seigel of Springfield, Mass. Judge Peter Plante of the Municipal Court of Hartford (Vt.) performed the ceremony at the Ballard home.
The city's Superintendent of Schools will ask the Board of Education to discontinue the 100-year-old mandated practice of Bible reading at school assemblies.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 18--We're Here II, a Triton Class boat owned by A.C. Watkins of the Port Washington Yacht Club, won the Huntington Yacht Club's 25th Heckscher Memorial Trophy race today by recording a corrected time of 8 hours 40 minutes 15 seconds for the 45-mile overnight event on Long Island Sound.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18-- Creation of the Allagash National Riverway in northern Maine at a cost of $7,450,000 was recommended today by the Department of the Interior.
REMSENBERG, L.I., Aug. 18 --Walter Kidde of Quiogue won the Gil M. Smith Memorial Cup here today in the Westhampton Yacht Squadron's hotely contested Old-Timers Invitation Regatta.

In France anyone who wants to bet on a horse race can walk into his neighborhood cafe instead of going out to the track. In New Zealand bettors in city, suburb and village can go to a sedate, rather bank-like, office to put up their money.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 (UPI)--Billy Casper Jr., out of action for three months with an injured hand, made up five strokes in the final round today to win the $40,000 Insurance City open golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 271.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18-- The United States girls' lawn tennis singles championship was taken by an Easterner for the first time since 1939 when third-seeded Julie Heldman of New York defeated top-seeded Janie Albert of Pebble Beach, Calif., 6--3, 7--5, today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

Two assistant district attorneys from, Queens plan to go to the Federal penitentiary at Leavenworth, Kan., soon to question Vito Genovese, the underworld leader who is serving a sentence for a narcotics violation.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 18--Three infiltrators from Arab territory were slain in the Negev over the weekend in two separate encounters with Israeli forces, it was announced here today.

The National Industrial Conference Board estimated yesterday that 2 per cent of the nation's entire working population--including nearly one out of every three scientists and engineers--was engaged in research and development.

An underwater sound beacon, using strontium 90 as its energy source, is being developed as a navigational aid by the Martin Company Nuclear Division, the Atomic Energy Commission announced here yesterday.
An attempt to break a 110year-old world record for trotting a horse 100 miles may be stopped before it begins.

Real estate promoters seeking to register syndication securities for sale in New York State must henceforth state in the prospectus that the use of realty upon which the securities are based, even outside the state, will not be refused to anyone because of race, religion or national origin.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 18--Robert Young of the Westhampton Beach Yacht Squadron, with two second-place finishes, moved into the lead today for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup. The competition is being sailed in 210 Class sloops.

Peter G. Levathes, former executive vice president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation is returning to the advertising business.

A special ejection system to allow a pilot to escape from an aircraft when there is no forward speed and little or no altitude has been built for the United States Army. The 100-pound ejection seat system will be used in three new experimental VTOL (vertical takeoff and landing) aircraft.

Civil disobedience has had a "decisive role" in breaking down racial barriers and Christians should not be loath to use it, a Bronx Presbyterian minister asserted yesterday.

Actors Equity Association may never join hands across the sea with the British Actors Equity, but the two performers' labor unions agreed yesterday on a proposal that should ease Anglo-American theatrical tension.
