More than 200,000 commuters braced yesterday for what may be the worst transportation scramble in the city's history if the nationwide railroad strike threatened for tomorrow materializes.

Technical Films Lab, Inc., a motion picture laboratory for the television and theatrical industries, has leased the entire third floor at 1150 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), between 44th and 45th Streets.
Seventy-six players from a11 the continents outside of North America arrived by plane from Amsterdam yesterday to compete in the amateur tennis championships of the United States.

WHEN Arthur Kopit was a young lad--younger than he is now--he probably was lost in a fun house at an amusement park. Or perhaps he had a nightmare in which he found himself on the dragon slide with the laughing lady. Maybe he read Dr. Spock when he should have been studying Batman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 --The House Agriculture Committee rejected today attempts to offer competing American farm workers the same employment and racial antidiscrimination benefits that Mexicans receive under the bracero program.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 27--A $29,000,000 county public works program to help alleviate rising . unemployment in the construction trades was announced today by Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 27--Thomas (Rabbi Tom) Trantino and Frank Falco were indicted today by the Bergen County grand jury on charges of murdering Dectective Sgt. Peter Voto and Gary Tedesco in Lodi yesterday.
President Kennedy urged American hospitals yesterday to see that all citizens received equal and expanded opportunities for health care.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug, 27 --Nearly every police department and gasoline station from New York to Washington wanted to know one thing today: How many buses would come south for the march on Washington?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)--The United States and Japan signed an agreement today authorizing a 3 per cent increase in Japanese cotton textile imports in 1964 and a further 5 per cent increase in 1965.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI)--President Kennedy's back is acting up again and he has been showing a limp while walking or climbing stairs in the last few days.

ATHENS, Aug. 27--It is unlikely we will ever know precisely what Tito and Khrushchev have been saying to each other at the Marshal's sybaritic Brioni retreat. Some years after participating in earlier SovietYugoslav talks, Milovan Djilas recalled their substance in "Conversations with Stalin." But Djilas is now in jail. It is improbable that anyone in the Tito-Khrushchev entourage is preparing another indiscretion.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 27--The Congolese Parliament has been called into special session to draft a new constitution for the Congo.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 27--A second place in a race that was rampant with confusion kept Joe Duplin of the Boston Harbor fleet the leader today in the Star Class North American sailing championship.

Three acres at the intersection of Getty Avenue and the Garden State Parkway in Cliftonn, N.J., have been sold by the Brook Chemical Corporation to the Murray Construction Company of Springfield, N.J. Richard M. Jacobs of the Louis Schlesinger Company was the broker.

ASSISI, Italy, Aug. 27 (UPI) --When Premier Khrushchev's son-in-law asked Pope John XXIII whether there could be closer contacts between the Kremlin and the Vatican, the late Pontiff replied: "It needs time. For now we can only hope and pray:"

THE New York City Ballet has returned to the City Center for a five-week fall season that will run through Sept. 29, and the way things were looking by the end of "Concerto Barocco" last night, the season promises to be a rewarding one.
WASHINGTON, Aug 27-- Members of the Conservative party from New York have taken the first steps toward a working alliance with likeminded members of the state's Republican delegation in the House.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest producer of automobile tires, plans to acquire a leading manufacturer of wheels for automobiles and trucks.
Dame Alicia Markova began her first season as director of the Metropolitan Opera Ballet yesterday with tryouts to fill nine vacancies for the coming opera season.
New Haven, Conn., borrowed $7,678,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance various city projects.

NEWARK, Aug. 27--Three young sisters and a small boy, his grandmother and his aunt died today in a fire in a 12family tenement. Two women and four children were injured leaping from the top floor of the three-story building.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--A vanguard of tens of thousands of Americans arrived tonight for the civil rights march on Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--The reaction of the white or northwest section of Washington to this week's big Negro demonstration is mainly one of annoyance. For a whole day, inhabitants of this privileged sanctuary won't be able, to buy a drink at a bar, or get a taxi downtown, or count on the colored cook coming in for dinner. Think of the white man's burden!
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- Leaders of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters met today to establish the machinery to negotiate its first national trucking-labor contracts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- A New Jersey committee of pediatricians reported to Congress today that only a few states had developed programs to protect children against the health hazard of radioactive fallout.

Hellenic Lines Limited has asked one of the nation's highest courts to order a United States marshal to serve a summons on Habib Bourguiba Jr., Ambassador from Tunisia, in a $13,175 action for an unpaid port bill.

Jim Bouton, the flame-throwing young right-hander of the Yankees, came within three outs of hurling the seasons first no-hitter in the American League at the Stadium last night as the Yankees defeated the Red Sox, 5--0, in the first half of a double-header before a crowd of 34,319.
ISRAEL became a member of the European Bridge League this month by a vote of 12 to 2, with four members of the league abstaining.

MADRID, Aug, 27 (AP)-- Premier Fidel Castro is the hero of most of the 54 American students waiting here for a plane home from the six-week vacation he financed for them in Cuba. However, several were disenchanted with the way things move--or do not move --on his Communst island.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27-- Even to those who may be inured by exposure to the ability of the New York Mets to fritter away a ball game at the last moment, tonight's 2-1 loss to the Pittsburgh Pirates, is hard to describe and harder to believe.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 27--The report of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization on Syrian and Israeli complaints produced a generally favorable reaction in Israel today.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen was enjoined last night from interrupting service on the Long Island Rail Road today, as it had earlier threatened to do. The union said it would comply with the court order.
SANTA FE, Aug. 27 (UPI) --A State Court judge warned the New Mexico legislature today that it had until Nov. 1 to reapportion the House of Representatives or he would do it himself.

ATLANTA, Aug, 27 (AP)-- Midnight explosions, both related to school integration, occurred in Louisiana and South Carolina as the South prepared for the fall opening of schools. No one was hurt by either blast.

Thomas Richardson, a former leader in the labor and civil rights fields, and most recently in advertising, died yesterday in the City Hospital at Elmhurst, Queens. He was 51 years old and lived at 27-47 Gilmore Street. East Elmhurst.

PULA, Yugoslavia, Aug. 27 --Premier Khrushchev and President Tito ended two days of official talks on Brioni Island today in "full mutual understanding and agreement on substantive questions of international development."

An imaginary street, known in Greenwich Village as the "road to nowhere," has been rerouted by the city back to what it has always been--a place for people to live.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 27.--The Secretary General, U Thant, conferred separately with Israeli and Syrian representatives today in his continuing effort to ease the tension along the Israeli-Syrian border.

WHEN Carl. J. Weinhardt Jr., a tall and noticeably handsome man 35 years old, accepted the directorship of Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art, the news surprised nearly everybody and dismayed most of his friends.

The Symphony of the Air is faced with a financial crisis that threatens its existence. Its debts have piled up to such an extent that if outside aid is not found shortly the orchestra, which has survived for nine seasons as a cooperative, will have to call it quits.

New York will be the setting for the feature film "The Pawnbroker," which goes into production on Sept. l6. The Landau Company, under whose aegis it will be produced, announced yesterday that Rod Steiger had been signed to play the title role.

Richard Harris, the Irish-born London star, is set for the title role in "Kelly," the 'musical 'by Eddie Lawrence and Moose Charlap. He will portray a young man, who after three attempts, musters enough courage to jump from the Brooklyn Bridge and becomes a hero.

The streets in and around Harlem have become a schoolroom for more than 150 children as a result of a casual effort by a former public school teacher. She and more than 70 others now are devoting their free time to tutoring, whereever there is need for individual instruction.

It will give away, absolutely free, to the horseplaying sweetie pies--brace yourself for this --trading stamps.

Scientists from the U.S. Public Health Service have been sent to Puerto Rico to investigate what may be an epidemic of dengue fever, an illness extremely rare in the Western Hemisphere during the past decade. It is transmitted to man only by the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which also is the carrier of yellow fever.

LONDON in 1752 was an overcrowded, dirty, unhealthy city. Fifteen-year-old Richard Larkin, an orphan from Philadelphia, quickly discovers that it is also a very dangerous city.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Aug. 31 (AP)--The Chicago White Sox took second place in the American League race today with a 2-0 victory over the Minnesota Twins on consecutive home runs in the ninth inning by Jim Landis and Floyd Robinson.
Many begonias, African violets, gardenias, geraniums, philodendrons and scheffleras have been spending the summer outdoors. But their vacation period is over, and the plants should be taken inside.

SEWANEE, Tenn., Aug. 31-- Miss Sarah Barnwell Elliott Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Reed Howe of Lookout Mountain, was married here this morning to William Wolverton Kirby-Smith, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Tompkins Kirby-Smith.
ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP)-- The Rockefeller administration said today that state revenue from personal income taxes would be $35,000,000 under original estimates for the current fiscal year.

THE Symphony of the Air is sick. It is too early to make any prognosis, but things do not look good for the organization. It is in debt, and it does not have the money to proceed with plans for the coming season (and some of those plans are elaborate). Unless a sum in the vicinity of $200,000 can be raised, it is most possible that the orchestra that refused to die will indeed die.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31--United Nations peacekeeping efforts in Yemen were heading into a crisis today. Only four days are left of the term for which they were financed and no early success in ending the fighting is in prospect.
The skyscraper being built by the Columbia Broadcasting System on the Avenue of the Americas, between 52d and 53d Streets, will have a striking facade of rough-surfaced black granite.

The country's stores--big, little, department, discount variety, chain--were crowded last week with young people and their mothers, all after a thousand and one essentials for the trek back to school. Sportswear, dresses, suits, footwear, children's wear, typewriters, notebooks, pencils and a variety of other types of merchandise, including even furniture or curtains for a dormitory room, shared in a bonanza of buying.
BERRYVILLE, Va., Aug. 31 --Senator Harry F. Byrd, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, wondered aloud today whether President Kennedy really needed all those planes, yachts and limousines.
"The day way important in itself and what we do with this day is even more important."

Waltz Song glided to victory in the $29,050 Maskette Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. The 5-year-old mare, owned by Thomas White, took the onemile race for fillies and mares by three lengths over Linita of the D.C. Stable. Ada L. Rice's Doll Ina was next, 1 lengths farther back.
Cuba's foreign policy pronouncements have again acquired a tone of strident aggressiveness that has been rising in pitch as if to jar negotiations for improved East-West relations.

The New York Giants will play the Green Bay Packers in Green Bay, Wis., tomorrow night and there are three fairly predictable events concerning the game. The new Green Bay City Stadium will be filled to the last seat in the last row; Sam Huff will be booed as he has never been booed before while Jim Taylor receives cheers, and the Packers will win because they have the better football team.

While some 50,000,000 American students have spent a relaxed two months or so, publishers of 150,000,000 mindstretchers have started on another record sales year. In fact, the textbook publishers speak of sales for the year to next June 30 running 10 to 20 per cent ahead of the preceding year's volume.
ATLANTA, Aug. 31--The march on Washington, whether successful or not in generating new support among Congressmen for civil rights legislation, had other significant results.

BLACKPOOL, England, Aug. 31--Bobby McGregor of Scotland broke his world 110-yard free-style record tonight during the national swimming championships. His time of 54.1 seconds bettered his mark of 0.54.4 set here last month.

The post-world war II surge in college enrollments will resume in force in September, 1964, according to Robert J. Keir, president of the Tuition Plan, Inc., which handles installment financing of college educations for thousands of students annually every year.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 31 --Some students of the sun believe that more has been learned about our parent star in the past few years than during the period since Galileo first discovered spots on its surface.
Main Street and Wall Street are on the alert as children troop back to school. For the ring of school bells once again means the jingle of cash registers to businessmen across the nation.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 31--Now that Sandy Koufax of the Los Angeles Dodgers has become the major leagues' first 20-game winner of the season, a merry scramble in the pitching industry is almost certain to follow in the remaining four weeks of the campaign.
Toronto and New York are fast becoming the field laboratories in a friendly competition to speed traffic flow by the use of electronic devices.

HOLLYWOOD. "I OUGHT to call this pic ture '417 2-5,'" said George Marshall, who is observing his 50th anni versary as a director by making his 417th movie, "Company of Cowards." The meaning of the two-fifths, in the title he leaves to the imagination. It is either what he drinks the day he finishes a movie, or odd parts of movies he did for others some years ago.
AT the age of 77 Hugo LaFayette Black has completed 26 years as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, a tenure exceeded in the past by only 16 members of that Court.
A jet-age airport is being built at "the place where the symbol of the Corn Goddess exists."
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 31--Alabama is preparing for its first step toward public school desegregation Monday in an atmosphere of tension and rising concern.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31--The Government held a long-awaited rally this morning, but the crowd was far smaller than had been expected. Thirty to forty thousand people attended. At least 150,000 had been expected.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 31--The European Commom Market after five years of smooth sailing apparently is heading into some stormy balance-of-payments weather.

DENVER, Aug. 31 (UPI)-- Dave Hill, a 26-year-old Jackson (Mich) pro, shot a oneunder-par 69 today and retained his lead through the third round of the $35,000 Denver open golf tournament. Hill had a 204 total.

Franklin Cole, president of the Marine Historical Association, which operates Mystic Seaport in Connecticut, has urged his members to search for a full-time paid director to manage the affairs of the association.

HERE we are at Labor Day, the dividing line, and where are we? The crystal ball shows some identifiable lights--the announced museum exhibitions and a big benefit show or two. These are the solid base of a season, but they don't supply its sparkle, its life, its surprises and discoveries. These come through the gallery shows. And here much is darkness.

Approximately 100 outstanding amateur cyclists will start in today's 100-mile Long Island dirt track bicycle championship at 1 o'clock at the Long Island Fair, Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I. They will compete for the Howard B. Wakeman Challenge Cup. Wakeman is the president of the Long Island Fair.

Business is continuing "at a satisfactory pace" through the summer doldrums and the vacation period. So report the country's purchasing agents, the men who buy materials and supplies for industry, in the monthly accounting of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31-- Congress averted a railroad strike this week, but at what cost to the free institution of collective bargaining?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)--The Agriculture Department reports the foreign economic outlook for the fiscal year ending next June 30 points to a continuation if not an expansion of recent high exports of United States agricultural commodities.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP)-- Dr. Stephen Rothman, dermatologist and professor emeritus of medicine at the University of Chicago, died today at the university hospital. He was 68 years old.

All work used in the glory of God and beneficial to man is holy, the Rev. Peter J. Dexnis said in a sermon yesterday.
BERKELEY, Caiif., Sept. 1-- Observations made this year in the United States and in recent years in Europe indicate that the crust of the restless earth is in constant vertical motion.

The trans-Atlantic chicken war seemed to be nearing a climax over the weekend as activity quickened on both sides of the ocean.

DENVER, Sept. 1 (UPI)-- Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez of Puerto Rico overtook Dave Hill on the back nine today to win the $35,000 Denver open, his first professional golf tournament victory.

John J. Lamula appealed yesterday to Richard S. Aldrich to hurry home from South America so that they could discuss the issues in their race for the Republican nomination for councilman at large in Manhattan.

President Kennedy is following an honorable and useful tradition in making a trip to 10 states in order to inspect national parks and seashores, wilderness areas and other conservation projects. Every President since Franklin D. Roosevelt has made such trips.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 --New York has something that is envied by a group of San Francisco esthetes--a regulation considerably stricter than this city's for controlling the density of buildings in downtown commerical areas.

ADEN, Sept. 1--A civil war between Moslem sects in the already embattled Yemen Republic seems imminent if the negotiations between President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and President Abdullah Al-Salal of Yemen prove fruitless.
LONDON, Sept. 1--Mary Somerville, a pioneer of educational broadcasts in Britain, died at her home in Bath today. She was 65 years old.

About 2,600,000 workers returning to their jobs tomorrow will receive raises of up to 10 cents an hour. The increases are the result of changes in the Federal minimum wage law.

A group of 20 Brooklyn ministers announced yesterday that they were prepared to open their churches as Freedom Schools if the Board of Education failed to produce a suitable timetable for school integration.

Cambodia's Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, has carried out his threat to break off diplomatic relations between his Buddhist kingdom and South Vietnam. His action was motivated by the Diem Government's crackdown on its Buddhist opponents and by what he claims to be new South Vietnamese military violations of Cambodia's borders.
WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 1 (AP)--Alfred B. Carb, a New York real-estate lawyer, died today in his sleep at his summer home. He was 61 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1-- The peace of the last long weekend of the summer lay over the capital today, and Washingtonians luxuriated in the golden radiance of the early autumn sun.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Sept. 1--Trinidad is making a determined effort to maintain her high standard of living.
After two years of test marketing, the Bristol-Myers Company will introduce three products tomorrow.
NEW DELHI, Sept 1--United States arms aid to India appears to be almost as embarrassing politically to the Government here as it is useful militarily.

NEW DELHI, Sept 1--President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan announced tonight a temporary doubling up of jobs in the Cabinet of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru following the resignation of six ministers last week.

A special investigative committee appointed by Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon has found that an overhaul of the nation's judicial system as it relates to maritime cases "is sorely needed."

The Rev. Avery B. Dulles, a Jesuit theologian, called on the Roman Catholic laity yesterday to help to unite Christendom. He called it "a living scandal" that Christians "are not joined in one fold, led by the same pastors."

LADENTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 1--Mrs. Cheever Porter's Irish setter, Ch. Tyronne Farm Rex, took best in show in a record entry of 873 at today's Rockland County Kennel Club show.

ATLANTA, Sept. 1--Southern newspapers have given extensive coverage and prominent display to the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom. A number commented favorably on the conduct of the demonstrators, but most disagreed with their specific objective of new civil rights legislation.

The New York Mets yesterday recalled 14 players from the minors. Seven will report this season. These transactions, ordinarily routine, this time reflected the recent furor caused by the disclosure of disagreement between Manager Casey Stengel and George Weiss, the Club president, concerning personnel.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 1--As the 24th Venice Film Festival moved into its second and final week today, observers sought a clear-cut favorite, though some films shown over the weekend triggered critical debates and elicited raves.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1--Pickets marched again today in protest against installation of mobile classrooms. About 60 Negroes paraded at the Guggenheim Elementary School. They said they had been "double-crossed" by the City Board of Education.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 1-- Three of the four plays for the 1964 season at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater were announced Saturday by the Minnesota Theater Company. Opening the season will be Shakespeare's "Henry V" and Shaw's "St. Joan."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP)--The Los Angeles Dodgers rallied today for three runs in the eighth inning, two of them on a double by a pinchhitter, Wally Moon, and maintained their six-game National League lead by defeating the San Francisco Giants, 5--3.

The Moregrand Realty Company of New York, realty investing concern, has purchased and taken title to the building containing 94 apartments at 147-15 Northern Boulevard, at Central Avenue, in Flushing, Queens.

The marriage of Miss Jane Alicia Rapaport, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving N. Rapaport of 799 Park Avenue, to Barton A. Shallat took place here last evening. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Shallat of Cincinnati.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 1-- A stranger from New York, up for the Labor Day weekend, expressed astonishment today to learn that he needed a registration number for the sleek new powerboat he was trying out on Candlewood Lake.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1-- Senator Barry Goldwater is embarking on a two-month journey to sell his brand of conservative Republicanism in 10 states that will have strong voices in naming the Republican Presidential nominee next year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3-- An eager young man, direct from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, walked into the M. H. De Young Memorial Museum today and took over his first job as a major museum director.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 3--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru indicated today that India would have to break an agreement with the United States for a high-powered radio transmitter unless the agreement was changed to conform with India's policy of nonalignment.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)--Senator Jacob K Javits teamed today with a fellow New York Republican, Governor Rockefeller, in attacking the Administration's handling of the balance-of-payments deficit.

MEN who work on the night shift often have difficulty maintaining stable family relationships, a group of researchers reported recently at a meeting of the American Sociological Association in Los Angeles.
GENEVA, Sept. 3 (UPI)-- Gen." Fazlollah Zahedi, former Premier of Iran, died here last night of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3-- The first major follow-up study of a massive "talent search" in the nation's high schools shows that the pool of talent could be doubled by the use of broadrange tests, two researchers said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) --Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor said, in testimony made public today, that he and other members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff assumed the Soviet Union would attempt to conduct clandestine tests prohibited by the partial nuclear test ban treaty.

MALVERNE, L.I., Sept. 3-- The executive board of the Woodfield Road Elementary School Parent-Teacher Association resigned today because the Malverne School board has not ended racial imbalance in the school district.
A London street sweeper scored a clean sweep in Times Square yesterday.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 3 --George Emlen Roosevelt, banker and yachtsman and a second cousin of President Theodore Roosevelt, died today in his home, Gracewood. He was 75 years old.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 3--Changing times are penetrating the long-inviolate gates of Tuxedo Park.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 3--The Haitian Government has requested an urgent meeting of the Security Council to consider Haiti's dispute with the Dominican Republic.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 3--Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd offered tonight to take over the British protectorates bordering South Africa.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3--This year's fashions in diplomacy, like this year's dresses by Dior, leave very little to the imagination. They disclose more than they conceal: naked diplomacy is now the fad.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Sept. 3--The "national route" from Katanga to the sea was reopened today after three years of chaos, war and secession.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 3-- Tentative plans for a Tanglewood type of shed on Nassau County's North Shore to house future summer productions of the Long Island Festival of the Arts were made known today.
The result of the vote in tomorrow's primary election for the Republican nomination for councilman at large in Manhattan is likely to have important political consequences.

WITH an impetuous sweep of his race quet Dennis Ralston sent the ball arching over the stands during the recent national doubles championship at Brookline, a championship he was to win with Chuck McKinley. The next day a critical Boston journalist referred to him as the Dick Stuart of tennis.

Israel and the West won a victory for morality in the United Nations Security Council yesterday, even if the Soviet Union did have the final word in vetoing the indirect condemnation of Syria for the "wanton murder" of two young Israeli farmers on the Israel-Syria frontier.
The first Soviet manned landing on the moon may come within three years and the first manned spaceship around the moon as early, as next year, according to an article in a Hungarian magazine.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3--Chicago port officials accused Eastern port interests today of serving "their own selfish interests" in seeking higher tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway.

ABERDEEN, Scotland, Sept. 3--British botanists have learned how to "shrink" plants by growing them in a wild tunnel. Their belief is that if they can reproduce the shrinking effect by chemical methods, some deserts could be cultivated with miniature breeds of drought and wind resistant crop plants.

MOSCOW, Sept. 2--"Two for the Seesaw," an American play that was pronounced ideologically unacceptable after its Moscow premiere last winter but continued to run despite repeated criticism, has now been grudingly declared a box-office hit.

STUDENT comfort and mischievousness are but two of the considerations that Eugene L. Seeley had in mind in designing the furnishings and interiors for New York University's Joe Weinstein Residence Halls.

Mayor Wagner campaigned for three hours amid intermittent rain showers last night in behalf of Richard M. Flynn, insurgent candidate for the Democratic nomination for councilman at large in the Bronx.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 3--Several celebrated playwrights voiced strong objection here today to the labels that critics hang on them.

Clyde Lee Grosscup, the poetquarterback from Santa Monica, Calif., lost his job yesterday, his employment by the New York Jets severed when the pro football teams of the National and American Leagues cut their rosters.
The inherent class and weight-carrying ability of the New York horseplayer was strikingly demonstrated yesterday at Aqueduct.
"The Cardinal," a film dealing with religious conflicts within the Roman Catholic Church, will have its world premiere on Dec. 11 under the sponsorship of Richard Cardinal Cushing of Boston.
MRS. DONNA MAE MIMS, the first woman driver to win a Sports Car Club of America national championship, hasn't been carried away by her success. She plans to
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 3 (AP)--Indonesia has filed a strong protest against Malaya's insistence on forming the Federation of Malaysia Sept. 16.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (UPI)-- Sonny Liston stole the show tonight when he paid a surprise visit to Shoreditch Town Hall, There he saw Jimmy McGrail, a welterweight, score his 17th consecutive victory--an eightround decision over Wilson Harris of Chicago.
Civil rights groups continued their preparations yesterday to boycott the city's public schools next week because the Board of Education had not set up a suitable timetable for school integration.
OTTAWA, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press)-- The largest trade balance in at least a decade appeared to be shaping up for Canada on the basis of export gains in the first seven months of the year.

TRENTON, Sept. 3--Leaders of craft unions in Elizabeth agreed today to consider competitive testing for the selection of apprentices. But they rejected a demand by civil rights groups that two nonwhites be admitted immediately to each apprentice program.
Everyone knows there are bulls and bears on Wall Street. But what about lions, elephants, zebras, impalas, kongonis, kudas and dik-liks?
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 3 (AP) -- A test pilot made two flights today in an experimental craft that doesn't have even a stub of a wing.

The test-ban treaty seems on its way to overwhelming approval by the Senate and the American people, the "hot line" between Moscow and Washington to prevent accidental war is installed and the Kremlin continues to display compara

WHILE so many designers seem bent on making women look like adolescent boys, Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue goes her own blithe, feminine way. She ignores the fuss over the sporty look, her dresses have waistlines, her

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 3--Under Secretary of State George W. Ball told President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan tonight that any close relationship between Pakistan and Communist China would nullify the sense of alliances between the United States and Pakistan.
BONN, Sept. 3--Prof. Hans Mayer, a prominent East German scholar and literary critic, has turned-his back on Communist East Germany and has decided to stay in West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has suggested to President Kennedy that India withdraw its request for United States assistance in constructing the controversial Bokaro steel plant.
The Harris-Intertype Corporation, manufacturer of printing equipment and electronic products, will expand into the business forms business.
The 14 Mosholu Corporation his sold the seven-story apartment building it constructed in 1961 at 6485-95 Broadway, northwest corner of Mosholu Avenue, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

For eight innings at the Polo Grounds yesterday, Joe Nuxhall of the Cincinnati Reds and Tracy Stallard of the New York Mets were locked in a firstclass pitching duel. The only run had been a fifth-inning homer by Marty Keough, the Cincinnati first baseman.

A difference of opinion appeared to be shaping up in the $100,000,000,000 savings and loan industry yesterday over a Government proposal to permit Federally-chartered savings associations to pay extra dividends on long-term accounts.

WHEN Zoe Oldenbourg's first novel, "The World Is Not Enough," was published 15 years ago, it was hailed in this space as the finest historical novel about the Middle Ages of this century, little short of a masterpiece.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- American and Soviet scientists will collaborate in the Antarctic this year in an unusual investigation of cosmic rays.

Governor Rockefeller has been freely giving advice to the Kennedy Administration, as he has a perfect right to do, on how to solve the Federal government's fiscal problems. But the people of New York would also benefit by a fuller explanation from Albany on how the state is doing with its money problems.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 3--The United Nations observation mission in Yemen has been assured two more months of life, United Nations sources said privately today, but has little hope of success.

BERLIN, Sept. 3--East Germany and China are conducting economic negotiations with a view to increasing trade between the two countries, Erwin Kerber, the East German Deputy Trade Minister, disclosed today.
"Archeology--Exploring the Past," at the Metropolitan Museum, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, is a collection of art from Egypt, the Middle East, Greece, Rome and pre-Columbian sites.

WHEN customers at the Food Shop of Abraham Straus examine a cooky tin minutely, chances are it is not flaws, but birthdays that concern the purchasers. The newest cooky hit at this store consists of two pounds of English assorted biscuits in cans that contain personality sketches based on readings of the stars. The birthday tin costs $1.99.
SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 3--Former Premier Song Yo Chan aligned himself today with the Liberal Democratic party, a new party advocating a "coalition of military and civilian political forces."

MOST of the bridge classes formerly taught by Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia, who died early last month, are to be taken over by Alvin Roth of New York, co-inventor of the Roth-Stone bidding system and considered to be the most widely recognized bridge theorist of the postWorld War II period.
Lee Remick and Angela Lansbury have agreed to co-star in Kermit Bloomgarden's production of "Side Show," the Arthur Laurents-Stephen Sondheim musical.
The United States Government decided yesterday to allow Juan O'Gorman, the leftist Mexican painter, to lecture in California.

Cinerama, Inc., developer and producer of the wide-screen process for motion-picture theaters, announced yesterday plans for the formation of an American company to market a proposed British television tape recorder that could be used in the home.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 4--A flaming Swissair jetliner crashed only minutes after take-off from Zurich Airport today, killing the 80 persons aboard, including one-fifth the population of a Swiss village.

Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, Inc., has been awarded the $4,500,000 advertising account of the De Luxe Reading Company, the toy-making subsidiary of the Philadelphia and Reading Corporation. The Zlowe Company is the former agency.
The International Union, of Electrical Workers presented a counter-proposal yesterday in its contract negotiations with the General Electric Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Senate approved today a $322,000,000 bill to continue full Government financing of the manpower development and training program for another year.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 4 -Weeb Ewbank continued to put his house in order today as he pointed the New York Jets toward their opening game in the American Football League, against the Patriots in Boston on Sunday.
Sterling Drug, Inc., is planning to enter the animal-health products field through the proposed acquisition of Whitmoyer Laboratories, Inc., of Myerstown, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Administration officials said today that Ngo Dinh Nhu, the South Vietnamese secret-police chief, was maneuvering to discredit and blackmail the United States. But they found him in a basically insecure position and predicted that his efforts would fail.

WILLIAM LOMBARDY of New York and Robert Byrne of Indianapolis, each scoring 11 2, tied for first place in the recent United States Open in Chicago, with the title going to Lombardy on the tie-breaking count.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP)--The trial of James R. Hoffa and seven other persons, charged with conspiring to divert $1,000,000 in union pension funds, was tentatively set today for Oct. 21.

A show entitled "The Great American Funeral" will be televised next month by the Columbia Broadcasting System. It will contain interviews with members of the funeral industry and with advocates of a reform to eliminate what they consider an extravagance in burial ritual.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) The former South Vietnamese Ambassador to the United States said today that no amount of foreign aid could now carry President Ngo Dinh Diem's regime to victory.

BUFFALO, Sept. 4 A battle over the nominations for two judicial posts is giving Erie County Republicans their bitterest, strangest and possibly most expensive primary fight in the memory of local politicians.
BOONTON, N.J., Sept. 4 Miss Abigail Jane Wootton and Alan Sproul Painter will be married here Nov. 30 in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church.
The way has been cleared for the Port of New York Authority to develop La Guardia Airport for the use of jet aircraft, it was reported here yesterday.
ONCE more the Atlantic flyway duck hunters have the season regulations in hand and are checking over the decoys and repainting the duck boats.
Two floors in the building at 60 Broad Street, have been leased by Spencer Trask Co., security dealers and members of the New York Stock Exchange.

Christ Chapel of the Riverside Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Helen Field Twombly, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gray H. Twombly of New York and Meredith, N.H., to Eric Watkins. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Armitage Watkins of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

YONKERS, Sept. 4 Harold (Sonny) Dancer Jr., the 27year-old reinsman who has been basking in the reflected glory of his uncles (Stanley and Vernon) and his father (Harold Sr.), is favored to reach his highest plateau tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.
BONN, Sept. 4 The West German Cabinet gave its provisional approval today to a compromise proposal to lower tariffs on chicken imports to the six-nation European Economic Community.

THE measure of good taste in journalism is difficult and debatable. The line separating necessary reportorial enterprise and either morbid curiosity or invasion of privacy is a fine one in a society enjoying the viability of different standards.
The Ward Baking Company, which paid its last dividend to common stockholders three years ago, bypassed the preferred shareholders yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 4 (UPI) Frank J. Merrick, Cuyahoga County Probate Court judge, said tonight that Charlayne Hunter and Walter Stovall, had attempted to get a marriage license here on June 4 but had failed because the information they gave was "deficient."
A wildcat strike by car inspectors hit Grand Central Terminal at 3 P.M. yesterday, causing delays up to 90 minutes on the New York Central and New Haven railroads.

SO GIFTED a football player had Lee Grosscup seemed to be that the New York Giants made him their No. 1 draft choice for 1959. And the shrewd Giants rarely make mistakes. But they fumbled the ball on Grosscup. He sat on the bench for three seasons and collected a fancy salary for little work.
The purchase of a 280-acre tract of the former Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney estate in Old Westbury, L.I., by the New York Institute of Technology was announced yesterday.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, Sept. 4 Vice President Johnson made an emphatic defense here tonight of often-criticized United States shipping policies. Goteborg is the largest shipbuilding center in Scandinavia.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 4 John Bateman, beginning his fourth year as Rutgers football coach, said today: "If we win the Princeton game, we're in business."
The possibility of a proxy fight over the 273-store S.H. Kress Co. variety chain became stronger yesterday when Genesco, Inc., said it would buy all tendered Kress shares if 50 per cent were offered.

Governor Rockefeller charged the Kennedy Administration last night with a pattern of "submerging principle to political accommodation and opportunism and therefore of delay in action until a full-blown crisis is upon us."
NEGRO models are breaking into the world of high fa shion, but their progress is slow.
Unusual costs adversely affected results of Miehle-GossDexter, Inc., in the quarter and nine months ended July 27, the printing equipment producer reported yesterday.

THE egg roll may never replace the pizza as a favor ite foreign kickshaw, but it has certainly come into its own within recent months as a popular snack from Mott Street to Coney Island and from Pell Street to Amsterdam Avenue.

Frank Froehling 3d, the forgotten hopeful of United States tennis, scored the most eventful victory in years by an American over an Australian in the national amateur championship yesterday. As a result, Australia has been shut out of the quarter-final round for the first time since 1950.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 French diplomacy has been playing a major antiAmerican role in Saigon since President de Gaulle injected France into the crisis last week.
Roy M. Cohn, a controversial figure of national prominence since the McCarthy era, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday that it had refinanced $100,000,000 of its outstanding debt with foreign central banks and other Governmental institutions in 29 countries.

VICOS, Peru, Sept. 3 The Indian peasants of this Andean community have moved in at decade from servitude and subsistence agriculture to selfgovernment, a share in they money economy and ownership of the land they work.
Leaders of the Liberal party agreed yesterday to endorse Justice Francis Bergan, who is the probable Democratic candidate for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals in the general election Nov. 5.

PRISTINA, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4 (AP) By day, heat waves shimmer over the treeless mountains on the border between Yugoslavia and Albania, deep in the southern Balkans. Occasionally the silence is broken by the call of a shepherd or the cry of a hawk.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 4 The Secretary General, U Thant, conceded today that United Nations peacemaking efforts in Yemen had failed so far and that the United Arab Republic was still sending fresh troops into that Red Sea country.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee and Mike Mansfield, the majority leader, strongly urged the Senate today to ratify the nuclear test ban treaty.
Led by sugar, prices of most commodities futures rose yesterday on the New York exchange.
Professionals in the Government bond market shuffled portfolios yesterday in anticipation of a Treasury advnace refunding announcement. The refunding announcement came just before the market closed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) Strong sales of durable goods increased retail sales in July 1 per cent above the June level and 6 per cent above the July, 1962, level.
The head of Northeast Airlines said yesterday that the company was confident it could prove its contention that the airline route to Florida could support three carriers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 The all-white days of the Portland, Ore., longshoremen's local are at an end, it was announced here today.

A riotous Long Island comingout party last weekend, at which a chandelier, furniture and more than a thousand window panes were broken, underlines a trend of growing delinquency among upper-class and middle-class youth.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Sept.4 The Israeli Government expressed today its "appreciation" of the favorable stand taken by an "overwhelming majority" in the United Nations Security Council on this country's charges of aggression by Syria.
The major tariff and trade negotiations that will open in Geneva next year were envisioned yesterday as facing a long and difficult road.
PARIS, Sept. 4 Robert Schuman, a leader of the postwar movement toward European unity, died today at his home near Metz of a bloodclot in the brain. He was 77 years old.

Maj. Gen. Alexander Dimitriyevich, Yugoslavia's Marshal of the Court under King Alexander I from 1926 to 1934 and a veteran of both World Wars, died of cancer Tuesday in the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. His age was 79 and he lived at 333 East 53d Street.

The contempt of law and courts that the leadership of the United Federation of Teachers continues to express almost daily in preparation for an illegal strike against the New York City school system next Monday is a challenge that must be faced unflinchingly by Mayor Wagner and Governor Rockefeller, as well as the Board of Education.
The 12-story office and store building at 565 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of 46th Street, has been purchased by a group of realty investors headed by Leo J. Margolin and Samuel Futterman.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 4 Supporters of Gov. George C. Wallace persuaded him not to resist court-ordered integration in Birmingham today. They believed a Federal-state clash in that city might set off violence that could not easily be brought under control.

LONDON, Sept. 4 Responsible Britons are calling for widespread reform in the structure of their Government. They hope to revitalize administration and policy-making, which remain much as they were at the end of World War II.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 4 A group of pupils from the predominantly Negro Lincoln School marched to three predominantly white schools this morning and participated in sitin demonstrations at two of them.

Roger Maris hit his 20th home run of the season and first since July 6 at the Stadium yesterday. It was fine for Maris and for the Yanks, but so far as young Jim Bouton was concerned the homer came one inning too late.
MALVERNE, L.I., Sept. 4 A school boycott, two sit-in demonstrations, picketing and the arrest of five Negro parents marked the opening of the school year here today.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 4 Lars Thorn, Sweden's representative, kept the point lead for the national 5.5-Meter Class sailing championship today, but the best racing was among the four Americans who finished ahead of him.
Mr. Jonathan Sheppard, a ruddy-cheeked, 22-year-old amateur rider from England, proved to be a scholar as well as a gentleman yesterday at Aqueduct.
Tens of thousands of investors are paying a needless premium when they buy over-the-counter stocks any securities not traded on an exchange.
The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation announced yesterday that it was seeking to buy a large block of common stock perhaps 1,000,000 shares from its shareholders at $19 a share.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--A union's bargaining rights should not be jeopardized because it has cooperated with the Government to work out a contract dispute in the aerospace industry, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Sept. 4 The Ford Motor Company has spent more than $300,000,000 to bring out a completely restyled line of Ford division cars.

SINGAPORE, Sept. 4 (UPI) Twenty-seven crew members of the American freighter Jacqueline Someck lodged a petition today with the United States Consulate here complaining of ill treatment by the ship' captain.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 4 The third annual women's triangular team golf match was won today by the Women's Cross County Golf Association.

LONDON, Sept. 4 Sterling, the silver penny of medieval England that became the descriptive term for the currency of Britain, stands today as one of the two major reserve currencies and the medium for transacting more than one-third of the world's trade.

The stock market failed to follow the script yesterday. The historic closing Dow-Jones high of 735.90 remained intact, but just barely.

Three young women of Long Island's North Shore were presented to society last night at parties given by their parents in their homes as part of the activities of the September "little season" for debutantes.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 4 Walter Hermann Golde, a composer, accompanist and voice teacher, died at his home here today. He was 76 years old.

The Dow Chemical Company is planning a $100,000,000 offering of 25-year debentures due Sept. 15, 1988, to reduce its short-term indebtedness. The company now has $108,000,000 of bank borrowings and other short-term debt outstanding.

Several prominent figures in sports and business make up the team of investors who completed yesterday the purchase of the Rawlings Sporting Goods Company from A.G. Spalding Bros., Inc., for about $10,500,000.
The advance of the London stock market continued yesterday.

WHERE would the rest of us be," H.L. Mencken once asked, "if we didn't steal his ideas every day?" He was speaking of James Gibbons Huneker (1857-1921), a great roaring critical bull in the American china shops of the arts.
PARIS, Sept. 4 The French Government announced further steps today to regulate the flow of foreign capital into France.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 4 The theater as an art form and means of entertainment and communication came in today for a severe drubbing at the International Drama Conference.

Authorization to build a 299seat theater in Cavanagh's Restaurant at 256 West 23d Street has been requested from the Department of Buildings. Awaiting the approval are Hugh Hardy, architect, and Jo Mielziner, theater and scenic designer.
NEWARK, Sept. 4 An allNegro slate running on a New Frontiers ticket will oppose Democratic and Republican candidates for state and county offices in the Nov. 5 election here.
BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 4 The British Trades Union Congress overwhelmingly endorsed today the idea that its leadership join with the Government and employers in planning the national economy.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 In its outdoor Hearst Greek Theater on the Berkeley campus, the University of California is about to begin a year-long observance of the Shakespeare quadricentennial.
EVERY schoolboy knows that Leonardo da Vinci was interested in art, music, architecture, philosophy, anatomy, botany, cosmology, optics, astronomy, flight, sculpture, mathematics, and city planning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Adm. George W. Anderson, recently replaced as Chief of Naval Operations, expressed grave concern today that a lack of confidence and trust was developing between the military and civilian echelons of the Defense Department.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Treasury announced today a massive advance refunding of $32,100,000,000 worth of securities that would be due next year and in 1966 and 1967.

That fumbling, lethargic giant of South Asia India has been shocked into life and hope, at least momentarily, by Prime Minister Nehru's daring political move. He has swept six of his principal Cabinet Ministers and six States' Chief Ministers out of office and into the hard grind of party politics.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--A final Congressional decision on the fate of Ellis Island was postponed today by the Senate Subcommittee on Intergovernmental Relations until at least next January.
LONDON, Sept. 4--"Man and Boy," Terence Rattigan's latest play with Charles Boyer in the leading role, had a warm reception at its opening at the Queen's Theater here tonight.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. Sept. 4 The young guests at the coming-out party who made a wreck of a rented ocean-front mansion here last weekend will face no criminal charges, the police said today.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Sept. 4 An epidemic of dengue fever is sweeping Puerto Rico, with more than 3,000 cases officially reported. Unofficial reports put the number at more than 10,000.
The nation's two top-ranking airlines, United and American, reported yesterday that they set passenger traffic records during August.
GEORGE EMLEN ROOSEVELT, who died Tuesday at the age of 75, was incontestably the favorite kibitzer of the most expert players at the Cavendish Club and other New York bridge clubs he belonged to.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Consumer installment credit continued to expand at a rapid rate in July, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 Arrests, picketing, neighborhood parent demonstrations, sit-ins and a group complaint at the Board of Education marked the open-...
PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 4 The Minister of External Affairs, Erik H. Louw, conceded today that it would be difficult to find a world leader well disposed toward South Africa.
BELLE CHASSE, La., Sept. 2 Leander H. Perez, who has stopped Negroes from voting and parochial classes from integrating, will attempt on Friday to stop men in uniform from drinking.
The Board of Education heard 50 speakers at its first public hearing yesterday on a proposed school construction budget for 1964-65 totaling a record $220,600,000.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 4 (AP) South Korean military authorities hauled one of their chief opponents out of a hospital bed tonight and took him off to prison. It was the second time in a month that former Premier Song Yo Chang was jailed.
EVERY 10 days a truck rolls into Smithtown, L.I., and from there goes to Rockwood, N.Y. At each place it drops off half a ton of food for the dogs in the two branches of the Dolomount Kennels.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 4--It is the prime function of a festival to provide novelty, and the Edinburgh Festival's last dance visitor is that rare bird, a German ballet company, which gave its first program at the Empire Theater here on Monday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4 Three major Russian "modernist" novels that have long been suppressed and ignored by Soviet critics were the subject of a detailed analysis today in the literary review Novy Mir.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The United States let it be known officially today that a reported proposal by the European Economic Community to reduce very slightly its levy on imported poultry would not be satisfactory.

BERLIN, Sept. 4--United States officials were unable today to find an American in East Berlin who identified himself as Capt. Alfred Svenson, an Army defector, and who said yesterday he was desperately trying to return to the West.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Sept. 4 Walter Winchell Jr. today withdrew assault charges against 14 of the 15 boys who drove a fleet of five cars onto his father's Greenburgh estate on the night of Aug. 24. The case of the 15th defendant was adjourned because his lawyer was absent.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 4 The Right Rev Raymond A. Wegmann, pastor of the Roman Catholic Our Lady of Prompt Succor Church, took a nap today after lunch.
Sperry Rand Corporation, the most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange for the last four days, rose 2 points from 14 last Wednesday to 16 yesterday, equaling its 1963 high.

"Square Dance," George Balanchine's amalgam of classical ballet, baroque music (Corelli and Vivaldi) and country-dance caller, is back in the repertory of the New York City Ballet. It was revived last night at the City Center after a rest period of three years.
The political prestige of Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner will be tested in the Republican and Democratic party primary elections in three boroughs of the city today.

A Brooklyn liquor dealer, joining the mounting protest against a proposed lifting of restrictions on the number of package stores, said yesterday that he had paid $85,000 "just for the key to the store" two years ago.
The novel popularly known as "Fanny Hill" was back in court yesterday after a mother brought action against a bookstore owner for selling a copy to her 16-year-old daughter.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 4--A biologist told a session of the 11th International Conference of Genetics here today that two babies had been born to women who had been artificially inseminated with spermatozoa stored for two months at 196 degrees below zero Centigrade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Administration is reluctantly prepared to drop its plans to help India build a state-owned steel plant at Bokaro.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Sept. 4 United States sources said tonight, after two days of high-level talks here, that Pakistan's intentions toward Communist China and the future of Pakistan's alliances with the West were "still unclear."
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept.4--A 40-year plan for development of the Bridgeport area was announced today. It envisages a doubling of the present population to 550,000.
The first book of a threevolume biography of the late Gen. George C. Marshall will be published Oct. 11 by Viking, under the title "George C. Marshall: Education of a General, 1880-1939."
Communication between the American people and their Government has been expanded to its highest degree since President Kennedy took office.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 Trying desperately to keep up with the league-leading Dodgers, the St. Louis Cardinals survived all sorts of alarms tonight to rack up their seventh straight victory. They had to use five pitchers to defeat the last-place New York Mets, 6 5.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 4 Angola's government in exile threatened today to intensify its war of liberation against Portugal. Holden Roperto, president of the exile group said this was his answer to the hard line taken by Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar.
ON the top floor of Stone House, a triplex antiques establishment at 111 West 10th Street, stands a grim example of late 19th century garden variety furniture.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission has completed initial action on the first 10,000 awards to claimants under the longcontested Philippines war damage program.
The Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers continued to plan yesterday for a teachers' strike even while they went on with their efforts to avert the walkout, scheduled for Monday.
The State of Washington borrowed $35,750,000 yesterday to finance schools and public buildings at an interest cost of 3.091 per cent.
A musician, Robert Atkinson, was standing in a bar at 125th Street and Eighth Avenue with a friend, sadly recounting the loss of his favorite jacket from his ransacked apartment.
A religious controversy has kept a film scheduled for next week's New York Film Festival from being shown in its country of origin.
LONDON, Sept. 4 After climbing to a four-month peak last week, the price of gold in the London bullion market continued today the decline of this week.

Angered over what it called "demands and threats" by the City Labor Department, the Building Industry Referral Committee is ignoring 1,875 Negroes and Puerto Ricans recruited by the city as potential members of all-white or predominantly white building trade unions.
Al Cooper's Herald Square Restaurant, 130 West 36th Street, CH 4-2828. This is a neat and somewhat expensive restaurant that admirably reflects the flavor of Manhattan.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 5 --The Brothers Fay of Houston --Albert with Flame and Ernest at the tiller of Pride--were the ace heavy-weather sailors in today's third race for the 5.5Meter Class national championship.

JUST as surely as ducks start flying south at this time of year, letters describing "revolutionary" new boating products begin fluttering from the mailbag. The descriptions cover everything from inflatable dinghies to detergents for cleaning the bilge.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 5 --Former Col. Talat Aydemir, leader of an unsuccessful revolt on May 21 against the Government of Premier Ismet Inonu, and six other former officers were sentenced to death today by a military tribunal in Ankara.

HUMLIKON, Switzerland, Sept. 5--Emergency aid and sympathetic neighbors poured into this stricken Swiss plateau village today as Humlikoners mourned the loss of one-fifth of their own people in a plane crash near Zurich yesterday.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday the best third fiscal quarter in its history.

ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 5-- The Veterans Administration opened a hearing here today on the alleged refusal of a Florida builder to sell a home to a Negro under the G.I. loan program in an all-white development near Cape Canaveral.

MALVERNE, L.I., Sept. 5-- Five more Negroes were arrested today as school boycotts, a sit-in demonstration and picketing continued in efforts to end racial imbalance in two Nassau County school districts.
Carmine G. De Sapio's dream of rebuilding his old political empire apparently was shattered last night--perhaps permanently.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 5--Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis took a two-stroke lead in the 13th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association senior championship today.

"Buy low, sell high" has long been the basic theory for successful investment. Now that the Dow-Jones industrial average has set a historic high, the memory of the sharp break of May 28 of last year seems dim and far away.

Eight persons who dumped rubbish and demonstrated in City Hall Plaza in a protest on discrimination and poor housing conditions on the Lower East Side received jail sentences of five days and 10 days yesterday in Criminal Court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--A steadily rising trend in business spending for new plants and equipment is expected in the last half of this year, but businessmen's latest plans show a slight downward revision from their projections of June.

BY one of the vagaries of the organizational plan of the American Contract Bridge League, the Hudson Valley Contract Bridge Association, which is conducting a tournament this weekend at Kingston, N.Y., in Ulster County, is officially an offshoot of the Westchester Bridge Association, two counties away as the Hudson flows.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --The Senate Labor Committee approved today President Kennedy's $236,400,000, bill to provide grants for construction of medical schools and loans for medical students. The vote was 13 to 2.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- The United States disclosed today that travel to South Vietnam by American officials and dependents had been restricted.
TRENTON, Sept. 5--Gov. Richard J. Hughes approved today a plan to hasten motorvehicle inspections and thereby end delays long criticized by motorists.

YONKERS, Sept. 5--For the first time in her glamorous career, defeat caught up with Ricci Reenie tonight at Yonkers Raceway. After having turned back all opposition in a dozen outings, Ricci Reenie finished third in the $54,702,50 Bronx Futurity pace before 22,520 fans.

Brown Brothers Harriman Co., said to be the oldest and largest private banking concern in the country, has added to its headquarters in the 35-story Wall Hanover Building at 63 Wall Street by leasing two additional floors. The lease, which is for 10 years, increases ...
The Board of Estimate deferred a vote yesterday on the controversial Breezy Point park proposal until next Wednesday.
Weakening after a strong start, world sugar prices dropped sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

After permitting members of his family to drive his regime to repressive acts that have aroused worldwide protests, President Ngo Dinh Diem has roused himself to reassert his authority as head of South Vietnam. He proclaims that lie is still chief of state and that he--not his brother or sister-in-law--makes state policy.
WHITWELL, Tenn., Sept 1 --From Howard Higgins' quiet, remote mountainside home near here, the view of the Cumberlands is spectacular.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5 (UPI)--The Houston Colts scored four unearned runs in the 10th inning and defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5--2, today.
PRINK HILL. IN the late afternoon a pileated woodpecker swoops into a maple in the dooryard and gives his wild cry.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 5-- Paul Kelly, professional at Sleepy Hollow, and Claude Pattemore of Hamilton, Ont.-- one of 16 players in the national blind golfers' tournament-- teamed with Robert Legg and Howard Fahey for a best-ball of 30 today to win a pro-amateur-celebrity event.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Pamela Reed Brooks to Justin J. Stevenson 3d.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 5 (UPI) --Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves has added another pitch to his arsenal, a knuckleball. The new pitch could add years to his life expectancy in baseball.
The Navy called off its fivemonth search for the nuclear submarine Thresher yesterday. The submarine went down off Cape Cod in 8,400 feet of water last April with 129 men.
GILSON, Ill., Sept. 5 (AP)-- Dr. Harry C. McKown, educator and author of textbooks and books on education, died today at the age of 71.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5--Americans in Saigon believe that Ngo Dinh Nhu, the powerful brother of President Ngo Dinh Diem, has been successful in his palace coup.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Senator Barry Goldwater said today he would introduce a formal reservation to the nuclear test ban treaty, making its effective date conditional on the withdrawal from Cuba of Soviet nuclear weapons, missiles and military personnel.

The factors and forces that shape President Kennedy's decisions are the subjects of a book by Theodore C. STORRS, Conn., Sept. 5-- Still operating on the theory that behind every black cloud football victories linger, Coach Bob Ingalls of the University of Connecticut is working hard to regain his winning touch.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Rain dampened but did not wash out the diplomatic welcome President Kennedy tendered today to King Mohammad Zahir and Queen Homaira of Afghanistan.
Fred Kronish, chairman of the Bensonhurst National Bank in Brooklyn, died yesterday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 86 years old and lived at 140 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn.
Another partnership between the Broadway theater and television is planned for this season.
THE young woman facing the task of decorating her first apartment and the matron who feels her home is due for a ground-up refurbishing may both wonder if their knowledge is adequate for the job.

THE "Ballet Gala" being presented in the Rebekah Harkness Foundation Dance Festival at Delacorte Theater in Central Park offers an extraordinarily, generous assortment of ballet companies, stars and choreographic styles in a program that lasts more than two and a half hours. The "Gala" was presented for the first time last night and will be repeated tonight.
A threatened citywide school boycott by thousands of Negro children was apparently averted last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5-- A floor of the Mark Hopkins Hotel with enough rooms for 76 persons has been reserved by Senator Barry Goldwater for the days before and during the Republican National Convention here in July.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 5 --Charles Lee Crandall Sr., who retired in 1951 as engineer in charge of field construction at all Port of New York Authorlity facilities, died yesterday at his home, 57 South Maple Avenue. He was 74 years old.

NEW YORK. Gov. Nelson Rockefeller of New York is not at the end but merely in the middle of his political crisis. For his remarriage has not only damaged his own chances of winning the Republican Presidential nomination, but has helped men and ideas he has fought all his life.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 5 (AP)--The President of South Vietnam and his younger brother declared in separate interviews today that the President was still the chief of state.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 5 --Six Negro women were arrested today for refusing to leave a predominantly white school where Negro pupils were continuing a sit-in demonstration.
"AMERICANS are always looking for bargains," Dr. James A. Cook commented, "yet they are overlooking the best bargain in the world in quality wines."
MOSCOW, Sept. 5--Aleksandr F. Zasyadko, a former deputy premier of the Soviet Union, died today of a heart attack. He would have been 53 years old on Saturday.

JOHN KEATS had three passionate loves in his short life: love of beauty, love of fame as an immortal poet, and love of the girl he would have married had the fates been kinder. The love of beauty enriched his life and his poetry. The love of fame tormented him. In a moment of confidence, he wrote: "I think I shall be among the English ...
HAWTHORNE, N.J., Sept. 5--School classes opened here today as they had for years past--with the Lord's Prayer and Bible readings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --A State Department spokesman said today that the rearrest of former Premier Song Yo Chang by the South Korean Government "can be viewed only as raising serious doubts that the presidential elections will be free."
PARIS, Sept. 5--The French Government is keeping a handsoff attitude toward the embroiled political situation in Saigon, according to French diplomatic sources.
BUFFALO, Sept. 5--Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney emerged as a decisive victor today in his primary election challenge to the Erie County Republican organization.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) --Senator Clifford P. Case charged today that Senator Stuart Symington was striking at Republicans in a pending report on the Senate stockpile inquiry.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5--The St. Louis Cardinals, intent on maintaining their pursuit of the league-leading Dodgers, and Casey Stengel, eager to examine his newest New York Mets, achieved their separate goals tonight as the Cardinals scored a 9-0 victory.

The Rev. Dr. Billy Graham will read lines written by Jack Benny's joke writers when he appears in a sketch on the seasonal premiere of the comedian's show Sept. 24 on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

In 1944, when a Boston securities dealer was charged with taking excessive profits in over-the-counter transactions, he replied that his prices to customers never exceeded the quotations appearing in local newspapers.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 5--The Stuttgart Ballet tonight completed its Edinburgh Festival appearances at the Empire Theater by giving the British premieres of one ballet by Kenneth MacMillan and two by John Cranko.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5--A Weather Bureau scientist has predicted that major smog attacks on the Northeast seaboard and Great Lakes region can be expected every three years.

Two favorable developments took place yesterday in the Nov. 1 to holders of record common stock of the Commonwealth Edison Company--a 5cent increase in the quarterly dividend and a new high of 53 7/8 in the price of the stock.
A major liquor company has appointed a Negro to an executive post.
Chateaugay, the Darby Dan Farm colt that won this year's Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes, gave a crowd of 26,283 at Aqueduct yesterday an example of his best form.
Capt. Georges Croisile took his last look at the city's skyline as master of the world's longest passenger liner from the bridge of the French Line's France yesterday.

BOSTON, Sept. 5--Negro and white pickets entered the headquarters building of the Boston School Committee for the first time today in protest over a plan for transferring pupils for one school to another.
MOSCOW, Sept. 5--Soviet authorities reported today the indictment in Leningrad of one of the largest precious metals speculation rings uncovered in the campaign against economic crime.
The Citizens Budget Commission warned yesterday that a continuation of the city's spending policies would "lead to annual budget increases in excess of $100,000,000."
BRIGHTON, England, Sept. 5 --The Trades Union Congress, representing eight million British workers, called today for more nationalization of industry.

The first electronic lighting control system in a professional theater in New York will be installed at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The playhouse, at Broadway and 65th Street, is expected to be completed in 1965.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- The Federal Reserve Board ruled today that state banks that are members of the Federal Reserve System should not have participated in the underwriting yesterday of $35,750,000 in bonds of the State of Washington.
The State Department of Public Works will open bids Sept. 19 for the construction of parking lots at five New York Central Railroad stations in Westchester and Putnam Counties.
The American Football League this weekend begins its fourth season of operation with two games tomorrow night and two more on Sunday.
Record lovers had a field day in the stock market yesterday. The Dow-Jones industrial average and the Standard Poor's combined average of 500 stocks soared to new closing highs.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 5--Vice President Johnson declared tonight that all discrimination based on religion, ancestry or race must be ended "if there is to be peace in the world."

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 6-- Communist China accused the Soviet Union today of having marshaled tens of thousands of Chinese in a plot to overthrow the regional government of a district along the Soviet border.
