Summer school in the great outdoors is not only for those who can go to campuses in the Green Mountains or the Rockies. Ten weeks of informal study came to an end this week under the shady trees of Central Park.

PARIS, Sept. 5--The limousines wait at the door. The women arrive accompanied by their maids. Men in business suits depart with telltale orange-colored shopping bags. Business is booming at Inno Passy, the latest link in the chain of Inno supermarkets.

Tests made during an epidemic in India earlier this year indicate that a drug has been found effective in the prevention of smallpox, according to a report published yesterday in London in Lancet, a British medical journal.
Contract negotiations between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers collapsed yesterday over one issue only--salary increases for the city's 43,000 teachers.

A number of American students who recently visited Cuba are going to demand State Department hearings to get back their passports. The Government has labeled the passports withdrawn because the students defied a United States ban on travel to Cuba.

PARIS, Sept. 5--France has warned Australia, New Zealand, Chile and Peru that her friendly relations with them were being endangered by their campaign against French plans to test a hydrogen bomb in the Pacific.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 5 -A small group of men and women, some of them carrying Confederate battle flags, gathered this morning in a downtown park.
Prices and volume on the London stock market declined yesterday.
Two of the nation's largest merchandisers--Sears, Roebuck Co. and Montgomery Ward Co.--made impressive gains in sales and earnings for the second quarter and the first half of this year.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP)--Dr. Leonid S. Snegireff, associate professor of chronic diseases at the Harvard School of Public Health, died today of a lung ailment in Peter Bent Brigham Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Belmont.
Portable classrooms to offset overcrowding will be ready, if the city's schools open Monday, at only six sites instead of 42--for reasons that suggest a comedy of errors.
Col. Isaac William Littell 3d of the Army died of a heart attack Tuesday in his home in Staunton, Va. His age was 56.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 5 (AP)--The United States army of experienced amateur golfers struggled to a 1 -point lead in the first half of the biennial Americas Cup competition today behind the steady play of Charlie Coe and Labron Harris Jr.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 5-- Nassau County voters in moderate to heavy numbers backed organization candidates for the most part today in Democratic and Republican primaries for public office.

A court order was issued yesterday restraining the teachers' union and its members from proceeding with plans for a school strike Monday. The order was served minutes after contract negotiations between the union and the Board of Education collapsed.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 5--Dr. Edward Teller declared tonight it was essential for this country to demand that space be free.
PARIS, Sept. 5--The Western allies are in a cautious mood about the possibility of agreement with the Soviet Union on further moves to reduce EastWest tensions.
It appears as if New York's Yankees, in romping off with the American League pennant and preparing themselves for another World Series, suddenly have taken to stressing endurance.
Sinkiang Province, a land of mountains and deserts inhabited mainly by non-Chinese Moslem peoples, has long been an area of Russian-Chinese conflict.

A constitutional amendment to define each citizen's social and economic rights was advocated last night by Prof. Carl J. Friedrich of Harvard University in an address before the American Political Science Association.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5--Mayor Richard J. Daley appealed today for negotiation "in a spirit of cooperation" to end the bitter dispute over de facto school segregation.
The first jet airliner to use La Guardia Airport was tested yesterday.
The Dow-Jones industrial average broke through to a historic high yesterday. Earlier this week Standard Poor's 500-stock index rose to a record high. The New York

For the second quarter of this year Irish International Airlines has reported a 58.8 per cent load factor, which it says is the highest of all International Air Transport Association members flying between this country and Europe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Senator today that Gov. George Senate today that Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama receives disability payments for psychoneurosis incurred during war.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 5--White parents protested today at an elementary school receiving Negro pupils transported from overcrowded schools. Later they took their complaints to a meeting of the Board of School Commissioners.

Ronald Barnes of Brazil played tennis with the touch of an Henri Cochet yesterday and defeated Dennis Ralston with as masterly a performance as ever has come from the racquet of a South American in our national championship.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 5--Gov. George C. Wallace arrived at his office this morning wearing dark glasses after a near sleepless night during which he persuaded the Birmingham School Board to close schools scheduled for integration.
Luigi Antonini, a stocky, white-maned labor leader who will be 80 years old next Wednesday, was awarded the city's Bronze Medallion by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

In a prophetic editorial Wednesday afternoon censuring Governor Wallace for blocking the court-ordered integration of Birmingham's schools, The Birmingham News said: "The Governor plows a bitter field. All our people will reap a rotten harvest."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 (AP)--Sonny Jurgensen, the star passer of the Philadelphia Eagles, and his only substitute, King Hill, settled their salary disputes with the club today. During the bitter negotiating session, after which each signed a contract, a chair arm was thrown across the room.
The United States Treasury's massive refunding program gave Government securities dealers their most active day yesterday in over a month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- With a mixture of idealism and commercialism, the Administration asked Congressional approval today for the sale of nearly a half-billion dollars worth of uranium for use as fuel in atomic power plants in Europe and India.
Richard S. Aldrich, the organization candidate and a cousin of Governor Rockefeller, narrowly won the Republican nomination for councilman at large in Manhattan yesterday over John J. Lamula.

LONDON, Sept. 5--Christine Keeler, the 21-year-old party girl who was a central figure in recent sex and security scandals, was arrested tonight. She was charged with perjury and with conspiracy to obstruct the course of justice.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 5--The International Drama Conference failed to agree today on whether the censor has not been miscast as completely villainous.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 5 --Coach Eddie Anderson brought his 74-man Holy Cross squad together yesterday for the first time and faced as usual with one of the most difficult schedules in the East; he was viewing the prospects of his 20th football season here with perplexity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (UPI)--President Kennedy's youngest brother, the Coast Guard and fishermen, alarmed over Soviet trawlers, supported today a bill to arrest, fine and jail foreign poachers who steal fish from United States waters.

Miss Lynn Langman, daughter of Mrs. Robert E. Simon Jr. of New York and Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and Dr. Louis Langman of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Philip Howard Lilienthal.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 5--The Birmingham Board of Education today closed three white schools at which Negroes had been scheduled to begin classes this morning.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 5 (UPI)--Gary Player, Don January and Billy Maxwell fired four-under-par 66's today and shared the opening-round lead in the $40,000 Utah open golf tournament.

MOHAMMAD ZAHIR, King of the remote monarchy of Afghanistan, has charted a course of social and political reform that has prevented his throne from being shaken by the winds of change that have swept the Asian continent. The King is a tall, lean, brown-faced man.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5-- Thirty-seven of the nation's largest drug companies went to court today to challenge a new government regulation on the labeling and advertising of their prescription drugs.

Burlap bag and coffee importer groups wired strong protests yesterday to the Bureau of Customs against a new duty on shipping containers that are used for a wide variety of bulk commodities.
Carmine G. De Sapio, the former leader of Tammany Hall, failed by 41 votes to make a political comeback in the primary election yesterday.
Roy M. Cohn returned yesterday to Federal Court, the scene of his earliest triumphs as a young, vigorous prosecutor. This time, however, he appeared as an incensed defendant.

Max Morath, a singer and pianist who describes himself as a man who is "completely out of touch with his environment," is proving his point each evening at the Blue Angel as he presents an amiable and warmhearted panorama of the music of that American age of innocence that extended from the nineties through World War I.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (UPI)--The Minnesota Vikings, prodded by Fran Tarkenton's passing, smashed the St. Louis Cardinals' defense tonight for a 35-0 victory in an exhibition game between the National Football League clubs.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 6 At the 25th annual Westchester Cotillion held tonight in the Shenorock Shore Club 51 young women from the county made their debuts. The young women were escorted by their fathers and presented to their mothers, who were seated on the platform at one end of the ballroom. The room was decorated with white flowers and garlands of green leaves.

Mayor Wagner in a late-hour intervention has arranged mediation of the salary dispute between the United Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education. But the teachers, keeping intact a shameful record of irresponsibility, have voted to go ahead with plans for their threatened Monday strike.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 6 Alvin Jackson tonight became the second New York Met pitcher to win 10 games in one season. He matched the total posted last year by Roger Craig by beating the Cincinnati Reds, 5 4, at Crosley Field.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 6 New Jersey stopped construction today on its $1,250,000 pavilion at the New York World's Fair, pending an investigation into the safety of the proposed structure.
State Republican leaders have removed the price tag from their offer to endorse the Democratic candidate for associate judge of the Court of Appeals this year, informed sources said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Chemists in the Food and Drug Administration have tentatively identified a sample of Krebiozen as a common amino acid, called creative, that is found in man and animals.
NEW YORK is a night town. Long after most people are asleep, the insomniac can buy a book or a bunch of flowers, have a permanent or eat right through dawn.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 6 Lars Thorn sailed Rush VII to an easy victory today and made it probable that the United States championship in the International 5.5-Meter Class would go to Sweden.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 6 (AP) Ezra Pound, the American poet who long held scant affection for his native country, said today that he hoped to visit the United States again soon. Things have changed, he declared.
MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 6 Some 3,000 white pupils attended classes at Murphy High School here today after the admission of two Negroes had been postponed until next week.

DENVER, Sept. 6 The richest nation in the world has a shortage of money or, more specifically, coins. However, there's still an ample supply of the "green stuff" or paper bills around.
Genesco, Inc., extended its offer yesterday to buy S.H. Kress Co. stock and also reported declines in sales and earnings for fiscal 1963.
The New York Yankees made it with what amounted to their junior-varsity squad at the Stadium last night as they set back the Detroit Tigers, 2 to 1. Whitey Ford gained his 21st victory of the year.

The Syntex Corporation, the pharmaceutical producer whose stock has been soaring on prospects for the company's birthcontrol pills, reported a sharp rise in earnings yesterday. The stock climbed to a new high before the announcement.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) The three domestic cargo airlines Slick, Flying Tiger and Riddle proposed today that passenger airline be barred from operating all-cargo aircraft.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 6-- President Ngo Dinh Diem's latest defeat of United States pressure to reform his authoritarian regime follows a pattern going back to his assumption of power from the former puppet emperor, Bao Dai, in 1954.
TRENTON, Sept. 6 An effort by the state to preserve a 213-year-old home threatened by the construction of a new interstate freeway appeared today to have been successful.
Judge Joseph A. Martinis has been transferred at hia own request from Bronx Criminal Court to a Manhattan assignment during the forthcoming trial of his son, Gareth, on charges of vehicular homicide.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 Like gigantic jackpots, the presses at the United States Mint here are spewing coins forth on an around-the-clock schedule, five days a week. Production was stepped up in July to meet the demand for coins following the annual mint "settlement" or audit.
ATHENS, Sept. 6--Greece suspended today until Dec. 31 all military exit control on visiting American citizens of Greek birth.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 A laser patented for the Air Force this week is expected to produce with increased efficiency the intense, narrow light beams which science hopes to harness for space communications.
Baptists and Roman Catholics in Massachusetts have joined hands in an unusual act of mercy.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 The Soviet Union, in a note published today, has called for an investigation of charges that the United States has been engaged in illegal delivery of military aircraft to the right-wing forces in Laos.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP)--Senator Stuart Symington confirmed today that he has refused to let former officials of the Eisenhower Administration see or answer a still-secret report on a Senate inquiry into the $8-billion Federal stockpiles.

YONKERS, Sept. 6 A powerful drive on the outside for the final five-eighths of a mile helped Rodare, a 7-year-old bay Gelding trotter by Rodney, score a half-length victory over Delight Hanover tonight before 20,120 at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:03 4/5.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 Unemployment declined by about half a million last month, the Labor Department reported today.

James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, called the Federal Reserve Board "irresponsible" yesterday for ruling that state-chartered member banks should not have participated in the underwriting Wednesday of $35,750,000 of State of Washington bonds.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Sept. 6 "We are askng for a major effort and we expect to get one. We are going all-out."

PARIS, Sept. 6--Dr. Paul Armand-Delille, a physician and a man described by many Frenchmen as responsible for wiping out a large part of Western Europe's rabbits, died here today. He was 89 years old.

A St. Louis broker said yesterday that he planned to propose the use of a highspeed electronic computer to "strengthen the national market for over-the-counter stocks." The computer would be used to speed distribution of price quotations.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Sept. 6 President Kennedy arrived here tonight to celebrate his father's 75th birthday. With him were his two brothers, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy; his sister, Mrs. Sargent Schriver, and her husband, and a brother-in-law, Stephen E. Smith. They landed at Otis Air Force Base despite hazardous conditions.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Sept. 6 U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, has ordered an unexpected cutback in the technical-assistance program in the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 United States officials estimated today that 50,000 to 70,000 Moslem nomads from the Chinese province of Sinkiang fled to the Soviet Union last year in a "spontaneous" protest against the Peking regime.
CHICAGO, Sept 6, (UPI) Soybean futures closed firm today, while corn and wheat were mixed on the Board of Trade.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 6 Because Gerry Barudin, a gangling, awkward-appearing quarterback, received his exposure to battle one year before the time schedule, Colgate will start this season with experienced hands at just about every position.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) Baseball passed a milestone tonight as the Cleveland Indians met the Washington, Senators in the 100,000th major league game. The first one was played 92 years ago, and Cleveland was in that one, too, and lost.

Concern about the deteriorating quality of bank credit has been voiced by William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Martin warns that relaxation of credit standards by lenders could lead to excessive speculation, followed by a bust. The evidence of deterioration is scanty, but a rise in delinquencies and defaults on home mortgages this year does indicate that, in some areas at least, the quality of credit is being strained.
The strike of city teachers scheduled for today was called off last night as jubilant members of the United Federation of Teachers voted 5,265 to 181 to accept a two-year contract.

The New York Central Railroad finally has decided to capitalize on the investment it made more than three years ago in the Flying Tiger Line, Inc., the air-freight carrier.

ENXALE, Portuguese Guinea Aug. 31--More than 60 Portuguese marines launched a carefully planned counterguerrilla operation here just after dawn today. They might just as well have not.

AS many a passenger has discovered, keeping one's figure shipshape on shipboard can be difficult--unless, of course, the voyage happens to be rough. The brisk sea air promotes a healthy appetite, which, with the eager aid of the ship's chef, can easily lead to extra pounds.

Quick Pitch was able to handle an overweight of two pounds competently in the $28,650 Brighton Beach Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Under a revised burden of 113 pounds, the 3-year-old colt, owned by Fortune Peter Ryan, won on the turf course by a neck from the favored David K. of the Harbor View Farm.

Mr. and Mrs. David Warren Swanson of Brooklyn Heights have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Hammann Swanson, to James Halsey Bell. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Waverly Bell of Essex Fells, N.J., and Buck Hill Falls, Va.
The Chinese-Soviet conflict appears to be heading toward revival of traditional great-power Russian and Chinese territorial rivalries in the Asian heartland.

TWO-FACED handbags for day, jewel-framed alligator bags for evening, and velvet or hemp luggage in wild colors and patterns are some of the items turning up this week in Macy's Little Shop of Accessories as a result of a European buying trip last stay by Roz Gersten, the shop's buyer.

ROME, Sept. 9--A boy looking for mushrooms on a hilltop in southern Sardinia found a stone inscribed with the figures of an ancient Semitic goddess. As a result the ruins of a Carthaginian town have been uncovered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9-- The Government today charged five men, including the sheriff and police chief of Winona, Miss., with having beaten and kicked five Negro prisoners during a racial incident last June.
Two junior high schools opened the year under the same roof yesterday in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 9 --Suffolk County called upon the Legislature today for a state referendum on off-track betting.
Premier Ahmed Ben Bella's rise to singlehanded control of a one-party system in Algeria is an example of how to win power after a revolution. He has eliminated or rendered ineffectual all his rivals.
Twelve men started painting the sky here yesterday. And it was neither a press agent's trick nor a bit of whimsy.
The bond market was a little quieter yesterday after adjusting most of last week to the higher yields of the Treasury's massive refunding operation.

EXPANDED network competition in evening news coverage was officially joined last night when the National Broadcasting Company's team of Chet Huntley and David Brinkley began their halfhour report, one week after ...
The discovery of 400 forged temporary permits for cabaret performers and employes was reported yesterday by the Police Department.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Sept. 9--Four public schools in this North Alabama city were desegregated today in an atmosphere of goodwill that pleased everyone concerned.

Prices ebbed in trading on the London stock market yesterday. Although there was a variety of good features among some industrial shares because of favorable company news, the industrial list followed a weaker trend.
For the first time in more than 10 years there was a teacher for every classroom in New York City yesterday, when more than a million pupils and 43,000 teachers began the new school term.

ALGIERS, Sept. 9--Premier Ahmed Ben Bella met today with officials of his National Liberation Front to discuss next Sunday's presidential election, to be held under rules set out in the one-party Constitution approved overwhelmingly by Algerian voters yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9-- Peter Abrams, engineer, business executive and civic leader, died yesterday. He was 74 years old.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 9 --A vocal critic of private-power interests proposed today the creation of a national power pool under a Federal charter.
The box-top brigade put on a show yesterday at the Coliseum. They were all over the place, with the latest in premiums. There was the familiar writing paper, with one's
PARIS, Sept. 9--France was advised today to hold down food prices and the pattern of wage increases, and to get rid of the popular notion that inflation is normal.

PARIS, Sept. 9--Jean-Louis Barrault, director of the Odeon, one of France's three national theaters, will take his company of French actors to New York in February for the start of an eight-week tour.

DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP)-- The auto industry put its production lines into high gear this week as it strived to get a full line of new cars into dealers' hands before the introduction of the 1964 models that will begin Sept. 20.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9-- President Kennedy will wait until tomorrow to see whether Gov. George C. Wallace allows admissions of Negro children to schools in Birmingham, Tuskegee and Mobile.
A new Catholic layman's cultural and literary quarterly has devoted more than half of its current issue to a symposium on "The Jew in American Culture."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 (AP)-- Hank Aaron's 39th homer drove in the winning runs in the second game as the Milwaukee Braves swept a double-header tonight from the Cincinnati Reds, 9--2, and 7--4. The Braves ran their winning streak to seven games.

NATHALIE DANA and Hamilton Fish Armstrong have just written engaging memoirs about growing up in the priv ileged Manhattan of horse cars, dancing schools, dawning social consciousness and life managed somehow without Clarence Day's father. They remember the balances of harshness and happiness.
A Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that a 21-month-old provision depriving the Board of Standards and Appeals of the power to grant zoning variances was illegal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP)--A national agreement to expand apprenticeship training programs was signed today by the Operative Plasterers and Cement Masons International Union and an employers' association.
SALEM, Mass., Sept. 9--The police were without a clue today in the 10th strangling death in eastern Massachusetts in 15 months.
Two large Brooklyn savings banks, the Dime and the Williamsburgh, raised their interest rates on new deposits yesterday to 4 per cent from 3 , effective Oct. 1.
Chateaugay, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes, has drawn top weight of 128 pounds for the Jerome Handicap on Saturday.

Rear Adm. William P. Robert, U.S.N., retired, died Friday in the Wheaton (Md.) Nursing Home after a short illness. He was 90 years old. Until recently the admiral, a naval architect, had lived in Washington.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP)-- About 250 white pickets demonstrated today at a high school in a white neighborhood. They were protesting the possible transfer there of Negro pupils from other schools.
Jacques Lusseyran, now a member of the faculty at Western Reserve University in Cleveland, lost his sight when he was 8 years old.

WHEN S. Richard Stern is asked how to make good tea--and he is asked frequently --his reply always begins: "Start with a good blend of fine teas." And, as president of the Grace Tea Company, this is just what he tries to provide.
PETERBOROUGH, N.H., Sept. 9--"If we can find a reliable passing quarterback to move our offense, I think this will turn out to be a fairly potent team."

The Alabama Story, like a Greek tragedy, moves toward its inevitable climax. Governor Wallace apparently is determined to make the Federal Government use its police powers to brush aside his state troopers and permit the entry of Negro children to the public schools in Birmingham, Mobile and Tuskegee. In those three cities he continued yesterday to defy Federal court orders.
A Queens State Supreme Court justice has ruled that badly written, trashy novels are entitled to the same constitutional protection against censorship as works of critically acclaimed authors.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 9--Negro leaders said today that they were proceeding with a program of boycotts aimed at increasing the number of Negroes in television production crews.
Six ships, the remnants of a 25-vessel United States-flag fleet once controlled by Manuel E. Kulukundis, yesterday veered toward the auctioneer's block.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 (AP) --Senator Barry Goldwater said today that the United States should give more support to freeing Cuba from the Communists. But he emphasized that Cubans themselves should take back the island and no American troops should be involved.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9-- Philosophy's role in bringing understanding, and comfort to man in an era of self-destruction was weighed and found wanting today by a philosopher.
The country's steel mills scored another slight increase in production in the week ended on Saturday.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 9-- Only 12 pupils reported for classes today at a predominantly Negro school here where a boycott has been called to protest the racial imbalance.

Officials of Pipefitters Union Local 638 testified yesterday before the City Commission on Human Rights that there were no Negroes or Puerto Ricans among the 4,000 members of the local who did construction work.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9-- President Kennedy announced day that he would appoint John A. Gronouski, 43 years old, Wisconsin's Commissioner of Taxation, as Postmaster General.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9--Barry Goldwater is too thorough a political realist to doubt that, so long as it appears he may be the Presidential choice of the next Republican National Convention, the effort to prevent this consummation will be one of the bitterest in American history for himself and for his family.

Title to the blockfront on the east side of the Avenue of the Americas, between 36th and 37th Street, has been taken by clients of Walter Scott Co. The block was bought from the Estate of A.A. Hageman, Herman Zuchs and Max Greenberg.
The trial of Gareth Martinis on a charge of assaulting a newspaper photographer was adjourned yesterday to Sept. 30 in Bronx Criminal Court.

Casting Note: U.S. Chickens Join Act of Russia's Favorite Clown PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9-- Oleg Popov, Russia's favorite clown, was not quite ready today to start his United States tour with the Moscow State Circus.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 9 --John Barnard Balding of Wheatley Road, former international polo player, died today at Glen Cove Hospital. His age was 56.
Taxpayers who are considering additions to their insurance and annuity programs might well wait until the new rules for pension plans are published. The Internal
TOKYO, Sept. 9 (AP)-- Communist China accused Premier Khrushchev and other Soviet leaders today of licking up "the spittie" of the United States to attack the Chinese Communist party.
The Douglas Aircraft Company scratched its name yesterday from the list of candidates for prime contractor on the proposed supersonic airliner.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 9 --Gov. George C. Wallace called out National Guard units tonight after all five Federal District Court judges in Alabama had enjoined him from halting public school desegregation.
A ceremony with Colonial costumes and patriotic band music marked the 299th anniversary of the founding of New York City yesterday in Bowling Green Park. About 1,000 persons attended.

The Atlantic Improvement Corporation, owner of 384 acres at Breezy Point in Queens, announced plans for a $3,000,000 beach club yesterday that could put a fresh crimp in the city's drive to create a great oceanfront park there.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9-- The National Institutes of Health raised today its figures on the amount of money sent last year for studies relating to the touchy issue of reproduction and birth control.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 9-- Listening to Cornell's coach, Tom Harp, one might think Gary Wood is the best college quarterback in the nation. Watching Wood in action might lead to this conclusion also.
LONDON, Sept. 9--"The seed sown a year ago is sprouting all over the place," one British financial official said today in commenting on the annual report of the International Monetary Fund.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 9 --George O'Day of Boston, who hasn't fingers enough to count all the major honors he has won, set out-for another big one today with the aplomb befitting an Olympic champion.
Coffee futures prices, which had been quiet for some time, percolated yesterday and led several other commodities in an upward climb on the New York exchanges.

Directors of the Servomation Corporation declared yesterday a 10-cent cash dividend and a 2 per cent stock dividend, both payable Oct. 10 to stockholders of record of Sept. 20. The last payment was an initial dividend of 10 cents in April.
Trained Christian leadership must be ready to reinstill democratic ideals in the Chinese people when they are liberated from Communism, a Chinese churchman and educator said here yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 9 (UPI)--Lawyers representing a Louisiana parish said today that they might ask a Federal district judge to hold leaders of the Congress of Racial Equality in contempt of court for demonstrating in Plaquemine, La., on Sept. 1.
MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 9 (AP) --At least four persons were injured tonight when a cannon misfired along the route of the American Legion's national convention parade, the Police said.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9--The Soviet Union charged in a note to the Chinese Communist Government today that Chinese railroad employes tried to smuggle "prohibited literature" into the Soviet Union across the Chinese border.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) --An allegedly erotic dance program by the Martha Graham troupe in Germany drew a shocked critical appraisal from a Brooklyn Congresswoman today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept 9-- The Philadelphia Orchestra Association and Local 77 of the American Federation of Musicians agreed today on the first contract for year-round employment in the history of major American orchestras.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (AP)-- Curt Simmons pitched a fivehitter tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals whipped the Chicago Cubs, 6-0, and trimmed the Los Angeles Dodgers' league lead to three games.
CATIO, Portuguese Guinea, Aug. 30--Seen from the air, this southern rice-producing region of Portuguese Guinea shows little sign of war.

OTTAWA, Sept. 9 (Canadian Press)--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson said today that Canada had told the United States emphatically that action was expected to protect Canadian vessels in United States ports.

Both Parties Select Bergan for Judge; Avoid a State Race The Democratic and Republican State Committees nominated Justice Francis Bergan, a Democrat, yesterday as the candidate of both parties for associate judge of the Court of Appeals.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9--President Kennedy said today that "it would not be helpful at this time" to reduce United States aid to South Vietnam.
MILLIONS of New Yorkers would have criminal records today if it weren't for Presiding Justice Francis Bergan of the Appellate Division, Third Department, in Albany.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP)--An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended today that the Santa Fe Railway be permitted to acquire control of the Western Pacific Railroad Company.
The McCrory Corporation has called a special stockholder meeting for Sept. 30 to vote on the proposed sale of its 98 per cent interest in the Lerner Stores Corporation to the Glen Alden Corporation.

THEY were in animated conversation when they were spotted together over the weekend in the new pro football Hall of Fame at Canton, Ohio. It was enough to stagger the imagination. Here was the perfect pair.
THE HAGUE, Sept. 9--A German scientist described experiments here today in which the action of genes was observed and correlated with specific functions of a living organism.

ARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 9 --More than 1,000 newspaper reporters, editors and printers went on a nationwide strike in Pakistan today to protest a new law regulating the press. No papers' went to press.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP)-- Marlin Burnham, a former Star Class champion from San Diego, Calif., won the first race today in the International Star Class world championship in Belmont Harbor.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9--The president of the National Education Association said today that the bargaining methods used by the United Federation of Teachers in New York to win salary increases "did not seem very effective."

A Federal grand jury investigation is getting under way tomorrow in Brooklyn into recent student travel to Cuba. Subpoenas have been issued for at least five leaders of the leftwing Progressive Labor Movement.

James B. Donovan, the lawyer who negotiated with the Cuban government for the release of prisoners, said yesterday that he would help negotiate the terms of a proposed agreement for an exchange of "peace hostages" with the Soviet Union.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 9--Jim Bouton, young Yankee righthander, tonight missed in his bid for a 20th victory for the second time in a week. And this time it was perhaps the most excruciating experience he has yet had to suffer when the Bombers blew the opener of a four-game series to the Athletics, 7--6.
NEWARK, Sept. 9--About 50 parents appeared today at the Hawthorne Avenue Elementary School to protest the transfer of their children to the Peshine Avenue School.
The E.L. Bruce Company, hardwood flooring producer, issued yesterday its first annual report since changing management last fall.
ALTHOUGH a lot is said about individuality in dressing, it is difficult to achieve except by those who have a little dressmaker or a large checking account.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. --Fathers who have deserted their children after agreeing to support them owe more than $10,000,000 to New Jersey state and county welfare agencies for care of the children. And means are being sought to correct this and other welfare abuses and to guard against their recurrence.
The evidence now coming in on the 1963 food production of the Communist world suggests that another lean year is ahead for consumers in the lands where Marx's dogma rules.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9-- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, the minority leader, gave complete support today to the treaty limiting nuclear tests to underground explosions.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 9--Labron Harris Jr., the titleholder, showed the way into the second round in the National Amateur golf cnampionship today.
ALBANY, Sept. 9--Governor Rockefeller withdrew today his 1962 campaign pledge not to raise taxes during a second term in office.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., Sept. 9 --A mass boycott of the schools here is planned for Friday, integration leaders announced today.
Miriam Hopkins and Walter Abel may appear in "Riverside Drive," two short plays written by John Donovan, a new playwright.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 9 (UPI) --Defense Minister Y.B. Chavan reported today that the Indian Army had added three divisions to its forces along the northern border to thwart the threat of an invasion from Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP)--The Agriculture Department estimated today that this year's Government-controlled cotton crop will total 14,310,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, an increase of 2 per cent over its forecast a month ago.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 9--Rolf Hochhuth's drama "Der Stellvertreter" ("The Vicar"), accusing Pope Pius XII of not protesting against Nazi cruelties during World War II, did not convince Stockholm's drama critics.
An eight-step program has been adopted to overcome a serious shortage of skilled, manpower in city government, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 9--The Soviet Union, in a speech marked by its moderation, promised today to cooperate in the search for East-West agreement on peaceful uses of outer space.
